Speaker: NA
Text: Wednesday, 11 May 2011

Speaker: NA
Text: The SPEAKER ( Mr Harry Jenkins)

Speaker: NA
Text: took the chair at 09:00, made an

Speaker: NA
Text: acknowledgement of country and read

Speaker: NA
Text: prayers.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Research Council

Speaker: NA
Text: Amendment Bill (No. 2) 2010

Speaker: NA
Text: Broadcasting Legislation Amendment

Speaker: NA
Text: (Digital Dividend and Other

Speaker: NA
Text: Measures) Bill 2011

Speaker: NA
Text: Returned from Senate

Speaker: NA
Text: Messages received from the Senate

Speaker: NA
Text: returning the bills without amendment or

Speaker: NA
Text: request.

Speaker: NA
Text: Migration Amendment (Strengthening

Speaker: NA
Text: the Character Test and Other

Speaker: NA
Text: Provisions) Bill 2011

Speaker: NA
Text: First Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill and explanatory memorandum

Speaker: NA
Text: presented by Mr Bowen.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill read a first time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: Mr BOWEN
Text: MCMahon-Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Immigration and Citizenship) (09:01): I

Speaker: NA
Text: move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: The purpose of this bill is to ensure that a

Speaker: NA
Text: visa applicant or holder will fail the character

Speaker: NA
Text: test should they be convicted of any offence

Speaker: NA
Text: committed while they are in immigration

Speaker: NA
Text: detention; and to increase the maximum

Speaker: NA
Text: penalty for the manufacture, possession, use

Speaker: NA
Text: or distribution of weapons by immigration

Speaker: NA
Text: detainees from three to five years

Speaker: NA
Text: imprisonment. These amendments are

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed in part to address issues arising

Speaker: NA
Text: from the recent criminal damage and riots at

Speaker: NA
Text: the Christmas Island detention centre in

Speaker: NA
Text: March and the Villawood Immigration

Speaker: NA
Text: Detention Centre in April 2011. Major

Speaker: NA
Text: damage was caused to the facilities as a

Speaker: NA
Text: result of these disturbances and there was

Speaker: NA
Text: significant risk of harm to other detainees

Speaker: NA
Text: and to staff at the facilities as well as more

Speaker: NA
Text: broadly to public order and safety.

Speaker: NA
Text: BILLS The bill is also intended to strengthen the

Speaker: NA
Text: powers under the Migration Act to provide a

Speaker: NA
Text: more significant disincentive for this sort of

Speaker: NA
Text: destructive behaviour now and in the future.

Speaker: NA
Text: The new provisions will apply to all people

Speaker: NA
Text: who are or have been in immigration

Speaker: NA
Text: detention: onshore and offshore arrivals,

Speaker: NA
Text: asylum seekers, or otherwise.

Speaker: NA
Text: Under these new provisions, a person who

Speaker: NA
Text: has been convicted of a criminal offence

Speaker: NA
Text: while in immigration detention could be

Speaker: NA
Text: refused a visa or have a visa cancelled. In

Speaker: NA
Text: keeping with Australia's international

Speaker: NA
Text: protection obligations, in such cases we will

Speaker: NA
Text: not return people to a place where they have

Speaker: NA
Text: a well-founded fear of persecution. Where it

Speaker: NA
Text: is not appropriate to remove people from

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia because they are owed protection,

Speaker: NA
Text: consideration could be given to the grant of a

Speaker: NA
Text: temporary visa to place them in the

Speaker: NA
Text: community until their removal from

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia is appropriate.

Speaker: NA
Text: The public announcement on 26 April

Speaker: NA
Text: 2011 of this legislative change put all

Speaker: NA
Text: detainees on notice that the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: government takes criminal behaviour by

Speaker: NA
Text: people in immigration detention very

Speaker: NA
Text: seriously and will take appropriate measures

Speaker: NA
Text: to deal with it.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is essential that anyone convicted of an

Speaker: NA
Text: offence in relation to the recent events at

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian immigration detention centres is

Speaker: NA
Text: covered by these new provisions and has the

Speaker: NA
Text: amended character test applied to them.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Australian community expects there

Speaker: NA
Text: to be consequences for unlawful behaviour.

Speaker: NA
Text: Commencing these amendments to the

Speaker: NA
Text: character test provisions on 26 April 2011

Speaker: NA
Text: ensures this bill delivers those consequences

Speaker: NA
Text: and the government's objectives are met.

Speaker: NA
Text: These changes will apply for the purposes of

Speaker: NA
Text: making a decision on or after 26 April 2011,

Speaker: NA
Text: whether the conviction or offence concerned

Speaker: NA
Text: occurred before, on or after that date.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Australian community also expects

Speaker: NA
Text: noncitizens who seek to remain in Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: to be of good character. To meet this

Speaker: NA
Text: expectation, the government must not only

Speaker: NA
Text: have the ability to act decisively and

Speaker: NA
Text: effectively, wherever necessary, to deal with

Speaker: NA
Text: criminal behaviour by immigration

Speaker: NA
Text: detainees, but also have the legislative basis

Speaker: NA
Text: to effect a refusal to grant a visa, or a

Speaker: NA
Text: cancellation of a visa, for those noncitizens

Speaker: NA
Text: who are not of good character. The

Speaker: NA
Text: government must be able to remove those

Speaker: NA
Text: noncitizens who have convictions for crimes

Speaker: NA
Text: committed in immigration detention in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia where possible and consistent with

Speaker: NA
Text: our international obligations.

Speaker: NA
Text: Among other things, section 501 of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Migration Act currently deals with matters

Speaker: NA
Text: that constitute serious criminal offences

Speaker: NA
Text: where a person can fail the character test.

Speaker: NA
Text: Noncitizens will fail the character test where

Speaker: NA
Text: they have been sentenced to a term of

Speaker: NA
Text: imprisonment of 12 months or more, or

Speaker: NA
Text: where the length of several sentences

Speaker: NA
Text: aggregates to two years or more. If a person

Speaker: NA
Text: fails the character test, this can be used

Speaker: NA
Text: basis for the refusal of a visa application or

Speaker: NA
Text: the cancellation of a visa that is held by a

Speaker: NA
Text: person. The proposed measures will amend

Speaker: NA
Text: the character test in section 501 of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Migration Act so that a person will fail the

Speaker: NA
Text: character test if the person is convicted of

Speaker: NA
Text: any offence committed while they are in

Speaker: NA
Text: immigration detention, regardless of the

Speaker: NA
Text: sentence imposed. The intended amendment

Speaker: NA
Text: will not limit the application of the existing

Speaker: NA
Text: provisions relating to the character test.

Speaker: NA
Text: bill therefore seeks to establish an additional

Speaker: NA
Text: benchmark for criminal behaviour that will

Speaker: NA
Text: automatically lead to a visa applicant or

Speaker: NA
Text: holder failing the character test if they are

Speaker: NA
Text: convicted of an offence committed while

Speaker: NA
Text: they are in immigration detention.

Speaker: NA
Text: Similarly, section 500A of the Migration

Speaker: NA
Text: Act provides that the minister may refuse the

Speaker: NA
Text: grant of a temporary safe haven visa or may

Speaker: NA
Text: cancel a temporary safe haven visa if a

Speaker: NA
Text: person has been sentenced to imprisonment

Speaker: NA
Text: of 12 months or more. Without limiting the

Speaker: NA
Text: application of the existing character

Speaker: NA
Text: provisions relating to section 500A of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Migration Act, the proposed measures will

Speaker: NA
Text: amend section 500A of the act so that the

Speaker: NA
Text: minister may also refuse to grant a safe

Speaker: NA
Text: haven visa, or may cancel a safe haven visa

Speaker: NA
Text: if the person is convicted of any offence

Speaker: NA
Text: committed while they are in immigration

Speaker: NA
Text: detention.

Speaker: NA
Text: For both the section 501 and section 500A

Speaker: NA
Text: amendments it is intended, if a person

Speaker: NA
Text: escapes from immigration detention, that any

Speaker: NA
Text: conviction for the offence of escaping or for

Speaker: NA
Text: an offence committed during or following

Speaker: NA
Text: their escape-up to the time of their being

Speaker: NA
Text: returned to immigration detention-be

Speaker: NA
Text: included.

Speaker: NA
Text: The amendments to sections 501 and

Speaker: NA
Text: 500A have been drafted to ensure that they

Speaker: NA
Text: as a apply only to persons who have been

Speaker: NA
Text: convicted of an offence by a court. The

Speaker: NA
Text: amendments made to sections 501 and 500A

Speaker: NA
Text: will not apply to a person who is charged

Speaker: NA
Text: before a court with an offence or offences

Speaker: NA
Text: and the court is satisfied in respect of that

Speaker: NA
Text: charge, or more than one of those charges,

Speaker: NA
Text: that the charge is proved, but has discharged

Speaker: NA
Text: the person without a conviction on that

Speaker: NA
Text: charge, or any of those charges. That is, there

Speaker: NA
Text: must be at least one conviction for the

Speaker: NA
Text: This amendments to sections 501 and 500A to

Speaker: NA
Text: apply. Currently section 197B of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Migration Act provides that an immigration

Speaker: NA
Text: detainee is guilty of an offence if he or she

Speaker: NA
Text: manufactures, possesses, uses or distributes a

Speaker: NA
Text: weapon. A weapon includes a thing made or

Speaker: NA
Text: adapted for use for inflicting bodily injury;

Speaker: NA
Text: or a thing where the detainee who has the

Speaker: NA
Text: thing intends or threatens to use the thing, or

Speaker: NA
Text: intends that the thing be used, to inflict

Speaker: NA
Text: bodily injury. The current maximum penalty

Speaker: NA
Text: is imprisonment for three years. The

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed amendment to section 197B of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Migration Act will increase the maximum

Speaker: NA
Text: penalty to five years imprisonment. The

Speaker: NA
Text: manufacture, possession, use and distribution

Speaker: NA
Text: of a weapon by a detainee puts at risk the

Speaker: NA
Text: personal safety of others in the immigration

Speaker: NA
Text: detention environment, including other

Speaker: NA
Text: detainees, Commonwealth officers,

Speaker: NA
Text: contracted detention services staff and

Speaker: NA
Text: visitors. The Australian community expects

Speaker: NA
Text: that there be robust sanctions to deal with

Speaker: NA
Text: people in immigration detention who

Speaker: NA
Text: threaten or inflict harm on other people and

Speaker: NA
Text: the intended increase in the maximum

Speaker: NA
Text: penalty for this offence reflects the

Speaker: NA
Text: seriousness with which the community views

Speaker: NA
Text: this offence.

Speaker: NA
Text: Conclusion

Speaker: NA
Text: In summary, people in immigration

Speaker: NA
Text: detention who might contemplate criminal

Speaker: NA
Text: behaviour, including the manufacture,

Speaker: NA
Text: possession or use of weapons, need to clearly

Speaker: NA
Text: understand the seriousness of such behaviour

Speaker: NA
Text: and legal consequences that could follow

Speaker: NA
Text: from that behaviour in terms of criminal

Speaker: NA
Text: convictions and visa outcomes. These

Speaker: NA
Text: changes will: strengthen the character test in

Speaker: NA
Text: section 501 of the Migration Act; strengthen

Speaker: NA
Text: the power to refuse or cancel a temporary

Speaker: NA
Text: safe haven visa in section 500A of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Migration Act; and provide further

Speaker: NA
Text: disincentive in relation to the manufacture

Speaker: NA
Text: and possession of weapons by detainees by

Speaker: NA
Text: increasing the maximum penalty in section

Speaker: NA
Text: 197B of the Migration Act. These measures

Speaker: NA
Text: are intended to send a strong and clear

Speaker: NA
Text: message that the kind of unacceptable

Speaker: NA
Text: behaviour recently seen at immigration

Speaker: NA
Text: detention centres will not be tolerated by the

Speaker: NA
Text: government.

Speaker: NA
Text: I commend the bill to the House.

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate adjourned.

Speaker: NA
Text: Families, Housing, Community

Speaker: NA
Text: Services and Indigenous Affairs and

Speaker: NA
Text: Other Legislation Amendment

Speaker: NA
Text: (Budget and Other Measures) Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: Consideration of Senate Message

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill returned from the Senate with

Speaker: NA
Text: amendments.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ordered that the amendments be

Speaker: NA
Text: considered immediately.

Speaker: NA
Text: Senate's amendments-

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) Clause 2, page 2 (table item 2), omit the table

Speaker: NA
Text: item, substitute:

Speaker: NA
Text: 2. Schedule 1 1 January 1 January

Speaker: NA
Text: 3. Schedule 2 1 July 1 July 2011

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) Schedule 2, heading, page 8 (lines 1 and 2),

Speaker: NA
Text: omit the heading, substitute:

Speaker: NA
Text: Schedule 2-Disability support pension

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) Schedule 2, item 7, page 9 (table item 2), after

Speaker: NA
Text: "1218AA", insert ", 1218AB".

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) Schedule 2, page 9 (before line 12), before

Speaker: NA
Text: item 8, insert:

Speaker: NA
Text: 7A After section 1218AA

Speaker: NA
Text: Insert:

Speaker: NA
Text: 1218AB Extended portability period for

Speaker: NA
Text: disability support pension

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) The Secretary may, by written

Speaker: NA
Text: determination, extend the person's portability

Speaker: NA
Text: period for disability support pension if all of the

Speaker: NA
Text: following circumstances (the qualifying

Speaker: NA
Text: circumstances) exist:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) the person is severely disabled (see

Speaker: NA
Text: subsection 23(4B));

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) the person is receiving disability support

Speaker: NA
Text: pension;

Speaker: NA
Text: (c) the person is wholly or substantially

Speaker: NA
Text: dependent on a family member of the person (see

Speaker: NA
Text: subsection 23(14));

Speaker: NA
Text: (d) the Secretary is satisfied that the person

Speaker: NA
Text: will be living with the family member of the

Speaker: NA
Text: person throughout the period of absence;

Speaker: NA
Text: (e) the family member of the person is

Speaker: NA
Text: engaged in employment in Australia for an

Speaker: NA
Text: employer immediately before the start of the

Speaker: NA
Text: period of absence;

Speaker: NA
Text: (f) the Secretary is satisfied that the family

Speaker: NA
Text: member of the person will be engaged in

Speaker: NA
Text: employment outside Australia for that employer

Speaker: NA
Text: throughout the period of absence.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) If the Secretary extends a person's

Speaker: NA
Text: portability period under subsection (1), the

Speaker: NA
Text: person's portability period for disability support

Speaker: NA
Text: pension, for the purposes of this Part, is the

Speaker: NA
Text: extended period.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) The Secretary may revoke the

Speaker: NA
Text: determination if any of the qualifying

Speaker: NA
Text: circumstances ceases to exist.

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) A determination under subsection (1) is

Speaker: NA
Text: a legislative instrument.

Speaker: NA
Text: Note: The heading to section 1218AA is

Speaker: NA
Text: altered by omitting "Extended" and substituting

Speaker: NA
Text: "Unlimited".

Speaker: Ms COLLINS
Text: Franklin-Parliamentary

Speaker: NA
Text: Secretary for Community Services) (09:09):

Speaker: NA
Text: I move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the amendments be agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: These amendments provide for portability of

Speaker: NA
Text: the disability support pension to be extended

Speaker: NA
Text: in certain circumstances in which a family

Speaker: NA
Text: member of a DSP recipient is seconded

Speaker: NA
Text: overseas for employment purposes. These

Speaker: NA
Text: amendments reflect the findings of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Senate committee inquiry on the Families,

Speaker: NA
Text: Housing, Community Services

Speaker: NA
Text: Indigenous Affairs and Other Legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: Amendment (Budget and Other Measures)

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill 2010. The government has been

Speaker: NA
Text: responsive. We recognise that some family

Speaker: NA
Text: members of disability support pensioners

Speaker: NA
Text: may be required to spend extended periods

Speaker: NA
Text: of time overseas as a result of their

Speaker: NA
Text: employment-for example, employees of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade.

Speaker: Mr ANDREWS
Text: Menzies) (09:10): I

Speaker: NA
Text: indicate that the coalition support these

Speaker: NA
Text: amendments. They are sensible, they are

Speaker: NA
Text: practical and they are common sense, and we

Speaker: NA
Text: will support this legislation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: Social Security Legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: Amendment (Job Seeker Compliance)

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill 2011

Speaker: NA
Text: Report from Committee

Speaker: Ms RISHWORTH
Text: Kingston) (09:11):

Speaker: NA
Text: On behalf of the Standing Committee on

Speaker: NA
Text: Education and Employment I present the

Speaker: NA
Text: committee's report entitled Advisory report

Speaker: NA
Text: on the Social Security Legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: Amendment (Job Seeker Compliance) Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: not 2011, incorporating a dissenting report from

Speaker: NA
Text: the member for Melbourne, together with the

Speaker: NA
Text: minutes of proceedings.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ordered that the report be made a

Speaker: NA
Text: parliamentary paper.

Speaker: Ms RISHWORTH
Text: by leave-The bill

Speaker: NA
Text: was referred by the House Selection

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee to the House Standing

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee on Education and Employment

Speaker: NA
Text: on 24 March 2011 for inquiry and report.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is the second bill referred to the

Speaker: NA
Text: education and employment committee under

Speaker: NA
Text: the new arrangements that provide for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Selection Committee to refer a bill to a

Speaker: NA
Text: committee for an advisory report.

Speaker: NA
Text: The inquiry received 16 submissions and

Speaker: NA
Text: and took evidence from government departments,

Speaker: NA
Text: employment and social security peak bodies,

Speaker: NA
Text: employment service providers and other

Speaker: NA
Text: stakeholders in two public hearings that were

Speaker: NA
Text: held in Melbourne and Canberra. We are

Speaker: NA
Text: especially grateful to the

Speaker: NA
Text: organisations and departments

Speaker: NA
Text: participated in the inquiry.

Speaker: NA
Text: The committee was struck by the passion

Speaker: NA
Text: for social welfare, commitment to

Speaker: NA
Text: employment participation and breadth of

Speaker: NA
Text: knowledge expressed in many submissions

Speaker: NA
Text: and by numerous witnesses. Although the

Speaker: NA
Text: committee recognises that broader issues

Speaker: NA
Text: were raised in relation to the social

Speaker: NA
Text: and welfare systems as a whole, the

Speaker: NA
Text: committee's focus must, of course, remain on

Speaker: NA
Text: the measures proposed by this bill. This bill

Speaker: NA
Text: seeks to tighten the compliance regime

Speaker: NA
Text: currently applicable to job seekers receiving

Speaker: NA
Text: participation payments by introducing

Speaker: NA
Text: payment suspensions for job seekers who fail

Speaker: NA
Text: to attend appointments with their

Speaker: NA
Text: employment service providers until they

Speaker: NA
Text: agree to reschedule that appointment.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is no doubt about the crucial role

Speaker: NA
Text: that sustained and meaningful employment

Speaker: NA
Text: participation plays in the lives of all

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians. The minister echoed the words

Speaker: NA
Text: of our Prime Minister when she indicated

Speaker: NA
Text: that the benefits of employment stretch far

Speaker: NA
Text: beyond the receipt of a pay packet.

Speaker: NA
Text: Employment participation brings with it a

Speaker: NA
Text: suite of benefits including not only economic

Speaker: NA
Text: security but also dignity, purpose and

Speaker: NA
Text: direction. A central element of fostering

Speaker: NA
Text: employment participation is encouraging job

Speaker: NA
Text: seekers to interact and engage with their

Speaker: NA
Text: employment service providers. A lot of

Speaker: NA
Text: people have spoken about this as a punitive

Speaker: NA
Text: action, but the government and the

Speaker: NA
Text: committee saw it as a way to engage job

Speaker: NA
Text: seekers and to get them to talk with their

Speaker: NA
Text: employment services, which is critical and

Speaker: NA
Text: important. The committee believes that this

Speaker: NA
Text: bill is a step in the right direction in this

Speaker: NA
Text: regard. I would like to respond to some of

Speaker: NA
Text: the assertions in the dissenting report, in

Speaker: NA
Text: particular that there was not support for this

Speaker: NA
Text: measure. In response to this claim, I draw the

Speaker: NA
Text: people, attention of the House to, for example, the

Speaker: NA
Text: who evidence from Dr Prins Ralston, Executive

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of Employment Solutions at Mission

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, who said that these measures will:

Speaker: NA
Text: … assist employment providers by encouraging

Speaker: NA
Text: job seekers to properly engage with the system.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is the core of what we believe-that these

Speaker: NA
Text: amendments will be a tool that will help us to

Speaker: NA
Text: better engage job seekers.

Speaker: NA
Text: security Ms Sinclair, CEO of the National

Speaker: NA
Text: Employment Services Association, said:

Speaker: NA
Text: The amendments outlined in the current bill are

Speaker: NA
Text: considered welcome improvements to the job

Speaker: NA
Text: seeker compliance framework and we believe

Speaker: NA
Text: should put a greater emphasis on engagement and

Speaker: NA
Text: participation.

Speaker: NA
Text: While recognising that there were mixed

Speaker: NA
Text: views expressed in the report of the CPSU,

Speaker: NA
Text: the union that represents the front-line

Speaker: NA
Text: workers, its submission said:

Speaker: NA
Text: The majority of CPSU members felt that the

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed changes would likely increase

Speaker: NA
Text: compliance by job seekers as payments would not

Speaker: NA
Text: be made until job seekers attended appointments.

Speaker: NA
Text: A majority of members also said that changes to

Speaker: NA
Text: notification for reconnection requirements would

Speaker: NA
Text: improve job seeker compliance.

Speaker: NA
Text: We recognise that some issues with the bill

Speaker: NA
Text: were brought up, especially in the

Speaker: NA
Text: administration of the system, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: committee's report contains 10

Speaker: NA
Text: recommendations which we believe will

Speaker: NA
Text: enhance the communication and equitable

Speaker: NA
Text: administration of the measures proposed in

Speaker: NA
Text: the bill.

Speaker: NA
Text: A strong message to the committee

Speaker: NA
Text: received from peak bodies and other

Speaker: NA
Text: stakeholders was that the social security

Speaker: NA
Text: system is complex and often confusing.

Speaker: NA
Text: Therefore, a key recommendation in our

Speaker: NA
Text: report centres on the production of plain

Speaker: NA
Text: English explanations of the changes

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed in the bill and the impact that they

Speaker: NA
Text: will have. The purpose of this

Speaker: NA
Text: recommendation is to combat and minimise

Speaker: NA
Text: complexity in order to enable effective

Speaker: NA
Text: communication of the changes proposed in

Speaker: NA
Text: the bill to all job seekers and to ensure that

Speaker: NA
Text: job seekers fully understand their obligations

Speaker: NA
Text: and are able to meaningfully engage with

Speaker: NA
Text: employment service providers. In a similar

Speaker: NA
Text: vein, the committee has recommended that

Speaker: NA
Text: the word 'special' be removed from the

Speaker: NA
Text: reasonable excuses provision proposed by

Speaker: NA
Text: the bill, again in order to simplify and clarify

Speaker: NA
Text: the measures proposed by the bill and ensure

Speaker: NA
Text: that they are implemented as intended

Speaker: NA
Text: without an unnecessary level of complexity.

Speaker: NA
Text: The committee has also recommended the

Speaker: NA
Text: development of consistent guidance and

Speaker: NA
Text: training materials for those who will be

Speaker: NA
Text: involved in the administration of the

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed compliance regime and the

Speaker: NA
Text: provision of comprehensive training to

Speaker: NA
Text: Centrelink and employment service provider

Speaker: NA
Text: staff. These measures will ensure the

Speaker: NA
Text: consistent and equitable application and

Speaker: NA
Text: administration of the proposed compliance

Speaker: NA
Text: regime across the board. Furthermore, the

Speaker: NA
Text: committee has recommended the collection

Speaker: NA
Text: of data in relation to why job seekers without

Speaker: NA
Text: a reasonable excuse miss appointments and a

Speaker: NA
Text: review of the impact of the measures

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed by this bill.

Speaker: NA
Text: recommendations are targeted at filling a

Speaker: NA
Text: perceived gap in the research conducted in

Speaker: NA
Text: the area of job seeker compliance and

Speaker: NA
Text: ensuring that a concerted effort is made to

Speaker: NA
Text: continue to monitor and evaluate the

Speaker: NA
Text: effectiveness of the proposed compliance

Speaker: NA
Text: regime.

Speaker: NA
Text: In relation to vulnerable job seekers, about

Speaker: NA
Text: whom many witnesses and submissions

Speaker: NA
Text: expressed concern, the committee has

Speaker: NA
Text: recommended that employment service

Speaker: NA
Text: providers utilise all re-engagement methods

Speaker: NA
Text: available to them, not only compliance

Speaker: NA
Text: action, in order to re-engage these job

Speaker: NA
Text: seekers. The committee recognises that

Speaker: NA
Text: vulnerable job seekers do have special needs

Speaker: NA
Text: that must be addressed properly. The

Speaker: NA
Text: committee has also recommended that

Speaker: NA
Text: additional training and resources be provided

Speaker: NA
Text: to Centrelink staff in order to raise awareness

Speaker: NA
Text: of vulnerable job seekers and ensure that

Speaker: NA
Text: their vulnerabilities are being identified and

Speaker: NA
Text: managed in a manner that is conducive to

Speaker: NA
Text: assisting these job seekers to find and

Speaker: NA
Text: maintain employment.

Speaker: NA
Text: The committee also acknowledges the

Speaker: NA
Text: concerns that were raised about the capacity

Speaker: NA
Text: of Centrelink staff to implement the

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed measures, given their current

Speaker: NA
Text: workload. I and the committee were pleased

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Department of Human Services has

Speaker: NA
Text: indicated that it will monitor this impact in

Speaker: NA
Text: consultation with Centrelink staff and

Speaker: NA
Text: rearrange working arrangements

Speaker: NA
Text: accordingly. The committee agrees that this

Speaker: NA
Text: monitoring should occur to ensure that no

Speaker: NA
Text: undue stress or unreasonable workloads are

Speaker: NA
Text: put on front-line staff.

Speaker: NA
Text: In closing, I would like to thank all the

Speaker: NA
Text: committee members who worked on this.

Speaker: NA
Text: There was a lot of constructive discussion

Speaker: NA
Text: and engagement on this. I would also like to

Speaker: NA
Text: These thank the committee secretariat for their

Speaker: NA
Text: support-in particular, Sara Edson and

Speaker: NA
Text: Larisa Michalko for their hard work on this

Speaker: NA
Text: inquiry. I commend the report to the House.

Speaker: Mr BANDT
Text: Melbourne) (09:20): by

Speaker: NA
Text: leave-We hear a lot in this place and

Speaker: NA
Text: elsewhere about evidence based policy, and

Speaker: NA
Text: indeed I think it was the member for Fraser

Speaker: NA
Text: who moved a motion to that effect which

Speaker: NA
Text: was passed in this House. But, if there were

Speaker: NA
Text: ever any proof needed that evidence based

Speaker: NA
Text: policy gives way to political imperatives

Speaker: NA
Text: every time, it was this inquiry process and

Speaker: NA
Text: this bill. As we have heard, the effect and the

Speaker: NA
Text: purpose of the bill is to impose sanctions on

Speaker: NA
Text: job seekers up to and including losing part of

Speaker: NA
Text: their pay that they will never get back.

Speaker: NA
Text: During the course of the inquiry, almost

Speaker: NA
Text: everyone who fronted up to the inquiry,

Speaker: NA
Text: either in the form of a written submission or

Speaker: NA
Text: to give us evidence in person, said that this

Speaker: NA
Text: was the wrong approach.

Speaker: NA
Text: Last year there was an independent review

Speaker: NA
Text: commissioned by this government into the

Speaker: NA
Text: compliance framework for the social security

Speaker: NA
Text: system. That review was chaired by

Speaker: NA
Text: Professor Julian Disney. There were a

Speaker: NA
Text: number of recommendations. Prior to the

Speaker: NA
Text: introduction of this bill, the government had

Speaker: NA
Text: not responded to the recommendations, but it

Speaker: NA
Text: is basing its bill on the review and says the

Speaker: NA
Text: review by Professor Disney gave support to

Speaker: NA
Text: the move to impose financial sanctions on

Speaker: NA
Text: job seekers. The only problem with that is

Speaker: NA
Text: that Professor Disney fronted up to the

Speaker: NA
Text: inquiry and gave evidence that he thought

Speaker: NA
Text: that, at best, this bill was premature and was

Speaker: NA
Text: in effect ill judged. He said that he only

Speaker: NA
Text: included a note about that in his independent

Speaker: NA
Text: report because it was raised by other parties

Speaker: NA
Text: during the course of the federal election. He

Speaker: NA
Text: did not think it was a good idea and it was

Speaker: NA
Text: not one that he would have generated

Speaker: NA
Text: himself. It was an idea he felt obliged to

Speaker: NA
Text: raise because it was circulating in public

Speaker: NA
Text: debate. In his recommendation that refers to

Speaker: NA
Text: this proposal, he said that at the very least

Speaker: NA
Text: should give all the other measures that he has

Speaker: NA
Text: recommended a year to bed down before we

Speaker: NA
Text: embark on something as punitive as

Speaker: NA
Text: suspending people's payments he reasons for

Speaker: NA
Text: that are clear. They were relayed to the

Speaker: NA
Text: committee by job agency after job agency

Speaker: NA
Text: who came before the committee to say that

Speaker: NA
Text: people find the social security system

Speaker: NA
Text: bewildering and that you cannot proceed on

Speaker: NA
Text: an assumption that the reason people miss

Speaker: NA
Text: appointments is that they are somehow

Speaker: NA
Text: seeking to work the system. In fact, evidence

Speaker: NA
Text: was given to the inquiry that the people who

Speaker: NA
Text: want to work the system are precisely the

Speaker: NA
Text: ones who will turn up to every meeting

Speaker: NA
Text: because they know what is required. The

Speaker: NA
Text: people who are going to be hit by this bill are

Speaker: NA
Text: not the ones who are rorting the system but,

Speaker: NA
Text: according to the evidence, the ones who are

Speaker: NA
Text: confused by the system and who potentially

Speaker: NA
Text: find it difficult. That is why the No. 1

Speaker: NA
Text: recommendation of the independent review

Speaker: NA
Text: was that there be a plain language reworking

Speaker: NA
Text: of all materials associated with job seeker

Speaker: NA
Text: compliance, because until we are sure that

Speaker: NA
Text: job seekers understand their obligations we

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot punish them for failing to meet them.

Speaker: NA
Text: The second implicit rationale in the bill is

Speaker: NA
Text: that job seekers are somehow not turning up

Speaker: NA
Text: for so-called illegitimate reasons. The

Speaker: NA
Text: problem with that, if we are serious about

Speaker: NA
Text: evidence based policy, is that you would

Speaker: NA
Text: imagine that someone would have been able

Speaker: NA
Text: to come to the inquiry and tell us why it is

Speaker: NA
Text: that people are missing appointments. No-

Speaker: NA
Text: one could do that. The department could not

Speaker: NA
Text: do that and none of the very small number of

Speaker: NA
Text: people who supported the submission could

Speaker: NA
Text: do that. What we do know from the figures is

Speaker: NA
Text: that 20 per cent of people who miss

Speaker: NA
Text: appointments are Indigenous Australians and

Speaker: NA
Text: that 47 per cent of the people who miss

Speaker: NA
Text: appointments are young people. No-one

Speaker: NA
Text: could explain why that was and no-one could

Speaker: NA
Text: we explain why it was justified that there should

Speaker: NA
Text: be a disproportionate impact on those people

Speaker: NA
Text: of these harsh penalties.

Speaker: NA
Text: What almost everyone who appeared

Speaker: NA
Text: before the inquiry agreed with was that we

Speaker: NA
Text: should go back to basics. First of all, let us

Speaker: NA
Text: find out why people are missing these

Speaker: NA
Text: appointments-find out whether it is because

Speaker: NA
Text: they do not have good transport options, find

Speaker: NA
Text: out whether it is because they do not

Speaker: NA
Text: understand the system, find out whether they

Speaker: NA
Text: knew this was necessary in order for

Speaker: NA
Text: continued payment-and then develop

Speaker: NA
Text: programs that are tailored to that. In fact,

Speaker: NA
Text: is going on. The inquiry heard that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Centrelink working group is looking at that

Speaker: NA
Text: at the moment; its work is not yet complete.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is why the Greens have put in a

Speaker: NA
Text: dissenting report. We cannot support the

Speaker: NA
Text: passage of this bill. We propose that time be

Speaker: NA
Text: given to allow the recommendations of the

Speaker: NA
Text: independent inquiry to go ahead, to allow the

Speaker: NA
Text: Centrelink working group to do its job of

Speaker: NA
Text: gathering a proper evidence base about why

Speaker: NA
Text: so many young people and so many

Speaker: NA
Text: Indigenous Australians are

Speaker: NA
Text: appointments, and to not take the approach

Speaker: NA
Text: that is more stick than carrot and potentially

Speaker: NA
Text: put some of our most disadvantaged job

Speaker: NA
Text: seekers, who are without an income, even

Speaker: NA
Text: further into dire straits.

Speaker: NA
Text: COMMITTEES

Speaker: NA
Text: Treaties Committee

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr KELVIN THOMSON (Wills)

Speaker: NA
Text: (09:25): On behalf of the Joint Standing

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee on Treaties, I present the

Speaker: NA
Text: committee's report entitled Report 116:

Speaker: NA
Text: Treaties tabled on 24 and 25 November

Speaker: NA
Text: 2010, 9 February and 1 March 2011 and

Speaker: NA
Text: Treaties referred on 16 November 2010

Speaker: NA
Text: (Part 3), incorporating a dissenting report.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ordered that the report be made a

Speaker: NA
Text: parliamentary paper.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr KELVIN THOMSON: by leave-

Speaker: NA
Text: The Joint Standing Committee on Treaties

Speaker: NA
Text: Report 116 contains the committee's views

Speaker: NA
Text: on 15 treaties ranging from amendments to

Speaker: NA
Text: CITES and the Australian-New Zealand

Speaker: NA
Text: Closer Economic Relations Trade

Speaker: NA
Text: Agreement to ILO conventions on the

Speaker: NA
Text: working conditions of sailors, the treatment

Speaker: NA
Text: of asbestos and occupational health and

Speaker: NA
Text: safety. I am happy to advise that this report

Speaker: NA
Text: deals with the last of the treaties for which

Speaker: NA
Text: that consideration was delayed by the 2010

Speaker: NA
Text: federal election. It is a credit to the

Speaker: NA
Text: committee's members that it has been able to

Speaker: NA
Text: consider and report on no less than 55

Speaker: NA
Text: treaties since the election and has met the

Speaker: NA
Text: agreed reporting deadline for each one of

Speaker: NA
Text: them. In addition, for many of the treaties the

Speaker: NA
Text: committee not only issued invitations to

Speaker: NA
Text: participate to its regular stakeholders,

Speaker: NA
Text: including government agencies and state and

Speaker: NA
Text: territory governments, but was able to take

Speaker: NA
Text: evidence from a range of other interested

Speaker: NA
Text: missing parties. For example, the committee's

Speaker: NA
Text: consideration of amendments to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian-New Zealand Closer Economic

Speaker: NA
Text: Relations Trade Agreement involved a visit

Speaker: NA
Text: to suiting manufacturers the Stafford Group,

Speaker: NA
Text: whose plant is in North Melbourne. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Stafford Group retails it suits under the

Speaker: NA
Text: brands Anthony Squires, Giotto and 1096.

Speaker: NA
Text: Anthony Squires is the only retailer of

Speaker: NA
Text: Report high-quality suits still manufacturing in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. The Stafford Group is concerned

Speaker: NA
Text: that this arrangement will be placed at risk

Speaker: NA
Text: by the amendments proposed to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian-New Zealand Closer Economic

Speaker: NA
Text: Relations Trade Agreement. The committee

Speaker: NA
Text: has been assured by the government that it is

Speaker: NA
Text: aware of the Stafford Group's tenuous

Speaker: NA
Text: position and that it is working to ameliorate

Speaker: NA
Text: the impact of the treaty amendments on that

Speaker: NA
Text: organisation.

Speaker: NA
Text: I also draw the parliament's attention to

Speaker: NA
Text: the participation of the seafaring community

Speaker: NA
Text: in the inquiry into the ILO Maritime Labour

Speaker: NA
Text: Convention. This convention is intended to

Speaker: NA
Text: provide a set of basic working conditions for

Speaker: NA
Text: seafarers employed in international

Speaker: NA
Text: commercial shipping. The convention

Speaker: NA
Text: requires, amongst other things, that seafarers

Speaker: NA
Text: be properly trained, have written legally

Speaker: NA
Text: enforceable pay and conditions, have

Speaker: NA
Text: appropriate living conditions and have access

Speaker: NA
Text: to medical care. Crucially, the convention

Speaker: NA
Text: will ensure that the conditions extend to

Speaker: NA
Text: ships registered in countries that are not

Speaker: NA
Text: party to the convention. International

Speaker: NA
Text: shipping that does not meet these conditions

Speaker: NA
Text: will face severe penalties when it enters the

Speaker: NA
Text: ports of convention signatories. The

Speaker: NA
Text: penalties will remove any shipping cost

Speaker: NA
Text: advantages attributable to poor working and

Speaker: NA
Text: living conditions for seafarers. Amongst

Speaker: NA
Text: those who have already ratified the

Speaker: NA
Text: convention are the flag of convenience states

Speaker: NA
Text: of Liberia, Panama and the Bahamas. The

Speaker: NA
Text: convention has been well received by the

Speaker: NA
Text: seafaring community in Australia. Amongst

Speaker: NA
Text: those expressing support for Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: ratification of the convention are peak

Speaker: NA
Text: employer organisations, Shipping Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: Ltd and the Australian Ship Owners

Speaker: NA
Text: Association; seafarers representatives, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Institute of Marine and Power

Speaker: NA
Text: Engineers and the Maritime Union of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia; and representatives of charities

Speaker: NA
Text: supporting seafarers, the Australian Council

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Mission to Seafarers and the Sydney

Speaker: NA
Text: Seafarers Centre. All of these organisations

Speaker: NA
Text: had useful suggestions about how the

Speaker: NA
Text: convention is implemented, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: committee commends their suggestions to

Speaker: NA
Text: the government for consideration.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is remarkable, therefore, given

Speaker: NA
Text: degree of across-the-board support for this

Speaker: NA
Text: convention, that coalition members and

Speaker: NA
Text: senators could not see their way clear to

Speaker: NA
Text: support it and have issued a dissenting

Speaker: NA
Text: report. It shows how deeply ideological they

Speaker: NA
Text: still are concerning industrial relations

Speaker: NA
Text: questions, how hostile they are to the work

Speaker: NA
Text: of the ILO, the International Labour

Speaker: NA
Text: Organisation. And it shows that, when you

Speaker: NA
Text: scratch below the surface, they have learnt

Speaker: NA
Text: nothing from the 2007 Work Choices

Speaker: NA
Text: debacle which led to their election defeat.

Speaker: NA
Text: Finally, report No. 116 expresses the

Speaker: NA
Text: committee's frustration about treaties

Speaker: NA
Text: amended without ratification that come into

Speaker: NA
Text: force before they are scrutinised by the

Speaker: NA
Text: committee or the public. For example, the

Speaker: NA
Text: treaty amending the International

Speaker: NA
Text: Convention for the Prevention of Pollution

Speaker: NA
Text: from Ships was tabled in parliament in

Speaker: NA
Text: November 2010, after having come into

Speaker: NA
Text: force some five months earlier. This does not

Speaker: NA
Text: need to happen. Changes to treaties amended

Speaker: NA
Text: without ratification are provided to signatory

Speaker: NA
Text: countries for consideration up to 12 months

Speaker: NA
Text: before they come into effect. This period

Speaker: NA
Text: allows signatory countries that do not agree

Speaker: NA
Text: to the changes to either opt out of the

Speaker: NA
Text: changes or attempt to have the changes

Speaker: NA
Text: removed. In the case of the treaty amending

Speaker: NA
Text: the International Convention for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prevention of Pollution from Ships, the

Speaker: NA
Text: amendments were provided to Australia in

Speaker: NA
Text: mid-2009 and the period for objecting to the

Speaker: NA
Text: treaty ended in June 2010. There is enough

Speaker: NA
Text: time in this 12-month period for parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: and the public to make a material

Speaker: NA
Text: contribution to the outcome. So our report

Speaker: NA
Text: recommends that amendments to treaties of

Speaker: NA
Text: this sort be referred to the parliament for

Speaker: NA
Text: consideration at the time they are first

Speaker: NA
Text: provided to Australia so that the parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: can have a say before the changes come into

Speaker: NA
Text: force. I commend the report to the House.

Speaker: NA
Text: the high Public Accounts and Audit Committee

Speaker: NA
Text: Report

Speaker: Mr OAKESHOTT
Text: Lyne) (09:32): On

Speaker: NA
Text: behalf of the Joint Committee of Public

Speaker: NA
Text: Accounts and Audit I present the

Speaker: NA
Text: committee's report entitled Report 422:

Speaker: NA
Text: Review of the 2009-10 Defence Materiel

Speaker: NA
Text: Organisation major projects report.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ordered that the report be made a

Speaker: NA
Text: parliamentary paper.

Speaker: Mr OAKESHOTT
Text: by leave-On 6

Speaker: NA
Text: December 2006 the Joint Committee of

Speaker: NA
Text: Public Accounts and Audit unanimously

Speaker: NA
Text: agreed to recommend that the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: National Audit Office receive additional

Speaker: NA
Text: funding to produce an annual report on

Speaker: NA
Text: progress in major Defence projects. This

Speaker: NA
Text: report would detail cost, schedule and

Speaker: NA
Text: capability information for a number of large

Speaker: NA
Text: acquisition projects. The government agreed

Speaker: NA
Text: with that recommendation and approved

Speaker: NA
Text: funding for the report in the May 2008

Speaker: NA
Text: budget. The intention was that the annual

Speaker: NA
Text: major projects report would provide a means

Speaker: NA
Text: by which accessible, transparent and

Speaker: NA
Text: accurate information could be made

Speaker: NA
Text: available to the parliament and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian public about the state of Defence

Speaker: NA
Text: major acquisition projects.

Speaker: NA
Text: The 2009-10 Defence Materiel

Speaker: NA
Text: Organisation major projects report is the

Speaker: NA
Text: third MPR to be produced, but only the

Speaker: NA
Text: second MPR to be reviewed and reported on

Speaker: NA
Text: by the committee. Therefore, through this

Speaker: NA
Text: review the committee has incorporated

Speaker: NA
Text: ongoing issues that were raised as part of the

Speaker: NA
Text: review of the pilot MPR in 2007-08 but also

Speaker: NA
Text: provides discussion on the Auditor-General's

Speaker: NA
Text: major findings in relation to the 2008-09

Speaker: NA
Text: MPR in addition to the 2009-10 MPR.

Speaker: NA
Text: Major acquisition projects are complex

Speaker: NA
Text: and often diverse in nature. This creates

Speaker: NA
Text: challenges for the DMO in presenting

Speaker: NA
Text: consistent data across projects and for the

Speaker: NA
Text: ANAO in reviewing this work. In particular,

Speaker: NA
Text: as qualified audit conclusions have been

Speaker: NA
Text: received for the 2007-08, 2008-09 and 2009-

Speaker: NA
Text: 10 MPRs, due to the exclusion of price and

Speaker: NA
Text: expenditure information expressed in base

Speaker: NA
Text: state dollars, the committee focused on

Speaker: NA
Text: evidence received in relation to this

Speaker: NA
Text: particular issue. Through

Speaker: NA
Text: recommendations the committee has

Speaker: NA
Text: requested that the DMO address the base

Speaker: NA
Text: state dollar issue associated with the

Speaker: NA
Text: qualified audit opinions given, with a

Speaker: NA
Text: resolution of the matter expected for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Other areas of importance highlighted

Speaker: NA
Text: during the review include the timing of the

Speaker: NA
Text: preparation of the MPR guidelines,

Speaker: NA
Text: determining the exit criteria for MPR

Speaker: NA
Text: projects, the impact of financial control

Speaker: NA
Text: frameworks on the cost, schedule and

Speaker: NA
Text: capability of projects, analysis of the Gate

Speaker: NA
Text: Review Assurance Board's process and

Speaker: NA
Text: inclusion of earnt value management systems

Speaker: NA
Text: data in the project data summary sheets for

Speaker: NA
Text: individual projects.

Speaker: NA
Text: The 2009-10 MPR builds on the level and

Speaker: NA
Text: presentation of information provided in the

Speaker: NA
Text: previous MPRs, which in turn improves the

Speaker: NA
Text: readability and utility of the document. As

Speaker: NA
Text: each successive MPR is intended to further

Speaker: NA
Text: progress and improve both accountability

Speaker: NA
Text: and transparency with regard to the

Speaker: NA
Text: management of major defence capital

Speaker: NA
Text: acquisition projects, it is important that the

Speaker: NA
Text: concerns highlighted through the assurance

Speaker: NA
Text: audit process, and consequently the

Speaker: NA
Text: committee's review, be dealt with and

Speaker: NA
Text: addressed by the DMO itself.

Speaker: NA
Text: On behalf of the committee I would like to

Speaker: NA
Text: congratulate the Auditor-General and the

Speaker: NA
Text: DMO on the cooperative manner in which

Speaker: NA
Text: they and their staff have worked to produce

Speaker: NA
Text: the 2009-10 MPR. Ultimately, the scrutiny

Speaker: NA
Text: provided through the review of the MPR

Speaker: NA
Text: should increase transparency and

Speaker: NA
Text: accountability and therefore provide the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian public with confidence that

Speaker: NA
Text: Defence procurement dollars are being spent

Speaker: NA
Text: wisely to provide Australian Defence Force

Speaker: NA
Text: personnel with the quality support they

Speaker: NA
Text: its deserve. I commend the report to the House.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mrs D'ATH (Petrie) (09:36): by leave-

Speaker: NA
Text: As Deputy Chair of the Joint Committee of

Speaker: NA
Text: Public Accounts and Audit, I rise to speak in

Speaker: NA
Text: support of report 422, Review of the 2009-10

Speaker: NA
Text: Defence Materiel Organisation Major

Speaker: NA
Text: Projects Report. As the chair, the member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Lyne, has already highlighted, this is

Speaker: NA
Text: the second major project report to be

Speaker: NA
Text: reviewed and reported on by the committee

Speaker: NA
Text: and the third major project report to be

Speaker: NA
Text: produced overall since the Joint Committee

Speaker: NA
Text: of Public Accounts and Audit unanimously

Speaker: NA
Text: agreed to recommend that the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: National Audit Office receive additional

Speaker: NA
Text: funding to produce an annual report on

Speaker: NA
Text: progress in major defence projects back in

Speaker: NA
Text: December 2006.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is important to acknowledge the reason

Speaker: NA
Text: such a report was created in the first place,

Speaker: NA
Text: which is to provide a means by which

Speaker: NA
Text: accessible, transparent and accurate

Speaker: NA
Text: information could be made available to the

Speaker: NA
Text: parliament and, importantly, the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: public about the state of defence major

Speaker: NA
Text: acquisition projects. The government

Speaker: NA
Text: recognises the importance of transparency

Speaker: NA
Text: and accountability in relation to the major

Speaker: NA
Text: project acquisitions by the Defence Materiel

Speaker: NA
Text: Organisation and the important role that the

Speaker: NA
Text: major projects report plays in providing that

Speaker: NA
Text: transparency and accountability.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is of note that, through its

Speaker: NA
Text: recommendations, the committee has

Speaker: NA
Text: requested that the Defence Materiel

Speaker: NA
Text: Organisation address the base-date dollar

Speaker: NA
Text: issue associated with the qualified audit

Speaker: NA
Text: opinions given, with the resolution of the

Speaker: NA
Text: matter expected for the 2011-12 major

Speaker: NA
Text: project report, the reason being that the

Speaker: NA
Text: qualified audit conclusions have been

Speaker: NA
Text: received for each and every one of the major

Speaker: NA
Text: project reports that have been produced. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: important that we overcome this problem of

Speaker: NA
Text: having these qualified audit conclusions. As

Speaker: NA
Text: the chair has indicated, quite a bit of

Speaker: NA
Text: evidence went to that point and there were

Speaker: NA
Text: questions from the committee members to

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure that we can overcome this problem in

Speaker: NA
Text: the future and provide more transparency.

Speaker: NA
Text: The work of the Defence Materiel

Speaker: NA
Text: only Organisation to improve accountability and

Speaker: NA
Text: transparency in regard to the management of

Speaker: NA
Text: major defence capital acquisition projects

Speaker: NA
Text: and the work that the Defence Materiel

Speaker: NA
Text: Organisation is doing to work with the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian National Audit Office to ensure

Speaker: NA
Text: this transparency and accountability is

Speaker: NA
Text: acknowledged. However, importantly, we

Speaker: NA
Text: must note that the concerns highlighted

Speaker: NA
Text: through the assurance audit process and

Speaker: NA
Text: consequently the committee's review must be

Speaker: NA
Text: dealt with and addressed by the DMO.

Speaker: NA
Text: I also take this opportunity to

Speaker: NA
Text: acknowledge and congratulate Mr Ian

Speaker: NA
Text: MCPhee, the Auditor-General, and Dr

Speaker: NA
Text: Stephen Gumley, the CEO of DMO, on the

Speaker: NA
Text: cooperative manner in which they and their

Speaker: NA
Text: staff have worked to produce the 2009-10

Speaker: NA
Text: major projects report. It is my pleasure to

Speaker: NA
Text: commend the report to the House.

Speaker: Mr OAKESHOTT
Text: I move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the House take note of the report.

Text: Scott): In accordance with standing order

Text: of the debate will be made an order of the

Speaker: NA
Text: day for the next sitting.

Speaker: NA
Text: That the order of the day be referred to the

Text: BILLS

Speaker: NA
Text: Corporations Amendment (Improving

Speaker: NA
Text: Accountability on Director and

Speaker: NA
Text: Executive Remuneration) Bill 2011

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate resumed on the motion:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: Ms BRODTMANN
Text: Canberra) (09:41):

Speaker: NA
Text: The Corporations Amendment (Improving

Speaker: NA
Text: Accountability on Director and Executive

Speaker: NA
Text: Remuneration) Bill 2011 is a step forward in

Speaker: NA
Text: ensuring that shareholders and Australians

Speaker: NA
Text: generally have faith in the accountability of

Speaker: NA
Text: directors and senior executives of Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: companies and, most importantly, in the

Speaker: NA
Text: fairness of their pay. It does this not by

Speaker: NA
Text: regulation but by an approach that respects

Speaker: NA
Text: the need for firms to operate freely in the

Speaker: NA
Text: market, at the same time giving shareholders

Speaker: NA
Text: the power they need to make sure that senior

Speaker: NA
Text: executives truly earn their pay.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is far from the only area in which

Speaker: NA
Text: government shows a decisive preference for

Speaker: NA
Text: market based solutions over regulation, a

Speaker: NA
Text: preference one would hope would be more

Speaker: NA
Text: widely shared and appreciated by those

Speaker: NA
Text: opposite. I say 'appreciated' because, just

Speaker: NA
Text: listening to this debate in the last few days

Speaker: NA
Text: and last night particularly, my colleagues in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Labor government were portrayed as

Speaker: NA
Text: crazy red raggers living in some socialist

Speaker: NA
Text: nirvana: every morning we leap out of bed,

Speaker: NA
Text: flick through our copy of the little red book,

Speaker: NA
Text: read out our favourite passages, sing a few

Speaker: NA
Text: rounds of The Internationale and then march

Speaker: NA
Text: off to work under the fluttering banner of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Soviet flag.

Speaker: Mr Husic
Text: That is what I do!

Speaker: Ms BRODTMANN
Text: Is that what you

Speaker: NA
Text: do? Was that this morning? Okay! I remind

Speaker: NA
Text: those opposite of what the Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: government-not just this Labor government

Speaker: NA
Text: but also Labor governments in the past-has

Speaker: NA
Text: done in introducing market based solutions

Speaker: NA
Text: for this country. In the 1980s we opened up

Speaker: NA
Text: the economy, we opened up markets, we

Speaker: NA
Text: opened up banks and we opened up the

Speaker: NA
Text: country, particularly to the Asia-Pacific. We

Speaker: NA
Text: cut protection. Most recently, since 2007 we

Speaker: NA
Text: have saved this economy from the global

Speaker: NA
Text: financial crisis. I hardly regard that as some

Speaker: NA
Text: sort of mad, red-ragging socialist bunch of

Speaker: NA
Text: people crazily singing The Internationale

Speaker: NA
Text: every morning.

Speaker: NA
Text: The issue of remuneration has been at the

Speaker: NA
Text: forefront of the minds of shareholders and

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian community for some time, an

Speaker: NA
Text: issue more pressing following the corporate

Speaker: NA
Text: collapses associated with the global financial

Speaker: NA
Text: crisis. People around the world were rightly

Speaker: NA
Text: outraged that senior executives continued to

Speaker: NA
Text: receive large pay packages-so-called

Speaker: NA
Text: performance bonuses and golden

Speaker: NA
Text: parachutes-at a time when their companies

Speaker: NA
Text: this were failing, leaving many average

Speaker: NA
Text: employees without jobs and their homes at

Speaker: NA
Text: risk. We in this country were spared the full

Speaker: NA
Text: extent of the effects of the global financial

Speaker: NA
Text: crisis thanks to the quick actions of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor government. But Australians remain

Speaker: NA
Text: highly concerned about the rates of executive

Speaker: NA
Text: pay. This concern is sharpened by the

Speaker: NA
Text: disparity between the pay packets of senior

Speaker: NA
Text: executives and those of average Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: working families. I am struck by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Productivity Commission's findings on this.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Productivity Commission reports that

Speaker: NA
Text: the top CEOs of Australian public companies

Speaker: NA
Text: receive pay some 110 times average

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian weekly earnings. This compares

Speaker: NA
Text: with the earnings of the CEOs of Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: smallest companies of just four times

Speaker: NA
Text: average Australian weekly earnings. In some

Speaker: NA
Text: cases, CEO remuneration grew by as much

Speaker: NA
Text: as 300 per cent in real terms between 1993

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians do not have a problem with

Speaker: NA
Text: other hardworking individuals earning more

Speaker: NA
Text: pay than they do. But they do have a

Speaker: NA
Text: problem with these remuneration packages,

Speaker: NA
Text: bonus schemes and golden parachutes being

Speaker: NA
Text: bestowed regardless of the actual

Speaker: NA
Text: performance of the individual. Given this, it

Speaker: NA
Text: is easy to understand why these packages are

Speaker: NA
Text: so hard for people to accept. We should not

Speaker: NA
Text: be surprised at the level of anger and

Speaker: NA
Text: mistrust that exists over this issue. Such

Speaker: NA
Text: mistrust is not healthy, as it undermines the

Speaker: NA
Text: basic strong sense of fairness that

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians have and the trust that is needed

Speaker: NA
Text: for a society based on the free market to

Speaker: NA
Text: function.

Speaker: NA
Text: There have been efforts in the past to

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure that management teams look after the

Speaker: NA
Text: best interests of shareholders, principally by

Speaker: NA
Text: linking performance to share value. This

Speaker: NA
Text: worked up to a point. But research shows

Speaker: NA
Text: that this linkage has been distorted. It has

Speaker: NA
Text: emerged that there are a number of factors

Speaker: NA
Text: that go into the calculation of remuneration,

Speaker: NA
Text: some of which are reasonable, some of

Speaker: NA
Text: which are the result of what can only be

Speaker: NA
Text: described as gaming. As the Productivity

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission mentioned, while local

Speaker: NA
Text: shareholder value plummeted in 2008 as the

Speaker: NA
Text: result of the GFC, the imported crisis, with

Speaker: NA
Text: some countries and sectors being propped up

Speaker: NA
Text: by taxpayers, executive pay seemed to

Speaker: NA
Text: emerge unscathed, crystallising a view that

Speaker: NA
Text: executives were being rewarded for failure

Speaker: NA
Text: after having been rewarded for success.

Speaker: NA
Text: The argument that these packages are

Speaker: NA
Text: required to acquire and keep the best talent

Speaker: NA
Text: also not supported by available evidence.

Speaker: NA
Text: One journal article notes that there is a

Speaker: NA
Text: turnover rate for senior executives of

Speaker: NA
Text: between four per cent and six per cent. The

Speaker: NA
Text: article states that it is a matter of judgment

Speaker: NA
Text: whether a turnover rate of five per cent is

Speaker: NA
Text: sufficient to create market pressure to raise

Speaker: NA
Text: levels of compensation by itself. It is also

Speaker: NA
Text: questionable whether independent

Speaker: NA
Text: remuneration committees are by themselves

Speaker: NA
Text: capable of better linking performance with

Speaker: NA
Text: reward, given some of the biases and

Speaker: NA
Text: conflicts of interest that may result. In

Speaker: NA
Text: Jennifer Hill and Charles Yablon, who are

Speaker: NA
Text: regular commentators on this issue, have

Speaker: NA
Text: noted that even carefully constructed

Speaker: NA
Text: remuneration packages will frequently

Speaker: NA
Text: provide corporate manager with incentives to

Speaker: NA
Text: use their strategic advantage within the

Speaker: NA
Text: company to prefer their own interests over

Speaker: NA
Text: those of the shareholders.

Speaker: NA
Text: This bill seeks to address these problems

Speaker: NA
Text: and allay the concerns of shareholders and

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians as a whole by implementing

Speaker: NA
Text: changes to the Corporations Act

Speaker: NA
Text: recommended by the Productivity

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission. It seeks to address the

Speaker: NA
Text: imbalance between shareholders and

Speaker: NA
Text: management and provide some much-needed

Speaker: NA
Text: help to ensure that boards are responsive to

Speaker: NA
Text: the concerns of shareholders. But rather than

Speaker: NA
Text: imposing a government limit on

Speaker: NA
Text: remuneration this bill seeks to make boards

Speaker: NA
Text: more accountable for their decisions on pay,

Speaker: NA
Text: improve the manner in which conflicts are

Speaker: NA
Text: dealt with and increase transparency and

Speaker: NA
Text: accountability in executive remuneration

Speaker: NA
Text: matters.

Speaker: NA
Text: It achieves these things by introducing the

Speaker: NA
Text: so-called three-strikes test. This test creates a

Speaker: NA
Text: process by which directors will face a spill

Speaker: NA
Text: motion on their position if over two

Speaker: NA
Text: consecutive years a company's remuneration

Speaker: NA
Text: report has been rejected by 25 per cent or

Speaker: NA
Text: is more of the votes. Should this spill motion

Speaker: NA
Text: be passed, directors will need to seek re-

Speaker: NA
Text: election at a spill meeting within 90 days of

Speaker: NA
Text: the AGM. This will make directors

Speaker: NA
Text: accountable for their decisions and

Speaker: NA
Text: responsive to their shareholders.

Speaker: NA
Text: This bill also seeks to bring greater

Speaker: NA
Text: transparency to the role of remuneration

Speaker: NA
Text: consultants. This measure reflects the

Speaker: NA
Text: concern expressed by some shareholders that

Speaker: NA
Text: remuneration consultants are placed in a

Speaker: NA
Text: potential conflict situation when they have to

Speaker: NA
Text: provide their advice, in the first instance, to

Speaker: NA
Text: fact, the very managers who are responsible for

Speaker: NA
Text: signing off on their services in the future.

Speaker: NA
Text: Obviously, this has the potential to create a

Speaker: NA
Text: situation whereby the consultant may feel

Speaker: NA
Text: constrained in what advice they can provide.

Speaker: NA
Text: To counter this potential conflict, this

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation will require that the reports of

Speaker: NA
Text: independent consultants go first to the non-

Speaker: NA
Text: executive directors or a remuneration

Speaker: NA
Text: committee rather than company executives.

Speaker: NA
Text: This bill also seeks to eliminate situations

Speaker: NA
Text: where key management personnel or closely

Speaker: NA
Text: related parties are voting on pay issues. The

Speaker: NA
Text: bill will prohibit such parties from voting on

Speaker: NA
Text: non-binding remuneration votes, which

Speaker: NA
Text: otherwise may distort the results and

Speaker: NA
Text: diminish their effectiveness as a feedback

Speaker: NA
Text: mechanism.

Speaker: NA
Text: The government is also committed to

Speaker: NA
Text: strengthening the link between performance

Speaker: NA
Text: and remuneration. That is a really important

Speaker: NA
Text: point to make. This bill will prohibit

Speaker: NA
Text: directors and senior executives from hedging

Speaker: NA
Text: their incentive remuneration. It is currently

Speaker: NA
Text: possible for a director or senior executive to

Speaker: NA
Text: hedge their exposure to incentive

Speaker: NA
Text: remuneration, thereby effectively bypassing

Speaker: NA
Text: the link between performance and pay. This

Speaker: NA
Text: is not consistent with the principles

Speaker: NA
Text: underlying a remuneration framework that

Speaker: NA
Text: seeks to ensure pay is fairly linked to

Speaker: NA
Text: achievement. I do not think that that is too

Speaker: NA
Text: much to ask.

Speaker: NA
Text: This bill is a comprehensive approach to

Speaker: NA
Text: the issues of remuneration of Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: boards and senior executives. It seeks to

Speaker: NA
Text: answer the questions and concerns of the

Speaker: NA
Text: community and shareholders over the issues

Speaker: NA
Text: of excessive executive pay, particularly in

Speaker: NA
Text: the light of poor performance. It does this

Speaker: NA
Text: without placing restrictive or draconian

Speaker: NA
Text: regulation on companies or by interfering

Speaker: NA
Text: drastically in the marketplace. I want to

Speaker: NA
Text: underscore that point, because from the way

Speaker: NA
Text: that the people opposite have been talking it

Speaker: NA
Text: seems that they view it as quite the contrary.

Speaker: NA
Text: It does not interfere in the marketplace. This

Speaker: NA
Text: bill enhances Australia's corporate

Speaker: NA
Text: governance framework, particularly

Speaker: NA
Text: transparency. It provides shareholders with

Speaker: NA
Text: the power they need to effectively monitor

Speaker: NA
Text: their own companies to ensure that boards

Speaker: NA
Text: and senior executives are delivering on the

Speaker: NA
Text: organisational outcomes and are rewarded

Speaker: NA
Text: accordingly. It gives shareholders the power

Speaker: NA
Text: to say no to packages that reward failure or

Speaker: NA
Text: poor performance, and it improves the

Speaker: NA
Text: governance of companies to ensure better

Speaker: NA
Text: reward for good performance and no reward

Speaker: NA
Text: for failure. Most importantly, it benefits not

Speaker: NA
Text: only shareholders but the economy as a

Speaker: NA
Text: whole. The benefits of this legislation are

Speaker: NA
Text: clear, and I commend it to the House.

Speaker: Mr TEHAN
Text: Wannon) (09:52): I rise

Speaker: NA
Text: today to talk on the Corporations

Speaker: NA
Text: Amendment (Improving Accountability on

Speaker: NA
Text: Director and Executive Remuneration) Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: 2011. The coalition will not oppose this bill

Speaker: NA
Text: but we will seek to make an important

Speaker: NA
Text: amendment to it. We will do that to make

Speaker: NA
Text: sure that we get the balance right in this bill.

Speaker: NA
Text: While we are broadly supportive of the

Speaker: NA
Text: objective to achieve better alignment

Speaker: NA
Text: between shareholders and boards on the

Speaker: NA
Text: issue of executive remuneration, we are

Speaker: NA
Text: concerned about the potential for unintended

Speaker: NA
Text: consequences which can flow from excessive

Speaker: NA
Text: and overly prescriptive regulation in this

Speaker: NA
Text: area-and, sadly, the Labor government

Speaker: NA
Text: have a strong history of excessive and overly

Speaker: NA
Text: prescriptive regulation. They continue to

Speaker: NA
Text: want to throttle the life out of business in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, and that is why we have to make

Speaker: NA
Text: sure that we get the balance right in this bill.

Speaker: NA
Text: This bill implements recommendations of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Productivity Commission in its recent

Speaker: NA
Text: inquiry into executive remuneration in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, which reported on 4 January 2010.

Speaker: NA
Text: Concern around the issue of executive

Speaker: NA
Text: remuneration led to the review by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Productivity Commission. The review

Speaker: NA
Text: commenced in 2009 and received 170

Speaker: NA
Text: submissions, showing that this is an issue

Speaker: NA
Text: which the community and the business

Speaker: NA
Text: community take incredibly seriously. The

Speaker: NA
Text: final report was provided to the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: government on 19 December 2009.

Speaker: NA
Text: An exposure draft elicited further

Speaker: NA
Text: comment and changes to the proposed

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation. The bill's main provisions

Speaker: NA
Text: include requiring a vote for directors to stand

Speaker: NA
Text: for re-election if they do not adequately

Speaker: NA
Text: address shareholder concerns

Speaker: NA
Text: remuneration issues over two consecutive

Speaker: NA
Text: years, the so-called two-strikes rule;

Speaker: NA
Text: changing regulation with respect to the use

Speaker: NA
Text: of remuneration consultants; prohibiting

Speaker: NA
Text: directors and executives from voting their

Speaker: NA
Text: shares on remuneration resolutions;

Speaker: NA
Text: prohibiting the hedging of incentive

Speaker: NA
Text: remuneration; requiring shareholder approval

Speaker: NA
Text: for declarations of 'no vacancy' at an annual

Speaker: NA
Text: general meeting; requiring that any directed

Speaker: NA
Text: proxies are voted and voted as directed; and

Speaker: NA
Text: reducing the complexity of the remuneration

Speaker: NA
Text: report by confining disclosures in the report

Speaker: NA
Text: to the key management personnel.

Speaker: NA
Text: Change to voting arrangements must be

Speaker: NA
Text: careful not to distort the wishes of the

Speaker: NA
Text: majority of shareholders. The views of a

Speaker: NA
Text: minority should not too easily hold the

Speaker: NA
Text: majority hostage. When it comes to the level

Speaker: NA
Text: of support required to reject a remuneration

Speaker: NA
Text: report, a process that can lead to a spill of

Speaker: NA
Text: board, we believe the bar has been set too

Speaker: NA
Text: low. We believe that an active minority

Speaker: NA
Text: could disrupt company proceedings if this

Speaker: NA
Text: bill is passed as it is.

Speaker: NA
Text: We will be moving an amendment in

Speaker: NA
Text: relation to the threshold for rejecting the

Speaker: NA
Text: remuneration report. As currently proposed,

Speaker: NA
Text: the threshold for the two-strikes rule is 25

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent of votes cast. The coalition will be

Speaker: NA
Text: moving an amendment to require the

Speaker: NA
Text: threshold to be 25 per cent of the total votes

Speaker: NA
Text: available to be cast, and this is an important

Speaker: NA
Text: amendment. Twenty-five per cent of the

Speaker: NA
Text: votes cast means that you could have seven

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent of company shareholders voting to

Speaker: NA
Text: remove a board. This is dangerous because,

Speaker: NA
Text: if you had an active minority wanting to

Speaker: NA
Text: disrupt the ongoing proceedings of a

Speaker: NA
Text: company, with this threshold they could do

Speaker: NA
Text: just that. We want to introduce an

Speaker: NA
Text: amendment which provides a sensible

Speaker: NA
Text: safeguard. Moving to a threshold of 25 per

Speaker: NA
Text: on cent of the total votes available to be cast

Speaker: NA
Text: seems to me a very sensible proposition and

Speaker: NA
Text: one which the House and the parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: should be able to agree on. As I have said,

Speaker: NA
Text: this will prevent a small number of

Speaker: NA
Text: shareholders dictating a result which is not

Speaker: NA
Text: shared by a majority of the passive non-

Speaker: NA
Text: voting shareholders. We will not oppose this

Speaker: NA
Text: bill but we want to make a sensible

Speaker: NA
Text: amendment which provides balance to it. I

Speaker: NA
Text: urge the House and the parliament to support

Speaker: NA
Text: our amendment.

Speaker: Ms SMYTH
Text: La Trobe) (09:58): I am

Speaker: NA
Text: very pleased to speak on the Corporations

Speaker: NA
Text: Amendment (Improving Accountability on

Speaker: NA
Text: Director and Executive Remuneration) Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: 2010, which strikes such a sensible balance

Speaker: NA
Text: in the community debate around director and

Speaker: NA
Text: executive salaries, bonuses and incentives. I

Speaker: NA
Text: am also pleased to see that the opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: will ultimately be supporting the bulk of this

Speaker: NA
Text: the legislation, although, given the remarks of

Speaker: NA
Text: some of those speakers during the course of

Speaker: NA
Text: this debate, it has obviously been quite a

Speaker: NA
Text: struggle to reach that very reasonable view. I

Speaker: NA
Text: have been particularly interested to hear

Speaker: NA
Text: remarks from opposition members in the

Speaker: NA
Text: debate about overregulation, which is quite a

Speaker: NA
Text: curious line of argument for a group of

Speaker: NA
Text: people who are ultimately going to support

Speaker: NA
Text: this bill. I really have to admire the ability of

Speaker: NA
Text: those members opposite who ran that line of

Speaker: NA
Text: argument with no shame. It is quite a

Speaker: NA
Text: balancing act and quite a skill. Some of those

Speaker: NA
Text: opposite seem to think that the coalition had

Speaker: NA
Text: a marvellous track record in minimising

Speaker: NA
Text: regulation when in government. I suspect

Speaker: NA
Text: that those members were possibly harking

Speaker: NA
Text: back to the wafer-thin volume of Work

Speaker: NA
Text: Choices regulations, or possibly the mere

Speaker: NA
Text: pamphlet that was John Howard's GST

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation. I really have a feeling that,

Speaker: NA
Text: during the break, some members opposite

Speaker: NA
Text: have been passing around old Family Ties

Speaker: NA
Text: DVDs, because there is more than a little bit

Speaker: NA
Text: of Alex P Keaton in the debate we have seen

Speaker: NA
Text: from the other side of the chamber, both in

Speaker: NA
Text: this session and at the end of the last. They

Speaker: NA
Text: seem to still be convinced by a curious and

Speaker: NA
Text: entirely fictional notion that they stand for

Speaker: NA
Text: small government and lessening regulation-

Speaker: NA
Text: and, suddenly, Reagan is back in the White

Speaker: NA
Text: House. They may want to have a quick recap

Speaker: NA
Text: on some of the regulatory interventions of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Howard government during its decade

Speaker: NA
Text: and more in office to perhaps disabuse

Speaker: NA
Text: themselves of that view. In any event, it is

Speaker: NA
Text: more than a little disingenuous to come to

Speaker: NA
Text: this place and masquerade as a free

Speaker: NA
Text: marketeer and then proceed to support the

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation with little more than a fig leaf

Speaker: NA
Text: amendment. But I will leave all that aside

Speaker: NA
Text: now because, as with so many other things,

Speaker: NA
Text: the opposition's views on this legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: ultimately will not rate, even as a footnote.

Speaker: NA
Text: This legislation developed by the

Speaker: NA
Text: government is a timely and even-handed

Speaker: NA
Text: regulatory response to genuine community

Speaker: NA
Text: concerns about executive remuneration.

Speaker: NA
Text: Those concerns came to the fore during the

Speaker: NA
Text: global financial crisis. Members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: opposition have said that we should not try

Speaker: NA
Text: to drag down people who have done well for

Speaker: NA
Text: themselves-that is, executives who have

Speaker: NA
Text: been paid significant sums-as though that

Speaker: NA
Text: was the intention of the legislation. No, it is

Speaker: NA
Text: about making sure that mums and dads, self-

Speaker: NA
Text: funded retirees and all others who invest in

Speaker: NA
Text: shares directly and indirectly can be

Speaker: NA
Text: confident that the savings they have scraped

Speaker: NA
Text: together to buy a few shares are not being

Speaker: NA
Text: squandered and that the companies they

Speaker: NA
Text: invest in are being managed sensibly and

Speaker: NA
Text: prudently.

Speaker: NA
Text: Obviously this legislation will have

Speaker: NA
Text: consequences for remuneration itself. But,

Speaker: NA
Text: more importantly, the legislation is focused

Speaker: NA
Text: on ensuring the confidence of the community

Speaker: NA
Text: generally, and investors in equities in

Speaker: NA
Text: particular, in the prudent management of the

Speaker: NA
Text: companies in which so many Australians

Speaker: NA
Text: invest their earnings. The bill responds to

Speaker: NA
Text: both the matters raised during the

Speaker: NA
Text: Productivity Commission inquiry on this

Speaker: NA
Text: issue and the findings of the commission.

Speaker: NA
Text: The commission took into account very

Speaker: NA
Text: wide-ranging submissions from the

Speaker: NA
Text: community, after extensive consultation. It

Speaker: NA
Text: noted in its report that the prime motivation

Speaker: NA
