Text: for its enquiry was a 'widespread perception

Speaker: NA
Text: that executives have been rewarded for

Speaker: NA
Text: failure or simply good luck'. The report goes

Speaker: NA
Text: on to say that 'certainly in some periods and

Speaker: NA
Text: for some CEOs, pay outcomes appear

Speaker: NA
Text: inconsistent with a reasonably efficient

Speaker: NA
Text: executive labour market'. This is reflected in

Speaker: NA
Text: the submission made to the enquiry by

Speaker: NA
Text: Professor David Peetz, of Griffith

Speaker: NA
Text: University. Professor Peetz's submission

Speaker: NA
Text: notes that the growth rate of CEO pay

Speaker: NA
Text: between 1971 and 2008 was around 470 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent, while for the same period average

Speaker: NA
Text: weekly earnings growth was around 54per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent. On any sensible view, members will

Speaker: NA
Text: certainly realise that that is out of kilter with

Speaker: NA
Text: community expectations about what are

Speaker: NA
Text: reasonable levels of pay for CEOs.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Productivity Commission noted:

Speaker: NA
Text: If the community came to regard executive

Speaker: NA
Text: as the product of poor corporate governance or

Speaker: NA
Text: weak regulation, this could undermine public

Speaker: NA
Text: confidence in the corporate sector itself,

Speaker: NA
Text: potentially detracting from the ability to raise

Speaker: NA
Text: equity capital and distorting the allocation in

Speaker: NA
Text: investment funds.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is a genuinely held concern about

Speaker: NA
Text: maintaining public confidence in our

Speaker: NA
Text: companies. It goes to whether people will

Speaker: NA
Text: believe that putting their money into shares

Speaker: NA
Text: is a good prospect, whether it will generate a

Speaker: NA
Text: good return or whether it will simply prop up

Speaker: NA
Text: inefficient and overpaid executives. These

Speaker: NA
Text: are reasons why a regulatory response of a

Speaker: NA
Text: balanced and reasonable kind that is being

Speaker: NA
Text: presented here today is responsible and

Speaker: NA
Text: timely.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Productivity Commission considered

Speaker: NA
Text: that certain trends in executive and director

Speaker: NA
Text: remuneration in Australia were inconsistent

Speaker: NA
Text: with effective executive labour markets and

Speaker: NA
Text: may actually have had the effect of

Speaker: NA
Text: weakening company performance. In

Speaker: NA
Text: particular, it cited incentive payments and

Speaker: NA
Text: termination payments as examples of such

Speaker: NA
Text: trends, noting that certain executive

Speaker: NA
Text: incentive payments may have delivered an

Speaker: NA
Text: unintended upside and that some termination

Speaker: NA
Text: payments considered by the Productivity

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission seemed excessive. Although the

Speaker: NA
Text: commission ultimately found that Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: existing corporate governance

Speaker: NA
Text: remuneration framework does rank highly

Speaker: NA
Text: internationally, it made

Speaker: NA
Text: recommendations to improve

Speaker: NA
Text: framework; many of those recommendations

Speaker: NA
Text: are reflected in the bill before us.

Speaker: NA
Text: Members will recall that, in early 2009,

Speaker: NA
Text: this government announced reforms to limit

Speaker: NA
Text: excessive termination benefits given to

Speaker: NA
Text: outgoing directors and executives. This was

Speaker: NA
Text: the beginning of reform in this area and we

Speaker: NA
Text: are now taking the next steps. My own

Speaker: NA
Text: experience in working with boards, and in

Speaker: NA
Text: pay relation to corporate governance, does lead

Speaker: NA
Text: me to expect that most company boards will

Speaker: NA
Text: act appropriately in relation to director and

Speaker: NA
Text: executive pay and that they will and do give

Speaker: NA
Text: due regard to the expectations of

Speaker: NA
Text: shareholders. We know that many boards are

Speaker: NA
Text: already very mindful of their responsibilities

Speaker: NA
Text: and community expectations in this regard.

Speaker: NA
Text: We also know that they take very seriously

Speaker: NA
Text: their commitments to corporate social

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility. It will be only those boards

Speaker: NA
Text: which are out of step with the kinds of

Speaker: NA
Text: shareholder expectations and community

Speaker: NA
Text: standards which are likely to be subject to

Speaker: NA
Text: the two strikes provisions of the bill. So I do

Speaker: NA
Text: consider that the bill reaches a very sensible

Speaker: NA
Text: balance between the interests of

Speaker: NA
Text: shareholders, the expectations of the wider

Speaker: NA
Text: community and the desire of businesses to

Speaker: NA
Text: give incentives to their executives to

Speaker: NA
Text: generate growth.

Speaker: NA
Text: Importantly, this bill will enable

Speaker: NA
Text: shareholders to hold directors to account for

Speaker: NA
Text: their decisions on executive salaries. It will

Speaker: NA
Text: better enable conflicts of interest in the

Speaker: NA
Text: remuneration-setting process to be

Speaker: NA
Text: addressed. It will increase transparency and

Speaker: NA
Text: accountability in matters of executive pay. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is appropriate that shareholders, who

Speaker: NA
Text: ultimately bear the risk associated with the

Speaker: NA
Text: performance of companies in which they

Speaker: NA
Text: hold equity, have an opportunity to

Speaker: NA
Text: and thoroughly scrutinise remuneration

Speaker: NA
Text: packages. The bill does this and provides for

Speaker: NA
Text: various those safeguards and balancing measures

Speaker: NA
Text: that through a variety of means. Speakers on this

Speaker: NA
Text: side in the debate have already referred to

Speaker: NA
Text: the two-strikes test, which would arise in the

Speaker: NA
Text: context of a company putting its

Speaker: NA
Text: remuneration to shareholder vote. It is a

Speaker: NA
Text: measure that is consistent with the

Speaker: NA
Text: underlying expectations in the Corporations

Speaker: NA
Text: Act that directors will be responsible for, and

Speaker: NA
Text: accountable to, shareholders in relation to all

Speaker: NA
Text: aspects of the management of a company,

Speaker: NA
Text: including executive remuneration.

Speaker: NA
Text: As we have heard, the bill also includes

Speaker: NA
Text: measures relating to remuneration

Speaker: NA
Text: consultants, which will deliver greater

Speaker: NA
Text: transparency for shareholders as they will be

Speaker: NA
Text: in a position to assess potential conflicts

Speaker: NA
Text: interest in a more successful way. The bill

Speaker: NA
Text: will help to prevent conflicts of interest by

Speaker: NA
Text: prohibiting key management personnel and

Speaker: NA
Text: their related shareholding entities from

Speaker: NA
Text: voting on remuneration related resolutions.

Speaker: NA
Text: The bill also seeks to ensure that the link

Speaker: NA
Text: between remuneration and performance is

Speaker: NA
Text: maintained by prohibiting directors and

Speaker: NA
Text: executives from hedging any incentive

Speaker: NA
Text: remuneration afforded to them. Finally, the

Speaker: NA
Text: bill contains measures to limit the

Speaker: NA
Text: remuneration details required to be disclosed

Speaker: NA
Text: in the remuneration report to the key

Speaker: NA
Text: management personnel of the consolidated

Speaker: NA
Text: entity. This simplifies the disclosures in the

Speaker: NA
Text: remuneration report to enable shareholders to

Speaker: NA
Text: better assess and understand the company's

Speaker: NA
Text: remuneration arrangements. It is intended to

Speaker: NA
Text: reduce the regulatory burden on companies,

Speaker: NA
Text: while maintaining an appropriate level of

Speaker: NA
Text: accountability.

Speaker: NA
Text: In conclusion, despite the observations

Speaker: NA
Text: made by those on-again off-again free

Speaker: NA
Text: marketeers on the opposition benches about

Speaker: NA
Text: overregulation, members should understand

Speaker: NA
Text: that this bill strikes a balance between the

Speaker: NA
Text: interests of shareholders, the expectations

Speaker: NA
Text: the wider community and a desire of

Speaker: NA
Text: business to give appropriate incentives to

Speaker: NA
Text: their executives to generate growth. It goes

Speaker: NA
Text: no further in amending the Corporations Act

Speaker: NA
Text: than is necessary to achieve those very

Speaker: NA
Text: eminently sensible aims.

Speaker: Mr TUDGE
Text: Aston) (10:08): I rise to

Speaker: NA
Text: speak on the Corporations Amendment

Speaker: NA
Text: (Improving Accountability on Director and

Speaker: NA
Text: Executive Remuneration) Bill 2011. As you

Speaker: NA
Text: would be aware, Mr Deputy Speaker, this

Speaker: NA
Text: bill arises out of the recommendations of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Productivity Commission report into

Speaker: NA
Text: executive remuneration. It reported on 4

Speaker: NA
Text: January 2010, and this bill aims to

Speaker: NA
Text: of implement its recommendations. We on this

Speaker: NA
Text: side of the House support the intent of this

Speaker: NA
Text: bill, and the coalition will not be opposing

Speaker: NA
Text: the bill. However, I have some reservations

Speaker: NA
Text: in relation to it which I would like to outline

Speaker: NA
Text: today. Some of the measures are overly

Speaker: NA
Text: prescriptive and I am not convinced they will

Speaker: NA
Text: actually be effective in addressing the

Speaker: NA
Text: particular problem which we are concerned

Speaker: NA
Text: about.

Speaker: NA
Text: To properly assess this bill, there are three

Speaker: NA
Text: questions that we should be asking. First,

Speaker: NA
Text: what are the problems that we are trying to

Speaker: NA
Text: fix? Second, are the existing mechanisms

Speaker: NA
Text: sufficient to fix those problems? Third, will

Speaker: NA
Text: the proposals that are on the table in this bill

Speaker: NA
Text: work to fix the problems? I would like to go

Speaker: NA
Text: through each of those three questions in turn.

Speaker: NA
Text: First of all, what are the problems that this

Speaker: NA
Text: bill is trying to fix? There is a community

Speaker: NA
Text: concern with executive salaries, particularly

Speaker: NA
Text: those for publicly listed companies. There

Speaker: NA
Text: are many senior executives in this country

Speaker: NA
Text: who are earning very large amounts of

Speaker: NA
Text: money on an annual basis. There are about

Speaker: NA
Text: nine people in the banking sector, I

Speaker: NA
Text: understand, who earn above $5 million per

Speaker: NA
Text: of annum. In the mining sector, there are people

Speaker: NA
Text: earning up to $15 million or $16 million per

Speaker: NA
Text: annum who are heading up publicly listed

Speaker: NA
Text: companies. The managing director of Coles

Speaker: NA
Text: apparently earns in excess of $8 million.

Speaker: NA
Text: These are extraordinary amounts of

Speaker: NA
Text: money by anyone's measure. I personally

Speaker: NA
Text: struggle to see how anyone is worth that

Speaker: NA
Text: amount of money, but a high salary alone

Speaker: NA
Text: does not necessarily mean there is a problem.

Speaker: NA
Text: The owners of a company should be able to

Speaker: NA
Text: pay whatever they believe is appropriate to

Speaker: NA
Text: their executives. After all, it is their

Speaker: NA
Text: company. If the owners of the company

Speaker: NA
Text: believe that their CEO should be paid

Speaker: NA
Text: $500,000, that is their decision. It should not

Speaker: NA
Text: be the job of the government to interfere

Speaker: NA
Text: with those decisions of the owners of

Speaker: NA
Text: companies to determine what the appropriate

Speaker: NA
Text: remuneration is for their executives. A

Speaker: NA
Text: problem only exists if the board, which sets

Speaker: NA
Text: the salary on behalf of the owners of the

Speaker: NA
Text: company, the shareholders, is not acting in

Speaker: NA
Text: the best interests of the shareholders in

Speaker: NA
Text: setting that remuneration-that is, there is an

Speaker: NA
Text: agency problem there or a conflict of interest

Speaker: NA
Text: arises.

Speaker: NA
Text: The government has not presented

Speaker: NA
Text: coherent evidence that directors of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian companies are indeed acting

Speaker: NA
Text: against the interests of their shareholders

Speaker: NA
Text: when setting executive remuneration.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, there is certainly a belief that

Speaker: NA
Text: sometimes this is the case, and I believe that

Speaker: NA
Text: it is sometimes the case, particularly when

Speaker: NA
Text: executives are remunerated very highly

Speaker: NA
Text: despite the fact that a business might be

Speaker: NA
Text: collapsing, or when an executive receives a

Speaker: NA
Text: large bonus when that executive may not

Speaker: NA
Text: have had much to do with the performance

Speaker: NA
Text: of a company but rather it is due to, for

Speaker: NA
Text: example, commodity prices increasing or

Speaker: NA
Text: due to a government regulation which has

Speaker: NA
Text: underpinned the performance of that

Speaker: NA
Text: particular company.

Speaker: NA
Text: That brings me to my second question: are

Speaker: NA
Text: the existing mechanisms available to fix the

Speaker: NA
Text: problem sufficient? As parliamentarians, we

Speaker: NA
Text: need to ensure that shareholders have

Speaker: NA
Text: appropriate degrees of protection and

Speaker: NA
Text: appropriate regulations to ensure that their

Speaker: NA
Text: interests and the interests of directors and

Speaker: NA
Text: executives are aligned. Shareholders need to

Speaker: NA
Text: be properly informed and properly

Speaker: NA
Text: empowered. But what are the existing

Speaker: NA
Text: mechanisms and are they sufficient? Already

Speaker: NA
Text: in the Corporations Act there are several

Speaker: NA
Text: mechanisms. There are the fiduciary duties.

Speaker: NA
Text: Directors have a legal obligation to act in the

Speaker: NA
Text: best interests of their shareholders, and there

Speaker: NA
Text: are some quite significant penalties if they do

Speaker: NA
Text: not do that. Second, there are some

Speaker: NA
Text: protections for minority interests in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Corporations Law. Finally, there is the

Speaker: NA
Text: ability for shareholders to sack directors if

Speaker: NA
Text: they do not believe that the directors are

Speaker: NA
Text: adequately representing their interests or if

Speaker: NA
Text: they have any concern in relation to the

Speaker: NA
Text: actions of the directors.

Speaker: NA
Text: All of those are available presently.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, for small shareholders I

Speaker: NA
Text: understand that it is difficult to access some

Speaker: NA
Text: of those provisions. However, those

Speaker: NA
Text: provisions in the Corporations Law are the

Speaker: NA
Text: basic building blocks of the law that exist

Speaker: NA
Text: presently. What the Productivity

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission says is that, despite the

Speaker: NA
Text: presence of those existing protections, there

Speaker: NA
Text: is at least the opportunity for perception of

Speaker: NA
Text: conflicts of interest to arise and that this

Speaker: NA
Text: should be addressed directly. I support those

Speaker: NA
Text: intentions. That brings me to my third

Speaker: NA
Text: question: will the proposals on the table in

Speaker: NA
Text: the form of this bill actually fix the problem?

Speaker: NA
Text: There are seven measures in this bill and,

Speaker: NA
Text: while some of them are worthwhile, I do

Speaker: NA
Text: have reservations about whether they will

Speaker: NA
Text: make a decisive impact and I do believe that

Speaker: NA
Text: there will be some negative impacts

Speaker: NA
Text: associated with some of the provisions. The

Speaker: NA
Text: seven measures, all up, are intended to

Speaker: NA
Text: empower shareholders and prevent any real

Speaker: NA
Text: or perceived conflicts of interest. That intent

Speaker: NA
Text: is a good one, but we need to look at the

Speaker: NA
Text: details to determine whether or not that

Speaker: NA
Text: intent is actually delivered upon and whether

Speaker: NA
Text: or not the downsides of being overly

Speaker: NA
Text: prescriptive will outweigh the benefits.

Speaker: NA
Text: Some of the seven measures do seem

Speaker: NA
Text: immediately sensible, in fact so sensible that

Speaker: NA
Text: it is surprising that some companies are not

Speaker: NA
Text: enacting these measures already. For

Speaker: NA
Text: example, one of the measures prevents key

Speaker: NA
Text: management personnel and parties closely

Speaker: NA
Text: related to them from participating in non-

Speaker: NA
Text: binding shareholder votes on remuneration

Speaker: NA
Text: and on spill resolutions. Clearly there would

Speaker: NA
Text: be a perception of a conflict of interest

Speaker: NA
Text: beneficiaries of the remuneration report were

Speaker: NA
Text: to vote on that remuneration report. So this

Speaker: NA
Text: seems to be a sensible provision.

Speaker: NA
Text: Second, the bill will prohibit an executive

Speaker: NA
Text: hedging his or her executive remuneration.

Speaker: NA
Text: These days, executive remuneration is

Speaker: NA
Text: structured so that the interests of the

Speaker: NA
Text: executive are very closely aligned with the

Speaker: NA
Text: interests of the shareholders-so, if

Speaker: NA
Text: shareholders do well, the executive should be

Speaker: NA
Text: better remunerated. But there have been

Speaker: NA
Text: instances where some executives have taken

Speaker: NA
Text: hedges on the side such that their interests

Speaker: NA
Text: are less aligned, meaning that a change in

Speaker: NA
Text: shareholder interests will not have the same

Speaker: NA
Text: impact on the remuneration of those

Speaker: NA
Text: individuals. This particular measure will

Speaker: NA
Text: outlaw executives hedging against their

Speaker: NA
Text: remuneration structure. Again that seems

Speaker: NA
Text: like a reasonable and sensible thing to do and

Speaker: NA
Text: again I am surprised that directors would

Speaker: NA
Text: indeed today allow their executives to hedge

Speaker: NA
Text: against the executive remuneration

Speaker: NA
Text: incentives.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think the cherry-picking rules included

Speaker: NA
Text: in this bill are also sensible as they also

Speaker: NA
Text: empower shareholders. With some of the

Speaker: NA
Text: other measures, however, I question the

Speaker: NA
Text: impact. I have reservations about whether

Speaker: NA
Text: they will make a significant difference in

Speaker: NA
Text: addressing the problem of unaligned interests

Speaker: NA
Text: between shareholders and directors and I do

Speaker: NA
Text: not think that executive remuneration as a

Speaker: NA
Text: whole will come down as a result of this bill.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are also some potential downsides

Speaker: NA
Text: to this bill. Overall it does add to the

Speaker: NA
Text: regulatory burden and the measures are very

Speaker: NA
Text: prescriptive. Joe Hockey, when introducing

Speaker: NA
Text: the coalition's response to this bill, said:

Speaker: NA
Text: The best way to support business is often for the

Speaker: NA
Text: government to get out of the way.

Speaker: NA
Text: if the I think we should always be very careful

Speaker: NA
Text: when introducing new regulations on top of

Speaker: NA
Text: all the existing regulations that companies

Speaker: NA
Text: have to abide by. When you look at some of

Speaker: NA
Text: the measures in this bill, they do appear to be

Speaker: NA
Text: very prescriptive. For example, one of the

Speaker: NA
Text: measures dictates how a company is to

Speaker: NA
Text: engage remuneration consultants. It seems to

Speaker: NA
Text: me that for this parliament to be determining

Speaker: NA
Text: how a company should engage remuneration

Speaker: NA
Text: consultants, or any other consultants, is very

Speaker: NA
Text: prescriptive. Surely it is up to the company

Speaker: NA
Text: to determine how it will engage consultants

Speaker: NA
Text: and the terms on which it will engage them?

Speaker: NA
Text: In relation to that provision, the president of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Business Council of Australia pointed

Speaker: NA
Text: out:

Speaker: NA
Text: This is inevitably going to distract directors from

Speaker: NA
Text: their most important roles, which are not the

Speaker: NA
Text: minutiae of supervising remuneration consultants,

Speaker: NA
Text: but much more important roles of making wise

Speaker: NA
Text: decisions about business direction, major

Speaker: NA
Text: investments and the like.

Speaker: NA
Text: The no vacancy rule, one of the seven

Speaker: NA
Text: measures of this bill, also has potential

Speaker: NA
Text: downsides. The principle inherent in that

Speaker: NA
Text: will provision is again sound, but there are

Speaker: NA
Text: potential downsides in that it will reduce

Speaker: NA
Text: flexibility in how boards operate. Again

Speaker: NA
Text: referring to the Business Council of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, they point out that sometimes

Speaker: NA
Text: there are very good reasons to appoint fewer

Speaker: NA
Text: than the maximum number of directors at a

Speaker: NA
Text: particular time-the board may want to limit

Speaker: NA
Text: expenses, the maximum number may be too

Speaker: NA
Text: large to enable effective decision making or

Speaker: NA
Text: the board may be deliberately waiting for

Speaker: NA
Text: someone with a particular specialist expertise minimum wage, while

Speaker: NA
Text: to go onto the board. This measure in the

Speaker: NA
Text: is going to force the board to make a rapid

Speaker: NA
Text: decision about a vacancy. I also have some

Speaker: NA
Text: concerns in relation to the two-strikes test

Speaker: NA
Text: and how it will operate. Indeed, the coalition

Speaker: NA
Text: will be moving amendments in this regard.

Speaker: NA
Text: In summary, having gone through the

Speaker: NA
Text: three questions I think we should be asking

Speaker: NA
Text: ourselves to properly assess this bill-is

Speaker: NA
Text: there a problem; are the existing mechanisms

Speaker: NA
Text: sufficient; and will the proposal fix the

Speaker: NA
Text: problems?-I come down marginally in

Speaker: NA
Text: favour of the bill. I hope it will have the

Speaker: NA
Text: impact intended, but I have my doubts. If it

Speaker: NA
Text: achieves nothing else, however, this bill

Speaker: NA
Text: should send a clear message to corporate

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia that the Australian people and its

Speaker: NA
Text: representatives in this parliament are

Speaker: NA
Text: concerned about excessive executive

Speaker: NA
Text: remuneration and that we do want

Speaker: NA
Text: corporations to be responsible in this regard.

Speaker: NA
Text: If corporations get that message and act upon

Speaker: NA
Text: that message, I think that will have more

Speaker: NA
Text: impact on this issue than any regulations we

Speaker: NA
Text: might introduce in this House.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr STEPHEN JONES (Throsby)

Speaker: NA
Text: (10:23): We are here today speaking on this

Speaker: NA
Text: bill for some important policy reasons that

Speaker: NA
Text: have a deep impact on our nation's character

Speaker: NA
Text: and Australia's egalitarian culture and

Speaker: NA
Text: traditions. Executive pay has seen some

Speaker: NA
Text: exceptional growth since the 1990s-around

Speaker: NA
Text: 13 per cent per year in real terms for the

Speaker: NA
Text: 100 companies and 16 per cent for

Speaker: NA
Text: companies in the ASX top 50. In 2008-09,

Speaker: NA
Text: the estimated total remuneration for CEOs of

Speaker: NA
Text: the top 20 companies was around $7.2

Speaker: NA
Text: million, or 110 times the average wage. This

Speaker: NA
Text: rapid growth in executive pay has been

Speaker: NA
Text: occurring at the very same time that these

Speaker: NA
Text: companies have been calling for wage

Speaker: NA
Text: restraint for their own employees and in the

Speaker: NA
Text: economy at large and opposition has been

Speaker: NA
Text: expressed to even modest increases in the

Speaker: NA
Text: their peak

Speaker: NA
Text: bill organisation, the Business Council of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, was barracking for the coalition's

Speaker: NA
Text: unfair Work Choices legislation, which had,

Speaker: NA
Text: as its sole objective, the driving down of

Speaker: NA
Text: wages for ordinary Australian families.

Speaker: NA
Text: While we are talking about the salaries of

Speaker: NA
Text: the very wealthy in our society, I want to

Speaker: NA
Text: state that I do not think that it is in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's national interest for the gap

Speaker: NA
Text: between top-income earners and lowand

Speaker: NA
Text: average-income earners to continue to

Speaker: NA
Text: increase at the rapid pace that we have seen

Speaker: NA
Text: in recent decades.

Speaker: NA
Text: The bill before the House may go some

Speaker: NA
Text: way towards reigning in the excesses of

Speaker: NA
Text: executive remuneration, but it will not fix the

Speaker: NA
Text: structural problems arising from the existing

Speaker: NA
Text: income divide in Australia. I do not see how

Speaker: NA
Text: it is in anyone's interest if low-income

Speaker: NA
Text: earners are forced to struggle to feed, clothe,

Speaker: NA
Text: house and transport themselves and their

Speaker: NA
Text: families, despite being in full-time paid

Speaker: NA
Text: employment.

Speaker: NA
Text: As has been noted recently by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Secretary of United Voice, Louise Tarrant,

Speaker: NA
Text: the recent history of Australia's economic

Speaker: NA
Text: development has seen a seen a restructuring

Speaker: NA
Text: of our economy so that risk has increasingly

Speaker: NA
Text: shifted from business and government to

Speaker: NA
Text: individual workers. This shift of risk has

Speaker: NA
Text: occurred through the loss of security of

Speaker: NA
Text: employment and the erosion of workplace

Speaker: NA
Text: top protections such as sick leave, minimum

Speaker: NA
Text: hours and penalties.

Speaker: NA
Text: Indeed, the coalition's Work Choices laws

Speaker: NA
Text: were designed to accelerate that shift of risk

Speaker: NA
Text: even further on to workers. Yet this transfer

Speaker: NA
Text: of risk has occurred at the very same time as

Speaker: NA
Text: corporate executives have increasingly been

Speaker: NA
Text: rewarding themselves for high-risk

Speaker: NA
Text: strategies, in particular through skyrocketing

Speaker: NA
Text: performance pay. That is why improving the

Speaker: NA
Text: accountability and transparency of executive

Speaker: NA
Text: remuneration is a welcome reform to

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's framework of corporate

Speaker: NA
Text: governance systems for those of us on this

Speaker: NA
Text: side of the House and the constituencies that

Speaker: NA
Text: we represent. We believe that governments

Speaker: NA
Text: have an important role to play to ensure that

Speaker: NA
Text: our market based economy functions

Speaker: NA
Text: efficiently and effectively. That is because

Speaker: NA
Text: we believe that corporations are created by

Speaker: NA
Text: government, not by god, and the laws under

Speaker: NA
Text: which they operate are the laws created by

Speaker: NA
Text: people in this place and not the laws of

Speaker: NA
Text: nature.

Speaker: NA
Text: Government regulation ensures that our

Speaker: NA
Text: economy works in the way that best reflects

Speaker: NA
Text: the interests of the broader community, of

Speaker: NA
Text: our interests as a society at large. In

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia we are fortunate to have a robust

Speaker: NA
Text: system of regulation in the corporate and

Speaker: NA
Text: financial sector and the measures in this

Speaker: NA
Text: represent further sensible and rational

Speaker: NA
Text: reforms to the corporate sector.

Speaker: NA
Text: The reforms being put forward in this

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation have come about following a

Speaker: NA
Text: thoroughgoing review by the Productivity

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission. I commend the Productivity

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission for their informative report and

Speaker: NA
Text: their contribution to knowledge in this

Speaker: NA
Text: subject area. In their report on executive

Speaker: NA
Text: remuneration, the Productivity Commission

Speaker: NA
Text: noted that Australia's corporate governance

Speaker: NA
Text: and remuneration framework is highly rated

Speaker: NA
Text: internationally.

Speaker: NA
Text: Our strong system of corporate

Speaker: NA
Text: governance served Australians well through

Speaker: NA
Text: the global financial crisis and it made the

Speaker: NA
Text: difference between the situation we faced in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia and that faced by other countries

Speaker: NA
Text: our region and in the Western world. But it

Speaker: NA
Text: not the nature of a reformist government like

Speaker: NA
Text: ours merely to be complacent and to rest on

Speaker: NA
Text: our laurels. That is why the Gillard

Speaker: NA
Text: government and the Parliamentary Secretary

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Treasurer, the member for Lindsay,

Speaker: NA
Text: have brought this legislation before the

Speaker: NA
Text: House. It is Labor's view that the

Speaker: NA
Text: marketplace in relation to the remuneration

Speaker: NA
Text: of directors and executives is not working

Speaker: NA
Text: effectively as it could or should be. We

Speaker: NA
Text: believe that the appropriate mechanism to

Speaker: NA
Text: redress this is to increase the accountability

Speaker: NA
Text: of boards to the owners of companies-that

Speaker: NA
Text: is, their shareholders.

Speaker: NA
Text: The measures in the bill before the House

Speaker: NA
Text: contain a number of provisions that will

Speaker: NA
Text: strengthen the accountability of boards and

Speaker: NA
Text: executives to their shareholders. First, the

Speaker: NA
Text: bill introduces a two-strikes rule that will

Speaker: NA
Text: require a board to better respond to

Speaker: NA
Text: shareholder concerns on remuneration issues.

Speaker: NA
Text: The mechanism for this two-strikes rule will

Speaker: NA
Text: be triggered where a company faces a 'no'

Speaker: NA
Text: bill vote by 25 per cent or more on its

Speaker: NA
Text: remuneration report for two years running.

Speaker: NA
Text: Where this occurs, and the board has not

Speaker: NA
Text: satisfactorily responded to shareholder

Speaker: NA
Text: concerns, that board will be subject to a

Speaker: NA
Text: 'spill' resolution. If more than 50 per cent of

Speaker: NA
Text: eligible shareholders vote to spill the board,

Speaker: NA
Text: there will be a requirement for the directors

Speaker: NA
Text: to stand for re-election at a subsequent

Speaker: NA
Text: meeting within 90 days.

Speaker: NA
Text: This bill also contains important measures

Speaker: NA
Text: regarding the treatment of remuneration

Speaker: NA
Text: consultants to ensure better accountability

Speaker: NA
Text: and transparency in their role regarding

Speaker: NA
Text: remuneration matters. Transparency will be

Speaker: NA
Text: enhanced because companies will be

Speaker: NA
Text: required to disclose details relating to the use

Speaker: NA
Text: of remunerations consultants, including the

Speaker: NA
Text: in consultant used and the payment made to

Speaker: NA
Text: is that consultant for the advice or any other

Speaker: NA
Text: advice provided to the company. I fail to see,

Speaker: NA
Text: as the member for Aston said previously,

Speaker: NA
Text: how this is some form or onerous or

Speaker: NA
Text: burdensome regulation on

Speaker: NA
Text: shareholders or companies at large.

Speaker: NA
Text: In addition, boards will be required to

Speaker: NA
Text: approve the engagement of remuneration

Speaker: NA
Text: consultants and these consultants will be

Speaker: NA
Text: required to report their remuneration

Speaker: NA
Text: recommendation to the non-executive

Speaker: NA
Text: directors of the remuneration committee of

Speaker: NA
Text: the company concerned. Directors and

Speaker: NA
Text: executives will no longer be able to

Speaker: NA
Text: participate in the non-binding shareholder

Speaker: NA
Text: vote on their own remuneration or on the

Speaker: NA
Text: spill motions. This measure will remove a

Speaker: NA
Text: significant conflict of interest-which has

Speaker: NA
Text: been described by members opposite as

Speaker: NA
Text: completely obvious-between directors,

Speaker: NA
Text: executives and their votes in regard to

Speaker: NA
Text: remuneration matters, and it will also extend

Speaker: NA
Text: to votes by key management personnel and

Speaker: NA
Text: their closely related parties in regard to their

Speaker: NA
Text: undirected proxies.

Speaker: NA
Text: Another common criticism made of

Speaker: NA
Text: executive remuneration is that it has focused

Speaker: NA
Text: too much on rewarding risk and short-term

Speaker: NA
Text: results rather than the long-term performance

Speaker: NA
Text: of the company. This situation was a

Speaker: NA
Text: particular characteristic of corporate

Speaker: NA
Text: behaviour in the United States in the lead-up

Speaker: NA
Text: to the global financial crisis and, regrettably,

Speaker: NA
Text: I believe it has yet to be satisfactorily

Speaker: NA
Text: resolved there, much to the detriment of

Speaker: NA
Text: American civil society. While the situation in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia does not approach the level of

Speaker: NA
Text: corporate scandal in the United States, it is

Speaker: NA
Text: nevertheless critical to continue to be

Speaker: NA
Text: vigilant about defending the integrity of our

Speaker: NA
Text: system of corporate governance and to

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure that government regulation is working

Speaker: NA
Text: effectively to achieve its aims.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think the bill before the House today

Speaker: NA
Text: demonstrates that where a system of self-

Speaker: NA
Text: regulation does not work then further

Speaker: NA
Text: regulatory steps need to be taken to guide

Speaker: NA
Text: market mechanisms towards

Speaker: NA
Text: boards, outcomes. It is a matter of public record that

Speaker: NA
Text: the existing system of non-binding votes has

Speaker: NA
Text: not had the desired effect on the actions of

Speaker: NA
Text: some boards in regards to the remuneration

Speaker: NA
Text: matters in their companies.

Speaker: NA
Text: The standout example that I am very

Speaker: NA
Text: familiar with here is Telstra, which

Speaker: NA
Text: notoriously in 2007 was repudiated by an

Speaker: NA
Text: outstanding 66 per cent of shareholders for

Speaker: NA
Text: its handling of remuneration matters. The

Speaker: NA
Text: board at the time blithely ignored the vote

Speaker: NA
Text: and shareholders were powerless to do

Speaker: NA
Text: anything about it. The arrogance of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Telstra board in 2007 was shocking and was

Speaker: NA
Text: rightly condemned by many in the financial

Speaker: NA
Text: media and more broadly. It was ironic that at

Speaker: NA
Text: the very same time that this company was

Speaker: NA
Text: taking a very harsh attitude towards the

Speaker: NA
Text: treatment of remuneration for its own

Speaker: NA
Text: employees and their own workplace rights it

Speaker: NA
Text: was operating with complete disregard to

Speaker: NA
Text: community norms, as expressed by its

Speaker: NA
Text: shareholders, in relation to its own executive

Speaker: NA
Text: pay. I know that the current executive team

Speaker: NA
Text: at Telstra are working hard to redress the

Speaker: NA
Text: toxic culture that had developed as a result of

Speaker: NA
Text: previous management regimes and

Speaker: NA
Text: employment practices, and the blithe

Speaker: NA
Text: disrespect and disregard for community

Speaker: NA
Text: values, and everybody welcomes any move

Speaker: NA
Text: towards a more civilised and mutually

Speaker: NA
Text: respectful corporate culture in that company

Speaker: NA
Text: and elsewhere. I can only wish it well in this

Speaker: NA
Text: regard.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are alternative proposals that have

Speaker: NA
Text: been talked about in this area. Some say that

Speaker: NA
Text: this regulation does not go far enough, and I

Speaker: NA
Text: must say that at times I have had sympathy

Speaker: NA
Text: with that view. The alternative proposal put

Speaker: NA
Text: by members opposite and foreshadowed in

Speaker: NA
Text: their amendment is that we should lift the bar

Speaker: NA
Text: even higher for shareholders-that is, the

Speaker: NA
Text: triggering of the two-strikes rule should not

Speaker: NA
Text: better be based on 25 per cent of the votes cast,

Speaker: NA
Text: which would trigger the spill motion and the

Speaker: NA
Text: requisite action of the shareholders, but that

Speaker: NA
Text: it should be based on 25 per cent of the votes

Speaker: NA
Text: that are eligible to be cast at an annual

Speaker: NA
Text: general meeting of a company. Anybody

Speaker: NA
Text: who has had any experience of the practical

Speaker: NA
Text: operation of annual general meetings of most

Speaker: NA
Text: companies, particularly large companies with

Speaker: NA
Text: a large share registry, will know that this

Speaker: NA
Text: the bar to an almost impossible level because

Speaker: NA
Text: it would be a very rare event indeed where

Speaker: NA
Text: 25 per cent of the eligible votes would be

Speaker: NA
Text: cast in a vote on a matter such as this.

Speaker: NA
Text: While many of those opposite have risen

Speaker: NA
Text: to speak in favour of the sentiment and the

Speaker: NA
Text: intent behind this bill-to put more

Speaker: NA
Text: regulation and give more control to the

Speaker: NA
Text: shareholders to address outrageous

Speaker: NA
Text: remuneration packages by executives-their

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed amendment to this regulation will

Speaker: NA
Text: have quite the opposite effect. It would

Speaker: NA
Text: neuter the effect of the bill and neuter the

Speaker: NA
Text: ability of shareholders to have any real say in

Speaker: NA
Text: controlling the remuneration packages of

Speaker: NA
Text: their directors and executives.

Speaker: NA
Text: The social contract in Australia that was

Speaker: NA
Text: the bedrock of our culture and our values has

Speaker: NA
Text: been severely challenged as executive pay

Speaker: NA
Text: has skyrocketed in recent decades. We

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot sit by and wring our hands each time

Speaker: NA
Text: we hear of multi-million dollar salaries being

Speaker: NA
Text: paid to corporate executives which are

Speaker: NA
Text: seemingly unrelated to the performance of

Speaker: NA
Text: their companies and the returns to

Speaker: NA
Text: shareholders. That is why I support the

Speaker: NA
Text: sensible measures in the bill before the

Speaker: NA
Text: House today, and that is also why I support

Speaker: NA
Text: the voices of others within the community in

Speaker: NA
Text: their continued campaigns to ensure fairness,

Speaker: NA
Text: security and dignity for all Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: workers, and that we do everything we can to

Speaker: NA
Text: narrow the gaps between the wealthy, the

Speaker: NA
Text: average Australians and the poor in this

Speaker: NA
Text: country.

Speaker: Mr BANDT
Text: Melbourne) (10:36): The

Speaker: NA
Text: health and success of a society is best judged

Speaker: NA
Text: by the level of equality between its citizens.

Speaker: NA
Text: The gap between the rich and poor, the

Speaker: NA
Text: extent to which someone profits from the

Speaker: NA
Text: labour of others and the capacity of someone

Speaker: NA
Text: to reap enormous wealth at the expense of

Speaker: NA
Text: lifts the Commonwealth have always been a

Speaker: NA
Text: measure of a sustainable and stable society.

Speaker: NA
Text: During the first three-quarters of the 20th

Speaker: NA
Text: century, Australia, like much of the

Speaker: NA
Text: developed world, was narrowing the gap

Speaker: NA
Text: between the highest and lowest incomes. The

Speaker: NA
Text: 1970s were the high point with the gap

Speaker: NA
Text: between rich and poor at its smallest perhaps

Speaker: NA
Text: in centuries, but since then the gap has been

Speaker: NA
Text: growing again, with most of the positive

Speaker: NA
Text: trends of the 20th century wiped out.

Speaker: NA
Text: Using the Australian Bureau of Statistics

Speaker: NA
Text: we can examine the income distribution

Speaker: NA
Text: between households. If disposable income

Speaker: NA
Text: was equally distributed between households,

Speaker: NA
Text: the bottom 20 per cent of households would

Speaker: NA
Text: have 20 per cent of total income and the top

Speaker: NA
Text: 20 per cent of households would also have

Speaker: NA
Text: 20 per cent of total income. In fact, the latest

Speaker: NA
Text: ABS figures show that the bottom fifth has

Speaker: NA
Text: just seven per cent of the income, whereas

Speaker: NA
Text: the top fifth has more than 40 per cent. And

Speaker: NA
Text: in the four years to 2010, the shares of the

Speaker: NA
Text: four bottom-fifths fell by about 0.5 a

Speaker: NA
Text: percentage point each, allowing the share of

Speaker: NA
Text: the top fifth to rise by two per cent. So why,

Speaker: NA
Text: under both Liberal and Labor governments,

Speaker: NA
Text: has there been this marked increase in

Speaker: NA
Text: inequality?

Speaker: NA
Text: Economic writer Ross Gittins in last year's

Speaker: NA
Text: ACTU Whitlam lecture outlined this recent

Speaker: NA
Text: data and attempted to answer the question.

Speaker: NA
Text: He said:

Speaker: NA
Text: No one can say with any certainly. Various

Speaker: NA
Text: factors could have contributed: the resources

Speaker: NA
Text: boom and the booming sharemarket before the

Speaker: NA
Text: global financial crisis, the continued rise in

Speaker: NA
Text: executive and finance-sector salaries and maybe

Speaker: NA
Text: the succession of income-tax cuts that benefited

Speaker: NA
Text: people on high incomes.

Speaker: NA
Text: But he went on to say:

Speaker: NA
Text: It would be a mistake to conclude, however,

Speaker: NA
Text: that all families with income sufficient to put

Speaker: NA
Text: them in the top 20 per cent have benefited

Speaker: NA
Text: equally. It‘s far more likely that the closer

Speaker: NA
Text: to the top of that 20 per cent the better you‘ve

Speaker: NA
Text: done. It‘s even possible that the share of people in

Speaker: NA
Text: the second-top 10 per cent has declined, as have

Speaker: NA
Text: the shares of the bottom 80 per cent of

Speaker: NA
Text: households.

Speaker: NA
Text: But it gets worse. According to Gittins,

Speaker: NA
Text: research using income tax statistics show

Speaker: NA
Text: that the top 120th of a per cent of individual

Speaker: NA
Text: taxpayers account for about two per cent of

Speaker: NA
Text: total taxable income. Let's just reflect on

Speaker: NA
Text: that. Someone in the top 0.05 per cent of

Speaker: NA
Text: taxpayers has income about 40 times their

Speaker: NA
Text: proportionate share. Gittins also says:

Speaker: NA
Text: The top 10th of a per cent accounts for 3 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent, the top half a per cent for 6 per cent,

Speaker: NA
Text: 1 per cent for 9 per cent, the top 5 per cent for 21

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent and the top 10 per cent for 31 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: So in fact it is the growth in income of the

Speaker: NA
Text: very top group of people in the wealthiest 20

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent of the income band that is driving

Speaker: NA
Text: this growth in inequality. According to

Speaker: NA
Text: Gittins this means:

Speaker: NA
Text: The shares of these top earners were declining

Speaker: NA
Text: until the early 1980s, but have increased since

Speaker: NA
Text: then, with the share of the top 10 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: growing from 25 per cent to 31 per cent. Why has

Speaker: NA
Text: this happened? I think it would have to do mainly

Speaker: NA
Text: with the explosion in executive salaries and the

Speaker: NA
Text: phenomenal expansion of the phenomenally paid

Speaker: NA
Text: financial services industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: While experiencing a short dip post the

Speaker: NA
Text: global financial crisis, executive salaries are

Speaker: NA
Text: continuing to soar, driving up this inequality

Speaker: NA
Text: in Australia. This skyrocketing of executive

Speaker: NA
Text: pay is based on the obscene levels of

Speaker: NA
Text: incentives and bonuses for company

Speaker: NA
Text: executives and has fuelled unsustainable

Speaker: NA
Text: business practices that resulted in the loss of

Speaker: NA
Text: jobs and shareholder wealth. Let's look again

Speaker: NA
Text: at the figures.

Speaker: NA
Text: The average total remuneration of a chief

Speaker: NA
Text: executive of a top-50 company listed on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Securities Exchange in 2010 was

Speaker: NA
Text: $6.4 million. This makes the average CEO's

Speaker: NA
Text: total pay packet almost 100 times that of the

Speaker: NA
Text: you are average worker. This is an obscene

Speaker: NA
Text: difference in remuneration. Why should

Speaker: NA
Text: anyone earn 100 times more than the average

Speaker: NA
Text: worker? Do they work 100 times as hard?

Speaker: NA
Text: Are they carrying out work that is a hundred

Speaker: NA
Text: times more risky, or difficult or dangerous?

Speaker: NA
Text: The reality is executives are being paid this

Speaker: NA
Text: amount because they are able to get away

Speaker: NA
Text: with it and they have been allowed to get

Speaker: NA
Text: away with it.

Speaker: NA
Text: We can get a greater sense of how unfair

Speaker: NA
Text: this difference is by looking at the increases

Speaker: NA
Text: in executive pay over last financial year.

Speaker: NA
Text: Executive pay rose by an average of almost

Speaker: NA
Text: the top $1 million, the equivalent of an extra

Speaker: NA
Text: $18,000 per week. Over the same period, the

Speaker: NA
Text: annual average wage for a full-time worker

Speaker: NA
Text: rose by just $3,200, or $62 a week-$18,000

Speaker: NA
Text: a week compared with $62 dollars a week.

Speaker: NA
Text: Yet we are constantly hearing lectures about

Speaker: NA
Text: the importance of wage restraint and the

Speaker: NA
Text: worry of a wages break-out amongst

Speaker: NA
Text: working people. What does one even do with

Speaker: NA
Text: an extra $18,000 a week?

Speaker: NA
Text: This has been a problem for some time

Speaker: NA
Text: with base pay for executives rising by 130

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent from 2001-2010, while in the same

Speaker: NA
Text: period average weekly earnings only rose by

Speaker: NA
Text: 52 per cent. Inflation over the same period

Speaker: NA
Text: was just 28.6 per cent. Again, we see this

Speaker: NA
Text: incredible difference with average workers

Speaker: NA
Text: gaining modest increases in their pay just

Speaker: NA
Text: keeping above inflation, while the top end of

Speaker: NA
Text: town is raking it in, with a whopping

Speaker: NA
Text: doubling of their pay over the last decade.

Speaker: NA
Text: Over the previous financial year across the

Speaker: NA
Text: economy, profits also soared by 27.5 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent. This imbalance is even greater in

Speaker: NA
Text: selected industries. Gross operating

Speaker: NA
Text: mining have risen by 60.6 per cent, while

Speaker: NA
Text: wages grew by just 3.8 per cent.

Speaker: NA
Text: Construction profits rose by 55.5 per cent,

Speaker: NA
Text: but wages by just 2.9 per cent. And profits in

Speaker: NA
Text: the information, media

Speaker: NA
Text: telecommunications sector grew by 10 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent-five times more than wages. Company

Speaker: NA
Text: profits as a share of national income are now

Speaker: NA
Text: back to the record levels of 2008, while the

Speaker: NA
Text: wages share is the lowest since 1964. So

Speaker: NA
Text: there has been no shortage of funds to fund

Speaker: NA
Text: wage increases for workers, but corporations

Speaker: NA
Text: have instead funded executive salaries. This

Speaker: NA
Text: is unfair and unsustainable, and it is little

Speaker: NA
Text: wonder that the community is angry when

Speaker: NA
Text: they are doing it tough and being asked to

Speaker: NA
Text: engage in wage restraint when corporate

Speaker: NA
Text: leaders are filling their own pockets.

Speaker: NA
Text: Here are some examples from last year of

Speaker: NA
Text: incredible increases in CEO pay from 2009

Speaker: NA
Text: to 2010. Tom Albanese, CEO of Rio Tinto,

Speaker: NA
Text: got $9,039,000, an increase of 328 per cent.

Speaker: NA
Text: Don Voelte from Woodside Petroleum is on

Speaker: NA
Text: $8,343,339-also a huge increase. Ralph

Speaker: NA
Text: Norris, CEO of the Commonwealth Bank,

Speaker: NA
Text: modest but still a nice little earner, is on

Speaker: NA
Text: $16,157,746, an increase of 75 per cent. And

Speaker: NA
Text: the list goes on: David Knox at Santos, $5

Speaker: NA
Text: million, an increase of 63 per cent; Marius

Speaker: NA
Text: Kloppers on $11 million, and so on.

Speaker: NA
Text: Something needs to be done to rein in these

Speaker: NA
Text: fat-cat salaries and excessive profits.

Speaker: NA
Text: Something needs to be done to address this

Speaker: NA
Text: growing inequality. The Greens have been

Speaker: NA
Text: seeking action on executive remuneration for

Speaker: NA
Text: some time. We have proposed real and

Speaker: NA
Text: practical measures to limit executive pay.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have moved a number of amendments to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Corporations Act in the past to

Speaker: NA
Text: implement our proposals. The most recent

Speaker: NA
Text: was at the end of 2009 to the Corporations

Speaker: NA
Text: Amendment (Improving Accountability on

Speaker: NA
Text: profits in Termination Payment) Bill.

Speaker: NA
Text: The measures we have proposed include:

Speaker: NA
Text: a cap on total executive remuneration of $5

Speaker: NA
Text: million to stop the excesses of the past

Speaker: NA
Text: decade but also to ensure that the majority of

Speaker: NA
Text: and executives continue to enjoy attractive

Speaker: NA
Text: remuneration packages. The limit that we

Speaker: NA
Text: have proposed is more than 10 times the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister's salary. We have also

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed: a remuneration formula to set

Speaker: NA
Text: executive pay at 30 times the average

Speaker: NA
Text: employee's wage; a top marginal tax rate of

Speaker: NA
Text: 50 per cent for incomes over $1 million a

Speaker: NA
Text: year; and a binding shareholder vote on

Speaker: NA
Text: company remuneration policy. The policy

Speaker: NA
Text: would set minimum standards to be included

Speaker: NA
Text: in remuneration packages which would, in

Speaker: NA
Text: turn, place limits on the size of remuneration

Speaker: NA
Text: packages covering base salaries,

Speaker: NA
Text: performance and termination pay and non-

Speaker: NA
Text: cash rewards. We believe that these

Speaker: NA
Text: measures are sensible and, if implemented,

Speaker: NA
Text: would have already started to rein in

Speaker: NA
Text: excessive executive salaries.

Speaker: NA
Text: Unfortunately, the government and the

Speaker: NA
Text: opposition have not had the courage to take

Speaker: NA
Text: strong action on this problem and support

Speaker: NA
Text: our measures. Instead, we have before us this

Speaker: NA
Text: bill today. The bill implements a number of

Speaker: NA
Text: the recommendations from the Productivity

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission's report from 2009on executive

Speaker: NA
Text: remuneration. The key measure in the bill is

Speaker: NA
Text: the two strike non-binding vote of

Speaker: NA
Text: shareholders on the remuneration report

Speaker: NA
Text: leading to a spill of the board.

Speaker: NA
Text: The first strike will occur when a

Speaker: NA
Text: company's remuneration report receives a no

Speaker: NA
Text: vote of 25 per cent or more. When this

Speaker: NA
Text: occurs, the company's subsequent

Speaker: NA
Text: remuneration report, the next year, must

Speaker: NA
Text: include an explanation of the board's

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed actions in response to the no vote

Speaker: NA
Text: or an explanation of why no action has been

Speaker: NA
Text: taken.

Speaker: NA
Text: The second strike occurs when a

Speaker: NA
Text: company's subsequent remuneration report

Speaker: NA
Text: receives a no vote of 25 per cent or more.

Speaker: NA
Text: When this occurs, shareholders will vote at

Speaker: NA
Text: the same AGM to determine whether the

Speaker: NA
Text: directors will need to stand for re-election. If

Speaker: NA
Text: this spill resolution passes with 50 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: or more of eligible votes cast, then the spill

Speaker: NA
Text: meeting will take place within 90 days.

Speaker: NA
Text: While this is a step forward from where

Speaker: NA
Text: we are now, the Greens would prefer a

Speaker: NA
Text: binding vote of shareholders

Speaker: NA
Text: remuneration policy which would set limits

Speaker: NA
Text: and give the shareholders that ability to

Speaker: NA
Text: configure payments in accordance with

Speaker: NA
Text: common sense. Under the provisions in the

Speaker: NA
Text: bill the potential for a spill of the board

Speaker: NA
Text: two votes at subsequent annual general

Speaker: NA
Text: meetings of shareholders expressing their

Speaker: NA
Text: concern with the remuneration of executives.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is, therefore, a significant amount of

Speaker: NA
Text: time between shareholders expressing

Speaker: NA
Text: displeasure and being in a position to act.

Speaker: NA
Text: During this time CEOs can continue to be

Speaker: NA
Text: paid obscene salaries.

Speaker: NA
Text: We understand the arguments put by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Productivity Commission against a binding

Speaker: NA
Text: vote, including that a binding vote would

Speaker: NA
Text: provide significant practical difficulties such

Speaker: NA
Text: as companies not being able to finalise a

Speaker: NA
Text: contract with an executive until shareholder

Speaker: NA
Text: approval was obtained, and could result in a

Speaker: NA
Text: deadlock arising between shareholders and

Speaker: NA
Text: the board regarding the appropriate levels of

Speaker: NA
Text: executive remuneration. We appreciate that

Speaker: NA
Text: the government's position is to encourage

Speaker: NA
Text: cultural change in large corporations

Speaker: NA
Text: regarding executive remuneration. However,

Speaker: NA
Text: we continue to hold reservations that these

Speaker: NA
Text: measures will in practical terms work to stop

Speaker: NA
Text: the excessive salaries that I have outlined

Speaker: NA
Text: today. We will be watching carefully how

Speaker: NA
Text: this process works in practice and the extent

Speaker: NA
Text: to which it does create cultural change and

Speaker: NA
Text: rein in executive remuneration packages.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Greens support the other measures in

Speaker: NA
Text: the bill to increase transparency with regard

Speaker: NA
Text: to executive remuneration. These include:

Speaker: NA
Text: increasing transparency and accountability

Speaker: NA
Text: with respect to the use of remuneration

Speaker: NA
Text: consultants, in particular, that remuneration

Speaker: NA
Text: consultants report to non-executive directors

Speaker: NA
Text: or the remuneration committee; addressing

Speaker: NA
Text: conflicts of interests that exist with directors

Speaker: NA
Text: and executives voting their shares on

Speaker: NA
Text: on remuneration resolutions. We agree that

Speaker: NA
Text: directors and executives with voting shares

Speaker: NA
Text: should not be allowed to vote on the

Speaker: NA
Text: remuneration reports. We also support:

Speaker: NA
Text: ensuring that remuneration remains linked to

Speaker: NA
Text: takes performance by prohibiting hedging of

Speaker: NA
Text: incentive remuneration; requiring

Speaker: NA
Text: shareholder approval for declarations of no

Speaker: NA
Text: vacancy at an annual general meeting;

Speaker: NA
Text: prohibiting proxy holders from cherry-

Speaker: NA
Text: picking the proxies they exercise by

Speaker: NA
Text: requiring that any directed proxies that are

Speaker: NA
Text: not voted default to the chair, who is

Speaker: NA
Text: required to vote the proxies as directed; and

Speaker: NA
Text: reducing the complexity of the remuneration

Speaker: NA
Text: report by confining disclosures in the report

Speaker: NA
Text: to the key management personnel.

Speaker: NA
Text: These measures also go to implementing

Speaker: NA
Text: some of the principles of executive

Speaker: NA
Text: remuneration agreed to by the G20 in

Speaker: NA
Text: September 2009. They will improve the way

Speaker: NA
Text: companies go about determining

Speaker: NA
Text: remuneration for executives, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: increased transparency of these measures is

Speaker: NA
Text: to be welcomed. However, this must be just

Speaker: NA
Text: the first step. Unless we move to serious caps

Speaker: NA
Text: and stronger regulation of executive salaries

Speaker: NA
Text: we will not begin to address the growing

Speaker: NA
Text: inequality we are experiencing in this

Speaker: NA
Text: country.

Speaker: Ms RISHWORTH
Text: Kingston) (10:50): I

Speaker: NA
Text: rise to support the Corporations Amendment

Speaker: NA
Text: (Improving Accountability on Director and

Speaker: NA
Text: Executive Remuneration) Bill 2011. The

Speaker: NA
Text: global financial crisis around the world put

Speaker: NA
Text: spotlight on and exposed some of the

Speaker: NA
Text: excessive remuneration packages

Speaker: NA
Text: company directors and executives.

Speaker: NA
Text: In Australia in the last 30 years the

Speaker: NA
Text: relativities between the average wage and

Speaker: NA
Text: executive pay have grown exponentially. In

Speaker: NA
Text: fact, CEO salaries of Australia's largest 300

Speaker: NA
Text: listed companies rose by 28 per cent in

Speaker: NA
Text: 07. This is compared to the average full-time

Speaker: NA
Text: income growth of 3.4 per cent over the same

Speaker: NA
Text: period. So there is a significant difference

Speaker: NA
Text: between the rise in CEO salaries and income

Speaker: NA
Text: growth. The community in Australia has

Speaker: NA
Text: registered its concern about this increase in

Speaker: NA
Text: disparity between the average wage income

Speaker: NA
Text: earner and the rise in CEO salaries.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the financial year just passed,

Speaker: NA
Text: companies on the S&P ASX 100 that filed

Speaker: NA
Text: remuneration reports revealed an average

Speaker: NA
Text: executive salary rise of 12 per cent with the

Speaker: NA
Text: highest being 93 per cent. These pay rises

Speaker: NA
Text: have all occurred despite difficult times and

Speaker: NA
Text: under difficult conditions, with CEOs, at the

Speaker: NA
Text: same time, calling for wage constraint for

Speaker: NA
Text: ordinary workers. It is important that the

Speaker: NA
Text: community is listened to when it comes to

Speaker: NA
Text: executive remuneration and that steps are

Speaker: NA
Text: taken to ensure that these salaries do get

Speaker: NA
Text: recognised. We need to ensure that

Speaker: NA
Text: regulation is made to make sure that they are

Speaker: NA
Text: fair and right and that shareholders get

Speaker: NA
Text: voices listened to. I am also certain that

Speaker: NA
Text: members of the House will recall the

Speaker: NA
Text: exposure of unreasonable termination

Speaker: NA
Text: benefits being afforded to departing directors

Speaker: NA
Text: of companies not long after the global

Speaker: NA
Text: financial crisis. The government addressed

Speaker: NA
Text: this issue in its 2009 announcement of

Speaker: NA
Text: reforms aimed at curbing these excessive

Speaker: NA
Text: golden handshake payments. The bill before

Speaker: NA
Text: the House seeks to build on those reforms by

Speaker: NA
Text: further strengthening Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: a remuneration framework. It is disappointing

Speaker: NA
Text: that while the opposition state that they agree

Speaker: NA
Text: of with the government their amendments

Speaker: NA
Text: effectively aim to keep the status quo. I do

Speaker: NA
Text: hope that the opposition comes to their

Speaker: NA
Text: senses, listen to community expectations and

Speaker: NA
Text: support the bill before the House.

Speaker: NA
Text: The bill will amend current limitations in

Speaker: NA
Text: 2006- order to provide shareholders with more

Speaker: NA
Text: control over the pay of directors.

Speaker: NA
Text: Shareholders are the legal owners of a

Speaker: NA
Text: company in which they invest. In doing so,

Speaker: NA
Text: they take ownership of the company's risk

Speaker: NA
Text: and also share in the company's profit and

Speaker: NA
Text: loss. Shareholders therefore deserve more

Speaker: NA
Text: control over how the pay of company

Speaker: NA
Text: executives is decided. This bill seeks to

Speaker: NA
Text: empower shareholders to influence their

Speaker: NA
Text: company's remuneration decisions by, firstly,

Speaker: NA
Text: introducing a two-strikes test.

Speaker: NA
Text: The current Corporations Act requires

Speaker: NA
Text: listed companies to put their remuneration

Speaker: NA
Text: report to a non-binding shareholder vote at

Speaker: NA
Text: an annual general meeting. However,

Speaker: NA
Text: shareholders have no means of recourse

Speaker: NA
Text: should they implement a strong 'no' vote

Speaker: NA
Text: which is then ignored by the company board.

Speaker: NA
Text: Under the bill before the House, the first

Speaker: NA
Text: strike will be initiated in the instance where a

Speaker: NA
Text: company's remuneration report receives a

Speaker: NA
Text: 'no' vote of 25 per cent or more. This results

Speaker: NA
Text: their in the company being required to provide

Speaker: NA
Text: direct evidence of the shareholders' concerns

Speaker: NA
Text: having been addressed or an outline as to

Speaker: NA
Text: why they have not. If shareholders remain

Speaker: NA
Text: dissatisfied and another vote results in a 'no'

Speaker: NA
Text: vote of 25 per cent or more then the second

Speaker: NA
Text: strike is triggered. The second strike gives

Speaker: NA
Text: shareholders the opportunity to vote on a

Speaker: NA
Text: resolution to spill the board and subject

Speaker: NA
Text: directors to re-election. If the spill resolution linked

Speaker: NA
Text: is passed by more than 50 per cent then a

Speaker: NA
Text: spill meeting will provide shareholders with

Speaker: NA
Text: the opportunity to vote on the re-election of

Speaker: NA
Text: each director. The two-strikes test is an

Speaker: NA
Text: important measure that finally holds

Speaker: NA
Text: unresponsive directors accountable for the

Speaker: NA
Text: decisions they make on executive

Speaker: NA
Text: remuneration.

Speaker: NA
Text: This bill also seeks to ensure that

Speaker: NA
Text: consultation between remuneration

Speaker: NA
Text: consultants and company executives remains

Speaker: NA
Text: transparent. A company's remuneration

Speaker: NA
Text: consultant will be required to declare that

Speaker: NA
Text: their recommendations are free from undue

Speaker: NA
Text: influence. As a means of ensuring further

Speaker: NA
Text: transparency, these recommendations will be

Speaker: NA
Text: provided to non-executive directors or the

Speaker: NA
Text: remuneration committee, rather than to the

Speaker: NA
Text: company's executive directors. The company

Speaker: NA
Text: will also be required to disclose details

Speaker: NA
Text: regarding the consultant used and the amount

Speaker: NA
Text: they were paid. These measures are focused

Speaker: NA
Text: on ensuring accountability and transparency

Speaker: NA
Text: within the remuneration framework.

Speaker: NA
Text: Shareholders have a right to be in a position

Speaker: NA
Text: to assess any potential conflict of interest,

Speaker: NA
Text: and this bill takes important steps towards

Speaker: NA
Text: ensuring that this remains the case.

Speaker: NA
Text: As a means of further reducing conflicts

Speaker: NA
Text: of interest, this bill also prohibits company

Speaker: NA
Text: directors and executives from voting on the

Speaker: NA
Text: remuneration report or the spill resolution.

Speaker: NA
Text: Directors and executives no doubt have an

Speaker: NA
Text: interest in approving their own remuneration

Speaker: NA
Text: agreements. Doing so affords them a

Speaker: NA
Text: considerable amount of power concerning

Speaker: NA
Text: their company's remuneration framework.

Speaker: NA
Text: This clearly represents a conflict of interest,

Speaker: NA
Text: and the measures proposed in this bill seek to

Speaker: NA
Text: remove that conflict.

Speaker: NA
Text: In line with the government's reforms to

Speaker: NA
Text: termination benefits, this bill also seeks to

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure that executive remuneration remains

Speaker: NA
Text: to performance. Incentive

Speaker: NA
Text: remuneration is designed to align directors'

Speaker: NA
Text: and executives' interests with those of

Speaker: NA
Text: shareholders; however, the hedging of

Speaker: NA
Text: incentive payments can severely skew this

Speaker: NA
Text: relationship. Directors and executives are

Speaker: NA
Text: currently able to hedge their exposure to

Speaker: NA
Text: incentive remuneration by entering into

Speaker: NA
Text: third-party contracts and effectively

Speaker: NA
Text: mitigating their personal financial interest in

Speaker: NA
Text: their company's success. The use of hedging

Speaker: NA
Text: is completely inconsistent with the values of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's remuneration framework.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, perhaps more concerning is the

Speaker: NA
Text: real, as well as the perceived, conflict of

Speaker: NA
Text: interest that arises when a director or

Speaker: NA
Text: executive enters into hedging arrangements.

Speaker: NA
Text: Such an arrangement may stand to see the

Speaker: NA
Text: director or executive benefit from a fall in

Speaker: NA
Text: their company's share price. Hedging by

Speaker: NA
Text: directors or executives distorts their

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibilities to their shareholders. The

Speaker: NA
Text: measures in this bill will ensure that the

Speaker: NA
Text: interests of shareholders and of the

Speaker: NA
Text: company's directors and executives remain

Speaker: NA
Text: synchronised.

Speaker: NA
Text: The bill also introduces a measure that

Speaker: NA
Text: prevents boards from announcing 'no

Speaker: NA
Text: vacancy' without the approval of its

Speaker: NA
Text: shareholders. This is an important step

Speaker: NA
Text: towards transferring company decision-

Speaker: NA
Text: making power back to shareholders. The no

Speaker: NA
Text: vacancy rule currently allows boards to

Speaker: NA
Text: govern the composition of the board and

Speaker: NA
Text: makes it difficult, if not impossible, for non-

Speaker: NA
Text: board-endorsed candidates to be elected.

Speaker: NA
Text: This promotes unaccountability from

Speaker: NA
Text: directors and executives and leaves

Speaker: NA
Text: shareholders without a voice, given that any

Speaker: NA
Text: candidate seeking to promote change within

Speaker: NA
Text: a company can essentially be prevented from

Speaker: NA
Text: reaching a board position that would allow

Speaker: NA
Text: them to instigate such change.

Speaker: NA
Text: The bill also introduces an amendment

Speaker: NA
Text: which will ensure the enfranchisement of

Speaker: NA
Text: every shareholder who chooses to vote at an

Speaker: NA
Text: annual general meeting. Currently, all

Speaker: NA
Text: directors except for the chair have the ability

Speaker: NA
Text: to disregard proxy votes that do not align

Speaker: NA
Text: with their personal views regarding a

Speaker: NA
Text: resolution. Indeed, annual general meetings

Speaker: NA
Text: can be held at times or locations that are not

Speaker: NA
Text: convenient for all shareholders. As such,

Speaker: NA
Text: many shareholders who are unable to attend

Speaker: NA
Text: in person are able to indicate their position

Speaker: NA
Text: by a proxy vote. These votes should be given

Speaker: NA
Text: just as much weighting as a vote from a

Speaker: NA
Text: shareholder present at the meeting. However,

Speaker: NA
Text: instead, these votes can currently be

Speaker: NA
Text: disregarded at a director's discretion. This

Speaker: NA
Text: cherry picking of votes from shareholders

Speaker: NA
Text: who have made specific declarations

Speaker: NA
Text: concerning their vote inevitably results in

Speaker: NA
Text: outcomes that by no means clearly represent

Speaker: NA
Text: the sentiment of shareholders. This bill will

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure that the outcome of a resolution vote

Speaker: NA
Text: reflects shareholder views rather than the

Speaker: NA
Text: cherry picked views of directors. In

Speaker: NA
Text: conclusion, under request from the

Speaker: NA
Text: government, the Productivity Commission

Speaker: NA
Text: undertook a broad review of Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: remuneration framework. The nine-month

Speaker: NA
Text: review process, which included a total of 170

Speaker: NA
Text: submissions and a series of public hearings,

Speaker: NA
Text: revealed that Australia's corporate

Speaker: NA
Text: governance and remuneration framework are

Speaker: NA
Text: ranked highly on an international scale.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, it also recommended a range of

Speaker: NA
Text: reforms to further strengthen Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: remuneration framework.

Speaker: NA
Text: The bill before the House today

Speaker: NA
Text: effectively responds to these

Speaker: NA
Text: recommendations. It will provide

Speaker: NA
Text: shareholders with a new level of power and

Speaker: NA
Text: ultimately improve the transparency and

Speaker: NA
Text: accountability of company directors and

Speaker: NA
Text: executives. It addresses the conflicts of

Speaker: NA
Text: interest that arise throughout the

Speaker: NA
Text: remuneration process and ensures that the

Speaker: NA
Text: sentiments of shareholders are appropriately

Speaker: NA
Text: represented by directors and executives.

Speaker: NA
Text: While Australia's remuneration

Speaker: NA
Text: framework is certainly strong, these

Speaker: NA
Text: innovative reforms will eliminate

Speaker: NA
Text: complacency and ensure that it remains

Speaker: NA
Text: effective well into the future. It will better

Speaker: NA
Text: reflect community standards when it comes

Speaker: NA
Text: to remuneration and pay of company

Speaker: NA
Text: executives, and I therefore commend the bill

Speaker: NA
Text: to the House.

Speaker: Mr ZAPPIA
Text: Makin) (11:01): I welcome

Speaker: NA
Text: the opportunity to speak on Corporations

Speaker: NA
Text: Amendment (Improving Accountability on

Speaker: NA
Text: Director and Executive Remuneration) Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: 2011, and I commend the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Kingston for the remarks she has just made

Speaker: NA
Text: on the bill in this place.

Speaker: NA
Text: In recent years public anger about

Speaker: NA
Text: excessive salaries and executive payouts has

Speaker: NA
Text: been widespread. Whilst the spotlight has

Speaker: NA
Text: been taken off executive salaries in recent

Speaker: NA
Text: times there is little, if any, justification for

Speaker: NA
Text: some of the remuneration we are still seeing.

Speaker: NA
Text: Nor is this issue just a matter for company

Speaker: NA
Text: shareholders. It is a matter that the wider

Speaker: NA
Text: community has a right to take an interest in,

Speaker: NA
Text: because in most cases the remuneration

Speaker: NA
Text: packages for senior executives have direct

Speaker: NA
Text: implications for the broader community.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is why this is a public interest issue, and

Speaker: NA
Text: why those people who argue that private

Speaker: NA
Text: sector remuneration is a matter for the

Speaker: NA
Text: private sector and not the business of

Speaker: NA
Text: government are wrong. It is the argument

Speaker: NA
Text: about why this is a matter of public interest

Speaker: NA
Text: that I will address in my remarks on this bill.

Speaker: NA
Text: Possibly every senior management

Speaker: NA
Text: appointment today is tied to performance,

Speaker: NA
Text: either by way of a performance bonus or

Speaker: NA
Text: simply because renewal of the employment

Speaker: NA
Text: contract is directly tied to performance. In

Speaker: NA
Text: the private sector the most used measure of

Speaker: NA
Text: performance and certainly the most

Speaker: NA
Text: persuasive is the annual profit or loss

Speaker: NA
Text: statement. Generally, the higher the profits

Speaker: NA
Text: the better the performance is considered.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is what most company owners and

Speaker: NA
Text: shareholders are driven by. Profit can be and

Speaker: NA
Text: usually is made from a range of actions, but

Speaker: NA
Text: when any of those actions are extreme or

Speaker: NA
Text: irresponsible it is the public that inevitably

Speaker: NA
Text: ends up paying one way or another. And

Speaker: NA
Text: therein lies the public interest test-a test

Speaker: NA
Text: that could be applied time and again, using

Speaker: NA
Text: many examples in numerous industry sectors

Speaker: NA
Text: over recent years.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have seen farmers being squeezed by

Speaker: NA
Text: monopoly retailers, manufacturers

Speaker: NA
Text: transferring their operations overseas, high-

Speaker: NA
Text: risk loan arrangements or investment

Speaker: NA
Text: schemes, construction shortcuts where safety

Speaker: NA
Text: standards are not complied with, transport

Speaker: NA
Text: industry drivers placed under unreasonable

Speaker: NA
Text: delivery deadlines, and collusion or similar

Speaker: NA
Text: practices and possibly corruption creeping

Speaker: NA
Text: into industry practices. Cutting costs and

Speaker: NA
Text: increasing sales are strategies almost

Speaker: NA
Text: universally implemented in business to

Speaker: NA
Text: increase profits-and I will speak more

Speaker: NA
Text: about both these matters. Cutting costs and

Speaker: NA
Text: reducing overheads can be achieved by

Speaker: NA
Text: investing in modernisation strategies,

Speaker: NA
Text: upskilling the workforce, streamlining

Speaker: NA
Text: production and other forward-thinking

Speaker: NA
Text: responsible strategies. The alternatives are

Speaker: NA
Text: reducing labour costs, not complying with

Speaker: NA
Text: regulatory standards, using

Speaker: NA
Text: componentry, taking extreme risks and other

Speaker: NA
Text: irresponsible measures-all of which appear

Speaker: NA
Text: to have become commonplace in business.

Speaker: NA
Text: I turn now to labour costs. Labour costs

Speaker: NA
Text: are frequently cut by placing unreasonable

Speaker: NA
Text: demands on workers, including longer

Speaker: NA
Text: working hours, which are often unpaid; by

Speaker: NA
Text: reducing the workforce numbers and

Speaker: NA
Text: working employees harder; by paying

Speaker: NA
Text: workers less than fair wages; by

Speaker: NA
Text: subcontracting work out; and by taking work

Speaker: NA
Text: offshore. It is all about squeezing more out

Speaker: NA
Text: of the labour force. The social costs of

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployment, housing, health and family

Speaker: NA
Text: breakdown, which inevitably follow when

Speaker: NA
Text: operations are transferred offshore, workers

Speaker: NA
Text: are placed under unreasonable work

Speaker: NA
Text: pressure, or work is subcontracted out so

Speaker: NA
Text: employers are no longer responsible for

Speaker: NA
Text: work conditions are all examples of where

Speaker: NA
Text: the consequences are inevitably paid for by

Speaker: NA
Text: the rest of society.

Speaker: NA
Text: We saw the collapse of the financial

Speaker: NA
Text: system because of high-risk lending practices

Speaker: NA
Text: or high-risk investment schemes. This was

Speaker: NA
Text: driven by executives who were in turn

Speaker: NA
Text: motivated by increased profits. Hardworking

Speaker: NA
Text: people lost their homes, their health, their

Speaker: NA
Text: savings and sometimes their lives because of

Speaker: NA
Text: the decisions of highly remunerated

Speaker: NA
Text: executives. In the five years prior to the 2008

Speaker: NA
Text: global financial crisis, senior executives of

Speaker: NA
Text: the five largest financial institutions in Wall

Speaker: NA
Text: Street were paid $3.6 billion in

Speaker: NA
Text: remuneration. They profited whilst others

Speaker: NA
Text: lost everything. They were rewarded for their

Speaker: NA
Text: failure.

Speaker: NA
Text: I turn now to the transport sector. Each

Speaker: NA
Text: year around 300 lives are lost and about

Speaker: NA
Text: 5,500 are injured because of cost-cutting in

Speaker: NA
Text: the transport sector. I quote from a

Speaker: NA
Text: submission from the Transport Workers

Speaker: NA
Text: Union from February this year on this very

Speaker: NA
Text: matter:

Speaker: NA
Text: inferior Each road death costs $1.7 million. Each

Speaker: NA
Text: injury in an incident costs $408 000. When the

Speaker: NA
Text: non-monetised social impact of road deaths,

Speaker: NA
Text: injuries and illness, family breakdown, pain and

Speaker: NA
Text: suffering is included in the measurement of what

Speaker: NA
Text: road deaths and injuries cost the community-

Speaker: NA
Text: The damages bill is immeasurable. The

Speaker: NA
