Text: report attributes the cause of the road

Speaker: NA
Text: transport safety crisis to economic factors;

Speaker: NA
Text: namely, the low level of driver remuneration

Speaker: NA
Text: and their methods of payment. As made clear

Speaker: NA
Text: in the NTC report, the high level of control

Speaker: NA
Text: exercised by clients over price, timing,

Speaker: NA
Text: destination and route causes operators to

Speaker: NA
Text: bear the costs that, ordinarily, are borne by

Speaker: NA
Text: customers. Denied a proper return, let alone

Speaker: NA
Text: a margin that exceeds the cost of capital,

Speaker: NA
Text: operators undercut each other, bid the price

Speaker: NA
Text: of transport down and attempt to recoup the

Speaker: NA
Text: losses caused by clients from drivers by not

Speaker: NA
Text: paying them for all work performed and by

Speaker: NA
Text: paying them through incentive rates. It says:

Speaker: NA
Text: Because employment is too often conditional

Speaker: NA
Text: on strict compliance with an operator's direction

Speaker: NA
Text: and client deadlines, drivers are prone to drive

Speaker: NA
Text: while fatigued, to speed, to take drugs and to

Speaker: NA
Text: skimp on maintenance.

Speaker: NA
Text: All of that arises because someone is trying

Speaker: NA
Text: to make a profit. Usually the CEO or an

Speaker: NA
Text: executive is the person driving that to the

Speaker: NA
Text: point that they do.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mining and construction workers' lives

Speaker: NA
Text: have been put at risk and lives lost or injured

Speaker: NA
Text: because of work practices imposed by

Speaker: NA
Text: employers. The recent spate of mining

Speaker: NA
Text: tragedies exposes some of these practices. In

Speaker: NA
Text: the building and construction sector, each

Speaker: NA
Text: year around 50 lives are lost and around

Speaker: NA
Text: 75,000 workers are injured through

Speaker: NA
Text: accidents, which in most cases are

Speaker: NA
Text: foreseeable and avoidable and which can be

Speaker: NA
Text: attributed to cost cutting. Yet people like Ark

Speaker: NA
Text: Tribe were taken to court for standing up for

Speaker: NA
Text: their right to a safe work environment.

Speaker: NA
Text: In food production, farm producers are

Speaker: NA
Text: squeezed for lower prices by the major

Speaker: NA
Text: grocery retailers in turn placing hardship and

Speaker: NA
Text: stress on farming families. The current milk

Speaker: NA
Text: price war has been linked to the executive

Speaker: NA
Text: remuneration of the Coles CEO with

Speaker: NA
Text: allegations that the Coles CEO will be paid

Speaker: NA
Text: millions of dollars if he increases the Coles

Speaker: NA
Text: profit. Discounting milk is a strategy

Speaker: NA
Text: currently being employed by Coles to

Speaker: NA
Text: increase market share of grocery sales and

Speaker: NA
Text: ultimately the Coles profit. The Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: dairy farmers say the discounted milk is

Speaker: NA
Text: already reducing the income of dairy farmers

Speaker: NA
Text: and threatens their ongoing viability. This is

Speaker: NA
Text: a claim that Coles is disputing of course. We

Speaker: NA
Text: have also seen farm products being sourced

Speaker: NA
Text: from overseas where production standards do

Speaker: NA
Text: not meet Australian standards, which in turn

Speaker: NA
Text: leads to health impacts on Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: consumers and a demise of Australian food

Speaker: NA
Text: production. Again these are decisions made

Speaker: NA
Text: by executives whose primary interest is

Speaker: NA
Text: profit. The impact on Australian farmers and

Speaker: NA
Text: the health impacts on Australian consumers

Speaker: NA
Text: are ultimately borne by governments.

Speaker: NA
Text: Another of the very concerning trends in

Speaker: NA
Text: recent times has been the use of overseas

Speaker: NA
Text: registered shipping and crews. We have now

Speaker: NA
Text: had several cases of extensive environmental

Speaker: NA
Text: disasters that have been attributed to cost-

Speaker: NA
Text: cutting decisions made by executives who

Speaker: NA
Text: are driven by profit. The environmental

Speaker: NA
Text: disaster on the Great Barrier Reef when a

Speaker: NA
Text: Chinese coal carrier ran aground, spilling

Speaker: NA
Text: about four tonnes of heavy fuel oil from a

Speaker: NA
Text: perforated fuel tank, has been attributed to a

Speaker: NA
Text: seaman being fatigued, having managed only

Speaker: NA
Text: 2½ hours of sleep in the previous 38½ hours.

Speaker: NA
Text: In February this year there was another

Speaker: NA
Text: shipping incident. It was associated with the

Speaker: NA
Text: multi-cat vessel Boskalis BKM 102 whilst

Speaker: NA
Text: working on the Gorgon project off Barrow

Speaker: NA
Text: Island. The four MUA crew members were

Speaker: NA
Text: put at risk and the pristine environment was

Speaker: NA
Text: badly polluted, because of the shoddy

Speaker: NA
Text: practices of the overseas shipping company.

Speaker: NA
Text: In addition, there was the Montara oil spill,

Speaker: NA
Text: which occurred in the Timor Sea on 21

Speaker: NA
Text: August 2009 and continued right up until

Speaker: NA
Text: November 2009. I understand that Indonesia

Speaker: NA
Text: and East Timor are now seeking

Speaker: NA
Text: compensation for the

Speaker: NA
Text: environmental damage done. Even if they are

Speaker: NA
Text: successful as to compensation and even if

Speaker: NA
Text: penalties are imposed, the reality is that the

Speaker: NA
Text: bulk of the environmental damage cost

Speaker: NA
Text: inevitably will fall onto governments and

Speaker: NA
Text: society.

Speaker: NA
Text: The measures in this bill provide

Speaker: NA
Text: increased accountability by CEOs to

Speaker: NA
Text: shareholders and conversely

Speaker: NA
Text: shareholders more control over executive

Speaker: NA
Text: remuneration, and they will be welcomed by

Speaker: NA
Text: many Australians. It is my view that most

Speaker: NA
Text: shareholders do not endorse the kinds of

Speaker: NA
Text: practices that I have alluded to in my

Speaker: NA
Text: remarks. It is my view that most

Speaker: NA
Text: shareholders want to see their executives

Speaker: NA
Text: acting responsibly. Time will enable us to

Speaker: NA
Text: determine whether the measures in this bill

Speaker: NA
Text: are sufficient to ensure the right level of

Speaker: NA
Text: accountability by CEOs. It is my view that

Speaker: NA
Text: many CEOs are still

Speaker: NA
Text: overremunerated and I would consider

Speaker: NA
Text: supporting additional measures that I believe

Speaker: NA
Text: could be taken to curb excessive CEO

Speaker: NA
Text: remuneration packages. I note the comments

Speaker: NA
Text: of members opposite and I understand that

Speaker: NA
Text: they intend moving an amendment. I also

Speaker: NA
Text: note comments they believe that essentially

Speaker: NA
Text: the government should not meddle in private

Speaker: NA
Text: enterprise. These comments were made by a

Speaker: NA
Text: number of these speakers. I reject that

Speaker: NA
Text: proposition. I believe that this legislation is a

Speaker: NA
Text: step in the right direction, and I commend it

Speaker: NA
Text: to the House.

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate adjourned.

Speaker: NA
Text: Midwife Professional Indemnity

Speaker: NA
Text: Legislation Amendment Bill 2011

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate resumed on the motion:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: Mr DUTTON
Text: Dickson) (11:12): Yet

Speaker: NA
Text: again the fact that the Midwife Professional

Speaker: NA
Text: extensive Indemnity Legislation Amendment Bill 2011

Speaker: NA
Text: is before the House today is proof that this

Speaker: NA
Text: government just cannot get anything right.

Speaker: NA
Text: The bill is yet another fix from Gillard Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: to legislation that it rushed into this

Speaker: NA
Text: parliament two years ago. It has been

Speaker: NA
Text: struggling to get it right ever since. Members

Speaker: NA
Text: will recall the troubled passage of the

Speaker: NA
Text: midwives and nurse practitioners bill and the

Speaker: NA
Text: give midwife and professional indemnity bills

Speaker: NA
Text: throughout 2009 and 2010. The Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Health and Ageing tried to blame the

Speaker: NA
Text: opposition. She then tried to blame the

Speaker: NA
Text: Senate-anybody but herself-for the delays

Speaker: NA
Text: in this legislation passing through this

Speaker: NA
Text: parliament. In fact, it was a case of the

Speaker: NA
Text: minister and the government rushing

Speaker: NA
Text: headlong to get the legislation into the

Speaker: NA
Text: parliament without taking the time to ensure

Speaker: NA
Text: that they had got it right. In the end, it was

Speaker: NA
Text: the government that was introducing

Speaker: NA
Text: grossly amendments to its own legislation as it

Speaker: NA
Text: moved through the parliament. Through the

Speaker: NA
Text: process Minister Roxon had to admit that she

Speaker: NA
Text: had got it wrong, and she had to backtrack.

Speaker: NA
Text: She had to placate concerned stakeholders,

Speaker: NA
Text: she had to clarify matters to a Senate

Speaker: NA
Text: committee and then the minister had to make

Speaker: NA
Text: amendments. Then, after the legislation had

Speaker: NA
Text: taken effect from July last year, the minister

Speaker: NA
Text: was forced to make new rules to cover the

Speaker: NA
Text: problems that this bill now seeks to remedy.

Speaker: NA
Text: And what were those problems?

Speaker: NA
Text: The answer to this is that the minister had

Speaker: NA
Text: bungled things yet again. Perhaps we should

Speaker: NA
Text: say 'as usual', because if we look back over

Speaker: NA
Text: the last 3½ years it certainly has been a

Speaker: NA
Text: litany of failure and inability to deliver even

Speaker: NA
Text: the most basic of legislative programs, and

Speaker: NA
Text: this is a reflection on the broader dilemma

Speaker: NA
Text: that the government face: the public now

Speaker: NA
Text: realises that this is a government that just

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot deliver on what it is that they

Speaker: NA
Text: propose.

Speaker: NA
Text: The drafting of the original legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: actually excluded one group of midwives

Speaker: NA
Text: from accessing the indemnity contribution

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme. The legislation treated those who

Speaker: NA
Text: operated through their own companies and

Speaker: NA
Text: were in fact self-employed the same as it

Speaker: NA
Text: treated those who were employed by larger

Speaker: NA
Text: organisations, such as hospitals or medical

Speaker: NA
Text: practices, and therefore as employed

Speaker: NA
Text: midwives. The legislation had excluded

Speaker: NA
Text: employed midwives from the scheme. The

Speaker: NA
Text: government presents this as an oversight. It

Speaker: NA
Text: was 'not the government's original intention',

Speaker: NA
Text: they say. And this bill to remedy the

Speaker: NA
Text: situation is presented as a technical fix for

Speaker: NA
Text: minor element of the act. What it is though is

Speaker: NA
Text: another error on the part of the government

Speaker: NA
Text: and of this minister. So, too, is the second

Speaker: NA
Text: matter this bill seeks to remedy. That

Speaker: NA
Text: mistake is presented as a 'typographical

Speaker: NA
Text: error'. Let me just explain what the

Speaker: NA
Text: typographical error goes to. What effectively

Speaker: NA
Text: the original legislation did was to enshrine

Speaker: NA
Text: law a formula to tax insurers of midwives at

Speaker: NA
Text: a rate far higher than the premium income

Speaker: NA
Text: those insurers received from the midwives

Speaker: NA
Text: for their insurance coverage. That is some

Speaker: NA
Text: typo! It is also typical of a government that

Speaker: NA
Text: continually talks about grandiose schemes

Speaker: NA
Text: and ambitions but then completely fails to do

Speaker: NA
Text: the hard yards to get the detail right.

Speaker: NA
Text: Exclude for the moment the monumental

Speaker: NA
Text: failures of the Rudd and Gillard governments

Speaker: NA
Text: with pink batts and school halls and green

Speaker: NA
Text: schemes. We have seen the failure to deliver

Speaker: NA
Text: time and time again in the area of health.

Speaker: NA
Text: Remember, for a start, the all-encompassing

Speaker: NA
Text: promise from Kevin Rudd to fix public

Speaker: NA
Text: hospitals: he was going to do it, remember,

Speaker: NA
Text: by mid-2009 and if he had not he was going

Speaker: NA
Text: to hold a referendum for the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: takeover of the nation's public hospitals. All

Speaker: NA
Text: we had by mid-2009 was a series of reports

Speaker: NA
Text: from the multitude of committees and

Speaker: NA
Text: had commissions and working groups and

Speaker: NA
Text: inquiries that Rudd Labor had

Speaker: NA
Text: commissioned. All we had by 2010 was a

Speaker: NA
Text: hastily thrown-together plan branded the

Speaker: NA
Text: national health and hospitals reform so that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Rudd-Gillard government could actually

Speaker: NA
Text: look like it was doing something to honour

Speaker: NA
Text: those commitments made to Australians in

Speaker: NA
Text: What did we get from the so-called

Speaker: NA
Text: reform? We certainly got lots of media

Speaker: NA
Text: releases, conferences and communiques, and

Speaker: NA
Text: plenty of colourful and expensive booklets

Speaker: NA
Text: outlining the grand health plan, some of

Speaker: NA
Text: a which had to be pulped within days of being

Speaker: NA
Text: printed, such was the hubris surrounding Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Rudd's and Ms Roxon's health reforms. Now,

Speaker: NA
Text: of course, it is a fact that Kevin Rudd was

Speaker: NA
Text: deposed. His historic reforms were shredded.

Speaker: NA
Text: Now we have the current Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: saying 'historic health reforms'-this has a

Speaker: NA
Text: familiar ring to it-which amount at this

Speaker: NA
Text: in stage to nothing more than an agreement

Speaker: NA
Text: with the premiers to get an agreement. An

Speaker: NA
Text: agreement to get an agreement. If anything

Speaker: NA
Text: sums Labor up, it is an intention to do

Speaker: NA
Text: something or an intention to have an

Speaker: NA
Text: intention to do something. An agreement to

Speaker: NA
Text: get an agreement-that is where this historic

Speaker: NA
Text: reform is as we stand in this parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: today. This is a government that has failed

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian public in so many areas, as I

Speaker: NA
Text: have said before, but none more so in my

Speaker: NA
Text: view than in health.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let us take another example: the so-called

Speaker: NA
Text: GP superclinics. They are so super that they

Speaker: NA
Text: resemble any other general practice across

Speaker: NA
Text: the country. Yet again, much was promised,

Speaker: NA
Text: but when we look at what is being

Speaker: NA
Text: delivered-we know what is being

Speaker: NA
Text: delivered-we see that it is taxpayers' money

Speaker: NA
Text: that is going to set up a practice in opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: to a practice which has been established

Speaker: NA
Text: through private investment. It is completely

Speaker: NA
Text: offensive, not just to the doctors and nurses

Speaker: NA
Text: who are involved but to patients as well. To

Speaker: NA
Text: make it worse, the government have decided

Speaker: NA
Text: that they will proffer preferential treatment

Speaker: NA
Text: in terms of the employment of the doctors,

Speaker: NA
Text: and presumably nurses in some cases as

Speaker: NA
Text: well, at these superclinics, which puts them

Speaker: NA
Text: at a competitive advantage to those practices

Speaker: NA
Text: which operate with the cost of capital being

Speaker: NA
Text: deployed into these centres. It is untenable

Speaker: NA
Text: that this situation continues. Ms Roxon had

Speaker: NA
Text: promised more than 60 of these so-called

Speaker: NA
Text: superclinics, and we know that just 10 of

Speaker: NA
Text: these clinics have opened across the country

Speaker: NA
Text: five years after they were promised, and

Speaker: NA
Text: completely and utterly over budget. Nothing

Speaker: NA
Text: this government touch does anything but turn

Speaker: NA
Text: to dust. The health portfolio contains one

Speaker: NA
Text: classic example after another of why Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: just cannot be trusted with the sort of

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation that is before the House today or,

Speaker: NA
Text: indeed, the general health program.

Speaker: NA
Text: Last night we saw the government make

Speaker: NA
Text: an announcement on mental health-an area

Speaker: NA
Text: of great importance to all Australians-that

Speaker: NA
Text: they tried to make people believe was in the

Speaker: NA
Text: order of $2.2 billion. But when you strip

Speaker: NA
Text: away that spin, the Australian public has

Speaker: NA
Text: discovered today that the government

Speaker: NA
Text: commits $583 million over the next four

Speaker: NA
Text: years, over the forward estimates. They have

Speaker: NA
Text: some money in the fifth year. But, strangely

Speaker: NA
Text: enough, five years time will be the third year

Speaker: NA
Text: of the next term of government. So, if you

Speaker: NA
Text: believe that Julia Gillard is going to last

Speaker: NA
Text: next two years, she then has to last the next

Speaker: NA
Text: three years beyond that as Prime Minister to

Speaker: NA
Text: implement this plan that was announced last

Speaker: NA
Text: night. It is complete and utter fantasy.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is a government that promises big. It

Speaker: NA
Text: promised big to the midwives, it promised

Speaker: NA
Text: big to the mental health community, but it

Speaker: NA
Text: has delivered nothing. This is a government

Speaker: NA
Text: that should hang its head in shame when it

Speaker: NA
Text: comes to the health portfolio because, whilst

Speaker: NA
Text: billions and billions of dollars has been

Speaker: NA
Text: squandered in pink batts, in all of these failed

Speaker: NA
Text: programs that the Labor government has

Speaker: NA
Text: delivered-

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr KJ

Speaker: NA
Text: Thomson): Order! I am reluctant-

Speaker: Mr DUTTON
Text: money has not been

Speaker: NA
Text: directed into these sorts of areas, which are

Speaker: NA
Text: incredibly important-

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: The shadow

Speaker: NA
Text: minister will resume his seat when I am

Speaker: NA
Text: drawing his attention to a matter, otherwise I

Speaker: NA
Text: will have to sit him down. I am reluctant to

Speaker: NA
Text: interrupt shadow ministers and speakers, but

Speaker: NA
Text: so far the shadow minister has had precious

Speaker: NA
Text: little to say about the bill before the House. I

Speaker: NA
Text: draw his attention to the fact that we are

Speaker: NA
Text: debating the Midwife Professional Indemnity

Speaker: NA
Text: Legislation Amendment Bill.

Speaker: Mr DUTTON
Text: What I have done in my

Speaker: NA
Text: speech thus far has been to demonstrate the

Speaker: NA
Text: failings of Labor, particularly in relation to

Speaker: NA
Text: this piece of legislation before the

Speaker: NA
Text: parliament. It is important for people to

Speaker: NA
Text: understand that this is yet another patch-up

Speaker: NA
Text: job by a government that just cannot get it

Speaker: NA
Text: right. I think it is completely reasonable, in

Speaker: NA
Text: drawing people's attention to the latest

Speaker: NA
Text: failings, this time in health, that we also

Speaker: NA
Text: draw their attention to Labor's other failings,

Speaker: NA
Text: because it gives people an understanding of

Speaker: NA
Text: the modus operandi of this government.

Speaker: NA
Text: They cannot get it right in the area of pink

Speaker: NA
Text: the batts; they cannot give pink batts away for

Speaker: NA
Text: free. They cannot get the midwives

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation right.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: I have told

Speaker: NA
Text: the shadow minister that he needs to be

Speaker: NA
Text: relevant to the bill. If he wishes to defy my

Speaker: NA
Text: ruling, I will sit him down and move to the

Speaker: NA
Text: next speaker.

Speaker: Mr DUTTON
Text: Why this is completely

Speaker: NA
Text: relevant is because it shows a course of

Speaker: NA
Text: conduct by a government that is out of

Speaker: NA
Text: control. The point is that it is not just

Speaker: NA
Text: restricted to the area of health. More money

Speaker: NA
Text: is needed in the area for doctors and nurses

Speaker: NA
Text: and for midwives in particular, but this is a

Speaker: NA
Text: government that has wasted money and this

Speaker: NA
Text: is a government that has said to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian public that it has health as a

Speaker: NA
Text: priority, yet every act both inside this

Speaker: NA
Text: portfolio and across broader government

Speaker: NA
Text: points to completely the opposite. I think it is

Speaker: NA
Text: a crying shame for Australian patients, for

Speaker: NA
Text: midwives who are affected directly by this

Speaker: NA
Text: bill, for all allied health professionals, that

Speaker: NA
Text: they see so much promised and yet have so

Speaker: NA
Text: little delivered. This is just the latest example

Speaker: NA
Text: of why this government cannot be trusted

Speaker: NA
Text: going forward. The midwives of Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: look at this piece of legislation as yet the

Speaker: NA
Text: latest example of why this government

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot be trusted into the future.

Speaker: NA
Text: We supported the original tranche of

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation in this area. We provided

Speaker: NA
Text: constructive input to the government. We

Speaker: NA
Text: warned them of some of the likely failings.

Speaker: NA
Text: Some of those failings have come to pass.

Speaker: NA
Text: They talk about typographical errors which

Speaker: NA
Text: in effect make the premium completely

Speaker: NA
Text: above and beyond what anybody could be

Speaker: NA
Text: expected to pay. Nobody could practise as a

Speaker: NA
Text: result of this legislation reasonably if they

Speaker: NA
Text: were in certain employment circumstances.

Speaker: NA
Text: As I say, we flagged the fact that this

Speaker: NA
Text: government would get yet another bill

Speaker: NA
Text: wrong. They did not let us down. Certainly

Speaker: NA
Text: they have let the Australian people down.

Speaker: NA
Text: We support the amendments because they

Speaker: NA
Text: make bad legislation better than it was, but

Speaker: NA
Text: ultimately what needs to be highlighted to

Speaker: NA
Text: this parliament and to the Australian people

Speaker: NA
Text: is that this is yet the latest example of a

Speaker: NA
Text: government that has failed at every turn, for

Speaker: NA
Text: which they should be condemned at the

Speaker: NA
Text: ballot box in two years time.

Speaker: Mr NEUMANN
Text: Blair) (11:24): I rise to

Speaker: NA
Text: speak in support of the Midwife Professional

Speaker: NA
Text: Indemnity Legislation Amendment Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: 2011. The member for Dickson urged us to

Speaker: NA
Text: put more money into hospitals, doctors,

Speaker: NA
Text: nurses and the health system generally. This

Speaker: NA
Text: is a bit rich coming from those opposite,

Speaker: NA
Text: when the Institute of Health and Welfare in

Speaker: NA
Text: October 2007 produced a damning report on

Speaker: NA
Text: the state of the health and hospital system in

Speaker: NA
Text: this country under the tutelage of the then

Speaker: NA
Text: minister, who happens to be the opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: leader, and he was a longstanding health

Speaker: NA
Text: minister at that time. The institute damned

Speaker: NA
Text: the Howard coalition government, saying

Speaker: NA
Text: that they had actually defunded, vis-a-vis the

Speaker: NA
Text: states and territories and the private health

Speaker: NA
Text: sector, health and hospital funding in this

Speaker: NA
Text: country. Even the now opposition leader-

Speaker: NA
Text: and we have had about three of them since

Speaker: NA
Text: 2007-at that time actually admitted during

Speaker: NA
Text: a campaign that was not one of his best and

Speaker: NA
Text: finest performances in terms of timeliness

Speaker: NA
Text: and preparedness to debate issues,

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly with the now Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Health-

Speaker: Mr Baldwin
Text: Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise

Speaker: NA
Text: a point of order. I am mindful of how you

Speaker: NA
Text: brought the member for Dickson to order to

Speaker: NA
Text: address the bill. I would suggest that you

Speaker: NA
Text: bring your attention to ask the current

Speaker: NA
Text: speaker to address the actual issues in the

Speaker: NA
Text: bill.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: The member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Paterson will be aware that the member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Dickson spoke for about 10 minutes

Speaker: NA
Text: before I drew his attention to the bill. But the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Blair no doubt is aware of the

Speaker: NA
Text: contents of the bill and I ask him to draw his

Speaker: NA
Text: remarks to the bill.

Speaker: Mr NEUMANN
Text: I am happy to do so,

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Deputy Speaker. I will just respond on

Speaker: NA
Text: one issue, and that is the GP superclinics. I

Speaker: NA
Text: say to the member for Dickson that the GP

Speaker: NA
Text: superclinic in Ipswich, which I am proud to

Speaker: NA
Text: have supported and sought the funding for at

Speaker: NA
Text: $2.5 million, was a wonderful institution for

Speaker: NA
Text: the Ipswich community at the time of the

Speaker: NA
Text: floods, being situated next to the main

Speaker: NA
Text: evacuation centre in Ipswich at the

Speaker: NA
Text: showground. If the member for Dickson

Speaker: NA
Text: wants to go and have a look at the Ipswich

Speaker: NA
Text: GP superclinic he is most welcome to at

Speaker: NA
Text: some stage. It is operating now under the

Speaker: NA
Text: great leadership of Dr Simon Barnett.

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to speak about what the coalition

Speaker: NA
Text: government failed to do with respect to

Speaker: NA
Text: midwifery and what we are doing in this

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation and what we have done since we

Speaker: NA
Text: were elected. The role of midwives and the

Speaker: NA
Text: issue of health funding and also insurance

Speaker: NA
Text: became very obvious back in about 2002 and

Speaker: NA
Text: also prior to that with the collapse of the

Speaker: NA
Text: insurance market after 9/11. There was a

Speaker: NA
Text: landmark obstetrics birth injury case which

Speaker: NA
Text: resulted in a payout of about $11 million and

Speaker: NA
Text: that initiated a crisis of confidence in the

Speaker: NA
Text: industry and also with respect to midwives

Speaker: NA
Text: across the country. With about 200 privately

Speaker: NA
Text: practising midwives paying about $800 a

Speaker: NA
Text: year for insurance, there simply was not a

Speaker: NA
Text: big enough pool of funds to contemplate a

Speaker: NA
Text: payout of that magnitude, and obviously

Speaker: NA
Text: insurance for midwives was a big issue.

Speaker: NA
Text: The coalition was in power in 2001-06

Speaker: NA
Text: and most of 2007, so it had over six years to

Speaker: NA
Text: resolve this issue. Surprisingly, it did

Speaker: NA
Text: was too hard for those opposite-inaction

Speaker: NA
Text: and inactivity on the issue was their motto.

Speaker: NA
Text: They were simply spending too much time

Speaker: NA
Text: attacking workers and not enough time

Speaker: NA
Text: noticing what was happening in the midwife

Speaker: NA
Text: sector. Since we got into power we took

Speaker: NA
Text: steps to find out about the issues facing

Speaker: NA
Text: midwives across the nation. In 2008 we

Speaker: NA
Text: directed the Commonwealth Chief Nurse and

Speaker: NA
Text: Midwifery Officer, Rosemary Bryant, to

Speaker: NA
Text: conduct a review of midwifery services in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. In addition a number of my

Speaker: NA
Text: colleagues and I lobbied very hard on this

Speaker: NA
Text: issue. I met with midwives in Queensland

Speaker: NA
Text: and I spoke at fora put on by the Maternity

Speaker: NA
Text: Coalition in the state. I spoke to a number of

Speaker: NA
Text: people in the industry, including a very

Speaker: NA
Text: prominent midwife in the Ipswich area,

Speaker: NA
Text: Teresa Walsh. I wish her and the other

Speaker: NA
Text: midwives well in their venture in relation to

Speaker: NA
Text: maternity services and midwifery services in

Speaker: NA
Text: Ipswich, Toowoomba and the western

Speaker: NA
Text: corridor and the business they are currently

Speaker: NA
Text: conducting. I had the privilege of serving on

Speaker: NA
Text: the local health community council with Cas

Speaker: NA
Text: MCCullough, a real mover and shaker in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Maternity Coalition in Queensland and

Speaker: NA
Text: someone who has argued strongly for reform

Speaker: NA
Text: for midwives. Cas has taken a very strong

Speaker: NA
Text: view that we need to make changes to

Speaker: NA
Text: support midwives and has certainly put into

Speaker: NA
Text: practice her commitment to caring for young

Speaker: NA
Text: children and for women who choose

Speaker: NA
Text: homebirths, as well as for women who

Speaker: NA
Text: choose to give birth in other ways. Cas's

Speaker: NA
Text: work is very well known in the West

Speaker: NA
Text: Moreton area, and I commend her for the

Speaker: NA
Text: work she is doing.

Speaker: NA
Text: It was Labor that brought three bills

Speaker: NA
Text: before this House in 2009 to support

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's midwives. Despite the great work

Speaker: NA
Text: done there, anomalies emerged from that

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation. The purpose of the Midwife

Speaker: NA
Text: Professional Indemnity (Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: not. It Contribution) Scheme Act 2010 and the

Speaker: NA
Text: associated Midwife Professional Indemnity

Speaker: NA
Text: (Run-off Cover Support Payment) Act 2010

Speaker: NA
Text: was to support the new MBS and PBS

Speaker: NA
Text: arrangements by enabling the establishment

Speaker: NA
Text: of a government supported professional

Speaker: NA
Text: indemnity scheme for eligible midwives

Speaker: NA
Text: from 1 July 2010. An unintended

Speaker: NA
Text: consequence emerged from the enactment of

Speaker: NA
Text: the contribution scheme legislation whereby

Speaker: NA
Text: midwives who were self-employed and had

Speaker: NA
Text: formed companies through which to operate

Speaker: NA
Text: their services were not eligible for a

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth contribution. That particular

Speaker: NA
Text: provision was set up to deal with private

Speaker: NA
Text: hospitals and large private obstetric practices

Speaker: NA
Text: as employers and was not intended to impact

Speaker: NA
Text: on companies established by a single

Speaker: NA
Text: midwife or a couple of midwives who were

Speaker: NA
Text: directors, shareholders and employees of that

Speaker: NA
Text: private company.

Speaker: NA
Text: Within large companies such as private

Speaker: NA
Text: hospitals and large obstetric practices, claims

Speaker: NA
Text: to a Commonwealth contribution scheme

Speaker: NA
Text: could be made by the employer. But if the

Speaker: NA
Text: midwife, who may be the sole director and

Speaker: NA
Text: sole shareholder, was also an employee, this

Speaker: NA
Text: made them ineligible to make a contribution

Speaker: NA
Text: claim, and that was never the federal Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: government's intention. The Midwife

Speaker: NA
Text: Professional Indemnity Legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: Amendment Bill 2011 has the very important

Speaker: NA
Text: task of tidying up the Midwife Professional

Speaker: NA
Text: Indemnity Scheme created under the 2010

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation. The bill before the chamber

Speaker: NA
Text: allows for a rule-making power to be

Speaker: NA
Text: established under section 11(3)(g), and thus

Speaker: NA
Text: tidies up the placement of the unintended

Speaker: NA
Text: words to a more appropriate part of the

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation. It also allows for future rules

Speaker: NA
Text: be made as and when new and innovative

Speaker: NA
Text: midwife self-employment arrangements

Speaker: NA
Text: occur, without the need to seek a separate

Speaker: NA
Text: amendment to the legislation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Of course, any new rules are subject to the

Speaker: NA
Text: scrutiny of the parliament to make sure the

Speaker: NA
Text: intention is consistent with the scheme

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation. As the member for Dickson

Speaker: NA
Text: pointed out, the bill does fix an error in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Midwife Professional Indemnity (Run-off

Speaker: NA
Text: Cover Support Payment) Bill 2010, which

Speaker: NA
Text: became legislation, which would, if left

Speaker: NA
Text: unchanged, impose a higher than intended

Speaker: NA
Text: tax on insurers of eligible midwives.

Speaker: NA
Text: This bill ensures that self-employed

Speaker: NA
Text: midwives can access the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: contribution scheme and amends the

Speaker: NA
Text: professional indemnity legislation of 2010 to

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure that the tax on insurers of eligible

Speaker: NA
Text: midwives is correctly calculated. These

Speaker: NA
Text: changes are important because self-

Speaker: NA
Text: employed midwives such as Teresa Walsh,

Speaker: NA
Text: whom I mentioned before, need to make sure

Speaker: NA
Text: that they can get access to that scheme and

Speaker: NA
Text: not fall foul of the previous provisions. We

Speaker: NA
Text: do not want them excluded from the

Speaker: NA
Text: operation of the provision.

Speaker: NA
Text: Today we see the federal Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: government putting the health and wellbeing

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australians at the forefront of legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: in fixing up this problem. We saw health,

Speaker: NA
Text: education, infrastructure and many aspects of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian economy front and centre in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Treasurer's speech last night with respect

Speaker: NA
Text: to employment and participation. We need to

Speaker: NA
Text: make sure that midwives participate not just

Speaker: NA
Text: in the economy but in the lives of women

Speaker: NA
Text: who choose to use midwives in the birthing

Speaker: NA
Text: of their children. This is an important

Speaker: NA
Text: difference in terms of legislation. It fixes up

Speaker: NA
Text: some problems and puts the scheme in a

Speaker: NA
Text: to better state. It makes sure that midwives

Speaker: NA
Text: have security and certainty and have access

Speaker: NA
Text: to the contribution, and it helps midwives

Speaker: NA
Text: such as Teresa Walsh in my electorate, and

Speaker: NA
Text: others, to access the scheme in the way that

Speaker: NA
Text: we always intended. For that reason, I

Speaker: NA
Text: commend the legislation to the House.

Speaker: Mr LYONS
Text: Bass) (11:34): I rise to

Speaker: NA
Text: speak in the House about the Midwives

Speaker: NA
Text: Professional Indemnity Legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: Amendment Bill 2011. Most people who

Speaker: NA
Text: provide professional services and advice to

Speaker: NA
Text: the general public take out a form of

Speaker: NA
Text: insurance that covers and protects them and

Speaker: NA
Text: their clients against adverse incidents that

Speaker: NA
Text: may lead to injury or some kind of financial

Speaker: NA
Text: loss. Civil engineers, for example, take out

Speaker: NA
Text: professional indemnity cover against the

Speaker: NA
Text: possibility that structures they build will

Speaker: NA
Text: become unsafe or may cause injury to

Speaker: NA
Text: people. Doctors take out medical indemnity

Speaker: NA
Text: cover against the possibility that they may

Speaker: NA
Text: injure their patients during the course of a

Speaker: NA
Text: medical procedure or as a result of a

Speaker: NA
Text: prescribed course of treatment.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the 2009-10 budget, the government

Speaker: NA
Text: announced the 'improving maternity services

Speaker: NA
Text: package'. The package provides for the

Speaker: NA
Text: introduction of Medicare supported services

Speaker: NA
Text: to provide greater choice for women during

Speaker: NA
Text: pregnancy, birthing and postnatal maternity

Speaker: NA
Text: care, including the provision of professional

Speaker: NA
Text: indemnity for midwives. The Midwife

Speaker: NA
Text: Professional Indemnity Scheme, which

Speaker: NA
Text: commenced on 1 July 2010, enabled a

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth contribution to be paid to

Speaker: NA
Text: insurers for the cost of eligible claims against

Speaker: NA
Text: eligible midwives. This act provides that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth contribution and the run-off

Speaker: NA
Text: cover for Commonwealth contribution are

Speaker: NA
Text: not payable for a claim that should be

Speaker: NA
Text: covered by the midwife's employer. This is

Speaker: NA
Text: to ensure that there is no intentional cost-

Speaker: NA
Text: shifting from the employer to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth.

Speaker: NA
Text: Following the passage of this legislation,

Speaker: NA
Text: it was brought to the government's attention

Speaker: NA
Text: that the operation of this provision

Speaker: NA
Text: effectively excluded self-employed

Speaker: NA
Text: midwives. This exclusion was not the

Speaker: NA
Text: government's policy intention. The member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Dickson, a born-to-ruler from the other

Speaker: NA
Text: side, did not raise this oversight during the

Speaker: NA
Text: passage of the original legislation, even

Speaker: NA
Text: though the opposition would have us believe

Speaker: NA
Text: that they have some divine right to

Speaker: NA
Text: knowledge and ability. To give a little

Speaker: NA
Text: background on this issue, before the

Speaker: NA
Text: enactment of the Midwife Professional

Speaker: NA
Text: Indemnity (Commonwealth Contribution)

Speaker: NA
Text: Scheme Act 2010, midwives were generally

Speaker: NA
Text: unable to obtain insurance to cover their

Speaker: NA
Text: practice. In order to protect their personal

Speaker: NA
Text: assets in case of a negligence suit, many

Speaker: NA
Text: midwives chose to set up a company, either

Speaker: NA
Text: alone or with other midwives, through which

Speaker: NA
Text: they operated. This meant that any legal

Speaker: NA
Text: actions taken were taken against the

Speaker: NA
Text: company, not the midwife personally.

Speaker: NA
Text: This bill also amends the Midwife

Speaker: NA
Text: Professional Indemnity (Run-Off Cover

Speaker: NA
Text: Support Payment) Act 2010 to ensure that

Speaker: NA
Text: the tax on insurers of eligible midwives is

Speaker: NA
Text: correctly calculated.

Speaker: NA
Text: This bill amends the Midwife Professional

Speaker: NA
Text: Indemnity (Commonwealth Contribution)

Speaker: NA
Text: Scheme Act 2010 to ensure that self-

Speaker: NA
Text: employed midwives can access the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth contribution. Essentially,

Speaker: NA
Text: this bill tidies up minor technical errors by

Speaker: NA
Text: placing the intended words in a more

Speaker: NA
Text: appropriate section of the act and corrects a

Speaker: NA
Text: typographical error.

Speaker: NA
Text: This bill is an important component of the

Speaker: NA
Text: government's maternity reform package. The

Speaker: NA
Text: package aims to improve the choices that are

Speaker: NA
Text: available to women in relation to maternity

Speaker: NA
Text: care. The total cost over four years of the

Speaker: NA
Text: professional indemnity for midwives

Speaker: NA
Text: component of the package is $25.2 million. I

Speaker: NA
Text: commend these changes to the House.

Speaker: NA
Text: Women and their babies must be the focus

Speaker: NA
Text: of maternity care. They should be able to feel

Speaker: NA
Text: they are in control of what is happening

Speaker: NA
Text: during pregnancy, childbirth and the

Speaker: NA
Text: postnatal period, based on their individual

Speaker: NA
Text: needs and having discussed the issues fully

Speaker: NA
Text: with their care providers. Australian women

Speaker: NA
Text: and their babies should be able to access

Speaker: NA
Text: high-quality, safe maternity services.

Speaker: NA
Text: This government has a proud record of

Speaker: NA
Text: delivering better health services for all

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians. Helping Australia's hospital

Speaker: NA
Text: system to recover from the dark days of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Howard-Abbott years was a daunting task

Speaker: NA
Text: for Labor when we came to office in 2007.

Speaker: NA
Text: In 2008 we boosted hospital funding by $20

Speaker: NA
Text: billion, a 50 per cent increase. We have also

Speaker: NA
Text: invested over $2.4 billion in health

Speaker: NA
Text: workforce measures. That is helping us to

Speaker: NA
Text: train over 1,000 nurses each year and double

Speaker: NA
Text: the number of GPs in training, and we have

Speaker: NA
Text: seen the Commonwealth's specialist training

Speaker: NA
Text: program expand from just 51, when Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Abbott was the health minister, to 518 this

Speaker: NA
Text: year. Plus, we have made a record $872.1

Speaker: NA
Text: million investment in preventative health.

Speaker: NA
Text: And just last night we announced measures

Speaker: NA
Text: to assist those with a mental illness.

Speaker: NA
Text: The government is delivering major

Speaker: NA
Text: reforms across the health system to improve

Speaker: NA
Text: the quality of services, responsiveness at a

Speaker: NA
Text: local level and access to care. We are

Speaker: NA
Text: governing for Australia's future. We are

Speaker: NA
Text: supporting Australian families. This is a

Speaker: NA
Text: small but important amendment. I

Speaker: NA
Text: congratulate those opposite, as they do

Speaker: NA
Text: support this amendment because it promotes

Speaker: NA
Text: choice and protects our valuable midwives.

Speaker: Mr CIOBO
Text: Moncrieff) (11:40): I rise to

Speaker: NA
Text: the speak to the Midwife Professional

Speaker: NA
Text: Indemnity Legislation Amendment Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: 2011, an important bill because it goes

Speaker: NA
Text: towards providing greater certainty and

Speaker: NA
Text: assurance to those midwives who are

Speaker: NA
Text: employed in their own businesses, in

Speaker: NA
Text: particular, following a series of changes

Speaker: NA
Text: were made in the Midwife Professional

Speaker: NA
Text: Indemnity (Commonwealth Contribution)

Speaker: NA
Text: Scheme Act 2010.

Speaker: NA
Text: Under this bill, which is relatively

Speaker: NA
Text: technical in nature, there have been changes

Speaker: NA
Text: made to ensure that self-employed midwives

Speaker: NA
Text: are able to access the Midwife Professional

Speaker: NA
Text: Indemnity Scheme. The bill also amends the

Speaker: NA
Text: Midwife Professional Indemnity (Run-Off

Speaker: NA
Text: Cover Support Payment) Act 2010 to ensure

Speaker: NA
Text: that the tax on insurers of eligible midwives

Speaker: NA
Text: is correctly calculated, after there was a

Speaker: NA
Text: typographical error in the act that imposed a

Speaker: NA
Text: much higher tax on the premium income of

Speaker: NA
Text: insurers of midwives.

Speaker: NA
Text: The situation that arose was that the tax

Speaker: NA
Text: payable exceeded the premium that was

Speaker: NA
Text: going to be charged. We are informed, as

Speaker: NA
Text: members of the opposition, that this was an

Speaker: NA
Text: unintentional consequence of a typographical

Speaker: NA
Text: error within the act. To the extent that this

Speaker: NA
Text: bill clarifies the intent of the original

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation and provides the assurance that is

Speaker: NA
Text: sought, the coalition is certainly supportive

Speaker: NA
Text: of it, as am I, as a member of the coalition.

Speaker: NA
Text: The role of midwives is crucial. My wife

Speaker: NA
Text: and I had the opportunity and indeed the

Speaker: NA
Text: great joy of having a child a little over two

Speaker: NA
Text: years ago now. There is no doubt that, for

Speaker: NA
Text: many women, midwives are a source of solid

Speaker: NA
Text: support, reassurance and knowledge when

Speaker: NA
Text: they take the journey of childbirth. The

Speaker: NA
Text: government should do anything it can to

Speaker: NA
Text: make it easier for women to practise the art

Speaker: NA
Text: of midwifery without the risk of there being

Speaker: NA
Text: a successful lawsuit hanging over their head

Speaker: NA
Text: for practices that are not negligent or

Speaker: NA
Text: reckless.

Speaker: NA
Text: We know that in past years there has been

Speaker: NA
Text: a massive increase in the number of tort

Speaker: NA
Text: actions against, amongst others, midwives.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have seen the repercussions, with there

Speaker: NA
Text: that being a large decrease in the number of

Speaker: NA
Text: midwives seeking to practise and changes in

Speaker: NA
Text: the structures that midwives adopt as

Speaker: NA
Text: employees, self-employed members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: community and indeed small business

Speaker: NA
Text: operators and proprietors, as they may well

Speaker: NA
Text: be.

Speaker: NA
Text: This bill before the House today provides

Speaker: NA
Text: certainty. It delivers on the policy intent of

Speaker: NA
Text: making sure that there is support for them to

Speaker: NA
Text: undertake their practices, given their

Speaker: NA
Text: importance in the community and making

Speaker: NA
Text: sure that we as a society recognise that

Speaker: NA
Text: women seek support when they go through

Speaker: NA
Text: the process of childbirth and in the many

Speaker: NA
Text: months leading up to it.

Speaker: NA
Text: As a husband, there was reassurance for

Speaker: NA
Text: me too to know that there was perhaps an

Speaker: NA
Text: alternative source of information that my

Speaker: NA
Text: wife could turn to beyond my mother-in-law

Speaker: NA
Text: or sisters. I was just grateful, frankly,

Speaker: NA
Text: wasn't me. In that vein, I think that we

Speaker: NA
Text: should be doing all that we can to make sure

Speaker: NA
Text: that the fine and delicate art of being a

Speaker: NA
Text: midwife is kept alive for as long as possible.

Speaker: NA
Text: It seems to me that, if anything should be

Speaker: NA
Text: labelled 'secret women's business', perhaps

Speaker: NA
Text: this should be. But then again that might just

Speaker: NA
Text: be an old-fashioned Steve Ciobo talking,

Speaker: NA
Text: rather than someone who is necessarily the

Speaker: NA
Text: most up-to-date-

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: Mr CIOBO
Text: snag. Having said all that,

Speaker: NA
Text: there remain some matters of interest for me

Speaker: NA
Text: that I have looked into with respect to

Speaker: NA
Text: midwifery for some of my constituents and

Speaker: NA
Text: which still to some extent remain unresolved,

Speaker: NA
Text: and they are around the issue of home births.

Speaker: NA
Text: We know that for many individuals the

Speaker: NA
Text: location they choose for having their child is

Speaker: NA
Text: a very personal choice. It might be in a

Speaker: NA
Text: hospital, but there are a number of women, I

Speaker: NA
Text: recognise, who hold the fundamental view

Speaker: NA
Text: that childbirth is a very natural thing-not

Speaker: NA
Text: something that requires

Speaker: NA
Text: intervention-and they often choose to have

Speaker: NA
Text: their child in the familiar, comfortable

Speaker: NA
Text: surroundings of their home. For those

Speaker: NA
Text: midwives who practice their art or their skills

Speaker: NA
Text: in people's homes, there is still, I am told by

Speaker: NA
Text: those in that industry, some uncertainty

Speaker: NA
Text: about their legal liabilities and their level of

Speaker: NA
Text: protection for homebirths. Although this act

Speaker: NA
Text: does not go directly to that matter, it is

Speaker: NA
Text: important to recognise that there are very

Speaker: NA
Text: active and vocal groups in many

Speaker: NA
Text: communities, not just in my own, who hold

Speaker: NA
Text: the view that we should be doing more to

Speaker: NA
Text: facilitate things for those women who would

Speaker: NA
Text: like to be midwives and for those women

Speaker: NA
Text: who would like to give birth in their own

Speaker: NA
Text: homes.

Speaker: NA
Text: So I just put on the record my support for

Speaker: NA
Text: those who choose to go down that path. It

Speaker: NA
Text: that it was not the pathway that my wife and I

Speaker: NA
Text: chose to go down. Notwithstanding that, I

Speaker: NA
Text: recognise it as a personal choice, a choice

Speaker: NA
Text: that many women make. Again, in that

Speaker: NA
Text: sense, I think policy should be directed

Speaker: NA
Text: towards assisting them, recognising, though,

Speaker: NA
Text: what for me was an inescapable fact-that

Speaker: NA
Text: there is, I believe, an elevated risk as a result

Speaker: NA
Text: of homebirths. That elevated risk

Speaker: NA
Text: notwithstanding, the reality is that there is of

Speaker: NA
Text: course no aspect of life that is without risk

Speaker: NA
Text: and I recognise the rights of those who

Speaker: NA
Text: choose to have their child in their own home.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am certainly pleased to support the bill

Speaker: NA
Text: before the House today. I recognise that it

Speaker: NA
Text: comes as a consequence of a typographical

Speaker: NA
Text: error. You would have thought, perhaps, that

Speaker: NA
Text: with so many eyes in the executive checking

Speaker: NA
Text: this legislation, and with so many others

Speaker: NA
Text: checking it, these kinds of errors would not

Speaker: NA
Text: take place. That notwithstanding, it has taken

Speaker: NA
Text: place, but it is being corrected and the

Speaker: NA
Text: opposition supports that. I commend the bill

Speaker: NA
Text: to the House.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr CRAIG THOMSON (Dobell)

Speaker: NA
Text: (11:51): I rise to support this piece of

Speaker: NA
Text: important legislation. The purpose of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Midwife Professional Indemnity

Speaker: NA
Text: (Commonwealth Contribution) Scheme Act

Speaker: NA
Text: 2010 and the associated Midwife

Speaker: NA
Text: Professional Indemnity (Run-off Cover

Speaker: NA
Text: Support Payment) Act 2011 was to support

Speaker: NA
Text: the new MBS and PBS arrangements by

Speaker: NA
Text: enabling the establishment of a government

Speaker: NA
Text: supported professional indemnity scheme for

Speaker: NA
Text: eligible midwives from 1 July last year.

Speaker: NA
Text: Those acts removed a longstanding barrier to

Speaker: NA
Text: appropriately qualified and experienced

Speaker: NA
Text: midwives wishing to provide high-quality

Speaker: NA
Text: midwifery services to Australian women as

Speaker: NA
Text: part of a collaborative team with doctors and

Speaker: NA
Text: other health professionals.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Midwife Professional Indemnity

Speaker: NA
Text: (Commonwealth Contribution Scheme) Act

Speaker: NA
Text: 2010 currently excludes employed midwives

Speaker: NA
Text: from accessing a Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: contribution and a run-off

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth contribution. This exclusion

Speaker: NA
Text: is to ensure that there is no intentional

Speaker: NA
Text: shifting from employers of midwives to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth. The bill tidies up the act by

Speaker: NA
Text: placing the rule-making powers in a more

Speaker: NA
Text: appropriate section and thus ensures that

Speaker: NA
Text: eligible self-employed midwives are not

Speaker: NA
Text: excluded from access to Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: contributions for claims that are made while

Speaker: NA
Text: they are in the workforce or for any claims

Speaker: NA
Text: that are made after they retire. By doing

Speaker: NA
Text: the act will continue to exclude other

Speaker: NA
Text: employed midwives, such as those employed

Speaker: NA
Text: by private hospitals, to prevent the cost-

Speaker: NA
Text: shifting-already referred to-from that

Speaker: NA
Text: sector to the Commonwealth by employers.

Speaker: NA
Text: The changes to the act proposed by this

Speaker: NA
Text: bill will also allow a specific rule-making

Speaker: NA
Text: power to appropriately address any new and

Speaker: NA
Text: innovative midwife self-employment models

Speaker: NA
Text: that may arise in the future. This was an

Speaker: NA
Text: issue of particular concern to midwives when

Speaker: NA
Text: the previous bills were before the parliament.

Speaker: NA
Text: This rule-making power will ensure the bill

Speaker: NA
Text: will be able to accurately describe midwives

Speaker: NA
Text: and employment arrangements which are

Speaker: NA
Text: within the scope of the government's

Speaker: NA
Text: maternity reform policy.

Speaker: NA
Text: The bill also corrects a typographical error

Speaker: NA
Text: in the Midwife Professional Indemnity (Run-

Speaker: NA
Text: Off Cover Support Payment) Act 2010

Speaker: NA
Text: which would, if left unchanged, impose a

Speaker: NA
Text: higher than intended tax on insurers of

Speaker: NA
Text: eligible midwives. The Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: government is proud to be implementing

Speaker: NA
Text: historic reforms to maternity care which

Speaker: NA
Text: recognise the skills of our highly trained

Speaker: NA
Text: midwives and provide more choice for

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian women while maintaining

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's strong record of high-quality, safe

Speaker: NA
Text: maternity services.

Speaker: NA
Text: I will spend a little bit of time looking at

Speaker: NA
Text: cover the background to these reforms. Improving

Speaker: NA
Text: maternity services in Australia: the report of

Speaker: NA
Text: costthe Maternity Services Review highlighted

Speaker: NA
Text: the complex nature of maternity services,

Speaker: NA
Text: which involve a mix of Commonwealth,

Speaker: NA
Text: state, territory and private arrangements. The

Speaker: NA
Text: report was developed following consultation

Speaker: NA
Text: with a broad range of stakeholders including

Speaker: NA
Text: individuals, health professionals, industry

Speaker: NA
Text: groups, researchers, professional

Speaker: NA
Text: organisations and national peak bodies. The

Speaker: NA
Text: this, report made a number of recommendations

Speaker: NA
Text: which focused on the need to improve

Speaker: NA
Text: maternal and peri-natal outcomes for

Speaker: NA
Text: Indigenous and rural Australians, improve

Speaker: NA
Text: choices available for pregnant women,

Speaker: NA
Text: increase access to high-quality maternity

Speaker: NA
Text: services and provide support for the

Speaker: NA
Text: maternity services workforce.

Speaker: NA
Text: The government responded to the report

Speaker: NA
Text: with a $120.5 million package to provide

Speaker: NA
Text: access for midwives to the Medicare

Speaker: NA
Text: Benefits Schedule and to Pharmaceutical

Speaker: NA
Text: Benefits Scheme medicines, and a

Speaker: NA
Text: government supported professional

Speaker: NA
Text: indemnity insurance scheme for eligible

Speaker: NA
Text: midwives. On 24 June 2009, the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Health and Ageing introduced legislation to

Speaker: NA
Text: facilitate these new arrangements. These

Speaker: NA
Text: arrangements are available for appropriately

Speaker: NA
Text: qualified and experienced midwives working

Speaker: NA
Text: in cooperation with obstetricians and health

Speaker: NA
Text: facilities as recommended by the report.

Speaker: NA
Text: These changes enable the clients of

Speaker: NA
Text: midwives and nurse practitioners to access

Speaker: NA
Text: services and medications subsidised by the

Speaker: NA
Text: MBS and PBS. There are currently around

Speaker: NA
Text: 350 qualified nurse practitioners in Australia,

Speaker: NA
Text: generally working in public hospitals.

Speaker: NA
Text: Initially about 50 nurse practitioners were

Speaker: NA
Text: expected to access the MBS and PBS for

Speaker: NA
Text: their clients in certain private and

Speaker: NA
Text: community settings, particularly in primary

Speaker: NA
Text: care and rural areas, from November 2010.

Speaker: NA
Text: For midwives to be eligible to participate

Speaker: NA
Text: in the new arrangements, they needed to

Speaker: NA
Text: meet advanced practice requirements and to

Speaker: NA
Text: have had collaborative arrangements with

Speaker: NA
Text: doctors. These requirements

Speaker: NA
Text: collaborative arrangements were developed

Speaker: NA
Text: in consultation with midwives, doctors and

Speaker: NA
Text: other stakeholders. The reform initiatives

Speaker: NA
Text: supported by this legislation allow for

Speaker: NA
Text: incremental reform within a strong

Speaker: NA
Text: framework of quality and safety. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: expected that around 700 eligible midwives

Speaker: NA
Text: will be participating in this measure over the

Speaker: NA
Text: next three years. The government

Speaker: NA
Text: understands the concerns in the community

Speaker: NA
Text: about registration and professional indemnity

Speaker: NA
Text: insurance and how this affects the

Speaker: NA
Text: involvement of midwives in homebirths. Our

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation has expanded Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: support for midwives and nurse practitioners

Speaker: NA
Text: in our community. They improve choice and

Speaker: NA
Text: extend Commonwealth funding for a range

Speaker: NA
Text: of midwife and nurse practitioner services

Speaker: NA
Text: for the first time ever, including providing

Speaker: NA
Text: antenatal care in the community and

Speaker: NA
Text: attending births in clinical settings. None of

Speaker: NA
Text: these bills have made homebirth unlawful.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, under an agreement made last

Speaker: NA
Text: year the states, territories and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth agreed to a two-year

Speaker: NA
Text: exemption for homebirthing midwives who

Speaker: NA
Text: are acting not within the state hospital

Speaker: NA
Text: system but in the private sector. A number of

Speaker: NA
Text: conditions and requirements were attached to

Speaker: NA
Text: that exemption, including that a

Speaker: NA
Text: homebirthing midwife must disclose to a

Speaker: NA
Text: mother who is interested in having a

Speaker: NA
Text: homebirth that they will not be insured for

Speaker: NA
Text: that procedure and making sure that people

Speaker: NA
Text: make an informed choice about undertaking

Speaker: NA
Text: a homebirth. The government asked

Speaker: NA
Text: homebirthing midwives to report each

Speaker: NA
Text: homebirth.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is currently not any good data

Speaker: NA
Text: across the country of how many homebirths

Speaker: NA
Text: actually occur. Independent midwives are

Speaker: NA
Text: not currently required to notify state and

Speaker: NA
Text: territory authorities or hospitals, nor have

Speaker: NA
Text: they been asked to. We will require,

Speaker: NA
Text: and however, participation in quality and safety

Speaker: NA
Text: frameworks-for example, reporting the

Speaker: NA
Text: results of homebirthing and incidents that are

Speaker: NA
Text: related to it.

Speaker: NA
Text: The government wants this work to be

Speaker: NA
Text: done collaboratively, by way of a peer

Speaker: NA
Text: review process. The consultation process is

Speaker: NA
Text: being overseen by Victoria through the

Speaker: NA
Text: national registration and accreditation

Speaker: NA
Text: process. The national Nursing and

Speaker: NA
Text: Midwifery Board will provide advice and

Speaker: NA
Text: protocols for homebirthing outside the

Speaker: NA
Text: publicly funded and auspiced services.

Speaker: NA
Text: Privately practising midwives-some of

Speaker: NA
Text: whom currently provide homebirthing

Speaker: NA
Text: services but do it as part of their

Speaker: NA
Text: employment, either with the state or with a

Speaker: NA
Text: private practising obstetrician-would not be

Speaker: NA
Text: affected by these changes as their insurance

Speaker: NA
Text: is already covered through their employment

Speaker: NA
Text: status. Clearly this arrangement will not

Speaker: NA
Text: apply in jurisdictions where no lawful

Speaker: NA
Text: homebirthing is occurring.

Speaker: NA
Text: The two-year exemption allows plenty

Speaker: NA
Text: more time for those protocols to be

Speaker: NA
Text: established and to be worked on. In the

Speaker: NA
Text: meantime, the arrangements ensure that

Speaker: NA
Text: homebirthing midwives can lawfully

Speaker: NA
Text: continue to provide the services in the

Speaker: NA
Text: jurisdictions currently allowed. They will

Speaker: NA
Text: continue to be uninsured-as they are

Speaker: NA
Text: currently. The government is collecting more

Speaker: NA
Text: data on homebirthing and there will be a

Speaker: NA
Text: process to further work through these

Speaker: NA
Text: protocols that would either bring more

Speaker: NA
Text: homebirthing services into the public system

Speaker: NA
Text: or potentially open the way in the future for

Speaker: NA
Text: an insurance product to be extended to cover

Speaker: NA
Text: them.

Speaker: NA
Text: Homebirthing programs operate in a

Speaker: NA
Text: number of state and territory systems with

Speaker: NA
Text: participating midwives coming under the

Speaker: NA
Text: insurance cover of the public health system.

Speaker: NA
Text: Midwives who provide maternity services in

Speaker: NA
Text: an independent private capacity, including

Speaker: NA
Text: assisting with homebirths, currently do so

Speaker: NA
Text: without indemnity cover as there are no

Speaker: NA
Text: products currently commercially available.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have met on a number of occasions with

Speaker: NA
Text: my local representatives of the Maternity

Speaker: NA
Text: Coalition. In fact, I first attended a meeting

Speaker: NA
Text: in my electorate of Dobell on the Central

Speaker: NA
Text: Coast some three years ago where these

Speaker: NA
Text: concerns were raised. They are legitimate

Speaker: NA
Text: concerns about making sure

Speaker: NA
Text: homebirthing is there as a choice for women.

Speaker: NA
Text: While homebirthing has been very much in

Speaker: NA
Text: the minority-in fact, much less than one per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent of pregnant women choose to give birth

Speaker: NA
Text: at home in Australia-it has nonetheless

Speaker: NA
Text: been at the forefront of innovation in relation

Speaker: NA
Text: to birthing. Water births and the like were

Speaker: NA
Text: products of homebirths. Everyone in this

Speaker: NA
Text: place must be a little concerned at the

Speaker: NA
Text: extremely high rates of caesarean operations

Speaker: NA
Text: in this country-well over 30 per cent, when

Speaker: NA
Text: the World Health Organisation talks about

Speaker: NA
Text: 15 per cent being around what would occur

Speaker: NA
Text: in most communities. On the Central Coast

Speaker: NA
Text: that problem is even greater, with Gosford

Speaker: NA
Text: Private Hospital having caesarean rates in

Speaker: NA
Text: excess of 50 per cent and Gosford Public

Speaker: NA
Text: Hospital having caesarean rates in excess of

Speaker: NA
Text: 40 per cent. So you can understand that

Speaker: NA
Text: women on the Central Coast do want to have

Speaker: NA
Text: options that involve midwives-so that a

Speaker: NA
Text: caesarean is much less likely.

Speaker: NA
Text: In March 2009, the Council of Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Governments signed an intergovernmental

Speaker: NA
Text: agreement to implement a single indemnity

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme which came into effect in July 2010.

Speaker: NA
Text: The scheme initially covered 10 health

Speaker: NA
Text: professions-medicine, nursing, midwifery,

Speaker: NA
Text: pharmacy, physiotherapy, podiatry,

Speaker: NA
Text: osteopathy, chiropractic, optometry and

Speaker: NA
Text: dental care including dentists, dental

Speaker: NA
Text: therapists, dental hygienists and dental

Speaker: NA
Text: prosthetists-and psychologists. Under the

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme there is a requirement for

Speaker: NA
Text: professional indemnity insurance as a

Speaker: NA
Text: mandatory condition of registration for all

Speaker: NA
Text: health professionals, including midwives.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is an important part of raising standards

Speaker: NA
Text: and providing public protection for patients

Speaker: NA
Text: and consumers. The Australian government

Speaker: NA
Text: is committed to building on our previous

Speaker: NA
Text: budget maternity services reform packages

Speaker: NA
Text: that by working with the states and territories and

Speaker: NA
Text: with key stakeholders, to develop a national

Speaker: NA
Text: maternity service plan to ensure coordination

Speaker: NA
Text: of maternity services across Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: Many members have previously spoken

Speaker: NA
Text: about their personal experiences in relation

Speaker: NA
Text: to midwifery. I would like to share with the

Speaker: NA
Text: House some of mine, too. My daughter

Speaker: NA
Text: Matilda was born at Wyong Hospital where

Speaker: NA
Text: the only service is midwifery. So in some

Speaker: NA
Text: areas, workforce shortages mean that choices

Speaker: NA
Text: for women are limited. We had a terrific

Speaker: NA
Text: experience with a midwife. In fact, we are

Speaker: NA
Text: pregnant again and we are going back to the

Speaker: NA
Text: same midwife. Our experience of the

Speaker: NA
Text: midwifery profession was very positive. At

Speaker: NA
Text: Wyong Hospital, there is a room which looks

Speaker: NA
Text: like any room you would have at home with

Speaker: NA
Text: a big bath and a bed and a midwife to guide

Speaker: NA
Text: you. You do not have the option of epidurals

Speaker: NA
Text: because there is not an obstetrician available

Speaker: NA
Text: at Wyong Hospital. Mothers who are at

Speaker: NA
Text: potential risk are automatically transferred

Speaker: NA
Text: Gosford Public Hospital. The group of

Speaker: NA
Text: mothers who have the opportunity to be

Speaker: NA
Text: involved with a midwife are certainly

Speaker: NA
Text: screened. That is very appropriate in making

Speaker: NA
Text: sure that we maintain safe outcomes for

Speaker: NA
Text: women giving birth. If developments in the

Speaker: NA
Text: birth cause concern, mothers

Speaker: NA
Text: immediately transferred by ambulance to

Speaker: NA
Text: Gosford hospital, 10 minutes down the road,

Speaker: NA
Text: where obstetricians and medical practitioners

Speaker: NA
Text: are available. In a sense, our region provides

Speaker: NA
Text: a choice through necessity rather than

Speaker: NA
Text: through anything else. I am very much in

Speaker: NA
Text: favour of making sure that homebirths are an

Speaker: NA
Text: option because of the terrific experiences

Speaker: NA
Text: that many women have had on the Central

Speaker: NA
Text: Coast, including my wife. This is an

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity to thank our midwife, Val

Speaker: NA
Text: Paynter, who has assisted in the births of

Speaker: NA
Text: hundreds of babies in the 30 years that she

Speaker: NA
Text: has been a midwife on the Central Coast. She

Speaker: NA
Text: is a great midwife and we were incredibly

Speaker: NA
Text: lucky. She has been midwife of the year

Speaker: NA
Text: twice, so we are indebted on the Central

Speaker: NA
Text: Coast for having someone of her experience

Speaker: NA
Text: there.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is an important issue and shows that

Speaker: NA
Text: we need to make sure that there are different

Speaker: NA
Text: models available so that women have choice

Speaker: NA
Text: and are given the maximum number of

Speaker: NA
Text: options. Not all women will choose to have

Speaker: NA
Text: birth assistance from a midwife, but those

Speaker: NA
Text: who do should be able to have that option.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is important legislation that builds

Speaker: NA
Text: the reforms. It builds on

Speaker: NA
Text: recommendations made to the government

Speaker: NA
Text: back in 2009. This government has acted on

Speaker: NA
Text: those recommendations. It is important that

Speaker: NA
Text: this bill is supported, and I note that the

Speaker: NA
Text: opposition are supporting it and that is very

Speaker: NA
Text: much appreciated. This is part of the ongoing

Speaker: NA
Text: reform to make sure that women have better

Speaker: NA
Text: choices and that we maintain the high quality

Speaker: NA
Text: and high safety standards that exist in our

Speaker: NA
Text: to maternity services throughout Australia. I

Speaker: NA
Text: commend this bill to the House.

Speaker: Dr STONE
Text: Murray) (12:01): The

Speaker: NA
Text: Midwife Professional Indemnity Legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: Amendment Bill 2011 is a very important

Speaker: NA
Text: piece of legislation. It aims to correct two

Speaker: NA
Text: serious flaws in the Midwife Professional

Speaker: NA
Text: are Indemnity (Commonwealth Contribution)

Speaker: NA
Text: Scheme Act 2010. Once amended, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: coalition supports this amendment, this will

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure self-employed midwives can access

Speaker: NA
Text: the insurance scheme-what an absurd

Speaker: NA
Text: omission that was at the time.

Speaker: NA
Text: The amendments also aim to fix up the

Speaker: NA
Text: Midwife Professional Indemnity (Run-off

Speaker: NA
Text: Cover Support Payment) Act 2010. The error

Speaker: NA
Text: in the latter act was a miscalculation which

Speaker: NA
Text: imposed a far higher tax on the premium

Speaker: NA
Text: income of insurers of midwives. The insurer

Speaker: NA
Text: would have paid more in tax than the entirety

Speaker: NA
Text: of the net premium. This has been passed off

Speaker: NA
Text: by the government as a typographical error,

Speaker: NA
Text: but it really is another example of sloppy

Speaker: NA
Text: policymaking that has had enormous

Speaker: NA
Text: implications for the profession of midwifery.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is a profession that has been under strain

Speaker: NA
Text: and stress for generations in this country as

Speaker: NA
Text: the competition continues between the so-

Speaker: NA
Text: called rights of doctors-mostly male

Speaker: NA
Text: doctors-to deliver babies compared to the

Speaker: NA
Text: rights of women and families to have choice,

Speaker: NA
Text: and to have that choice include midwives

Speaker: NA
Text: who are properly and appropriately insured.

Speaker: NA
Text: Obviously, we the coalition support the

Speaker: NA
Text: on amendments to the act. We want to allow

Speaker: NA
Text: the self-employed midwives into the scheme

Speaker: NA
Text: which gives a Commonwealth contribution

Speaker: NA
Text: to the insurer for the cost of eligible midwife

Speaker: NA
Text: claims. We support the correction of the so-

Speaker: NA
Text: called typographical error which imposed the

Speaker: NA
Text: wrong tax calculation on the insurer. But

Speaker: NA
Text: midwives continue to wonder what this

Speaker: NA
Text: government has against highly qualified and

Speaker: NA
Text: experienced midwives being able to take out

Speaker: NA
Text: government supported insurance for home

Speaker: NA
Text: births. Particularly for many in rural and

Speaker: NA
Text: regional Australia, a home birth can be not

Speaker: NA
Text: only a preferred way to have the joy of new

Speaker: NA
Text: baby come into the home but also the safest

Speaker: NA
Text: and best option when you are many

Speaker: NA
Text: kilometres away from a hospital or when the

Speaker: NA
Text: travelling conditions are difficult. In some

Speaker: NA
Text: sort of emergency, like our recent floods, a

Speaker: NA
Text: lot of our women are better off by being

Speaker: NA
Text: assured that a home birth is an option if a

Speaker: NA
Text: professionally qualified woman is nearby.

Speaker: NA
Text: Under this government's policy, midwives

Speaker: NA
Text: assisting with home births are still not able

Speaker: NA
Text: be insured. They have a two-year exemption

Speaker: NA
Text: for insurance cover, which will run out in

Speaker: NA
Text: June 2012. Why can't these women come

Speaker: NA
Text: under this Commonwealth assisted MIGA

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme right now? The lack of security

Speaker: NA
Text: about their futures and their insurance status

Speaker: NA
Text: is obviously very problematic. Meanwhile,

Speaker: NA
Text: the absurdity is that all midwives-whether

Speaker: NA
Text: they are assisting in home births or not-

Speaker: NA
Text: must have insurance for the anteand post-

Speaker: NA
Text: natal consultations, which are invariably part

Speaker: NA
Text: of a home birth program. So the whole thing

Speaker: NA
Text: is absolutely absurd. Midwives cannot get

Speaker: NA
Text: insurance for the home delivery, but they

Speaker: NA
Text: must have insurance for their support visits

Speaker: NA
Text: before and after the birth. This system can

Speaker: NA
Text: make for a serious problem, obviously, if a

Speaker: NA
Text: midwife wants to work with a team of other

Speaker: NA
Text: professional midwives but they do not have

Speaker: NA
Text: the special insurance that is required to cover

Speaker: NA
Text: home births and postand pre-natal

Speaker: NA
Text: consultations.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is another very serious problem

Speaker: NA
Text: with this legislation and the government's

Speaker: NA
Text: policy, and it again particularly affects rural

Speaker: NA
Text: communities. It is a fact that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth insurance program, which

Speaker: NA
Text: uses the Medical Insurance Group Australia,

Speaker: NA
Text: will not insure midwives who are called to

Speaker: NA
Text: assist in fewer than 30 baby deliveries per

Speaker: NA
Text: year. It might be fine in metropolitan

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia for a midwife to give assistance in

Speaker: NA
Text: more than 30 deliveries a year-they may

Speaker: NA
Text: assist in 30, 50 or 80 deliveries a year-but

Speaker: NA
Text: in regional Australia many midwives are

Speaker: NA
Text: very busy and fully employed in doing a

Speaker: NA
Text: range of postand pre-natal support, but do

Speaker: NA
Text: not assist in more than 30 deliveries a year.

Speaker: NA
Text: Under this scheme they are not insurable

Speaker: NA
Text: because they do not have the magic 30

Speaker: NA
Text: deliveries a year that make them eligible for

Speaker: NA
Text: this MIGA scheme. I ask this government to

Speaker: NA
Text: to immediately address this problem because it

Speaker: NA
Text: is a serious issue for highly professional

Speaker: NA
Text: midwives in rural and regional areas, who

Speaker: NA
Text: often have even more years of midwifery

Speaker: NA
Text: experience than their sisters in metropolitan

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: Under this government's policy and the

Speaker: NA
Text: MIGA involvement in the insurance for

Speaker: NA
Text: midwives you need to have at least three

Speaker: NA
Text: years professional post-graduation

Speaker: NA
Text: experience before you are eligible to access

Speaker: NA
Text: the insurance scheme. That is absurd. So a

Speaker: NA
Text: young midwife who has just completed her

Speaker: NA
Text: training, who has graduated and who is a

Speaker: NA
Text: professional midwife cannot access this

Speaker: NA
Text: government supported insurance scheme for

Speaker: NA
Text: three years. What other profession has that

Speaker: NA
Text: sort of constraint? What does that do to a

Speaker: NA
Text: young woman planning to become a midwife

Speaker: NA
Text: when she realises that for the first three years

Speaker: NA
Text: she is going to have exceptionally higher

Speaker: NA
Text: costs in trying to find some insurance-if she

Speaker: NA
Text: can-to cover that three-year period? It is

Speaker: NA
Text: extremely difficult. I refer in particular to Ms

Speaker: NA
Text: Andrea Quanchi. She is a midwife with 25-

Speaker: NA
Text: plus years experience. Her daughter recently

Speaker: NA
Text: graduated and of course she is not eligible

Speaker: NA
Text: for insurance right now. She wants to join

Speaker: NA
Text: her mother as a midwife in private practice.

Speaker: NA
Text: Andrea is a brilliant, professional and highly

Speaker: NA
Text: respected midwife who is the only midwife

Speaker: NA
Text: in private practice serving a large part of

Speaker: NA
Text: southern New South Wales and all of

Speaker: NA
Text: northern Victoria. She is an extraordinary

Speaker: NA
Text: woman doing an extraordinary job. Her

Speaker: NA
Text: services are much sought after, but she is

Speaker: NA
Text: caught in this insurance trap whereby

Speaker: NA
Text: midwives must perform homebirths without

Speaker: NA
Text: insurance for two years. She is caught in the

Speaker: NA
Text: trap where she cannot bring on newly

Speaker: NA
Text: qualified midwives to assist her in

Speaker: NA
Text: homebirthing because of the three-year rule.

Speaker: NA
Text: She is also caught in the trap where she

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot get assistance from other midwives to

Speaker: NA
Text: do preand postnatal consultations with her

Speaker: NA
Text: homebirthing patients because those

Speaker: NA
Text: professional midwives must have the

Speaker: NA
Text: insurance to undertake preand postnatal

Speaker: NA
Text: visits.

Speaker: NA
Text: There was an incident recently in my part

Speaker: NA
Text: of the world during the very serious

Speaker: NA
Text: flooding. Ms Quanchi had a patient who had
