Speaker: NA
Text: given birth but, unfortunately, she was on

Speaker: NA
Text: other side of the floodwaters. She asked a

Speaker: NA
Text: very competent local midwife to undertake

Speaker: NA
Text: the postnatal consultation for her but found

Speaker: NA
Text: that this midwife did not have the insurance.

Speaker: NA
Text: She then approached the local Wangaratta

Speaker: NA
Text: hospital and was told they could not support

Speaker: NA
Text: her because it had been a homebirth and, 'It

Speaker: NA
Text: was her problem.'

Speaker: NA
Text: The member for Lyne

Speaker: NA
Text: homebirthing. In Australia, we should have

Speaker: NA
Text: the option to homebirth and with the birth of

Speaker: NA
Text: subsequent children enjoy the special

Speaker: NA
Text: additional support that is provided to women

Speaker: NA
Text: in the home. As our previous speaker

Speaker: NA
Text: highlighted, in Australia we have some of

Speaker: NA
Text: the highest levels of medical interventions in

Speaker: NA
Text: births in the developed world. An

Speaker: NA
Text: extraordinary number of caesareans are

Speaker: NA
Text: undertaken and too often it seems those

Speaker: NA
Text: caesareans are undertaken for the

Speaker: NA
Text: convenience of the medical profession rather

Speaker: NA
Text: than for the best health considerations of the

Speaker: NA
Text: women who are delivering.

Speaker: NA
Text: As everybody knows, we have a chronic

Speaker: NA
Text: shortage of obstetricians and gynaecologists

Speaker: NA
Text: in rural Victoria, and indeed throughout rural

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. That is why highly professional,

Speaker: NA
Text: competent midwives are so critical to the

Speaker: NA
Text: delivery of health services in rural Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: It again highlights the problem with this

Speaker: NA
Text: government's refusal to amend its

Speaker: NA
Text: catastrophic independent youth allowance

Speaker: NA
Text: policy. The independent youth allowance

Speaker: NA
Text: enabled country students who had finished

Speaker: NA
Text: year 12 and been offered university places-

Speaker: NA
Text: for example, in nursing-to go somewhere

Speaker: NA
Text: else to train, typically in a capital city. Those

Speaker: NA
Text: would be future nurses cannot now access

Speaker: NA
Text: nursing training and midwifery training

Speaker: NA
Text: because too often their families cannot afford

Speaker: NA
Text: the $20,000 or more that it costs for country

Speaker: NA
Text: students to be supported in their studies

Speaker: NA
Text: while living away from home.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have the absurd situation now from

Speaker: NA
Text: the yesterday's budget where another 16,000

Speaker: NA
Text: skilled migrants will be admitted into rural

Speaker: NA
Text: and regional areas under the regional skilled

Speaker: NA
Text: migration scheme. On the other hand, we

Speaker: NA
Text: have discrimination in the access to the

Speaker: NA
Text: independent youth allowance-

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Ms AE

Speaker: NA
Text: Burke): Order! I think I have been very

Speaker: NA
Text: generous to the member for Murray. I ask

Speaker: NA
Text: praised her to come back to the bill before the

Speaker: NA
Text: House.

Speaker: Dr STONE
Text: The point I was making is

Speaker: NA
Text: that we have a shortage of nurses and

Speaker: NA
Text: midwives in rural Australia. We have a

Speaker: NA
Text: shortage of gynaecologists, obstetricians and

Speaker: NA
Text: GPs who will deliver babies. There is a

Speaker: NA
Text: policy solution to all this. Firstly,

Speaker: NA
Text: immediately remove the three-year

Speaker: NA
Text: qualification period after graduation when a

Speaker: NA
Text: midwife cannot access the new government

Speaker: NA
Text: supported insurance scheme.

Speaker: NA
Text: government should immediately address the

Speaker: NA
Text: problem of homebirthing and insurance.

Speaker: NA
Text: With the exemption running out in June next

Speaker: NA
Text: year, midwives need to know what is going

Speaker: NA
Text: to happen after that in regard to insurance

Speaker: NA
Text: and homebirths. This government must also

Speaker: NA
Text: realise that a threshold of performing 30

Speaker: NA
Text: births before you can access insurance is far

Speaker: NA
Text: too high for midwives in rural and regional

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. Many of these midwives have

Speaker: NA
Text: decades of experience. They may be

Speaker: NA
Text: delivering 25 or 27 babies. There should be a

Speaker: NA
Text: case-by-case assessment of their insurance

Speaker: NA
Text: needs and competencies rather than a 30

Speaker: NA
Text: baby cut-off in their ability to access this

Speaker: NA
Text: MIGA scheme.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am concerned that the next generation of

Speaker: NA
Text: midwives who should be from rural and

Speaker: NA
Text: regional Australia and who are most likely to

Speaker: NA
Text: go back and practice in rural and regional

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia will not be able to access tertiary

Speaker: NA
Text: studies because of the new independent

Speaker: NA
Text: youth allowance policy implications. Their

Speaker: NA
Text: families cannot afford to help them live away

Speaker: NA
Text: from home during their years of study. They

Speaker: NA
Text: simply do not have the means.

Speaker: NA
Text: As a member of the coalition, I support

Speaker: NA
Text: the fixing of the mistakes in these bills

Speaker: NA
Text: before us today, but the legislation does not

Speaker: NA
Text: comprehensively address the problems

Speaker: NA
Text: facing Australian midwives or the problems

Speaker: NA
Text: facing women and families wanting to have

Speaker: NA
Text: safe, well supported births in country areas,

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly those seeking homebirths. In the

Speaker: NA
Text: 21st century what is happening in Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: is a disgrace. It is akin to the discrimination

Speaker: NA
Text: against midwives that occurred centuries

Speaker: NA
Text: ago. We just have to get over it and

Speaker: NA
Text: understand that women need choices, and

Speaker: NA
Text: that professional midwives must be given the

Speaker: NA
Text: same insurance support and considerations

Speaker: NA
Text: This that other professions receive.

Speaker: Ms ROXON
Text: Gellibrand-Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Health and Ageing) (12:14): In summing up

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to thank members for their

Speaker: NA
Text: contributions to the debate on this bill.

Speaker: NA
Text: Unfortunately, a lot of members have strayed

Speaker: NA
Text: an extraordinarily long way from the topic. I

Speaker: NA
Text: might remind members opposite that to come

Speaker: NA
Text: in here and criticise the situation in relation

Speaker: NA
Text: to midwives, when it is the Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: government that for the first time ever has

Speaker: NA
Text: properly acknowledged and provided access

Speaker: NA
Text: to the MBS for midwives and it is also our

Speaker: NA
Text: government which is the first government to

Speaker: NA
Text: introduce an insurance scheme for midwives,

Speaker: NA
Text: and say that the situation in Australia is a

Speaker: NA
Text: disgrace and that other problems should be

Speaker: NA
Text: fixed, which their government in 12 years

Speaker: NA
Text: never ever addressed in any way, is a bit

Speaker: NA
Text: rich.

Speaker: NA
Text: The amendment to this particular bill is

Speaker: NA
Text: relatively a minor one, but it is an important

Speaker: NA
Text: step in ensuring that appropriately qualified

Speaker: NA
Text: and experienced self-employed midwives

Speaker: NA
Text: will continue to have access to secure and

Speaker: NA
Text: reliable Commonwealth supported

Speaker: NA
Text: professional indemnity cover. This bill

Speaker: NA
Text: makes sense and gives certainty for self-

Speaker: NA
Text: employed midwives and the women and

Speaker: NA
Text: families that they care for. Like the

Speaker: NA
Text: government's recent investment in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Medical Benefits Scheme and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme for access

Speaker: NA
Text: of patients to eligible midwives, this

Speaker: NA
Text: amendment bill will continue to ensure that

Speaker: NA
Text: there is improved access to maternity

Speaker: NA
Text: services and improved choices for Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: women. That is why our government took

Speaker: NA
Text: this action in the first place and we are very

Speaker: NA
Text: proud of our record. I commend the bill to

Speaker: NA
Text: the House.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Third Reading

Speaker: Ms ROXON
Text: by leave-I move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this bill be now read a third time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill read a third time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Therapeutic Goods Legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: Amendment (Copyright) Bill 2011

Speaker: NA
Text: Returned from Senate

Speaker: NA
Text: Message received from the Senate

Speaker: NA
Text: returning the bill without amendment or

Speaker: NA
Text: request.

Speaker: NA
Text: Social Security Legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: Amendment (Job Seeker Compliance)

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate resumed on the motion:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: Ms LEY
Text: Farrer) (12:17): I rise today to

Speaker: NA
Text: speak on the Social Security Legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: Amendment (Job Seeker Compliance) Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: 2011. This bill seeks to introduce much

Speaker: NA
Text: needed improvements to the compliance

Speaker: NA
Text: requirements for job seekers. Unemployment

Speaker: NA
Text: is currently 4.9 per cent and many businesses

Speaker: NA
Text: are crying out for staff, yet job seeker

Speaker: NA
Text: income support for 2011-12 is still estimated

Speaker: NA
Text: to cost taxpayers $7.2 billion. In March

Speaker: NA
Text: 2011, 179,041 job seekers were classified as

Speaker: NA
Text: long-term unemployed, meaning that they

Speaker: NA
Text: have been on income support for 12 months

Speaker: NA
Text: or more. In yesterday's budget the term,

Speaker: NA
Text: which is already in existence but certainly

Speaker: NA
Text: featured in the budget, was 'very long-term

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployed'. That gives us a sense of the

Speaker: NA
Text: nature of this problem. On top of a very

Speaker: NA
Text: sizeable income support budget, billions of

Speaker: NA
Text: dollars is spent by the government to provide

Speaker: NA
Text: job search support.

Speaker: NA
Text: Whilst I have a few criticisms of the

Speaker: NA
Text: current system, there are countless

Speaker: NA
Text: organisations offering employment services

Speaker: NA
Text: to job seekers nationally. These people are at

Speaker: NA
Text: the coalface and work very hard to place

Speaker: NA
Text: people into jobs. On a personal note it is a

Speaker: NA
Text: privilege to meet people who work in our job

Speaker: NA
Text: service agencies, particularly with

Speaker: NA
Text: challenging individuals. These people have

Speaker: NA
Text: dedicated their lives to getting those people

Speaker: NA
Text: into work and onto a meaningful pathway in

Speaker: NA
Text: life. But noncompliance has costs for these

Speaker: NA
Text: employment service providers and for

Speaker: NA
Text: Centrelink. Having to constantly phone job

Speaker: NA
Text: seekers to ask why they did not attend a

Speaker: NA
Text: meeting are distractions that take away from

Speaker: NA
Text: the core role of the employment services

Speaker: NA
Text: provider-getting someone into a job. It is as

Speaker: NA
Text: simple as that.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill 2011

Speaker: NA
Text: We need to ensure that job seekers are

Speaker: NA
Text: given the support they need to take up job

Speaker: NA
Text: vacancies that exist. However, if a job seeker

Speaker: NA
Text: is not attending appointments, they are not

Speaker: NA
Text: going to get off welfare anytime soon. The

Speaker: NA
Text: first stage or an early stage is to attend those

Speaker: NA
Text: appointments. In the last 12 months

Speaker: NA
Text: approximately two million job interviews,

Speaker: NA
Text: activities or provider appointments were

Speaker: NA
Text: missed by job seekers with no valid excuse

Speaker: NA
Text: given. This is a clear indictment of the

Speaker: NA
Text: failure of the current compliance system and

Speaker: NA
Text: of the urgent need for reform.

Speaker: NA
Text: We need to drastically improve job seeker

Speaker: NA
Text: engagement with employment services

Speaker: NA
Text: providers. I suspect that part of the reason for

Speaker: NA
Text: this abysmal attendance record stems from

Speaker: NA
Text: the fact that many job seekers believe they

Speaker: NA
Text: will not be penalised if they fail to attend an

Speaker: NA
Text: appointment. In all likelihood they may well

Speaker: NA
Text: be right, with only half of all participation

Speaker: NA
Text: reports lodged with Centrelink being upheld.

Speaker: NA
Text: These are reports provided by the job service

Speaker: NA
Text: agency to Centrelink, which is the agency

Speaker: NA
Text: that must withhold payment for non-

Speaker: NA
Text: attendance.

Speaker: NA
Text: We know that there are many reasons why

Speaker: NA
Text: people do not make job interviews and we

Speaker: NA
Text: understand that some of those reasons stem

Speaker: NA
Text: from the nature of that person's life. They

Speaker: NA
Text: may be vulnerable, they may be homeless

Speaker: NA
Text: and they may have all sorts of issues with

Speaker: NA
Text: which they are dealing, and those issues are

Speaker: NA
Text: recognised by the system. This is not an

Speaker: NA
Text: approach that suggests that everybody will

Speaker: NA
Text: be put into a category of losing income

Speaker: NA
Text: support should they not attend. But I am

Speaker: NA
Text: waiting with interest to see how this

Speaker: NA
Text: government describes those vulnerabilities in

Speaker: NA
Text: the regulations. In other words, how it draws

Speaker: NA
Text: that very careful distinction between those

Speaker: NA
Text: who need a bit of a push to attend an

Speaker: NA
Text: employment interview and those who, with

Speaker: NA
Text: the best will in the world, cannot.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Rudd government has to shoulder the

Speaker: NA
Text: blame for watering down mutual obligation

Speaker: NA
Text: with their failed employment services reform

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation in 2008 and letters sent by both

Speaker: NA
Text: the then minister and the department deputy

Speaker: NA
Text: secretary urging providers to turn a blind eye

Speaker: NA
Text: to job seeker noncompliance. This was a

Speaker: NA
Text: clear strategy of the Labor Party, certainly

Speaker: NA
Text: the Labor Left, voicing their disapproval of

Speaker: NA
Text: the concept of mutual obligation. We have

Speaker: NA
Text: also seen Work for the Dole virtually

Speaker: NA
Text: abolished under Labor with the March

Speaker: NA
Text: figures indicating only 9,151 people were

Speaker: NA
Text: participating in Work for the Dole. This

Speaker: NA
Text: program has been remarkably successful in

Speaker: NA
Text: giving job seekers a work-like experience,

Speaker: NA
Text: and Teaching Skills in Demand has come

Speaker: NA
Text: under fire from Labor ever since its

Speaker: NA
Text: inception. This is a clear sign of the lack of

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment the government has to mutual

Speaker: NA
Text: obligation. But the decision that we see

Speaker: NA
Text: reflected in this bill, to get a bit more serious

Speaker: NA
Text: about making job seekers comply with their

Speaker: NA
Text: obligations, is a positive move in the right

Speaker: NA
Text: direction. Unfortunately, it has taken three

Speaker: NA
Text: years to come about, during which time

Speaker: NA
Text: many job seekers have become complacent.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mutual obligation requires people in receipt

Speaker: NA
Text: of income support to make reasonable efforts

Speaker: NA
Text: to look for a job. There are, regrettably, some

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians who do view welfare as a

Speaker: NA
Text: lifestyle choice. A firm but fair compliance

Speaker: NA
Text: regime sends to these people the message

Speaker: NA
Text: that it is not okay to sit at home and cash

Speaker: NA
Text: your welfare cheque with no intention of

Speaker: NA
Text: ever really looking for a job. Income support

Speaker: NA
Text: payments are designed to be a temporary

Speaker: NA
Text: safety net, nothing more. There is a

Speaker: NA
Text: continuum between somebody's obligations

Speaker: NA
Text: to contribute to the society in which they live

Speaker: NA
Text: and society's obligations to look after its

Speaker: NA
Text: most vulnerable and disadvantaged. We in

Speaker: NA
Text: the coalition will never walk away from the

Speaker: NA
Text: obligation that governments have to look

Speaker: NA
Text: after the most disadvantaged-those who

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot cope. But into the love has to come

Speaker: NA
Text: the tough. The tough love approach has been

Speaker: NA
Text: missing from this government's approach

Speaker: NA
Text: with some fairly poor results, particularly for

Speaker: NA
Text: the job seekers themselves.

Speaker: NA
Text: Welfare dependency is a real concern in

Speaker: NA
Text: this country. There are suburbs where

Speaker: NA
Text: intergenerational unemployment is rife. We

Speaker: NA
Text: have to break the mindset that you can live

Speaker: NA
Text: on welfare from the cradle to the grave, but

Speaker: NA
Text: that is a very tough challenge and it requires

Speaker: NA
Text: a tough approach. Children should not be

Speaker: NA
Text: raised to believe that they are entitled to a

Speaker: NA
Text: lifetime of taxpayer funded welfare, but they

Speaker: NA
Text: need to be shown the benefits and

Speaker: NA
Text: possibilities of a job. That children are

Speaker: NA
Text: growing up in households where no

Speaker: NA
Text: generation has worked-we are into the

Speaker: NA
Text: fourth generation in terms of

Speaker: NA
Text: intergenerational unemployment-underlines

Speaker: NA
Text: the dimensions of that challenge. It is very

Speaker: NA
Text: hard for a child who has never known a

Speaker: NA
Text: parent or role model who has worked for a

Speaker: NA
Text: living to understand the reward a job brings,

Speaker: NA
Text: from both a social point of view and a

Speaker: NA
Text: financial point of view. The best way to help

Speaker: NA
Text: these children overcome the disadvantage

Speaker: NA
Text: that faces them is to help them get a good

Speaker: NA
Text: education and a job.

Speaker: NA
Text: I mentioned the privilege of meeting

Speaker: NA
Text: people who work with job seekers.

Speaker: NA
Text: Everywhere I go I also meet those who are

Speaker: NA
Text: conducting the programs that try to bring a

Speaker: NA
Text: group of people who have been completely

Speaker: NA
Text: disengaged from the system back into the

Speaker: NA
Text: system and back onto that pathway. Some of

Speaker: NA
Text: those programs work amazingly well, and I

Speaker: NA
Text: thank the providers. I am not going to name

Speaker: NA
Text: them because I would miss out on somebody

Speaker: NA
Text: important.

Speaker: NA
Text: Just on the weekend, in the west of my

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate of Farrer, near the small town of

Speaker: NA
Text: Pooncarie-which is on the Darling River

Speaker: NA
Text: for those who do not know it-I met

Speaker: NA
Text: somebody who was involved in taking a

Speaker: NA
Text: group of kids from the bush who had never

Speaker: NA
Text: known meaningful employment and training

Speaker: NA
Text: them in horticulture. The training they

Speaker: NA
Text: received would lead to a horticulture

Speaker: NA
Text: certificate II. The feedback I got about this

Speaker: NA
Text: program, which is one of the government's

Speaker: NA
Text: current programs, was that it was not really

Speaker: NA
Text: working very successfully. The young

Speaker: NA
Text: people concerned would come, they would

Speaker: NA
Text: have the sandwiches at morning tea-which

Speaker: NA
Text: underscores the fact they may not have eaten

Speaker: NA
Text: at home-and then they would disappear,

Speaker: NA
Text: because there was nothing actually forcing

Speaker: NA
Text: them to stay there for a day's work.

Speaker: NA
Text: problem was that they were completing

Speaker: NA
Text: training that did not really mean much to

Speaker: NA
Text: them at that point in time. There are times

Speaker: NA
Text: when there is much work for those with a

Speaker: NA
Text: horticulture certificate but there is an

Speaker: NA
Text: abundance of people qualified in this area

Speaker: NA
Text: and at the moment there are very few jobs,

Speaker: NA
Text: given the shocking state of our wine grape

Speaker: NA
Text: industry. They could not see a connection

Speaker: NA
Text: between what they were being asked to do

Speaker: NA
Text: and a future job.

Speaker: NA
Text: My friend was frustrated, quite frankly,

Speaker: NA
Text: because he had put a lot of effort in-he

Speaker: NA
Text: wanted them to get out of the cycle they

Speaker: NA
Text: were in-and people were turning up and not

Speaker: NA
Text: doing what they were supposed to. When he

Speaker: NA
Text: asked them in detail, they said what they

Speaker: NA
Text: really wanted to do was to learn to read and

Speaker: NA
Text: write. They really wanted to learn to read

Speaker: NA
Text: and write because then they could get a

Speaker: NA
Text: drivers licence and could drive. Many of

Speaker: NA
Text: these people, unfortunately, do drive but are

Speaker: NA
Text: not licensed. That was a practical thing that

Speaker: NA
Text: they could see, and it is a piece of education

Speaker: NA
Text: that has been sorely missed. I see some

Speaker: NA
Text: literacy and numeracy funding in the

Speaker: NA
Text: budget-not very much-and I am really

Speaker: NA
Text: interested to see that it does not just dissipate

Speaker: NA
Text: at bureaucracy level but hits the ground in a

Speaker: NA
Text: really meaningful sense.

Speaker: NA
Text: The point is that in the current

Speaker: NA
Text: environment there is no TAFE course for

Speaker: NA
Text: these particular work experience people to

Speaker: NA
Text: attend that could be signed off as allowing

Speaker: NA
Text: them to participate in this program. They had

Speaker: NA
Text: to do a certificate II in horticulture or some

Speaker: NA
Text: other comparable certificate, but what they

Speaker: NA
Text: really needed was literacy and numeracy

Speaker: NA
Text: change. That comes down to an area in our

Speaker: NA
Text: VET and training system that needs to be

Speaker: NA
Text: looked at carefully. So when we see the

Speaker: NA
Text: headline numbers and when we see that this

Speaker: NA
Text: is the outcome, we really do have to look in

Speaker: NA
Text: detail at the program, and the simple

Speaker: NA
Text: The other approach often works best.

Speaker: NA
Text: To finish this story, the fellow I was

Speaker: NA
Text: talking to spent quite a bit of time, out of

Speaker: NA
Text: hours, teaching these young people how to

Speaker: NA
Text: read and write. He put in front of them

Speaker: NA
Text: information that was relevant-not the sort

Speaker: NA
Text: of story books you would see in grade 2 but

Speaker: NA
Text: something they could actually read: road

Speaker: NA
Text: signs, traffic rules and basic instructions.

Speaker: NA
Text: They all came to life. They all loved it and

Speaker: NA
Text: actually saw a meaning and a purpose, and

Speaker: NA
Text: that is the key.

Speaker: NA
Text: Youth unemployment remains an ongoing

Speaker: NA
Text: concern. We need to address this to prevent

Speaker: NA
Text: longer term social disadvantage. I have

Speaker: NA
Text: spoken with employers desperate to take on

Speaker: NA
Text: apprentices, but they cannot find people

Speaker: NA
Text: willing to take on an apprenticeship and who

Speaker: NA
Text: are capable of doing so. There is currently a

Speaker: NA
Text: seasonally adjusted unemployment rate of

Speaker: NA
Text: 11.3 per cent for people aged 15 to 24. That

Speaker: NA
Text: is just not acceptable. It is so critical that

Speaker: NA
Text: keep these young people engaged with their

Speaker: NA
Text: employment services provider and that we

Speaker: NA
Text: work with them to help them get the skills

Speaker: NA
Text: and education they need to lift them out of

Speaker: NA
Text: the poverty trap and decrease the threat of

Speaker: NA
Text: social isolation which can occur with long-

Speaker: NA
Text: term unemployment. Long-term

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployment is not that far away for

Speaker: NA
Text: someone who today does not have a job, who

Speaker: NA
Text: lost their job three months ago. The slide

Speaker: NA
Text: from being in that position to being long-

Speaker: NA
Text: term unemployed and struggling to get a job

Speaker: NA
Text: can happen very fast and in quite a dramatic

Speaker: NA
Text: sense that affects your entire life experience.

Speaker: NA
Text: Something we should be aware of with the

Speaker: NA
Text: long-term unemployed is that it would be

Speaker: NA
Text: better for those in the early stages of

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployment to be looked after and

Speaker: NA
Text: helped-that is, perhaps more help is needed

Speaker: NA
Text: at the front end of that experience-before

Speaker: NA
Text: they actually slip into

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployment. Underlying this legislation is

Speaker: NA
Text: a clear and simple message. It is one of

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility. People must

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility for their own lives. If they

Speaker: NA
Text: have a legitimate reason and are unable to

Speaker: NA
Text: attend a meeting with their job services

Speaker: NA
Text: provider or if they cannot attend a job

Speaker: NA
Text: interview then they need to advise in

Speaker: NA
Text: advance. It is simple and it echoes what the

Speaker: NA
Text: vast majority of us take as a given: if you

Speaker: NA
Text: know you are ill, pick up the phone and let

Speaker: NA
Text: your office or workplace know. This is what

Speaker: NA
Text: is being asked of job seekers-not much

Speaker: NA
Text: more than a common courtesy. I know that

Speaker: NA
Text: vulnerable people in difficult positions may

Speaker: NA
Text: not be able to manage this, but we have to

Speaker: NA
Text: take it as just a small thing and a step in the

Speaker: NA
Text: right direction. You may still be in bed, you

Speaker: NA
Text: may be struggling to cope, but you can pick

Speaker: NA
Text: up the phone, you can make the call and you

Speaker: NA
Text: can say, 'I will not be there for today's

Speaker: NA
Text: interview; I need to reschedule.' As soon as

Speaker: NA
Text: we somebody re-engages with their employment

Speaker: NA
Text: services provider, their payment will be

Speaker: NA
Text: reinstated.

Speaker: NA
Text: So, to put it simply, at the beginning, if

Speaker: NA
Text: they do not turn up, their payment is

Speaker: NA
Text: suspended. If they re-engage, their payment

Speaker: NA
Text: is reinstated. Therefore, the responsibility

Speaker: NA
Text: rests with the job seeker to determine how

Speaker: NA
Text: long they will have their welfare payments

Speaker: NA
Text: withheld. In other words, when they re-

Speaker: NA
Text: engage, their welfare payment is reinstated

Speaker: NA
Text: and they will also be back paid. Those job

Speaker: NA
Text: seekers who do the right thing and attend

Speaker: NA
Text: their appointments or reschedule them in

Speaker: NA
Text: advance if they are not in a position to attend

Speaker: NA
Text: will not be penalised. But for those who

Speaker: NA
Text: deliberately shirk their responsibilities there

Speaker: NA
Text: will be a price to pay. Yet it is vital that the

Speaker: NA
Text: most vulnerable of these job seekers are not

Speaker: NA
Text: penalised unfairly. As I said, the legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: is designed to afford a measure of protection,

Speaker: NA
Text: long-term but we need to see how that protection is

Speaker: NA
Text: described in the relevant regulations.

Speaker: NA
Text: In my describing in a simple sense the

Speaker: NA
Text: take

Speaker: NA
Text: principle behind this-of course, like most

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation, this is full of unbelievably

Speaker: NA
Text: complicated detail-the House will note that

Speaker: NA
Text: there are significant requirements on

Speaker: NA
Text: Centrelink. They are that Centrelink act in

Speaker: NA
Text: real time, that Centrelink suspend payments

Speaker: NA
Text: while the person is disengaged and, if the

Speaker: NA
Text: person reconnects, that Centrelink reinstate

Speaker: NA
Text: payment in order to give the person the

Speaker: NA
Text: message that once you are in the system and

Speaker: NA
Text: working to assist yourself and to meet your

Speaker: NA
Text: obligations then your welfare payments will

Speaker: NA
Text: continue.

Speaker: NA
Text: Those of us who understand the

Speaker: NA
Text: complicated computer systems in our large

Speaker: NA
Text: departments will agree it is quite a tall order.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am concerned that the IT system in

Speaker: NA
Text: Centrelink may not be up to this, with the

Speaker: NA
Text: best will in the world. We saw that the

Speaker: NA
Text: budget is slashing Public Service numbers,

Speaker: NA
Text: and Centrelink needs to be resourced to do

Speaker: NA
Text: this job properly because the whole principle

Speaker: NA
Text: that underpins this legislation will fall to bits

Speaker: NA
Text: if a person who re-engages with the system

Speaker: NA
Text: actually does not receive their payment and

Speaker: NA
Text: catch up quickly. I know that those who are

Speaker: NA
Text: receiving Newstart allowance-some

Speaker: NA
Text: $239-are not in a position to look after

Speaker: NA
Text: themselves. This is a necessary and tough

Speaker: NA
Text: message, but it also needs the counterpart of

Speaker: NA
Text: the agency acting quickly to reinstate the

Speaker: NA
Text: funding where required. It is pretty scary

Speaker: NA
Text: when you look at some public policy which

Speaker: NA
Text: is designed around IT systems. The response

Speaker: NA
Text: so often when you contact an agency is, 'The

Speaker: NA
Text: system won't allow it.' So we need to make

Speaker: NA
Text: sure that the Centrelink system does allow

Speaker: NA
Text: this. It is a sensible measure which should go

Speaker: NA
Text: a considerable way towards reversing the

Speaker: NA
Text: sharp increase in attendance failures by job

Speaker: NA
Text: seekers. We need to drive home a real work

Speaker: NA
Text: ethic whilst ensuring that the system is both

Speaker: NA
Text: reasonable and manageable.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are real problems with the current

Speaker: NA
Text: system, and NESA have identified these in

Speaker: NA
Text: their submission to the House inquiry into

Speaker: NA
Text: this legislation. I should note that this

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation was referred to the House of

Speaker: NA
Text: Representatives Standing Committee on

Speaker: NA
Text: Education and Employment. The report was

Speaker: NA
Text: done very quickly. Congratulations to the

Speaker: NA
Text: members. I think it was tabled this morning.

Speaker: NA
Text: NESA, who I just mentioned, are the

Speaker: NA
Text: National Employment Services Association.

Speaker: NA
Text: They are the peak body for Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: employment services, the only national peak

Speaker: NA
Text: body that represent the community, private,

Speaker: NA
Text: public and government sectors. Some of their

Speaker: NA
Text: comments in their submission to the House

Speaker: NA
Text: standing committee are instructive and I

Speaker: NA
Text: think they bear repeating. They make the

Speaker: NA
Text: point that there is clear support for the

Speaker: NA
Text: principle that individuals should take

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility for undertaking steps to

Speaker: NA
Text: improve their circumstances and not be

Speaker: NA
Text: dependent on the welfare system to the

Speaker: NA
Text: extent that they have the capacity to do so.

Speaker: NA
Text: NESA also believe that, following a

Speaker: NA
Text: period of implementation, there will be a

Speaker: NA
Text: further opportunity to strengthen the

Speaker: NA
Text: compliance framework to better support job

Speaker: NA
Text: seeker engagement and workforce

Speaker: NA
Text: participation. They indicate that there is

Speaker: NA
Text: more to be done in this area and there are

Speaker: NA
Text: improvements that can be made around the

Speaker: NA
Text: compliance requirements. They note that a

Speaker: NA
Text: considerable investment is made by

Speaker: NA
Text: government to ensure the welfare of its

Speaker: NA
Text: citizens and to provide services to assist

Speaker: NA
Text: them to address circumstances. That is the

Speaker: NA
Text: biggest outgoing cost that governments face,

Speaker: NA
Text: and it is significant. The amendments, NESA

Speaker: NA
Text: says, as outlined in the current bill are

Speaker: NA
Text: considered welcome improvements to the job

Speaker: NA
Text: seeker compliance framework and will

Speaker: NA
Text: provide greater emphasis on engagement and

Speaker: NA
Text: participation. Because they are a peak body,

Speaker: NA
Text: I think it is worth noting that they have

Speaker: NA
Text: endorsed the principle that is at work here.

Speaker: NA
Text: Just on the subject of the inquiry of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House of Representatives standing

Speaker: NA
Text: committee, there were 10 recommendations.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am not going to read them all out, but there

Speaker: NA
Text: are a couple that I will note because I think

Speaker: NA
Text: that when a committee looks at legislation in

Speaker: NA
Text: detail and takes submissions-and there

Speaker: NA
Text: were some good submissions; they have not

Speaker: NA
Text: all agreed with this and they have not all

Speaker: NA
Text: agreed with the approaches that are in place,

Speaker: NA
Text: but they have still been good submissions-

Speaker: NA
Text: the recommendations that it comes forward

Speaker: NA
Text: with are certainly worth noting. It

Speaker: NA
Text: recommended that a brief, plain English

Speaker: NA
Text: explanation of the proposed changes be

Speaker: NA
Text: produced and made available to job seekers.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is so important. We are talking about

Speaker: NA
Text: people amongst whom many are barely

Speaker: NA
Text: literate. The principle is sound but if we were

Speaker: NA
Text: to confront them with the requirements, even

Speaker: NA
Text: perhaps not in a legislative sense, it would go

Speaker: NA
Text: over the heads of many of them and perhaps

Speaker: NA
Text: even many of us. So that is a good

Speaker: NA
Text: recommendation.

Speaker: NA
Text: The committee recommended that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Department of Education, Employment and

Speaker: NA
Text: Workplace Relations, the Department of

Speaker: NA
Text: Human Services, employment services

Speaker: NA
Text: providers and other stakeholders work

Speaker: NA
Text: together to develop consistent guidance and

Speaker: NA
Text: training material to accompany the bill. That

Speaker: NA
Text: comes down to resources. The government

Speaker: NA
Text: has to not only announce measures but walk

Speaker: NA
Text: the walk, and resources are needed in this

Speaker: NA
Text: area.

Speaker: NA
Text: The committee recommended that

Speaker: NA
Text: Centrelink and employment services

Speaker: NA
Text: provider staff be provided

Speaker: NA
Text: comprehensive training in relation to the

Speaker: NA
Text: measures proposed by the bill and the

Speaker: NA
Text: guidelines. Centrelink have a huge workload.

Speaker: NA
Text: Those of us who have Centrelink agencies in

Speaker: NA
Text: our towns and have a relationship between

Speaker: NA
Text: our electorate offices and those people know

Speaker: NA
Text: how hard they work. It seems that when the

Speaker: NA
Text: government-and this is common with all

Speaker: NA
Text: governments-needs to put a program or

Speaker: NA
Text: something somewhere it often ends up with

Speaker: NA
Text: Centrelink. So they certainly need, as I said,

Speaker: NA
Text: the resources and the training. The

Speaker: NA
Text: committee also recommended

Speaker: NA
Text: employment services providers be given

Speaker: NA
Text: clear and comprehensive guidance on how to

Speaker: NA
Text: utilise their discretion to submit a

Speaker: NA
Text: participation report on a missed appointment.

Speaker: NA
Text: We need discretion built in, because no

Speaker: NA
Text: government could legislate for every single

Speaker: NA
Text: set of circumstances for a vulnerable job

Speaker: NA
Text: seeker. But the discretion has to be used

Speaker: NA
Text: well. Officers who are required to suspend

Speaker: NA
Text: payments need to have the confidence when

Speaker: NA
Text: the time comes to actually suspend the

Speaker: NA
Text: payment.

Speaker: NA
Text: The committee also recommended that

Speaker: NA
Text: employment services providers should be

Speaker: NA
Text: advised to utilise all re-engagement

Speaker: NA
Text: mechanisms available to them in relation to

Speaker: NA
Text: vulnerable job seekers. That

Speaker: NA
Text: recommendation comes from having looked

Speaker: NA
Text: through the submissions, including from

Speaker: NA
Text: ACOSS and some of the welfare rights

Speaker: NA
Text: organisations and headspace. That is what

Speaker: NA
Text: they highlighted-they were worried

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly about young, vulnerable job

Speaker: NA
Text: seekers. We need to be assured that there is

Speaker: NA
Text: not a one-size-fits-all approach. I know there

Speaker: NA
Text: are indicators for those people already in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Centrelink and Job Services system, but

Speaker: NA
Text: again we need to see how their

Speaker: NA
Text: circumstances will be addressed when this

Speaker: NA
Text: with actually takes place. Of course the committee

Speaker: NA
Text: recommended that the House pass the job

Speaker: NA
Text: seeker compliance bill, which is clearly what

Speaker: NA
Text: we are doing.

Speaker: NA
Text: I said that there were real problems with

Speaker: NA
Text: the current system, and NESA have

Speaker: NA
Text: identified those in their submission-in

Speaker: NA
Text: particular, the administrative burden of

Speaker: NA
Text: submitting participation reports is onerous

Speaker: NA
Text: for providers and can in some instances take

Speaker: NA
Text: up to 28 days. The NESA submission says:

Speaker: NA
Text: ... where no reasonable excuse is determined,

Speaker: NA
Text: providers generally consider that the more

Speaker: NA
Text: that immediate loss of payment will provide better

Speaker: NA
Text: reinforcement and a stronger and more direct

Speaker: NA
Text: deterrent for the reconnection failure.

Speaker: NA
Text: As I have said, we need those who operate

Speaker: NA
Text: within the system to have the confidence to

Speaker: NA
Text: actually take the step-not easy-to suspend

Speaker: NA
Text: the payment, recognising that it is

Speaker: NA
Text: interests of the job seeker.

Speaker: NA
Text: In conclusion, the coalition supports this

Speaker: NA
Text: shift to a more rigorous compliance

Speaker: NA
Text: regime-one that is firm, but certainly still

Speaker: NA
Text: fair. Under these rules, job seekers will lose

Speaker: NA
Text: their payment immediately, which in turn

Speaker: NA
Text: should help reinforce in their mind the

Speaker: NA
Text: linkage between welfare and responsibility. I

Speaker: NA
Text: congratulate the government on finally

Speaker: NA
Text: recognising that the coalition's approach in

Speaker: NA
Text: this area is the right one. I commend the bill

Speaker: NA
Text: and the committee's report to the House.

Speaker: Mr HUSIC
Text: Chifley) (12:39): I support

Speaker: NA
Text: the Social Security Legislation Amendment

Speaker: NA
Text: (Job Seeker Compliance) Bill 2011. I want to

Speaker: NA
Text: canvass a number of matters, but specifically

Speaker: NA
Text: I refer to the work of my colleague the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Kingston and the House of

Speaker: NA
Text: Representatives Standing Committee on

Speaker: NA
Text: Education and Employment, which I think

Speaker: NA
Text: has brought down a very considered set of

Speaker: NA
Text: recommendations. It is important for us to

Speaker: NA
Text: step back and put all this within the context

Speaker: NA
Text: of what the government is seeking to do

Speaker: NA
Text: broadly in the area of welfare reform and

Speaker: NA
Text: especially as it sits within the needs of the

Speaker: NA
Text: economy-where we are at; where we sit

Speaker: NA
Text: right now. It is worth noting that some of the

Speaker: NA
Text: things that are confronting the economy have

Speaker: NA
Text: sat in the economy for some time and have

Speaker: NA
Text: been reflected upon by the Reserve Bank for

Speaker: NA
Text: some time. Specifically I refer to the impact

Speaker: NA
Text: that capacity constraints have on the

Speaker: NA
Text: economy, chiefly through, for example,

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure road blocks or the impact that

Speaker: NA
Text: skill shortages have on the economy in

Speaker: NA
Text: driving wages up and not having skilled

Speaker: NA
Text: people to drive productivity and help the

Speaker: NA
Text: economy as it moves, particularly in the

Speaker: NA
Text: context of us emerging from the GFC.

Speaker: NA
Text: Productivity has been low for many years

Speaker: NA
Text: and does need to be increased if we expect

Speaker: NA
Text: our economy to continue growing and we

Speaker: NA
Text: expect ourselves to make a mark on the

Speaker: NA
Text: in the best international scene as well.

Speaker: NA
Text: The challenge for us is to work out how

Speaker: NA
Text: we can get people, particularly those who are

Speaker: NA
Text: long-term unemployed, to participate more

Speaker: NA
Text: fully in the work force and how we can assist

Speaker: NA
Text: those people to obtain the level of personal

Speaker: NA
Text: skill necessary, which is demanded by

Speaker: NA
Text: industry, business and commerce today, and

Speaker: NA
Text: so be able to have a meaningful engagement

Speaker: NA
Text: in the economy. Ultimately, I believe work

Speaker: NA
Text: should not of itself be seen just as an

Speaker: NA
Text: economic activity but as a means for people

Speaker: NA
Text: to pursue their own personal aspirations,

Speaker: NA
Text: fund their activities and provide security and

Speaker: NA
Text: hope in many respects for what they want to

Speaker: NA
Text: do for themselves, their families and those

Speaker: NA
Text: close to them and the communities in which

Speaker: NA
Text: they reside.

Speaker: NA
Text: Our economy is currently experiencing

Speaker: NA
Text: the equivalent of a sonic boom when it

Speaker: NA
Text: comes to investment, and to ensure that the

Speaker: NA
Text: economy is able to progress as far as it can

Speaker: NA
Text: and as strongly as it can we do need to

Speaker: NA
Text: address infrastructure issues and capacity

Speaker: NA
Text: constraints brought about by skill shortages.

Speaker: NA
Text: Addressing skill shortages lies behind the

Speaker: NA
Text: budget delivered last night. It puts in place

Speaker: NA
Text: significant economic reforms that will help

Speaker: NA
Text: us in the years ahead. This bill and some of

Speaker: NA
Text: the other measures announced by the

Speaker: NA
Text: government have been designed to find a

Speaker: NA
Text: way to add to the pool of employees and skill

Speaker: NA
Text: them up and enable them to meaningfully

Speaker: NA
Text: engage in the economy. From within that

Speaker: NA
Text: perspective, this bill, along with some of the

Speaker: NA
Text: other work done in the budget, is designed to

Speaker: NA
Text: have a meaningful impact.

Speaker: NA
Text: The bill was referred to the education and

Speaker: NA
Text: employment committee on 24 March for

Speaker: NA
Text: inquiry, and 16 submissions were received.

Speaker: NA
Text: My colleague the member for Kingston, the

Speaker: NA
Text: chair of the committee, tabled the advisory

Speaker: NA
Text: report on the Social Security Legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: Amendment (Job Seeker Compliance) Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: this morning. One thing that is noteworthy,

Speaker: NA
Text: and I think this was reflected upon by the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Kingston, is the degree of

Speaker: NA
Text: passion for social welfare and the

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment to employment participation.

Speaker: NA
Text: The inquiry drew comments from a range of

Speaker: NA
Text: different perspectives, but clearly people are

Speaker: NA
Text: concerned to ensure that the jobless are

Speaker: NA
Text: engaged back in the economy-but, at the

Speaker: NA
Text: same time, in seeking to meet this objective

Speaker: NA
Text: we need to ensure the conditions imposed are

Speaker: NA
Text: not onerous or counterproductive.

Speaker: NA
Text: I sought to engage with people in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Chifley electorate on this issue, and I

Speaker: NA
Text: discussed some of these plans with people

Speaker: NA
Text: who had been fortunate enough to graduate

Speaker: NA
Text: from the Green Jobs program in Western

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney. I anticipated only being there for a

Speaker: NA
Text: short period of time for the graduation and in

Speaker: NA
Text: fact stayed for two hours, canvassing a range

Speaker: NA
Text: of issues with some people who I believe are

Speaker: NA
Text: a credit to their community. We discussed

Speaker: NA
Text: the things that they want to do in progressing

Speaker: NA
Text: from a position where they believed they did

Speaker: NA
Text: not have an opportunity to get a job that was

Speaker: NA
Text: meaningful, beneficial and satisfying to them

Speaker: NA
Text: to a position now where they are looking

Speaker: NA
Text: with a great degree of confidence to where

Speaker: NA
Text: they head. They said to me that when they

Speaker: NA
Text: engaged with job providers one of their

Speaker: NA
Text: concerns was that they were referred to job

Speaker: NA
Text: interviews that they do not themselves feel

Speaker: NA
Text: will provide them with a job that will sustain

Speaker: NA
Text: their interest into the long term. One of the

Speaker: NA
Text: things that I am very mindful of with this bill

Speaker: NA
Text: is that, while you can refer people to job

Speaker: NA
Text: interviews, there obviously has to be a

Speaker: NA
Text: connection with the interests of the person

Speaker: NA
Text: you are referring to those interviews.

Speaker: NA
Text: Interviews are one thing; accepting a final

Speaker: NA
Text: offer of employment is another. But in that

Speaker: NA
Text: meeting and that very positive discussion

Speaker: NA
Text: that I had with young people in Western

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney who had been unemployed for quite

Speaker: NA
Text: some time they indicated to me that they

Speaker: NA
Text: would be referred to employers for work that

Speaker: NA
Text: they were not interested in.

Speaker: NA
Text: In fact, I recall that one of the successful

Speaker: NA
Text: graduates said to me: 'The reason I was

Speaker: NA
Text: attracted to this program was simple. I was at

Speaker: NA
Text: a job provider's premises'-this is how

Speaker: NA
Text: simple it was-'and I saw a brochure that

Speaker: NA
Text: was green. I turned it over and it talked about

Speaker: NA
Text: this program. I said instantly that this was

Speaker: NA
Text: what I wanted to do.' So he followed it up.

Speaker: NA
Text: He stuck with the program. This person is

Speaker: NA
Text: now going to be engaged in horticulture in a

Speaker: NA
Text: major Western Sydney council, Hawkesbury

Speaker: NA
Text: City Council. I remember just the enthusiasm

Speaker: NA
Text: on his face and the fact that he said: 'I didn't

Speaker: NA
Text: want to go into a warehouse-it wasn't for

Speaker: NA
Text: me. I didn't want to go into the logistics

Speaker: NA
Text: industry or transport. I wanted to do

Speaker: NA
Text: something with my hands but outside and

Speaker: NA
Text: feeling like I was making a contribution to

Speaker: NA
Text: the environment.'

Speaker: NA
Text: The key with job providers, as I said, is

Speaker: NA
Text: obviously that referring people on for

Speaker: NA
Text: interviews is just one thing. Making sure that

Speaker: NA
Text: they attend is important, as is checking, if

Speaker: NA
Text: that person does not attend, that they have a

Speaker: NA
Text: reasonable excuse as to why. I note that the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Kingston indicated today that

Speaker: NA
Text: there has been a recommendation put

Speaker: NA
Text: forward for some moderation in the criteria,

Speaker: NA
Text: so that 'reasonable' rather than 'special'

Speaker: NA
Text: excuses should be taken into account by

Speaker: NA
Text: Centrelink before making a decision on

Speaker: NA
Text: benefits. I think that is an important measure.

Speaker: NA
Text: I was equally moved to consider the point

Speaker: NA
Text: made by the member for Melbourne that

Speaker: NA
Text: engagement with the social security system,

Speaker: NA
Text: social security law and practice as

Speaker: NA
Text: maintained by Centrelink does present

Speaker: NA
Text: people with a challenge in its complexity.

Speaker: NA
Text: The member for Kingston, the chair of the

Speaker: NA
Text: committee, also reflected in her contribution

Speaker: NA
Text: this morning on the importance of having

Speaker: NA
Text: plain English materials available to explain

Speaker: NA
Text: to people these measures that will be

Speaker: NA
Text: enacted, letting them understand clearly what

Speaker: NA
Text: is at stake and their rights and

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibilities under this system.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think these are important measures. But

Speaker: NA
Text: again I come back to the point that, if we put

Speaker: NA
Text: in place a punitive measure, that will not be

Speaker: NA
Text: to the longer term benefit of the people we

Speaker: NA
Text: are seeking to help. I am encouraged, having

Speaker: NA
Text: had discussions with the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Kingston on this issue, because I have a deep

Speaker: NA
Text: interest in the bill, particularly for the seat

Speaker: NA
Text: that I represent-Chifley, in Western

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney, where we have our fair share of

Speaker: NA
Text: long-term unemployed and where retention

Speaker: NA
Text: rates are lower than the national average. In

Speaker: NA
Text: fact, when I reflect on it, political parties

Speaker: NA
Text: either persuasion have sought to tighten up

Speaker: NA
Text: compliance in welfare reform. It makes for

Speaker: NA
Text: great headlines, but whether or not it has a

Speaker: NA
Text: meaningful impact on the long-term

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployed is the next step that needs to be

Speaker: NA
Text: considered.

Speaker: NA
Text: In terms of the long-term unemployed

Speaker: NA
Text: themselves, we potentially look to hit a

Speaker: NA
Text: barrier where some of those people are not

Speaker: NA
Text: engaging in the economy for particular

Speaker: NA
Text: reasons-one of which, I would advance, is

Speaker: NA
Text: mental health issues, for example, or

Speaker: NA
Text: disability. What support measures are in

Speaker: NA
Text: place to ensure that they can start to engage

Speaker: NA
Text: with employers and take on work? It is not

Speaker: NA
Text: that they do not have a passion for it; it is

Speaker: NA
Text: that there are barriers that need to be

Speaker: NA
Text: addressed. We always need to be mindful of

Speaker: NA
Text: those. Again, in the consultations and

Speaker: NA
Text: discussions with the chair, the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Kingston, she said that this was a matter that

Speaker: NA
Text: had come up during the course of the public

Speaker: NA
Text: submissions and meetings that took place. It

Speaker: NA
Text: was reflected upon, too, that for people who

Speaker: NA
Text: did engage in the system who had, for

Speaker: NA
Text: example, a mental health issue or a

Speaker: NA
Text: disability, even if they had short periods of

Speaker: NA
Text: work and then lapsed-for want of a better

Speaker: NA
Text: term, for the purpose of ease of discussion in

Speaker: NA
Text: this debate-they still found a point at which

Speaker: NA
Text: they could re-engage and those periods of

Speaker: NA
Text: engagement lengthened. That is important as

Speaker: NA
Text: well.

Speaker: NA
Text: As I said, both sides of the House take

Speaker: NA
Text: punitive measures in this regard, and I am

Speaker: NA
Text: certainly not a bleeding heart. I think the

Speaker: NA
Text: priority is to keep people engaged in work, to

Speaker: NA
Text: keep people in a position where they are able

Speaker: NA
Text: to earn money for their own sake and their

Speaker: NA
Text: family's sake and meet the aspirations that

Speaker: NA
Text: they have for themselves and the ones they

Speaker: NA
Text: love. But this problem of long-term

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployment has bedevilled both sides of

Speaker: NA
Text: politics and we need to have (1) a

Speaker: NA
Text: of commitment to provide adequate resources

Speaker: NA
Text: and (2) patience so that we will commit over

Speaker: NA
Text: the long term to dealing with this long-term

Speaker: NA
Text: problem. We need to deal with the problem

Speaker: NA
Text: from an economic perspective, because

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly in an environment where we

Speaker: NA
Text: have skills shortages we must get those

Speaker: NA
Text: people re-engaged, and from a social and

Speaker: NA
Text: community perspective as well. Those are

Speaker: NA
Text: the points that I am very mindful of in this

Speaker: NA
Text: debate, in considering this bill, and in

Speaker: NA
Text: broader welfare reform as well. But this does

Speaker: NA
Text: not deny-both sides of politics share this-

Speaker: NA
Text: that we do need to find ways to keep people

Speaker: NA
Text: engaged in the economy and in the

Speaker: NA
Text: community.

Speaker: NA
Text: From an employment perspective,

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly through the course of a global

Speaker: NA
Text: financial crisis when 16 million jobs were

Speaker: NA
Text: lost in other advanced economies, I am

Speaker: NA
Text: proud of the fact that in our country we have

Speaker: NA
Text: been able to create more than 300,000 jobs

Speaker: NA
Text: since the GFC began. That included a

Speaker: NA
Text: training program, Work for the Dole projects

Speaker: NA
Text: et cetera. In this year's budget, as I have

Speaker: NA
Text: mentioned, the government is working

Speaker: NA
Text: towards and continuing its commitment to

Speaker: NA
Text: building our future workforce capabilities,

Speaker: NA
Text: especially through training and skilling

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians to boost the economy. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: building on the reforms the government has

Speaker: NA
Text: delivered in education, welfare and

Speaker: NA
Text: employment services. With obtaining a job

Speaker: NA
Text: comes a sense of responsibility and personal

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment, especially for the long-term

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployed for whom motivation to seek a

Speaker: NA
Text: job is difficult. However, there are many

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunities available and means to obtain

Speaker: NA
Text: assistance. The Minister for Employment

Speaker: NA
Text: Participation has previously said that for

Speaker: NA
Text: many years the rate at which job seekers

Speaker: NA
Text: attend appointments with employment

Speaker: NA
Text: services has been around 55 per cent and that

Speaker: NA
Text: the system is demand driven and there are no

Speaker: NA
Text: more waiting lists. This calls for a greater

Speaker: NA
Text: improvement in the appointments designed

Speaker: NA
Text: to help job seekers get into work. The bill

Speaker: NA
Text: improves the relationship of those seeking

Speaker: NA
Text: work and those wanting to help them find

Speaker: NA
Text: work .The proposed bill is a method to

Speaker: NA
Text: encourage job seekers to take steps to attend

Speaker: NA
Text: that first crucial appointment and to continue

Speaker: NA
Text: these appointments to help find work.

Speaker: NA
Text: Attending an appointment, commitment and

Speaker: NA
Text: punctuality are skills that job seekers can

Speaker: NA
Text: take when applying for future jobs.

Speaker: NA
Text: The suspension of income support

Speaker: NA
Text: payments for job seekers who fail to attend

Speaker: NA
Text: an appointment or participate in an activity

Speaker: NA
Text: with their employment service provider

Speaker: NA
Text: sends a sense of immediacy and seriousness

Speaker: NA
Text: at the importance of attending those

Speaker: NA
Text: appointments and activities to help find a

Speaker: NA
Text: job. If the job seeker fails to re-engage and

Speaker: NA
Text: does not have a reasonable excuse-a

Speaker: NA
Text: reconnection failure for missing their

Speaker: NA
Text: appointments-then there will be a penalty

Speaker: NA
Text: deducted from their next payment. However,

Speaker: NA
Text: if the job seeker then agrees to re-engage and

Speaker: NA
Text: to stay engaged and meet this requirement

Speaker: NA
Text: then payment is restored in full. The bill

Speaker: NA
Text: heads up job seekers to go down the right

Speaker: NA
Text: path and early intervention at the appropriate

Speaker: NA
Text: appointment stage looks at those affected by

Speaker: NA
Text: long-term unemployment. The bill

Speaker: NA
Text: encourages recipients into participation in

Speaker: NA
Text: work and community life and is part of our

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment to welfare reform. I commend

Speaker: NA
Text: the bill to the House.

Speaker: Mr TUDGE
Text: Aston) (12:54): I rise to

Speaker: NA
Text: speak on and support the Social Security

Speaker: NA
Text: Legislation Amendment (Job Seeker

Speaker: NA
Text: Compliance) Bill 2011. The bill in question

Speaker: NA
Text: will enhance the current job seeker

Speaker: NA
Text: compliance framework by providing

Speaker: NA
Text: additional incentives for job seekers to

Speaker: NA
Text: engage with their employment service

Speaker: NA
Text: providers and to participate fully in activities

Speaker: NA
Text: designed to improve their employment

Speaker: NA
Text: prospects. The bill is going to introduce

Speaker: NA
Text: suspension of payment for job seekers

Speaker: NA
Text: following an initial failure to attend an

Speaker: NA
Text: appointment or, in some instances, an

Speaker: NA
Text: activity such as training or Work for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Dole. As soon as a job seeker agrees to

Speaker: NA
Text: attend the appointment, however, their

Speaker: NA
Text: payment will be restored with full back

Speaker: NA
Text: payment.

Speaker: NA
Text: Under this bill all job seekers will be

Speaker: NA
Text: required to attend a rescheduled appointment

Speaker: NA
Text: regardless of their reasoning for missing the

Speaker: NA
Text: initial one. If the job seeker attends the

Speaker: NA
Text: rescheduled appointment they will not be

Speaker: NA
Text: penalised as such. If a job seeker, however,

Speaker: NA
Text: does not attend the rescheduled appointment,

Speaker: NA
Text: payment will again be suspended but this

Speaker: NA
Text: time if they do not have a reasonable excuse

Speaker: NA
Text: for missing the appointment they will incur a

Speaker: NA
Text: reconnection failure and lose payment for

Speaker: NA
Text: each day from the second missed

Speaker: NA
Text: appointment until they do attend a

Speaker: NA
Text: rescheduled appointment-that is, there will

Speaker: NA
Text: be no back pay for that particular period.

Speaker: NA
Text: Why is this particular bill necessary?

Speaker: NA
Text: There are reasons both in principle and in

Speaker: NA
Text: philosophy and there are also some very

Speaker: NA
Text: specific reasons why this bill is necessary.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let me first outline some of the broader

Speaker: NA
Text: principles why this bill is necessary. The

Speaker: NA
Text: broader principle is that we should be doing

Speaker: NA
Text: everything that we can to reasonably get

Speaker: NA
Text: people off welfare and into work. We do no

Speaker: NA
Text: service to anybody, whether it is to the

Speaker: NA
Text: broader community or indeed to unemployed

Speaker: NA
Text: people, by allowing people to stay on

Speaker: NA
Text: welfare without any responsibilities being

Speaker: NA
Text: attached to that welfare payment. I do not

Speaker: NA
Text: believe that we are a compassionate society

Speaker: NA
Text: by not attaching responsibilities to welfare.

Speaker: NA
Text: In fact, I do not think it is compassionate at

Speaker: NA
Text: all to not attach responsibilities to welfare.

Speaker: NA
Text: have seen this in my own electorate of Aston

Speaker: NA
Text: where people who become welfare

Speaker: NA
Text: dependent over time and do not accept jobs

Speaker: NA
Text: that are available for them to pursue become

Speaker: NA
Text: debilitated and you end up having long-term

Speaker: NA
Text: welfare dependence and long-term

Speaker: NA
Text: debilitation.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have also seen this in Indigenous

Speaker: NA
Text: communities at close quarters. I spent a few

Speaker: NA
Text: years working with Noel Pearson in the Cape

Speaker: NA
Text: York Institute where we were working on

Speaker: NA
Text: some welfare reform measures which indeed

Speaker: NA
Text: have become some of the groundbreaking

Speaker: NA
Text: welfare reform measures that are being

Speaker: NA
Text: rolled out in other places across Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: The insight which Noel Pearson had was that

Speaker: NA
Text: long-term welfare without reciprocity,

Speaker: NA
Text: without responsibility being added to welfare

Speaker: NA
Text: payments, can indeed lead to debilitation. I

Speaker: NA
Text: think that is a very important point which

Speaker: NA
Text: Pearson has been making very strongly for

Speaker: NA
Text: the last decade. He has spearheaded that

Speaker: NA
Text: effort to get all of us to be thinking

Speaker: NA
Text: differently about welfare-that it should not

Speaker: NA
Text: be a destination in itself but rather rightly

Speaker: NA
Text: considered a safety net for people in difficult

Speaker: NA
Text: circumstances and that welfare has

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibilities attached to it as well. So that

Speaker: NA
Text: is a very, very important principle which I

Speaker: NA
Text: think we need to stop and pause and think

Speaker: NA
Text: about. That should govern our actions in

Speaker: NA
Text: relation to welfare reform efforts-that is,

Speaker: NA
Text: that there is responsibility attached to

Speaker: NA
Text: welfare payments.

Speaker: NA
Text: The coalition has been talking about this

Speaker: NA
Text: broad principle for a long time. We

Speaker: NA
Text: introduced in the Howard government the

Speaker: NA
Text: Work for the Dole scheme and we also

Speaker: NA
Text: introduced mutual obligation as a broad

Speaker: NA
Text: principle. These were both very good

Speaker: NA
Text: measures which were put in place. I am

Speaker: NA
Text: pleased that the government is now saying

Speaker: NA
Text: that it also believes in some of those

Speaker: NA
Text: principles. I certainly was concerned, I think

Speaker: NA
Text: I it was in 2008, when the employment

Speaker: NA
Text: minister at the time was telling Centrelink

Speaker: NA
Text: officers that they should not be breaching

Speaker: NA
Text: people who had not been delivering upon

Speaker: NA
Text: their job compliance requirements. I think it

Speaker: NA
Text: is important that we have a system in place

Speaker: NA
Text: and that it is adhered to. That is the broader

Speaker: NA
Text: philosophical reason why I think this bill is

Speaker: NA
Text: an important step in the right direction. If we

Speaker: NA
Text: look at the actual specifics, we will also see

Speaker: NA
Text: that action needs to be taken in this particular

Speaker: NA
Text: area. When we look at the data we see that,

Speaker: NA
Text: currently, unemployment is at a low point,

Speaker: NA
Text: about 4.9 per cent. By long-term historical

Speaker: NA
Text: standards we have very low unemployment.

Speaker: NA
Text: At the same time, however, there are

Speaker: NA
Text: 179,000 people in long-term unemployment

Speaker: NA
Text: and there are of course many people who are

Speaker: NA
Text: in short-term unemployment. One of the key

Speaker: NA
Text: economic issues that we have at the same

Speaker: NA
Text: time is indeed a labour shortage, a skills

Speaker: NA
Text: shortage. I hear about it every day in my

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate and we read about it in the

Speaker: NA
Text: newspapers on a daily basis: businesses

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot find workers-sometimes workers at

Speaker: NA
Text: be reasonably entry level jobs, low-skill jobs.

Speaker: NA
Text: Of course, there is also great demand for

Speaker: NA
Text: skilled workers. But at the same time that

Speaker: NA
Text: these jobs are going begging only 55 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: of job seekers are actually attending

Speaker: NA
Text: appointments with employment service

Speaker: NA
Text: providers. So 45 per cent of appointments

Speaker: NA
Text: with job service providers are being missed.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the last 12 months alone, approximately

Speaker: NA
Text: two million job interviews, activities or

Speaker: NA
Text: provider appointments were missed. These

Speaker: NA
Text: are staggering numbers. When only 55 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent of people are attending their

Speaker: NA
Text: appointments then I think we do need to look

Speaker: NA
Text: more closely at that and strengthen some of

Speaker: NA
Text: the compliance measures. This bill heads in

Speaker: NA
Text: the right direction on that.

Speaker: NA
Text: The bill itself outlines a broad framework.

Speaker: NA
Text: In some respects, the devil in the detail of

Speaker: NA
Text: this bill will come about by looking at the

Speaker: NA
Text: specifics of what is defined as a 'reasonable

Speaker: NA
Text: excuse' for not attending an appointment. Of

Speaker: NA
Text: course, there are many valid, legitimate

Speaker: NA
Text: reasons for not attending an appointment.

Speaker: NA
Text: You could be in an accident yourself and

Speaker: NA
Text: therefore physically unable to get to an

Speaker: NA
Text: appointment. There could be other very

Speaker: NA
Text: legitimate reasons why you cannot make an

Speaker: NA
Text: appointment and they should be specified

Speaker: NA
Text: and documented so that Centrelink officials

Speaker: NA
Text: are aware of those. But we do not want to

Speaker: NA
Text: make the list so broad that it will be overly

Speaker: NA
Text: easy for a job seeker to avoid having to

Speaker: NA
Text: deliver upon their obligations. We need to

Speaker: NA
Text: carefully think about and carefully define

Speaker: NA
Text: what a reasonable excuse is for not attending

Speaker: NA
Text: interviews or job seeker appointments. We

Speaker: NA
Text: will be watching very carefully what the

Speaker: NA
Text: regulations say in relation to that.

Speaker: NA
Text: We also need to look at what the burden

Speaker: NA
Text: on Centrelink will be. This bill introduces

Speaker: NA
Text: some additional burdens on Centrelink to

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure that the measures can be enacted and

Speaker: NA
Text: enacted in a timely manner. Centrelink

Speaker: NA
Text: obviously needs to be properly resourced to

Speaker: NA
Text: deal with these additional burdens so that the

Speaker: NA
Text: agency can act quickly and send the message

Speaker: NA
Text: quickly to the job seeker so that the job

Speaker: NA
Text: seeker understands that a penalty will be

Speaker: NA
Text: coming. I assume this will also require

Speaker: NA
Text: additional IT investment in Centrelink's

Speaker: NA
Text: systems for that to occur. That needs to be

Speaker: NA
Text: examined, and I have heard very little about

Speaker: NA
Text: what is going to occur in that area.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are also some recommendations and

Speaker: NA
Text: other issues which should be addressed

Speaker: NA
Text: concurrently with the introduction of this

Speaker: NA
Text: bill. Some of these came up at the House of

Speaker: NA
Text: Representatives Standing Committee on

Speaker: NA
Text: Education and Employment inquiry into this

Speaker: NA
Text: bill. I was a part of that inquiry. Some of

Speaker: NA
Text: those recommendations are quite sensible.

Speaker: NA
Text: One is the need for additional research or

Speaker: NA
Text: additional data to be collected on exactly

Speaker: NA
Text: why people are failing to meet their job

Speaker: NA
Text: seeker appointments and their requirements

Speaker: NA
Text: under the compliance regimes. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Brotherhood of St Laurence, which made a

Speaker: NA
Text: submission, suggested that we need a 'more

Speaker: NA
Text: considered understanding through research

Speaker: NA
Text: of the reasons why the various subgroups

Speaker: NA
Text: and subpopulations of job seekers are not

Speaker: NA
Text: connecting well with their service providers'.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think the recommendation that additional

Speaker: NA
Text: research be undertaken is sensible.

Speaker: NA
Text: I will highlight some of the other

Speaker: NA
Text: recommendations that came out of the House

Speaker: NA
Text: of Representatives inquiry that I think the

Speaker: NA
Text: government should consider closely and,

Speaker: NA
Text: hopefully, enact. Recommendation 2

Speaker: NA
Text: recommended 'developing consistent

Speaker: NA
Text: guidance and training materials to

Speaker: NA
Text: accompany the bill'. I think recommendation

Speaker: NA
Text: 4 is worthy of consideration and

Speaker: NA
Text: implementation. The committee

Speaker: NA
Text: recommended that employment service

Speaker: NA
Text: providers be given clear and comprehensive

Speaker: NA
Text: guidance as to how to utilise their discretion

Speaker: NA
Text: to submit a participation report on a missed

Speaker: NA
Text: appointment. In fact, one issue which came

Speaker: NA
Text: out very strongly through the parliamentary

Speaker: NA
Text: inquiry was that employment service

Speaker: NA
Text: providers do have a broad range of discretion

Speaker: NA
Text: and that having additional guidelines would

Speaker: NA
Text: help them make responsible and timely

Speaker: NA
Text: decisions.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let me conclude by, again, reiterating my

Speaker: NA
Text: support for this bill. I think it is a bill

Speaker: NA
Text: is heading in the right direction as a further

Speaker: NA
Text: measure of welfare reform. As I said

Speaker: NA
Text: previously, welfare reform is something

Speaker: NA
Text: which the coalition has been talking about

Speaker: NA
Text: for some time, and it enacted some important

Speaker: NA
Text: measures when it was in government. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: also an area in which I have had a personal

Speaker: NA
Text: interest and have worked for a period of

Speaker: NA
Text: time. I support the measures. I hope that they

Speaker: NA
Text: do have an impact in supporting job seekers

Speaker: NA
Text: to find work which they can get satisfaction

Speaker: NA
Text: from doing and in getting them off the

Speaker: NA
Text: welfare payment system.

Speaker: Mr NEUMANN
Text: Blair) (13:06): I speak

Speaker: NA
Text: in support of the Social Security Legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: Amendment (Job Seeker Compliance) Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: 2011. Last night in his budget speech the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer talked about jobs, workforce

Speaker: NA
Text: participation and getting for people what the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister has often described as the

Speaker: NA
Text: benefit and dignity of work. I would describe

Speaker: NA
Text: it as self-esteem and self-belief; that is what

Speaker: NA
Text: it is about. Getting a person a job is the best

Speaker: NA
Text: way to redistribute wealth in this country.

Speaker: NA
Text: The old-fashioned notions that you engage in

Speaker: NA
Text: some sort of Marxist or communistic

Speaker: NA
Text: redistribution of wealth are well and truly

Speaker: NA
Text: gone out of the pantheon of responsible

Speaker: NA
Text: political parties in this country. The idea

Speaker: NA
Text: get a person a job. If you create jobs you

Speaker: NA
Text: create wealth, you create financial security

Speaker: NA
Text: and you create self-esteem, not just in the

Speaker: NA
Text: household but in the next generation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Intergenerational poverty is attacked by

Speaker: NA
Text: getting a person a job. Sometimes you need

Speaker: NA
Text: to be tough; you need to be a person who

Speaker: NA
Text: gives someone a prod. A government

Speaker: NA
Text: sometimes needs to do that. Sometimes

Speaker: NA
Text: governments need to express that tough love.

Speaker: NA
Text: Sometimes we need to actually provide an

Speaker: NA
Text: incentive for people to break out of the cycle

Speaker: NA
Text: of the despair and depression of

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployment.

Speaker: NA
Text: Last night the Treasurer talked about

Speaker: NA
Text: which creating infrastructure projects that will

Speaker: NA
Text: create jobs in my home state of Queensland.

Speaker: NA
Text: This bill is about making sure that people

Speaker: NA
Text: will work in those types of projects-

Speaker: NA
Text: projects that will create important wealth

Speaker: NA
Text: across Queensland through the mining boom

Speaker: NA
Text: and across the agricultural sector, in retail

Speaker: NA
Text: and construction and all across South-East

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland and Queensland generally. What

Speaker: NA
Text: we saw last night was the creation of

Speaker: NA
Text: incentives to work, a carrot-and-stick

Speaker: NA
Text: approach that will deliver a new workplace

Speaker: NA
Text: development fund to create 130,000 new

Speaker: NA
Text: training places over four years. In my home

Speaker: NA
Text: state of Queensland we will see trade

Speaker: NA
Text: apprentice income bonuses for 95,800

Speaker: NA
Text: Queenslanders, who will receive a $1,700

Speaker: NA
Text: benefit. In my electorate, 2,786 people will

Speaker: NA
Text: enjoy the benefit of that sort of trade bonus

Speaker: NA
Text: income assistance.

Speaker: NA
Text: You will see incentives for employment,

Speaker: NA
Text: and that is what we are talking about here in

Speaker: NA
Text: this legislation-incentives to help people to

Speaker: NA
Text: get jobs. Obviously in my electorate we will

Speaker: NA
Text: need that help as we recover from the flood,

Speaker: NA
Text: but we will see that help across Queensland.

Speaker: NA
Text: In Queensland, 48,887 of the very long-term

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployed-people who have been without

Speaker: NA
Text: work for two years or more-will get help to

Speaker: NA
Text: is to find work and prepare for work, with an

Speaker: NA
Text: additional $2.7 million from 2012 to 2015 to

Speaker: NA
Text: support local employment services as well.

Speaker: NA
Text: We are going to see that across Queensland

Speaker: NA
Text: and elsewhere, and we are going to see that

Speaker: NA
Text: as we get these people back into

Speaker: NA
Text: employment.

Speaker: NA
Text: Unemployment in this country is 4.9 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent. In America it is about 8.8 per cent and

Speaker: NA
Text: across the European zone it is about 9.9 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent. As the Treasurer said in a speech I

Speaker: NA
Text: heard not more than 10 or 15 minutes ago,

Speaker: NA
Text: we do not have a person to spare. So

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation of the sort before us today

Speaker: NA
Text: in with the narrative we are talking about in

Speaker: NA
Text: creating wealth, creating jobs, creating

Speaker: NA
Text: productivity growth and making sure that

Speaker: NA
Text: economic development is spread across the

Speaker: NA
Text: whole economy, particularly in flood

Speaker: NA
Text: affected areas of Queensland.

Speaker: NA
Text: This bill represents another example of

Speaker: NA
Text: how the federal Labor government is helping

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployed people back to work. I grew up

Speaker: NA
Text: in a household in which my dad was a

Speaker: NA
Text: cleaner at the meatworks and my mum was a

Speaker: NA
Text: shop assistant, so I knew how important a

Speaker: NA
Text: job was in what is traditionally described as

Speaker: NA
Text: a working-class family in Ipswich. I know

Speaker: NA
Text: the importance of hard work to self-esteem,

Speaker: NA
Text: to career possibilities, to being able to fulfil

Speaker: NA
Text: potential, to provide for your family the kind

Speaker: NA
Text: of financial security it needs and to build a

Speaker: NA
Text: worthwhile life of not just affluence but also

Speaker: NA
Text: security. Employment is absolutely essential

Speaker: NA
Text: to creating a productive nation and to

Speaker: NA
Text: supporting families, and to give a firm

Speaker: NA
Text: direction to job seekers is absolutely critical.

Speaker: NA
Text: This bill implements our election

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment to introduce tougher rules for

Speaker: NA
Text: job seekers. Announced on 11 August 2010

Speaker: NA
Text: as part of our program was a policy named

Speaker: NA
Text: Modernising Australia's Welfare System.

Speaker: NA
Text: The amendments in this bill will improve the

Speaker: NA
Text: current job seeker compliance framework by

Speaker: NA
Text: providing additional incentives for job

Speaker: NA
Text: seekers to engage with their employment

Speaker: NA
Text: service providers and to participate fully in

Speaker: NA
Text: activities designed to improve their

Speaker: NA
Text: employment prospects.

Speaker: NA
