Text: We have seen over and over how long-

Speaker: NA
Text: term unemployment can destroy self-esteem,

Speaker: NA
Text: create intergenerational poverty and cause

Speaker: NA
Text: whole communities to go into despair, to go

Speaker: NA
Text: into activities of crime and to have poor

Speaker: NA
Text: health outcomes and regression. When

Speaker: NA
Text: does fit communities are not healthy in their

Speaker: NA
Text: economic prospect, people get an unhealthy

Speaker: NA
Text: physical outlook on life and engage in all

Speaker: NA
Text: kinds of nefarious behaviour. So getting a

Speaker: NA
Text: person a job is a good way not just to reduce

Speaker: NA
Text: criminal activities but also to improve the

Speaker: NA
Text: prospects of regional and rural areas as well

Speaker: NA
Text: as urban areas across the country.

Speaker: NA
Text: Too many Australians who are without a

Speaker: NA
Text: job and are capable of work rely on

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployment benefits or the like. At a time

Speaker: NA
Text: when our economy is going from strength to

Speaker: NA
Text: strength, particularly enjoying the benefit of

Speaker: NA
Text: the mining boom, we need to make sure we

Speaker: NA
Text: can get people into employment. Talking to

Speaker: NA
Text: manufacturing industries in my electorate, in

Speaker: NA
Text: Ipswich and Somerset, as well as people in

Speaker: NA
Text: the metalworks industries across my

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate and big employers like Swift

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia at Dinmore, where there is one of

Speaker: NA
Text: the biggest meatworks across the country, I

Speaker: NA
Text: hear them crying out for more and more

Speaker: NA
Text: employment. We are seeing more and more

Speaker: NA
Text: people going from, say, the Bremer Institute

Speaker: NA
Text: of TAFE, before they have completed their

Speaker: NA
Text: TAFE courses, onto the mining sector. So we

Speaker: NA
Text: are creating these workforce shortages,

Speaker: NA
Text: scattered around economies west, south and

Speaker: NA
Text: north of Brisbane.

Speaker: NA
Text: This government is determined to make

Speaker: NA
Text: sure that unemployed people get back in the

Speaker: NA
Text: workforce and can be engaged as productive

Speaker: NA
Text: members of our society. People who have

Speaker: NA
Text: jobs are more likely to engage in civic

Speaker: NA
Text: society. They are more likely to be involved

Speaker: NA
Text: in sporting groups and RSLs. They are more

Speaker: NA
Text: likely to be involved in church and charitable

Speaker: NA
Text: work. They are more likely to help the

Speaker: NA
Text: homeless. They are more likely to be on P&F

Speaker: NA
Text: associations. They are more likely to

Speaker: NA
Text: participate in civic life, because they feel

Speaker: NA
Text: they have a stake in it. So this is good not

Speaker: NA
Text: just for social inclusion but for social equity

Speaker: NA
Text: and for the benefit of our economic

Speaker: NA
Text: development. At times it means that we have

Speaker: NA
Text: to be disciplined; we have to be tough, and

Speaker: NA
Text: the government takes a parens patriae

Speaker: NA
Text: approach when it comes to this. It is a case of

Speaker: NA
Text: adopting a fairly paternalistic approach, but

Speaker: NA
Text: it is necessary. This bill will introduce

Speaker: NA
Text: suspension of payments for job seekers

Speaker: NA
Text: following an initial failure to attend an

Speaker: NA
Text: appointment or, in some circumstances, an

Speaker: NA
Text: activity such as a Work for the Dole scheme.

Speaker: NA
Text: As soon as the job seeker agrees to attend

Speaker: NA
Text: this appointment, their payment will be

Speaker: NA
Text: restored with full back pay. All job seekers

Speaker: NA
Text: will be required to attend a rescheduled

Speaker: NA
Text: appointment regardless of their reason for

Speaker: NA
Text: missing the first appointment. If a job seeker

Speaker: NA
Text: attends the rescheduled appointment, they

Speaker: NA
Text: will not be penalised. In this way, job

Speaker: NA
Text: seekers will learn to understand the

Speaker: NA
Text: importance of taking personal measures to

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure that they find work. When they get a

Speaker: NA
Text: job, if the job starts at 9 am, they cannot

Speaker: NA
Text: say, 'I'm going to turn up at 10 or 11 am.'

Speaker: NA
Text: What employer would want that? They need

Speaker: NA
Text: discipline in their lives, and the discipline

Speaker: NA
Text: that they will gain in attending these

Speaker: NA
Text: rescheduled appointments will be very

Speaker: NA
Text: important for them. In this way, job seekers

Speaker: NA
Text: will be encouraged to actively look for future

Speaker: NA
Text: employment prospects and will get used to

Speaker: NA
Text: the idea of fulfilling their obligations.

Speaker: NA
Text: Should a job seeker not attend a

Speaker: NA
Text: rescheduled appointment, payment will again

Speaker: NA
Text: be suspended. But this time, if they do not

Speaker: NA
Text: have a reasonable excuse for missing the

Speaker: NA
Text: appointment, they will incur a reconnection

Speaker: NA
Text: failure fee and lose payment for each day

Speaker: NA
Text: from the second missed appointment until

Speaker: NA
Text: they reconnect. And they will not receive

Speaker: NA
Text: any back pay. That is the stick approach.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is punishment. Reasonable-excuse

Speaker: NA
Text: provisions are going to be tightened so that if

Speaker: NA
Text: a job seeker has a reasonable excuse for not

Speaker: NA
Text: attending an appointment or activity it will

Speaker: NA
Text: not be accepted if they could have given

Speaker: NA
Text: advance notice of their inability to attend. In

Speaker: NA
Text: this way, job seekers will be under no

Speaker: NA
Text: illusions as to the expectation of the federal

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor government that they need to take

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility in securing employment. In

Speaker: NA
Text: this way, the self-esteem, the pride or the

Speaker: NA
Text: dignity-whatever you want to call it-of

Speaker: NA
Text: work and the value of contributing to the

Speaker: NA
Text: ongoing prosperity of their country and their

Speaker: NA
Text: respective communities can become an

Speaker: NA
Text: important part of their lives. That will be

Speaker: NA
Text: good for them and good for their children as

Speaker: NA
Text: well. If they have not experienced it in the

Speaker: NA
Text: past, it will be good for them to pass on that

Speaker: NA
Text: message-as employers will, no doubt, when

Speaker: NA
Text: they ultimately find a job.

Speaker: NA
Text: We cannot afford lost opportunities in

Speaker: NA
Text: terms of employment. In an electorate like

Speaker: NA
Text: mine, which includes the two fastest growing

Speaker: NA
Text: areas in south-east Queensland, Somerset at

Speaker: NA
Text: 4.2 per cent growth last year and Ipswich at

Speaker: NA
Text: just 3.5 per cent growth, we cannot afford to

Speaker: NA
Text: have people not in employment. The

Speaker: NA
Text: development of the whole corridor west of

Speaker: NA
Text: Brisbane is crucial, and jobs created locally,

Speaker: NA
Text: with people trained and employed locally,

Speaker: NA
Text: are absolutely vital.

Speaker: NA
Text: This approach involves us engaging in

Speaker: NA
Text: what I would have to describe as some pretty

Speaker: NA
Text: tough big brother tactics. But that is

Speaker: NA
Text: absolutely necessary. We know that job

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunities are crucial. We need to tell

Speaker: NA
Text: people that. We need to tell that to our

Speaker: NA
Text: children and our neighbours and our friends.

Speaker: NA
Text: As someone who has employed dozens and

Speaker: NA
Text: dozens of people in his working life, I can

Speaker: NA
Text: tell you that it is extremely important that

Speaker: NA
Text: you get the right person for the job and that

Speaker: NA
Text: that person knows that they have to turn up

Speaker: NA
Text: on time, be there, work and contribute. This

Speaker: NA
Text: approach looks tough. It is tough. It should

Speaker: NA
Text: be tough, because it will benefit the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian economy. I commend the

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation to the House.

Speaker: Dr SOUTHCOTT
Text: Boothby) (13:18): In

Speaker: NA
Text: speaking on the Social Security Legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: Amendment (Job Seeker Compliance) Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: 2011, it is worth going back three years to

Speaker: NA
Text: the heady days of Kevin 07 and the first

Speaker: NA
Text: months of the government and all of the

Speaker: NA
Text: things that Labor had promised that sounded

Speaker: NA
Text: so good at the time but which have turned

Speaker: NA
Text: out to be massive failures. These include the

Speaker: NA
Text: trades training centres, the productivity

Speaker: NA
Text: places program, the GP superclinics and,

Speaker: NA
Text: later, pink batts and school halls. You need

Speaker: NA
Text: to have a memory longer than a goldfish to

Speaker: NA
Text: remember why we are debating this. When

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor were elected they proceeded to

Speaker: NA
Text: dismantle the Job Network and they wound

Speaker: NA
Text: back the principle of mutual obligation that

Speaker: NA
Text: had underpinned the creation of more than

Speaker: NA
Text: two million jobs, more than one million of

Speaker: NA
Text: them full-time jobs.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have a personal interest in this because,

Speaker: NA
Text: as opposition spokesperson on employment

Speaker: NA
Text: participation from 2007 to 2009, I remember

Speaker: NA
Text: what the Labor Party did. When they came

Speaker: NA
Text: into government, very early on the

Speaker: NA
Text: departmental secretary advised employment

Speaker: NA
Text: service providers to be lenient on job

Speaker: NA
Text: regarding their mutual obligations. But then

Speaker: NA
Text: they came up with this concept of no show,

Speaker: NA
Text: no pay. The opposition warned at the time

Speaker: NA
Text: that this would be a failure-a massive

Speaker: NA
Text: failure-and that it would see a rise in long-

Speaker: NA
Text: term unemployment and do nothing to

Speaker: NA
Text: address welfare dependency. Today, we have

Speaker: NA
Text: the very sorry picture of Australia having

Speaker: NA
Text: one of the highest rates of jobless families in

Speaker: NA
Text: the world. We need to go back and

Speaker: NA
Text: remember why mutual obligation is

Speaker: NA
Text: important.

Speaker: NA
Text: Work for the Dole is commonly

Speaker: NA
Text: understood as being one of the landmark

Speaker: NA
Text: programs of mutual obligation. Since it was

Speaker: NA
Text: introduced in 1997, more than 600,000 have

Speaker: NA
Text: participated in Work for the Dole. They have

Speaker: NA
Text: gained the discipline and dignity of

Speaker: NA
Text: performing useful work while developing

Speaker: NA
Text: life skills critical to obtaining and keeping a

Speaker: NA
Text: real job. The Labor Party promised to keep

Speaker: NA
Text: Work for the Dole at the 2007 election. But

Speaker: NA
Text: by their actions they have allowed it to decay

Speaker: NA
Text: and become a hollow shell of what it was.

Speaker: NA
Text: Since 2007, Work for the Dole participation

Speaker: NA
Text: has fallen by 60 per cent to less than 10,000.

Speaker: NA
Text: Under the coalition, Work for the Dole

Speaker: NA
Text: projects were designed to address at least one

Speaker: NA
Text: skill in demand. Work for the Dole helped by

Speaker: NA
Text: breaking the cycle of welfare dependency

Speaker: NA
Text: and encouraging a work ethic. It helped to

Speaker: NA
Text: get job seekers job ready. The evidence

Speaker: NA
Text: shows that the longer someone is out of the

Speaker: NA
Text: workforce the less likely it is that they will

Speaker: NA
Text: ever work again. Work for the Dole provides

Speaker: NA
Text: people with a job-like experience, giving

Speaker: NA
Text: them skills and getting them into a work

Speaker: NA
Text: routine. The coalition has always held very

Speaker: NA
Text: strongly that those in receipt of

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployment benefits must recognise that

Speaker: NA
Text: they have a subsequent responsibility to look

Speaker: NA
Text: for work and contribute back to the society

Speaker: NA
Text: seekers that supports them. When Labor were

Speaker: NA
Text: elected, they proposed the introduction of a

Speaker: NA
Text: no-show, no-pay compliance system.

Speaker: NA
Text: Incredibly, this meant that, if a job seeker

Speaker: NA
Text: missed a job interview, if they did not turn

Speaker: NA
Text: up to a Work for the Dole activity or if they

Speaker: NA
Text: did not attend an appointment with their

Speaker: NA
Text: employment service provider, they were

Speaker: NA
Text: docked one day's pay, $44.93 as at 5

Speaker: NA
Text: December 2008, when it was introduced.

Speaker: NA
Text: It gives me no pleasure at all to say that

Speaker: NA
Text: the points the opposition made in late 2008

Speaker: NA
Text: and early 2009 have been proven right. At

Speaker: NA
Text: the time in October 2008 when Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: introduced this failed system, I said:

Speaker: NA
Text: In striking a balance between engagement and

Speaker: NA
Text: sanction, the government have got the balance

Speaker: NA
Text: wrong.

Speaker: NA
Text: I also said:

Speaker: NA
Text: Going into the future, we will see, sadly,

Speaker: NA
Text: increased numbers of long-term unemployed if

Speaker: NA
Text: the Labor government have their system for

Speaker: NA
Text: employment services passed by this parliament …

Speaker: NA
Text: Since then we have seen that the numbers of

Speaker: NA
Text: long-term unemployed have skyrocketed,

Speaker: NA
Text: and they have skyrocketed particularly since

Speaker: NA
Text: the introduction of Job Services Australia in

Speaker: NA
Text: July 2009. At the moment, the percentage of

Speaker: NA
Text: long-term unemployed as a proportion of the

Speaker: NA
Text: total unemployed is over 20 per cent. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: the highest it has been in at least five years.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have also seen huge increases in the

Speaker: NA
Text: numbers of people who are classified as

Speaker: NA
Text: long-term unemployed. On the ABS figures,

Speaker: NA
Text: when Labor came to power there were less

Speaker: NA
Text: than 70,000 Australians who were long-term

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployed. There are now almost 120,000

Speaker: NA
Text: on the ABS figures. But on the job seeker

Speaker: NA
Text: figures it is even worse than that. On the

Speaker: NA
Text: figures that I have, in March 2011 there were

Speaker: NA
Text: 179,041 job seekers listed as long-term

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployed.

Speaker: NA
Text: Now, incredibly, Labor's no-show, no-pay

Speaker: NA
Text: system will not even last two years. It was

Speaker: NA
Text: already obvious that this was a massive

Speaker: NA
Text: failure within a year of them introducing it.

Speaker: NA
Text: Unbelievably, in the last 12 months there

Speaker: NA
Text: have been approximately two million job

Speaker: NA
Text: interviews, activities or

Speaker: NA
Text: appointments missed by job seekers with no

Speaker: NA
Text: excuses or with unsatisfactory excuses given.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is yet another example of a government

Speaker: NA
Text: which has lost its way and of a government

Speaker: NA
Text: which has been shown to be completely

Speaker: NA
Text: incompetent in addressing the challenges of

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployment and the challenges of welfare

Speaker: NA
Text: reform. The high rate of missed

Speaker: NA
Text: appointments over the last 12 months is clear

Speaker: NA
Text: evidence that the Labor government's

Speaker: NA
Text: watering down of mutual obligation in 2008

Speaker: NA
Text: with their no-show, no-pay compliance

Speaker: NA
Text: model did not work.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not like, as a rule, to quote from

Speaker: NA
Text: myself, but in October 2008 I said:

Speaker: NA
Text: The problem with weakening the compliance

Speaker: NA
Text: regime is that it will be much less effective in

Speaker: NA
Text: changing behaviour for the positive. It will

Speaker: NA
Text: become a toothless tiger.

Speaker: NA
Text: And that is why we are here today. When

Speaker: NA
Text: you hear the government speakers, it is as if

Speaker: NA
Text: they are saying, 'We have to come in and be

Speaker: NA
Text: tough and get more compliance.' This is a

Speaker: NA
Text: classic example of trying to fix a problem

Speaker: NA
Text: that you have created. This was created by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Labor Party, by the government and by

Speaker: NA
Text: the incompetence of your ministers. We said

Speaker: NA
Text: that no show, no pay would not work

Speaker: NA
Text: because there was not enough disincentive.

Speaker: NA
Text: Clearly that is right. There have been more

Speaker: NA
Text: than two million missed interviews, missed

Speaker: NA
Text: appointments and missed attendances at

Speaker: NA
Text: things like Work for the Dole. This is yet

Speaker: NA
Text: another policy failure from the government.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is a policy failure of their own creation.

Speaker: NA
Text: This bill seeks to correct the government's

Speaker: NA
Text: own failure by reinstating some tougher

Speaker: NA
Text: compliance measures for job seekers with

Speaker: NA
Text: activity test requirements, and this is a

Speaker: NA
Text: welcome restoration. But it is a totally

Speaker: NA
Text: unnecessary restoration. It is only necessary

Speaker: NA
Text: because the government in their wisdom

Speaker: NA
Text: decided that they would water down mutual

Speaker: NA
Text: obligation-and there are still some

Speaker: NA
Text: provider problems on that front. Work for the Dole, as

Speaker: NA
Text: I said, is a hollow shell of what it was. Of the

Speaker: NA
Text: new Job Services Australia structure that was

Speaker: NA
Text: announced with so much fanfare in 2008-09,

Speaker: NA
Text: much of it has not even survived this year's

Speaker: NA
Text: budget. It has not even gone for three years

Speaker: NA
Text: and already the government have realised

Speaker: NA
Text: that things like the Innovation Fund are not

Speaker: NA
Text: working, and they have been allowed to fall

Speaker: NA
Text: by the wayside.

Speaker: NA
Text: The opposition welcomes a firm but fair

Speaker: NA
Text: system to ensure that those receiving income

Speaker: NA
Text: support who are capable of working

Speaker: NA
Text: recognise that welfare is a temporary safety

Speaker: NA
Text: net and not a lifestyle choice. On the

Speaker: NA
Text: specifics of the legislation, in the event of a

Speaker: NA
Text: job seeker failing to attend an appointment or

Speaker: NA
Text: a required activity like Work for the Dole

Speaker: NA
Text: without a reasonable excuse being given in

Speaker: NA
Text: advance, support payments for that job

Speaker: NA
Text: seeker will be suspended. The onus will then

Speaker: NA
Text: be on the job seeker to attend a rescheduled

Speaker: NA
Text: appointment, when their payment will be

Speaker: NA
Text: reinstated with back pay. If the job seeker

Speaker: NA
Text: fails to attend the rescheduled appointment,

Speaker: NA
Text: payment will be suspended indefinitely until

Speaker: NA
Text: they do attend an appointment, with no back

Speaker: NA
Text: pay payable. In addition, the reasonable-

Speaker: NA
Text: excuse provisions are also being tightened to

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure that even if there was a reasonable

Speaker: NA
Text: excuse it will not be accepted if they could

Speaker: NA
Text: have given advance notice for not attending.

Speaker: NA
Text: In closing, I welcome

Speaker: NA
Text: acknowledgement by the government that

Speaker: NA
Text: their no-show, no-pay compliance system

Speaker: NA
Text: has failed. The results are there for all to

Speaker: NA
Text: two million missed job interviews,

Speaker: NA
Text: appointments and activities and long-term

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployment now at 179,000, compared

Speaker: NA
Text: with 69,900 when Labor came to power. I

Speaker: NA
Text: think it is regrettable that these have been

Speaker: NA
Text: two wasted years for people who are on

Speaker: NA
Text: welfare, for people who are long-term

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployed, but I do welcome the

Speaker: NA
Text: acknowledgement by the government that

Speaker: NA
Text: their system has failed. We are now moving

Speaker: NA
Text: on to Job Services Australia mark 2, and I

Speaker: NA
Text: welcome the changes proposed today to

Speaker: NA
Text: restore tougher compliance measures for job

Speaker: NA
Text: seekers.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms O'NEILL (Robertson) (13:30): I rise

Speaker: NA
Text: to speak in support of the Social Security

Speaker: NA
Text: Legislation Amendment (Job Seeker

Speaker: NA
Text: Compliance) Bill 2011. The task of welfare

Speaker: NA
Text: reform and management is obviously not an

Speaker: NA
Text: easy one; however, it is one of the very

Speaker: NA
Text: important tasks and activities of this

Speaker: NA
Text: parliament. Welfare and participation

Speaker: NA
Text: payments are fundamental in ensuring that

Speaker: NA
Text: an appropriate social safety net exists in this

Speaker: NA
Text: country. It is the Australian Labor Party that

Speaker: NA
Text: has always recognised the great need for

Speaker: NA
Text: appropriate welfare in our society. It is the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Labor Party that has always

Speaker: NA
Text: recognised the need for appropriate

Speaker: NA
Text: participation payments in our society. In

Speaker: NA
Text: representing my electorate of Robertson, I

Speaker: NA
Text: am mindful that my work in this place

Speaker: NA
Text: should have a positive, practical impact on

Speaker: NA
Text: not only the lives of those in my electorate

Speaker: NA
Text: but all Australians.

Speaker: NA
Text: The practical considerations of any

Speaker: NA
Text: changes to legislation should be the

Speaker: NA
Text: dominant purpose for the welfare reform that

Speaker: NA
Text: we are undertaking-practical considerations

Speaker: NA
Text: the such as what benefits the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: community the most, and what is most

Speaker: NA
Text: beneficial for the long-term economic

Speaker: NA
Text: see: progress of the nation. This bill seeks to

Speaker: NA
Text: provide sensible reform to job seeker

Speaker: NA
Text: compliance. The role of participation

Speaker: NA
Text: payments is to provide welfare for the

Speaker: NA
Text: duration that a person is seeking employment

Speaker: NA
Text: until they are able to attain it. Indeed, under

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian social security system, job

Speaker: NA
Text: seekers are required to actively look for

Speaker: NA
Text: employment when they receive participation

Speaker: NA
Text: payments.

Speaker: NA
Text: This bill delivers on an election

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment that was part of the

Speaker: NA
Text: 'Modernising Australia's welfare system'

Speaker: NA
Text: package that was announced on 11 August

Speaker: NA
Text: 2011. The central component of this bill is

Speaker: NA
Text: the incentive it provides job seekers when

Speaker: NA
Text: they are receiving participation payments.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Social Security Administration Act 1999

Speaker: NA
Text: will be amended to provide for the

Speaker: NA
Text: suspension of a job seeker's income support

Speaker: NA
Text: payment if they fail to attend an appointment

Speaker: NA
Text: or engage in an activity such as training. This

Speaker: NA
Text: provision has the practical effect of

Speaker: NA
Text: providing an incentive for job seekers to

Speaker: NA
Text: attend appointments when required and to

Speaker: NA
Text: participate in activities that will benefit their

Speaker: NA
Text: future prospects of employment.

Speaker: NA
Text: Under the amendments, the suspension of

Speaker: NA
Text: income support payment will occur after the

Speaker: NA
Text: reporting of an initial failure to attend an

Speaker: NA
Text: appointment without a reasonable excuse, or

Speaker: NA
Text: a failure to participate in training actives

Speaker: NA
Text: without a reasonable excuse. Importantly,

Speaker: NA
Text: full income support payments will be

Speaker: NA
Text: restored when the job seeker re-engages with

Speaker: NA
Text: appointments and training requirements. This

Speaker: NA
Text: provides an important incentive for job

Speaker: NA
Text: seekers to comply with the requirements set

Speaker: NA
Text: down in the act. It is also important that

Speaker: NA
Text: these requirements are complied with not

Speaker: NA
Text: just for the benefit of the national economy

Speaker: NA
Text: and the wise expenditure of funds on welfare

Speaker: NA
Text: payments but also for the financial, social

Speaker: NA
Text: and emotional health of job seekers. Going

Speaker: NA
Text: out each day to look for work and being

Speaker: NA
Text: knocked back can, I think, sometimes be a

Speaker: NA
Text: very disheartening experience. In the

Speaker: NA
Text: evidence that we heard on this matter during

Speaker: NA
Text: the education and employment inquiry were

Speaker: NA
Text: stories of how critical it was for job seekers

Speaker: NA
Text: to have the engagement with service

Speaker: NA
Text: providers who were able to assist them to

Speaker: NA
Text: continue that journey, to identify areas that

Speaker: NA
Text: they might need training in and to share the

Speaker: NA
Text: experience of sometimes failure in achieving

Speaker: NA
Text: the jobs that they were after. It is vital that

Speaker: NA
Text: they reconnect and continue to share that

Speaker: NA
Text: journey towards full employment, which is

Speaker: NA
Text: so important for all Australians. There is so

Speaker: NA
Text: much to be said for the dignity of work, not

Speaker: NA
Text: just because of the freedom that it gives us

Speaker: NA
Text: and the money that we earn from it and then

Speaker: NA
Text: spend in our own particular way but also

Speaker: NA
Text: because of the connection it gives us with

Speaker: NA
Text: other human beings on a daily basis. People

Speaker: NA
Text: notice when we show up. People notice

Speaker: NA
Text: when we might not be there. Opportunities

Speaker: NA
Text: for care are provided in the workplace in

Speaker: NA
Text: very significant ways. It is not fair that some

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians should miss out on that. The

Speaker: NA
Text: capacity for service providers in this field to

Speaker: NA
Text: help people re-engage should not be

Speaker: NA
Text: underestimated, and that is why these

Speaker: NA
Text: appointments can be really critical in helping

Speaker: NA
Text: people succeed.

Speaker: NA
Text: Recently, I was involved in an apprentice

Speaker: NA
Text: drive by the Central Coast Group Training,

Speaker: NA
Text: and I wrote to over 500 small businesses in

Speaker: NA
Text: the seat of Robertson about it. I am pleased

Speaker: NA
Text: to report that the group training scheme

Speaker: NA
Text: reached its target of employing 30

Speaker: NA
Text: apprentices and trainees within 30 days-in

Speaker: NA
Text: fact, it exceeded its target. The vast majority

Speaker: NA
Text: of businesses to which I wrote were small

Speaker: NA
Text: businesses. An example of one small

Speaker: NA
Text: business that did employ a trainee from the

Speaker: NA
Text: apprentice drive was Ozone Express

Speaker: NA
Text: Laundrette. I have seen many generations of

Speaker: NA
Text: young people from the Central Coast

Speaker: NA
Text: transition through our vocational education

Speaker: NA
Text: and training system into small business. I can

Speaker: NA
Text: say without hesitation that I am passionate

Speaker: NA
Text: about youth employment in my region.

Speaker: NA
Text: Group training schemes and apprenticeships

Speaker: NA
Text: are vital in reducing the level of youth

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployment. But this of itself is not

Speaker: NA
Text: effective unless tied to the opportunities that

Speaker: NA
Text: can be provided by employment providers

Speaker: NA
Text: who assist particularly young people in

Speaker: NA
Text: getting into work. We need an appropriate

Speaker: NA
Text: system of compliance to encourage job

Speaker: NA
Text: seekers to go out and get on with looking for

Speaker: NA
Text: work.

Speaker: NA
Text: The suspension of payments provides the

Speaker: NA
Text: much needed incentive for some job seekers

Speaker: NA
Text: to re-engage quickly with their employment

Speaker: NA
Text: service provider and then when they do what

Speaker: NA
Text: is required they will get paid. In a way, this

Speaker: NA
Text: sort of communication with an employment

Speaker: NA
Text: service provider is an opportunity to practise

Speaker: NA
Text: such skills-for instance, if one of the

Speaker: NA
Text: children is sick or if you are unwell. This is

Speaker: NA
Text: an opportunity for people who might have

Speaker: NA
Text: been out of employment for a long time to

Speaker: NA
Text: practise the skills of managing their life to a

Speaker: NA
Text: point where they are able to make a phone

Speaker: NA
Text: call in advance and connect back in. For

Speaker: NA
Text: people who take that for granted it seems a

Speaker: NA
Text: small skill, but for people who lose agency

Speaker: NA
Text: and a sense of capacity when they have had a

Speaker: NA
Text: few knock-backs, this skill can be something

Speaker: NA
Text: that can fall off. So, obviously, this

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation is going to assist in encouraging

Speaker: NA
Text: people to undertake those common

Speaker: NA
Text: courtesies that are part of participating in a

Speaker: NA
Text: workplace.

Speaker: NA
Text: This bill also reforms the suspension of

Speaker: NA
Text: payments when job seekers continue to fail

Speaker: NA
Text: to comply with job seekers' requirements. If

Speaker: NA
Text: a job seeker does fail to re-engage, their

Speaker: NA
Text: payment will be suspended pending an

Speaker: NA
Text: agreement to re-engage and they will lose

Speaker: NA
Text: payment for each day after this missed

Speaker: NA
Text: appointment. The payment will only be

Speaker: NA
Text: resumed after they attend a scheduled

Speaker: NA
Text: reappointment. This bill provides, through

Speaker: NA
Text: this mechanism, for an early intervention

Speaker: NA
Text: system in the provision of participation

Speaker: NA
Text: payments and compliance with the

Speaker: NA
Text: requirements of engagement in seeking work

Speaker: NA
Text: and attending appointments. The suspension

Speaker: NA
Text: of payment as a result of the initial failure

Speaker: NA
Text: attend an appointment or engage with

Speaker: NA
Text: training can enable problems related to

Speaker: NA
Text: workplace participation to be addressed

Speaker: NA
Text: early. Additionally, I firmly believe that

Speaker: NA
Text: most appropriate to provide the incentive for

Speaker: NA
Text: actively looking for employment early in the

Speaker: NA
Text: job search period. This enables issues in

Speaker: NA
Text: regards to workplace participation to be

Speaker: NA
Text: managed early. Whilst there must also be

Speaker: NA
Text: positive incentives in looking for work,

Speaker: NA
Text: penalties need to operate in regards to failing

Speaker: NA
Text: to comply with the requirements attached to

Speaker: NA
Text: the payment. The requirements that affect the

Speaker: NA
Text: provision of a participation payment must be

Speaker: NA
Text: clear and certain. Under this legislation, the

Speaker: NA
Text: consequences for not attending appointments

Speaker: NA
Text: and activities will be increased in clarity and

Speaker: NA
Text: immediacy and will have a much better

Speaker: NA
Text: effect in terms of helping people make the

Speaker: NA
Text: connection between missing the appointment

Speaker: NA
Text: and then losing their participation payment

Speaker: NA
Text: for that period of time.

Speaker: NA
Text: These reforms to the provision of income

Speaker: NA
Text: support to job seekers cannot be taken

Speaker: NA
Text: lightly. It is very important to recognise that,

Speaker: NA
Text: if a person has incurred the penalty of a

Speaker: NA
Text: suspended payment for an initial failure to

Speaker: NA
Text: attend an appointment, payment will be

Speaker: NA
Text: restored with full back payment once the re-

Speaker: NA
Text: engagement occurs. But this legislation does

Speaker: NA
Text: tighten the provisions that enable a

Speaker: NA
Text: reasonable excuse to be provided. The most

Speaker: NA
Text: important change in this regard is that an

Speaker: NA
Text: excuse is not reasonable if a job seeker could

Speaker: NA
Text: have given advance notice but failed to do

Speaker: NA
Text: so.

Speaker: NA
Text: I understand that the incentives that are

Speaker: NA
Text: provided under this legislation only partly

Speaker: NA
Text: address concerns relating to unemployment

Speaker: NA
Text: and workplace participation. The most

Speaker: NA
Text: important means of ensuring that job seekers

Speaker: NA
Text: can find employment is the provision of a

Speaker: NA
Text: strong economy. We saw in the budget last

Speaker: NA
Text: to night the platform for ensuring that

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians get work and keep work and that

Speaker: NA
Text: we grow job opportunities in this country.

Speaker: NA
Text: Indeed, it was this government that so

Speaker: NA
Text: it is successfully stimulated the economy during

Speaker: NA
Text: the global financial crisis and helped

Speaker: NA
Text: maintain our low level of unemployment. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is this government that continues to work to

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure that unemployment remains low and

Speaker: NA
Text: that job seekers can transition into

Speaker: NA
Text: employment.

Speaker: NA
Text: Whilst we do this, we also need to ensure

Speaker: NA
Text: that our social security services are

Speaker: NA
Text: modernised and provide the right incentives

Speaker: NA
Text: to people. As stated, another component of

Speaker: NA
Text: our response to unemployment, especially

Speaker: NA
Text: youth unemployment, is to provide access to

Speaker: NA
Text: training. In this regard, welfare can provide

Speaker: NA
Text: means to a hand up rather than merely a

Speaker: NA
Text: hand-out. The Australian government is well

Speaker: NA
Text: assisted by organisations such as group

Speaker: NA
Text: training schemes in addition to job training

Speaker: NA
Text: networks that assist in the provision of

Speaker: NA
Text: training to job seekers. In last night's budget

Speaker: NA
Text: we saw a very practical and significant

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment to that. Additionally, we must

Speaker: NA
Text: also acknowledge the good and effective

Speaker: NA
Text: work done by non-government organisations

Speaker: NA
Text: who participate in this field. Mission

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia and the Salvation Army are just

Speaker: NA
Text: two that spring to mind in terms of working

Speaker: NA
Text: to provide employment opportunities for job

Speaker: NA
Text: seekers and working to help job seekers re-

Speaker: NA
Text: form their identity and recover their hopes

Speaker: NA
Text: for participation and the freedom that work

Speaker: NA
Text: offers. These organisations play a great

Speaker: NA
Text: complementary role to the work of

Speaker: NA
Text: government and they engage very effectively

Speaker: NA
Text: with our community and with people who

Speaker: NA
Text: need a bit of a hand every now and then.

Speaker: NA
Text: This legislation is effective

Speaker: NA
Text: modernising our welfare system. It does

Speaker: NA
Text: provide incentives where they are needed

Speaker: NA
Text: and it does provide encouragement to stay

Speaker: NA
Text: within the boundaries of appropriate

Speaker: NA
Text: behaviours that would be replicated in the

Speaker: NA
Text: workplace. Employment participation is

Speaker: NA
Text: fundamental if we wish our economy to be

Speaker: NA
Text: strong and if we want to have a strong

Speaker: NA
Text: society. This is a practical reform. It is not

Speaker: NA
Text: based on ideological rhetoric. It is based

Speaker: NA
Text: practical consideration of the needs of our

Speaker: NA
Text: system of social security. It is practically

Speaker: NA
Text: engaging and it will be practically applicable

Speaker: NA
Text: to ensure that income support payments are

Speaker: NA
Text: appropriately provided. I believe this

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation will contribute to the generation

Speaker: NA
Text: of a culture in which welfare is not seen as a

Speaker: NA
Text: hand-out but as a hand up. It will certainly

Speaker: NA
Text: encourage the young and the old and the

Speaker: NA
Text: people in between who have been

Speaker: NA
Text: disconnected from the workplace into further

Speaker: NA
Text: a engagement with their service provider for

Speaker: NA
Text: the opportunity of jobs that will produce. I

Speaker: NA
Text: commend the legislation to the House.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mrs GRIGGS (Solomon) (13:42): I rise

Speaker: NA
Text: to offer my comments on the Social Security

Speaker: NA
Text: Legislation Amendment (Job Seeker

Speaker: NA
Text: Compliance) Bill 2011 by recognising that

Speaker: NA
Text: this is indeed a national issue. This bill aims

Speaker: NA
Text: to introduce tougher compliance measures

Speaker: NA
Text: for job seekers who have activity test

Speaker: NA
Text: requirements. If passed this bill will

Speaker: NA
Text: introduce a suspension of income support

Speaker: NA
Text: payments for job seekers following a failure

Speaker: NA
Text: to attend participation activities including an

Speaker: NA
Text: appointment with the employment services

Speaker: NA
Text: provider or, in some circumstances, an

Speaker: NA
Text: activity such as training or work for the dole.

Speaker: NA
Text: Unemployment in Australia is currently low

Speaker: NA
Text: at a seasonally adjusted rate of 4.9 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: in March 2011, with 179,000-odd job

Speaker: NA
Text: seekers classified as long-term unemployed

Speaker: NA
Text: at the same time. While the latest

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployment figures show that the

Speaker: NA
Text: in Northern Territory unemployment is just

Speaker: NA
Text: over two per cent and is the lowest in the

Speaker: NA
Text: country, we are losing more people to

Speaker: NA
Text: interstate migration than are being gained. In

Speaker: NA
Text: my electorate of Solomon, we have a

Speaker: NA
Text: transient population whereby workers will

Speaker: NA
Text: take their skills and trades elsewhere to

Speaker: NA
Text: where they are better paid or if there are no

Speaker: NA
Text: jobs in the Northern Territory for them. In

Speaker: NA
Text: the last month it has been reported in the

Speaker: NA
Text: on a Northern Territory News that this is

Speaker: NA
Text: happening now, with many skilled and

Speaker: NA
Text: semiskilled workers going to higher paid

Speaker: NA
Text: jobs in Western Australia and Queensland.

Speaker: NA
Text: Yet, despite such low

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployment rates and jobs being

Speaker: NA
Text: available, in the last 12 months across

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia approximately two million job

Speaker: NA
Text: interviews and appointments were missed by

Speaker: NA
Text: job seekers with no valid excuse given. Job

Speaker: NA
Text: seekers are required to undertake these

Speaker: NA
Text: activities as part of their mutual obligation,

Speaker: NA
Text: yet it is clear, by the high number of missed

Speaker: NA
Text: appointments nationally, that job seekers are

Speaker: NA
Text: in fact ignoring their obligations. It is critical

Speaker: NA
Text: that these job seekers are encouraged to re-

Speaker: NA
Text: engage with mainstream society and actively

Speaker: NA
Text: seek employment in order to break the cycle

Speaker: NA
Text: of welfare dependency.

Speaker: NA
Text: The coalition requires a fair but firm

Speaker: NA
Text: system to ensure that those in receipt of

Speaker: NA
Text: income support who can work have a

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility to look for work and

Speaker: NA
Text: contribute back to the society that supports

Speaker: NA
Text: them. In addition to this, they need to

Speaker: NA
Text: recognise that welfare is a temporary safety

Speaker: NA
Text: net and not a lifestyle choice. As the member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Robertson said, we are also supportive of

Speaker: NA
Text: the system giving a hand up.

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate interrupted.

Speaker: NA
Text: STATEMENTS BY MEMBERS

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr JOHN COBB (Calare) (13:45): I rise

Speaker: NA
Text: today to express my disappointment for the

Speaker: NA
Text: agricultural industry in the budget. Not only

Speaker: NA
Text: has the government delivered nothing for the

Speaker: NA
Text: industry; it has also failed to alleviate the

Speaker: NA
Text: crippling shortage of skilled workers. With

Speaker: NA
Text: the worst drought in the nation's history at an

Speaker: NA
Text: end, our agricultural industry is gradually

Speaker: NA
Text: returning to full production. In order to

Speaker: NA
Text: achieve this, the industry desperately needs

Speaker: NA
Text: skilled workers. The mining boom has been

Speaker: NA
Text: tremendous for the Australian economy but

Speaker: NA
Text: disastrous for Australian agricultural

Speaker: NA
Text: employment. The agricultural sector

Speaker: NA
Text: national produces fine, hardworking employees who

Speaker: NA
Text: are very attractive to the mining sector and

Speaker: NA
Text: are drawn by generous salaries.

Speaker: NA
Text: Under Labor's budget commitment, $280

Speaker: NA
Text: million has been provided to boost

Speaker: NA
Text: apprenticeships, but to be eligible an

Speaker: NA
Text: apprentice must be undertaking a trade that

Speaker: NA
Text: appears on the National Skills Needs List.

Speaker: NA
Text: Agriculture and horticulture, as part of that,

Speaker: NA
Text: are not included on that list. Agriculture will

Speaker: NA
Text: not be able to return to its prime position as

Speaker: NA
Text: an economic powerhouse of the nation

Speaker: NA
Text: without new generations of skilled

Speaker: NA
Text: tradespeople. The government has no clue

Speaker: NA
Text: when it comes to agriculture; it needs to

Speaker: NA
Text: listen to the industry and include agriculture

Speaker: NA
Text: in its apprenticeship and training program.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Export Awards: Pivot

Speaker: NA
Text: Maritime International

Speaker: Mr LYONS
Text: Bass) (13:46): I am most

Speaker: NA
Text: pleased to congratulate Dr Jeff Hawkins and

Speaker: NA
Text: Dr Luz Hawkins on their recent success in

Speaker: NA
Text: the 49th annual Australian Export Awards.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is the second year running that they

Speaker: NA
Text: have secured a win in the Export Awards.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is a fantastic achievement. Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: exporters play a pivotal role in the prosperity

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget and stability of the national economy, with

Speaker: NA
Text: their perseverance and ingenuity creating

Speaker: NA
Text: jobs and new businesses which benefit all of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: Pivot Maritime International, operated by

Speaker: NA
Text: Luz and Jeff, is a great example of this

Speaker: NA
Text: ingenuity. Its success in international

Speaker: NA
Text: business deserves recognition, which is why

Speaker: NA
Text: the International Australian Export Awards,

Speaker: NA
Text: now in its 49th year, is so important. Pivot

Speaker: NA
Text: Maritime produces maritime simulators for

Speaker: NA
Text: commercial shipping, recreational boating

Speaker: NA
Text: and defence. But, unlike its competitors,

Speaker: NA
Text: Pivot also operates a simulator, employing

Speaker: NA
Text: its own simulators in its training, consultancy

Speaker: NA
Text: and research services, and working in close

Speaker: NA
Text: partnership with strategic clients to assist

Speaker: NA
Text: them to make optimal use of their simulators.

Speaker: NA
Text: This strategy ensures the company is

Speaker: NA
Text: continually validating and improving the

Speaker: NA
Text: effectiveness and efficiency of its systems.

Speaker: NA
Text: Pivot's target markets include the USA, Asia-

Speaker: NA
Text: Pacific and Europe as well as, of course,

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. This is a company from Legana in

Speaker: NA
Text: Tasmania. I congratulate Jeff and Luz on

Speaker: NA
Text: their wonderful business in my electorate of

Speaker: NA
Text: Bass. (Time expired)

Speaker: NA
Text: Aston Electorate: Volunteering

Speaker: Mr TUDGE
Text: Aston) (13:48): This week

Speaker: NA
Text: is National Volunteer Week, so there is no

Speaker: NA
Text: better time than this week to highlight the

Speaker: NA
Text: role of volunteers in our community and to

Speaker: NA
Text: say thank you. Volunteers are the glue that

Speaker: NA
Text: holds together our civil society. Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: volunteers contribute more than 700 million

Speaker: NA
Text: hours of community service each year. Over

Speaker: NA
Text: 5.4 million people volunteer in some

Speaker: NA
Text: capacity each year, a number which has risen

Speaker: NA
Text: from 3.2 million 10 years ago. In my

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate of Aston over 19,000 people

Speaker: NA
Text: volunteer each year for an organisation or

Speaker: NA
Text: group, and this does not include many carers

Speaker: NA
Text: or others who volunteer individually. They

Speaker: NA
Text: do a tremendous job and often put in huge

Speaker: NA
Text: numbers of hours each week, whether it is in

Speaker: NA
Text: scouts and guides, running the local football

Speaker: NA
Text: and netball clubs or participating in local

Speaker: NA
Text: environment groups or local charities.

Speaker: NA
Text: Last week I had the opportunity to thank

Speaker: NA
Text: some of the volunteers from one of the

Speaker: NA
Text: largest volunteer organisations in my

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate, Bridges, which was formerly

Speaker: NA
Text: known as Knox Community Volunteers.

Speaker: NA
Text: Capably led by CEO Mandi Hyland, Bridges

Speaker: NA
Text: coordinates over 2,000 volunteers to provide

Speaker: NA
Text: transport, social activities and support for

Speaker: NA
Text: elderly residents in Knox. I would like to

Speaker: NA
Text: again express my thanks to the volunteers at

Speaker: NA
Text: Bridges for their tireless work and to all the

Speaker: NA
Text: volunteers in Knox and Whitehorse. You

Speaker: NA
Text: make our community a better place and I am

Speaker: NA
Text: very proud to be your federal representative.

Speaker: NA
Text: Melbourne Electorate: Carringbush

Speaker: NA
Text: Adult Education Centre

Speaker: Mr BANDT
Text: Melbourne) (13:50): Last

Speaker: NA
Text: week I visited the Carringbush adult

Speaker: NA
Text: education centre in my electorate of

Speaker: NA
Text: Melbourne. The electorate of Melbourne has

Speaker: NA
Text: the highest number of public housing

Speaker: NA
Text: dwellings of any electorate in the country

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Carringbush centre provides critical

Speaker: NA
Text: learning opportunities for the residents of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Richmond housing estates and the

Speaker: NA
Text: surrounding areas. I learnt a lot from the

Speaker: NA
Text: people I met in Richmond who were engaged

Speaker: NA
Text: in the language and literacy program-their

Speaker: NA
Text: extraordinary skills, their talents, their desire

Speaker: NA
Text: to live a good and peaceful life here in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia and also their desire to engage in

Speaker: NA
Text: meaningful work. I also learnt about the

Speaker: NA
Text: difficulties they encounter securing jobs, the

Speaker: NA
Text: importance of language, literacy and

Speaker: NA
Text: numeracy classes and their challenges in

Speaker: NA
Text: accessing affordable health and dental care.

Speaker: NA
Text: In yesterday's budget there are some

Speaker: NA
Text: things that are going to help them, like the

Speaker: NA
Text: beginning of the Greens initiative to put

Speaker: NA
Text: dental care into Medicare, but unfortunately

Speaker: NA
Text: they, like many other migrants and refugees

Speaker: NA
Text: in Australia, have been forgotten. We have,

Speaker: NA
Text: especially in Melbourne, a wealth of people

Speaker: NA
Text: who have come here from overseas and who

Speaker: NA
Text: have often been living in the country for

Speaker: NA
Text: many years, with skills, degrees and

Speaker: NA
Text: qualifications that are going unrecognised.

Speaker: NA
Text: They face barriers to employment, and one

Speaker: NA
Text: of the key ones is language. It is my hope

Speaker: NA
Text: that at some stage the government moves

Speaker: NA
Text: beyond seeing job seekers as people who do

Speaker: NA
Text: not want to work and that instead we begin

Speaker: NA
Text: supporting these people, especially those

Speaker: NA
Text: who face language barriers, into meaningful

Speaker: NA
Text: and decent employment in Melbourne.

Speaker: NA
Text: Flinders Electorate: Somerville Police

Speaker: NA
Text: Station

Speaker: Mr HUNT
Text: Flinders) (13:51): I rise, on

Speaker: NA
Text: behalf of the people of Somerville, to

Speaker: NA
Text: welcome the news that the Victorian

Speaker: NA
Text: government has approved the creation of a

Speaker: NA
Text: police station for Somerville. This is overdue

Speaker: NA
Text: news, it is welcome news, it is important

Speaker: NA
Text: news and it will make a difference to the

Speaker: NA
Text: safety and security of families on the streets

Speaker: NA
Text: of Somerville and within the homes of the

Speaker: NA
Text: residents of Somerville. This has been a

Speaker: NA
Text: longstanding campaign and project. Along

Speaker: NA
Text: with my state colleague, Neil Burgess,

Speaker: NA
Text: Councillor Lynn Bowden and many others

Speaker: NA
Text: within the community we have held public

Speaker: NA
Text: meetings, we have had petitions, we have

Speaker: NA
Text: written letters, we have campaigned hard,

Speaker: NA
Text: and this is a great tribute to the people of

Speaker: NA
Text: Somerville. Stage 1 of the project will be the

Speaker: NA
Text: identification and acquisition of an

Speaker: NA
Text: appropriate plot of land for the Somerville

Speaker: NA
Text: police station by the state government. Stage

Speaker: NA
Text: 2 of the project will be the planning of the

Speaker: NA
Text: station in relation to that land. Stage 3 will

Speaker: NA
Text: be the construction and implementation. That

Speaker: NA
Text: project is now underway. The search for

Speaker: NA
Text: land, the search for an appropriate place for a

Speaker: NA
Text: police station and the acquisition of that land

Speaker: NA
Text: is the task right now. In the meantime we

Speaker: NA
Text: want to work with the community to see that

Speaker: NA
Text: they get the police station they have wanted

Speaker: NA
Text: and the station they have deserved and

Speaker: NA
Text: needed. It is a great tribute and a great

Speaker: NA
Text: outcome to the persistence of the Somerville

Speaker: NA
Text: community. (Time expired)

Speaker: NA
Text: Fraser Electorate: Welcoming the

Speaker: NA
Text: Babies

Speaker: Dr LEIGH
Text: Fraser) (13:53): On 27

Speaker: NA
Text: March this year I held Canberra's inaugural

Speaker: NA
Text: 'Welcoming the Babies' event at Stage 88 in

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Park. Over 150 mums, dads,

Speaker: NA
Text: bubs, brothers and sisters enjoyed a perfect

Speaker: NA
Text: Canberra autumn morning while taking the

Speaker: NA
Text: time to engage with local services and other

Speaker: NA
Text: families. As a parent of two young boys

Speaker: NA
Text: myself, I know the challenging moments that

Speaker: NA
Text: one has in raising a family: endless nappy

Speaker: NA
Text: changes, throwing food at dinner time and

Speaker: NA
Text: early wake-ups. For example, my one-year-

Speaker: NA
Text: old arose at 4.15 this morning. That is why I

Speaker: NA
Text: believe it is important to celebrate being a

Speaker: NA
Text: parent and to share survival tips.

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to thank ACT Playgroups, ACT

Speaker: NA
Text: Health and the breastfeeding initiative,

Speaker: NA
Text: senior child health policy and immunisation

Speaker: NA
Text: officers, Anglicare, the Breastfeeding

Speaker: NA
Text: Association, Bundle Baby Ultrasound, Cafe

Speaker: NA
Text: 2U, DJ Dennis, Gymbaroo, Kidsafe, Kings

Speaker: NA
Text: Swim School, Junior Entertainment, Monkey

Speaker: NA
Text: Mania, Players Football Club, Post and Ante

Speaker: NA
Text: Natal Depression Support and Information,

Speaker: NA
Text: Soul Yoga, MC Laurie MCDonald and guest

Speaker: NA
Text: speaker Pam Cahir, and my staff and

Speaker: NA
Text: volunteers from the ACT Labor Party for

Speaker: NA
Text: cooking sausages, staffing our tent and

Speaker: NA
Text: helping other stallholders. I would also like

Speaker: NA
Text: to thank Treasurer Wayne Swan, who

Speaker: NA
Text: pioneered this kind of event, making him 'the

Speaker: NA
Text: father of Welcoming the Babies'. As first-

Speaker: NA
Text: time dad Tito Hasan told me, 'It's been great

Speaker: NA
Text: to see kids having fun. My wife and I see the

Speaker: NA
Text: range of things out there for first-time

Speaker: NA
Text: parents. I'm looking forward to coming back

Speaker: NA
Text: next year.'

Speaker: NA
Text: MCPherson Electorate: Gold Coast

Speaker: NA
Text: Quarry

Speaker: NA
Text: Mrs ANDREWS (MCPherson) (13:54):

Speaker: NA
Text: Boral Resources is pushing ahead with its

Speaker: NA
Text: proposal for a quarry in Tallebudgera Valley

Speaker: NA
Text: within the electorate of MCPherson, despite

Speaker: NA
Text: significant opposition from local residents as

Speaker: NA
Text: well as the broader Gold Coast community.

Speaker: NA
Text: My office has been inundated with calls,

Speaker: NA
Text: emails and letters from a community that is

Speaker: NA
Text: outraged over the proposal. So determined is

Speaker: NA
Text: the community to stop the proposed quarry

Speaker: NA
Text: that a community action group called 'Stop

Speaker: NA
Text: the Gold Coast Quarry' has been formed and

Speaker: NA
Text: is actively campaigning against the project.

Speaker: NA
Text: The management committee of 'Stop the

Speaker: NA
Text: Gold Coast Quarry' comprises community

Speaker: NA
Text: representatives Sam Stewart, Robert

Speaker: NA
Text: Balanda, Marco Scholten, Lorraine Cook,

Speaker: NA
Text: Niki Naday and Tony Davis. They are united

Speaker: NA
Text: in their determination to stop the proposed

Speaker: NA
Text: quarry.

Speaker: NA
Text: A petition tabled in the Queensland state

Speaker: NA
Text: parliament and essentially asking for the

Speaker: NA
Text: development application to be refused

Speaker: NA
Text: received over 9,000 signatures. I have

Speaker: NA
Text: attended several community meetings about

Speaker: NA
Text: this issue, including a recent rally held

Speaker: NA
Text: two weeks ago. This rally alone resulted in

Speaker: NA
Text: an additional 1,000 signatures for the

Speaker: NA
Text: petition, gathered in a couple of hours.

Speaker: NA
Text: Residents do not want a quarry in their

Speaker: NA
Text: backyard. They do not want their pristine

Speaker: NA
Text: bushland torn up. They do not want trucks

Speaker: NA
Text: clogging the already congested roads on the

Speaker: NA
Text: southern Gold Coast. They do not want to

Speaker: NA
Text: listen to the noise from blasting, sirens and

Speaker: NA
Text: crushers. They do not want the value of their

Speaker: NA
Text: property to drop. (Time expired)

Speaker: NA
Text: Canberra Electorate: Liz Dawson

Speaker: Ms BRODTMANN
Text: Canberra) (13:56):

Speaker: NA
Text: Today I rise to honour another Canberra

Speaker: NA
Text: legend, Liz Dawson. Liz is a tireless and

Speaker: NA
Text: tenacious advocate for the homeless and

Speaker: NA
Text: disadvantaged in the ACT. She is one of the

Speaker: NA
Text: brains and drivers behind the Common

Speaker: NA
Text: Ground project here in Canberra which aims

Speaker: NA
Text: to provide permanent housing and structured

Speaker: NA
Text: co-located services for the homeless and

Speaker: NA
Text: people with drug and alcohol dependency

Speaker: NA
Text: and mental health issues. Until recently Liz

Speaker: NA
Text: also volunteered with the Salvation Army

Speaker: NA
Text: and was relentless in pursuing funding for a

Speaker: NA
Text: dental program for the homeless. Liz is one

Speaker: NA
Text: formidable woman and a great source of

Speaker: NA
Text: inspiration for many women here in

Speaker: NA
Text: Canberra. The side-effects of a recent

Speaker: NA
Text: operation seriously impaired her vision but

Speaker: NA
Text: that has not stopped her in her tracks.

Speaker: NA
Text: Instead, Liz is now advocating for the

Speaker: NA
Text: visually impaired in addition to the homeless

Speaker: NA
Text: and disadvantaged.

Speaker: NA
Text: Liz Dawson's resilience, energy and

Speaker: NA
Text: selfless commitment to improving the lives

Speaker: NA
Text: of others are something to behold. She leaves

Speaker: NA
Text: people decades younger in the shade. In this

Speaker: NA
Text: National Volunteers Week and on behalf of

Speaker: NA
Text: the people of Canberra, particularly the

Speaker: NA
Text: disempowered, I want to thank Liz Dawson

Speaker: NA
Text: for her significant contribution to our

Speaker: NA
Text: community. I would also like to thank the

Speaker: NA
Text: about thousands of Canberrans who serve their

Speaker: NA
Text: community through volunteering every day.

Speaker: NA
Text: Hasluck Electorate: West Rise

Speaker: NA
Text: Disability Competition

Speaker: Mr WYATT
Text: Hasluck) (13:57): I stand

Speaker: NA
Text: here today to draw attention to the good

Speaker: NA
Text: work of the West Rise Disability

Speaker: NA
Text: Competition in Kalamunda. West Rise is a

Speaker: NA
Text: competition for intellectually disabled people

Speaker: NA
Text: within Hasluck and Perth's eastern suburbs

Speaker: NA
Text: and is the first such basketball competition of

Speaker: NA
Text: its kind in Western Australia. West Rise

Speaker: NA
Text: brings together over 40 people aged 12 and

Speaker: NA
Text: upwards with an intellectual disability and

Speaker: NA
Text: teaches them, through sport, skills such as

Speaker: NA
Text: teamwork and commitment and promotes

Speaker: NA
Text: confidence building. It has proven so

Speaker: NA
Text: successful that it has now expanded into two

Speaker: NA
Text: divisions to allow for more specialised

Speaker: NA
Text: coaching. What is so great about this

Speaker: NA
Text: program is that it is often held alongside

Speaker: NA
Text: mainstream competitions and this

Speaker: NA
Text: inclusiveness with non-intellectually

Speaker: NA
Text: impaired people helps make these people

Speaker: NA
Text: feel closer to the community that they live in.

Speaker: NA
Text: None of this would be possible without

Speaker: NA
Text: the hard work and dedication of coach and

Speaker: NA
Text: founder Chris Saligari. Chris works at the

Speaker: NA
Text: highly regarded Kalamunda Senior High

Speaker: NA
Text: School education support centre and saw

Speaker: NA
Text: first-hand the benefits of sport for the

Speaker: NA
Text: intellectually impaired. Despite not having

Speaker: NA
Text: any children or family of her own with a

Speaker: NA
Text: disability, Chris took time to start this

Speaker: NA
Text: competition and is ably assisted by her son

Speaker: NA
Text: and coach Michael Saligari and coach Ed

Speaker: NA
Text: Thime. I thank Chris for her commitment to

Speaker: NA
Text: helping others and for starting such a

Speaker: NA
Text: wonderful competition in Hasluck for the

Speaker: NA
Text: east metropolitan's intellectually impaired

Speaker: NA
Text: people. I am proud to be their patron.

Speaker: NA
Text: Rush, Mr Scott

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: to acknowledge the great work done by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Attorney-General, Robert MCClelland, the

Speaker: NA
Text: foreign minister, Kevin Rudd, and many

Speaker: NA
Text: other members on behalf of Lee and Chris

Speaker: NA
Text: Rush and their son Scott. Lee and Chris are

Speaker: NA
Text: my constituents in Graceville and I want to

Speaker: NA
Text: commend people like Chris Hayes, the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Fowler, for the great work they

Speaker: NA
Text: have done to ensure that Scott has started the

Speaker: NA
Text: journey to being released from prison.

Speaker: NA
Text: Obviously there is a lot more work to be

Speaker: NA
Text: done but at least this is getting him off death

Speaker: NA
Text: row as the first part of that process.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: Order! The time

Speaker: NA
Text: allotted for members' statements has

Speaker: NA
Text: concluded.

Speaker: NA
Text: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Text: Warringah-Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition) (14:00): My question is to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister. I refer the Prime Minister to

Speaker: NA
Text: the government's $2 billion cut to family

Speaker: NA
Text: benefits, including for those earning as little

Speaker: NA
Text: as $45,000 a year, while its spending on the

Speaker: NA
Text: boat people crisis has blown out by $1.75

Speaker: NA
Text: billion. Why is the government tougher on

Speaker: NA
Text: families than it is on border protection?

Speaker: Ms GILLARD
Text: Lalor-Prime Minister)

Speaker: NA
Text: (14:00): I thank the Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition for his question. Let me explain

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Leader of the Opposition the

Speaker: NA
Text: fundamentals of this budget. This budget is

Speaker: NA
Text: bringing the budget back into surplus in

Speaker: NA
Text: 2012-13, as promised. That has meant that

Speaker: NA
Text: we have needed to take a series of tough

Speaker: NA
Text: decisions. We did not want to see in this

Speaker: NA
Text: budget the profligacy of the Howard years

Speaker: NA
Text: during mining boom mark 1. Consequently,

Speaker: NA
Text: when you look at this budget, you see an

Speaker: NA
Text: average increase in expenditure of one per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent, compared with an average increase in

Speaker: NA
Text: expenditure of 3.6 per cent under the

Speaker: NA
Text: Howard government. We are being so

Speaker: NA
Text: rigorous on bringing the budget back to

Speaker: NA
Text: surplus in 2012-13, exactly as promised,

Speaker: NA
Text: because we are determined to continue to

Speaker: NA
Text: deliver to the Australian people a strong

Speaker: NA
Text: economy which gives them the benefit of

Speaker: NA
Text: jobs-750,000 created already, with another

Speaker: NA
Text: half a million to be created in the years to

Speaker: NA
Text: come. So, yes, there have been some tough

Speaker: NA
Text: decisions taken in this budget in relation to

Speaker: NA
Text: savings.

Speaker: NA
Text: On the family payments question that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition raised, let me say

Speaker: NA
Text: what the actual information is.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: order. The Prime Minister was asked a

Speaker: NA
Text: question about the government's spending

Speaker: NA
Text: blow-out on border protection versus its cut

Speaker: NA
Text: for family benefits. She was not asked to

Speaker: NA
Text: give an adjournment speech about the budget

Speaker: NA
Text: in general. She should go back to that point.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: Order! The Manager of

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition Business will resume his seat.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Prime Minister was talking about that

Speaker: NA
Text: aspect of the question as the Manager of

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition Business rose. I am not sure

Speaker: NA
Text: whether some comments are sotto voce just

Speaker: NA
Text: for discussion amongst people, but it might

Speaker: NA
Text: help if people did not speak while I was

Speaker: NA
Text: speaking and then I would not misinterpret it

Speaker: NA
Text: as reflections upon the chair.

Speaker: Ms GILLARD
Text: The Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition asked me about family payments.

Speaker: NA
Text: For the clarification of the House and for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition so that he has the

Speaker: NA
Text: accurate information-and I believe that he

Speaker: NA
Text: is under an obligation to make sure that what

Speaker: NA
Text: he says to the Australian people is

Speaker: NA
Text: accurate-family payments will still increase

Speaker: NA
Text: under this budget. All fortnightly rates will

Speaker: NA
Text: still increase for family tax benefits A and B.

Speaker: NA
Text: I understand that the Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition does not want the facts but these

Speaker: NA
Text: are the facts. For example, on 1 July the

Speaker: NA
Text: maximum rate will increase by $113 per

Speaker: NA
Text: annum for a child between the ages of zero

Speaker: NA
Text: and 12 and by $146 per annum for a child

Speaker: NA
Text: between the ages of 13 and 15. In relation to

Speaker: NA
Text: family tax benefit B, for the youngest child

Speaker: NA
Text: under five years of age, per family there is a

Speaker: NA
Text: $95 increase annually; for kids aged between

Speaker: NA
Text: five and 18 years, $66 annually.

Speaker: NA
Text: This budget honours our commitment to

Speaker: NA
Text: increase payments for the parents of

Speaker: NA
Text: teenagers, as we said we would during the

Speaker: NA
Text: election campaign. So parents of teenagers

Speaker: NA
Text: on the maximum rate can look forward to an

Speaker: NA
Text: increase of $4,208 in their family payments

Speaker: NA
Text: if they have a child of 16 to 17 years and

Speaker: NA
Text: $3,741 if they have a child of 18 to 19 years.

Speaker: NA
Text: They are important figures about family

Speaker: NA
Text: payments in this budget and if the Leader of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition wants to accurately talk about

Speaker: NA
Text: this budget, he should be referring to those

Speaker: NA
Text: figures.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Leader of the Opposition also raised

Speaker: NA
Text: with me the cost of mandatory detention and

Speaker: NA
Text: continuing to process asylum seekers. I

Speaker: NA
Text: support mandatory detention. I believe it is

Speaker: NA
Text: an appropriate policy to check people who

Speaker: NA
Text: come to this country unauthorised-to check

Speaker: NA
Text: their health, to check their security status and

Speaker: NA
Text: to process their claims. So we will continue

Speaker: NA
Text: to fund mandatory detention because it is the

Speaker: NA
Text: right thing to do. We will continue with the

Speaker: NA
Text: Malaysia agreement which has been the

Speaker: NA
Text: subject of discussion in this House this week

Speaker: NA
Text: and which was announced by me and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Immigration and Citizenship on

Speaker: NA
Text: Saturday. It is a big blow for people-

Speaker: NA
Text: smugglers and aimed at breaking the people-

Speaker: NA
Text: smugglers' business model. It is the right

Speaker: NA
Text: thing to do. It is better than a three-word

Speaker: NA
Text: slogan.

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr CRAIG THOMSON (Dobell)

Speaker: NA
Text: (14:05): My question is to the Treasurer.

Speaker: NA
Text: Will the Treasurer outline to the House what

Speaker: NA
Text: last night's budget says about Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: economic performance and prospects?

Speaker: Mr SWAN
Text: Lilley-Deputy Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister and Treasurer) (14:06): I thank the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Dobell for that question. The

Speaker: NA
Text: budget I handed down last night reaffirms

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's record as one of the best

Speaker: NA
Text: performing developed economies in the

Speaker: NA
Text: global economy. We have strong growth

Speaker: NA
Text: prospects, we have strong job creation and

Speaker: NA
Text: we are getting the budget back in the black in

Speaker: NA
Text: record time.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have avoided in this country the very

Speaker: NA
Text: high rates of unemployment that have

Speaker: NA
Text: occurred in other advanced economies and

Speaker: NA
Text: we have avoided the crippling levels of debt

Speaker: NA
Text: that we have seen in other advanced

Speaker: NA
Text: economies. We have a budget bottom line

Speaker: NA
Text: which is indeed the envy of the developed

Speaker: NA
Text: world and levels of deficit and debt which

Speaker: NA
Text: are the envy of the developed world but,

Speaker: NA
Text: despite this strength, we know there has been

Speaker: NA
Text: short-term softness. We know that parts of

Speaker: NA
Text: our country have been badly affected by

Speaker: NA
Text: natural disasters, and we know that many

Speaker: NA
Text: parts of the economy still feel the overhang

Speaker: NA
Text: of the global financial crisis and the global

Speaker: NA
Text: recession, which is also weighing very

Speaker: NA
Text: heavily on government revenues. And of

Speaker: NA
Text: course there are many businesses out there

Speaker: NA
Text: that are certainly struggling under the weight

Speaker: NA
Text: of the high dollar.

Speaker: NA
Text: But against all of this we know that we

Speaker: NA
Text: have a very big investment pipeline in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. We are going to go through an

Speaker: NA
Text: investment boom, with business investment

Speaker: NA
Text: set to reach 50-year highs in the years ahead.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is why we are forecasting growth of

Speaker: NA
Text: four per cent in 2011-12 and 3¾ per cent in

Speaker: NA
Text: 2012-13. And that is why we are forecasting

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployment to come down to 4.5 per cent,

Speaker: NA
Text: because at the core of this budget is our

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment to jobs, jobs and more jobs.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is our commitment. It is not a

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment that was shared by those

Speaker: NA
Text: opposite during the global financial crisis

Speaker: NA
Text: and the global recession. If they had had

Speaker: NA
Text: their way, unemployment in this country

Speaker: NA
Text: would be far higher and deficits and debt

Speaker: NA
Text: would be far higher.

Speaker: NA
Text: So we are very optimistic about the future

Speaker: NA
Text: of our economy, because we can now build

Speaker: NA
Text: on the strength of our economy as we come

Speaker: NA
Text: through the global recession. That is why the

Speaker: NA
Text: budget gets us back in the black, gets more

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians into better jobs, gives more help

Speaker: NA
Text: to families and, particularly-something we

Speaker: NA
Text: are all proud of on this side of the House-

Speaker: NA
Text: invests in mental health. So the budget is

Speaker: NA
Text: about laying down an economic blueprint for

Speaker: NA
Text: the future so we can succeed in the Asian

Speaker: NA
Text: century and maximise the opportunities for

Speaker: NA
Text: our children and our grandchildren.

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Text: Warringah-Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition) (14:09): My question is again to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Prime Minister. Will the Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: confirm that the budget allocates $13.7

Speaker: NA
Text: million for a carbon tax advertising

Speaker: NA
Text: campaign? How can the budget include

Speaker: NA
Text: propaganda for a carbon tax but not the

Speaker: NA
Text: carbon tax itself?

Speaker: Ms GILLARD
Text: Lalor-Prime Minister)

Speaker: NA
Text: (14:09): To the Leader of the Opposition I

Speaker: NA
Text: say: how quickly they forget. Many may

Speaker: NA
Text: think I am referring to the Work Choices

Speaker: NA
Text: advertising campaign, an obscenity overseen

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Leader of the Opposition and the

Speaker: NA
Text: shadow Treasurer, but actually I am referring

Speaker: NA
Text: to last year's budget papers, because the

Speaker: NA
Text: climate change line item he is referring to

Speaker: NA
Text: appeared in last year's budget papers and has

Speaker: NA
Text: been brought forward into this year's budget

Speaker: NA
Text: papers. So can I say to the Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition, before he starts making

Speaker: NA
Text: inflammatory claims about where line items

Speaker: NA
Text: in the budget have come from, that he should

Speaker: NA
Text: perhaps do some budget study. That

Speaker: NA
Text: allocation for the climate change fund was

Speaker: NA
Text: standing in the last budget.

Speaker: NA
Text: On the question of memory: the Leader of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition of course was a very senior

Speaker: NA
Text: minister in the Howard government and he

Speaker: NA
Text: may recall the goods and services tax. He

Speaker: NA
Text: may also recall that the then Prime Minister,

Speaker: NA
Text: John Howard, announced that a full two

Speaker: NA
Text: years before he accounted for it in the budget

Speaker: NA
Text: papers. One can only assume from the

Speaker: NA
Text: reaction of the Leader of the Opposition that

Speaker: NA
Text: each and every day of those two years he

Speaker: NA
Text: was running around to the Prime Minister's

Speaker: NA
Text: office saying to John Howard, 'I just can't

Speaker: NA
Text: bear it; I can't continue to serve as a minister

Speaker: NA
Text: while this isn't accounted for in the budget.'

Speaker: NA
Text: Does anybody really think that is what

Speaker: NA
Text: happened? Well, no, that is not what

Speaker: NA
Text: happened, because of course the Leader of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition is always keen to apply a

Speaker: NA
Text: standard to others that he does not apply to

Speaker: NA
Text: himself.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let us get to the basis of this question.

Speaker: NA
Text: is because the Leader of the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: would prefer to come into this parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: and continue his climate change fear

Speaker: NA
Text: campaign than deal with the matters in the

Speaker: NA
Text: budget. He does not care about a strong

Speaker: NA
Text: economy; he has got no policies or plans for

Speaker: NA
Text: one. He does not care about bringing the

Speaker: NA
Text: budget back to surplus; he has got an $11

Speaker: NA
Text: billion black hole on his side of the ledger.

Speaker: NA
Text: He does not care about the creation of

Speaker: NA
Text: employment in our nation; he has got no

Speaker: NA
Text: policies or plans that relate to creating

Speaker: NA
Text: employment. He does not care about the

Speaker: NA
Text: future of our healthcare system; when he had

Speaker: NA
Text: the opportunity, he ripped $1 billion out of

Speaker: NA
Text: public hospitals. He does not care about the

Speaker: NA
Text: future of our schools, because he went to the

Speaker: NA
Text: last election promising to rip the best part

Speaker: NA
Text: $3 billion out of Australian schools. He does

Speaker: NA
Text: not care about Australian apprenticeships,

Speaker: NA
Text: because he went to the last election

Speaker: NA
Text: promising a $2 billion cut to apprentices.

Speaker: NA
Text: So there is no mystery that the Leader of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition does not come into this place

Speaker: NA
Text: to debate the budget. He cannot and he will

Speaker: NA
Text: not, because he is a big risk to the budget

Speaker: NA
Text: the nation's economic future-a risky

Speaker: NA
Text: approach taken every day. Every big call

Speaker: NA
Text: required of a leader in this nation he has got

Speaker: NA
Text: wrong, most particularly the calls necessary

Speaker: NA
Text: for the global financial crisis and keeping

Speaker: NA
Text: people in work. We will continue to get the

Speaker: NA
Text: big calls right, we will continue to manage

Speaker: NA
Text: the budget and get it back into surplus and

Speaker: NA
Text: we will continue to prioritise the jobs of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians, because this budget is centrally

Speaker: NA
Text: about jobs and opportunity for Australians

Speaker: NA
Text: right around the nation-and the Leader of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition has just turned his back on

Speaker: NA
Text: that.

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms O'NEILL (Robertson) (14:13): My

Speaker: NA
Text: question is to the Prime Minister. How will

Speaker: NA
Text: It the budget deliver on the government's

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment to return to surplus and help

Speaker: NA
Text: families with the cost of living?

Speaker: Ms GILLARD
Text: Lalor-Prime Minister)

Speaker: NA
Text: (14:13): I thank the member for her

Speaker: NA
Text: question. On delivering our fiscal prudence

Speaker: NA
Text: in this budget, the statistics are there for all

Speaker: NA
Text: to see. As promised, we will return the

Speaker: NA
Text: budget to surplus in 2012-13-back in the

Speaker: NA
Text: black, just as we promised the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: people. We will do that because the

Speaker: NA
Text: important thing to assist Australians as our

Speaker: NA
Text: economy moves towards full capacity is to

Speaker: NA
Text: make sure that the government is not adding

Speaker: NA
Text: to inflationary pressures. That is why we are

Speaker: NA
Text: determined to run such a tight spending

Speaker: NA
Text: policy. That is why across the forward

Speaker: NA
Text: estimates you are seeing growth in spending

Speaker: NA
Text: of on average at one per cent. The last time that

Speaker: NA
Text: occurred in Australia was in 1988 e have

Speaker: NA
Text: delivered a year with a negative in front of

Speaker: NA
Text: increasing growth-that is, spending will go

Speaker: NA
Text: backwards. The Howard government never

Speaker: NA
Text: delivered a year of spending reduction.

Speaker: NA
Text: Rather, they delivered spending growth in

Speaker: NA
Text: excess of three per cent on average even at

Speaker: NA
Text: and the top of resources boom mark I. The best

Speaker: NA
Text: thing we can do to assist families with cost-

Speaker: NA
Text: of-living pressures is to keep our economy

Speaker: NA
Text: strong and to bring the budget to surplus so

Speaker: NA
