Text: as to not add to inflationary pressures which

Speaker: NA
Text: would then feed into the cost of living for

Speaker: NA
Text: working families.

Speaker: NA
Text: But we can do some things as well to

Speaker: NA
Text: directly assist working families, to assist

Speaker: NA
Text: families under cost of living pressure, and in

Speaker: NA
Text: this budget we have. We are assisting

Speaker: NA
Text: families with teenagers. Our family payment

Speaker: NA
Text: system has made the old-fashioned

Speaker: NA
Text: assumption that somehow kids leave school

Speaker: NA
Text: when they are very young. We are in a

Speaker: NA
Text: modern economy-we need them to stay in

Speaker: NA
Text: school. So families with teenagers will get

Speaker: NA
Text: special new benefits.

Speaker: NA
Text: For some of our lower income working

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians, we have pulled forward the low-

Speaker: NA
Text: income tax offset so they can benefit week

Speaker: NA
Text: by week from the money from that low

Speaker: NA
Text: income tax offset to take a little bit of

Speaker: NA
Text: pressure off and to more clearly demonstrate

Speaker: NA
Text: to people the rewards of work. We have in

Speaker: NA
Text: this budget honoured our commitment to

Speaker: NA
Text: include school uniforms in the education tax

Speaker: NA
Text: refund because we want to assist families

Speaker: NA
Text: with the costs of getting kids to school. We

Speaker: NA
Text: have in this budget honoured our

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment to enable families to get their

Speaker: NA
Text: childcare payments fortnightly, because we

Speaker: NA
Text: understand that that too will provide a

Speaker: NA
Text: cost of living relief.

Speaker: NA
Text: We understand that right around the

Speaker: NA
Text: nation there are families battling cost-of-

Speaker: NA
Text: living pressures. As a government we will be

Speaker: NA
Text: working with them, doing what we need to

Speaker: NA
Text: do to keep our economy strong, to keep

Speaker: NA
Text: people in jobs and employment, to make sure

Speaker: NA
Text: they have decent working conditions when

Speaker: NA
Text: they are there-which is why we got rid of

Speaker: NA
Text: Work Choices-and to provide targeted

Speaker: NA
Text: relief in a budget that will get us back into

Speaker: NA
Text: black exactly as promised.

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget

Speaker: Mr HOCKEY
Text: North Sydney) (14:16):

Speaker: NA
Text: My question is to the Treasurer. I refer the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer to his own budget papers which

Speaker: NA
Text: state that a drop of just four per cent in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's terms of trade would wipe out the

Speaker: NA
Text: government's projected surplus in two years

Speaker: NA
Text: time. Treasurer, if Labor ever delivers its

Speaker: NA
Text: first surplus in 21 years, will it not be a

Speaker: NA
Text: surplus made in China and not made in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia?

Speaker: Mr SWAN
Text: Lilley-Deputy Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister and Treasurer) (14:17):

Speaker: NA
Text: shadow Treasurer is proof that hot air is not

Speaker: NA
Text: an economic policy. The fact is that we are

Speaker: NA
Text: bringing this budget back into the black, we

Speaker: NA
Text: are doing it by making savings, we are doing

Speaker: NA
Text: it in 2012-13 and we are doing it despite the

Speaker: NA
Text: opposition's fiscal vandalism and their

Speaker: NA
Text: refusal to support responsible savings. Fair

Speaker: NA
Text: dinkum! The shadow Treasurer was on

Speaker: NA
Text: television last night. He said on the one hand

Speaker: NA
Text: that it was too tough and on the other hand

Speaker: NA
Text: that we are not spending enough. This

Speaker: NA
Text: shadow Treasurer walks both sides of the

Speaker: NA
Text: street all the time. The fact is that we will

Speaker: NA
Text: come back to surplus because this

Speaker: NA
Text: government has done the hard yards. We

Speaker: NA
Text: have put in place the spending restraints that

Speaker: NA
Text: those opposite were not capable of

Speaker: NA
Text: bit of exercising during their 12 years in

Speaker: NA
Text: government. We have average spending each

Speaker: NA
Text: year over the budget estimates increasing by

Speaker: NA
Text: just one per cent. When they were in power,

Speaker: NA
Text: it was increasing by 3.7 per cent. They went

Speaker: NA
Text: on a spending spree at the height of mining

Speaker: NA
Text: boom Mark I. We are doing the hard yards of

Speaker: NA
Text: bringing the budget back to surplus in 2012-

Speaker: NA
Text: 13 by making $22 billion worth of savings

Speaker: NA
Text: and putting in place one of the biggest fiscal

Speaker: NA
Text: consolidations or returns to surplus that we

Speaker: NA
Text: have seen in this country.

Speaker: NA
Text: The shadow Treasurer quotes some

Speaker: NA
Text: sensitivity analysis from the budget papers.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is not the central forecast in the budget

Speaker: NA
Text: papers and he seeks to misrepresent it. He

Speaker: NA
Text: seeks to misrepresent it for political

Speaker: NA
Text: purposes. We will come back to surplus in

Speaker: NA
Text: 2012-13, because that is the central forecast

Speaker: NA
Text: that we have from the advisers who work

Speaker: NA
Text: both with them as forecasters and with us as

Speaker: NA
Text: forecasters. We are doing it despite the fact

Speaker: NA
Text: that there have been substantial revenue

Speaker: NA
Text: write-downs. We are doing it because we

Speaker: NA
Text: have shown the strict fiscal discipline to

Speaker: NA
Text: bring our budget back to surplus, a discipline

Speaker: NA
Text: The that those on that side of the House simply

Speaker: NA
Text: do not understand.

Speaker: NA
Text: We are coming back to surplus and we are

Speaker: NA
Text: doing it in a responsible way with a very

Speaker: NA
Text: strict fiscal policy and we will do it in 2012-

Speaker: NA
Text: 13. We will build surpluses after that and we

Speaker: NA
Text: will continue to apply our two per cent cap.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is a stark difference between the

Speaker: NA
Text: approach of us on this side of the House and

Speaker: NA
Text: the approach of those opposite. What they

Speaker: NA
Text: want to do in reality is to wreck the surplus.

Speaker: NA
Text: If they succeeded in wrecking the surplus,

Speaker: NA
Text: they would put price pressures into the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian economy and all Australians

Speaker: NA
Text: would be the victims of that.

Speaker: Mr HOCKEY
Text: North Sydney) (14:20):

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Speaker, I ask a supplementary question.

Speaker: NA
Text: I refer to the Treasurer's statement that the

Speaker: NA
Text: coalition was reckless with its spending

Speaker: NA
Text: during its term of government. Treasurer,

Speaker: NA
Text: will you confirm that at no stage over the

Speaker: NA
Text: next four years will this government get

Speaker: NA
Text: spending as low as it was in the last year of

Speaker: NA
Text: the coalition, at 22.9 per cent of GDP?

Speaker: Mr SWAN
Text: Lilley-Deputy Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister and Treasurer) (14:20): You have

Speaker: NA
Text: to give him points for trying. Our forecasts

Speaker: NA
Text: this budget show the fastest fiscal

Speaker: NA
Text: consolidation in history and $22 billion

Speaker: NA
Text: worth of savings. The reason we are in a

Speaker: NA
Text: position to come back to surplus in 2012-13

Speaker: NA
Text: is that we moved to support our economy

Speaker: NA
Text: during the global financial crisis and the

Speaker: NA
Text: global recession. If they had been in charge

Speaker: NA
Text: during that period, deficits would be far

Speaker: NA
Text: higher and debt would be far higher right

Speaker: NA
Text: now. Our deficits and debt are lower than

Speaker: NA
Text: one-tenth of the levels elsewhere in the

Speaker: NA
Text: advanced world because of the courageous

Speaker: NA
Text: decisions we on this side of the House took

Speaker: NA
Text: to support our economy. The consequence of

Speaker: NA
Text: that is that there is low unemployment in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia at 4.9 per cent, going down to 4.5

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent. If they had been in charge, the

Speaker: NA
Text: starting point of the budget would have been

Speaker: NA
Text: higher deficits and higher debt. What we are

Speaker: NA
Text: doing now is bringing our spending down

Speaker: NA
Text: through a very strict cap.

Speaker: Mr Hockey
Text: Mr Speaker, I rise on a

Speaker: NA
Text: point of order. My question was very

Speaker: NA
Text: specific. Will the Treasurer indicate where in

Speaker: NA
Text: the budget papers-anywhere-does this

Speaker: NA
Text: government get spending down to that in the

Speaker: NA
Text: last year of the Howard government?

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The Treasurer will

Speaker: NA
Text: directly relate his response to the question.

Speaker: Mr SWAN
Text: We are controlling spending

Speaker: NA
Text: in a way which the Howard government was

Speaker: NA
Text: completely and utterly incapable of doing.

Speaker: NA
Text: The spending increases over their period,

Speaker: NA
Text: during the boom and over a five-year period,

Speaker: NA
Text: were 3.7. For us it is one per cent. That is all

Speaker: NA
Text: the evidence you need.

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget

Speaker: Mr BANDT
Text: Melbourne) (14:23): My

Speaker: NA
Text: question is to the Treasurer. Our minerals

Speaker: NA
Text: belong to all Australians, yet much of the

Speaker: NA
Text: profit disappears overseas and the mining

Speaker: NA
Text: boom places burdens on the rest of the

Speaker: NA
Text: in economy, where most people live and work.

Speaker: NA
Text: My own state of Victoria must compete with

Speaker: NA
Text: the miners for labour and capital, pushing up

Speaker: NA
Text: costs and restraining infrastructure

Speaker: NA
Text: investment. Despite this, the mining sector

Speaker: NA
Text: gets a big leg up in your budget on top of

Speaker: NA
Text: their free kick on the mining tax. Where is

Speaker: NA
Text: the plan for those sectors of the economy

Speaker: NA
Text: that are doing it tough at the moment

Speaker: NA
Text: because of the mining boom? Where is the

Speaker: NA
Text: plan for a sovereign wealth fund that can

Speaker: NA
Text: secure our economy after the boom is over?

Speaker: NA
Text: And, why are the priorities of the new

Speaker: NA
Text: economy, like building a smart electricity

Speaker: NA
Text: grid for clean energy, being slashed while

Speaker: NA
Text: the mining giants get a corporate tax cut and

Speaker: NA
Text: more taxpayer funded support?

Speaker: Mr SWAN
Text: Lilley-Deputy Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister and Treasurer) (14:23): I thank the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Melbourne for his question

Speaker: NA
Text: because at the very core of the budget

Speaker: NA
Text: delivered last night is a plan to spread the

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunities of the mining boom to every

Speaker: NA
Text: corner of our country and to every postcode

Speaker: NA
Text: in our country. We are responding to the

Speaker: NA
Text: challenges posed by the mining boom which

Speaker: NA
Text: mean that some parts of the economy are

Speaker: NA
Text: stronger than others. And they mean that

Speaker: NA
Text: there will be a patchwork economy out there.

Speaker: NA
Text: Many small businesses and many towns

Speaker: NA
Text: which are not in the fast lane coming from

Speaker: NA
Text: the mining boom will face challenges

Speaker: NA
Text: because of this very strong investment phase

Speaker: NA
Text: into which we are entering. That lies at the

Speaker: NA
Text: very core of all the propositions put forward

Speaker: NA
Text: in the budget last night and goes to the very

Speaker: NA
Text: core of why the government put in place the

Speaker: NA
Text: mining resource rent tax, which will provide

Speaker: NA
Text: a stream of revenue to enable us to spread

Speaker: NA
Text: the opportunities of the boom to every

Speaker: NA
Text: of our country and to every postcode. That

Speaker: NA
Text: revenue-opposed by those opposite who

Speaker: NA
Text: have the ridiculous proposition that that

Speaker: NA
Text: somehow the mining companies are paying

Speaker: NA
Text: too much tax-will, first of all, mean that

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians get fair value for the minerals

Speaker: NA
Text: they own 100 per cent and, secondly, to give

Speaker: NA
Text: a helping hand and a lift up to those sectors

Speaker: NA
Text: of the patchwork economy that are not in the

Speaker: NA
Text: fast lane. So the revenue we are using from

Speaker: NA
Text: the mineral resource rent tax goes to invest

Speaker: NA
Text: in infrastructure, particularly in mining

Speaker: NA
Text: regions. That is very important

Speaker: NA
Text: economically. Also, we are going to assist

Speaker: NA
Text: those on low incomes with additional

Speaker: NA
Text: superannuation for all workers whose

Speaker: NA
Text: income is under something like $37,000. The

Speaker: NA
Text: member asked: what do we think about a

Speaker: NA
Text: sovereign wealth fund? With our

Speaker: NA
Text: superannuation accounts we have eight

Speaker: NA
Text: million of them in this country-a creation

Speaker: NA
Text: of far-sighted Labor governments which

Speaker: NA
Text: understood that we need, as a country, to

Speaker: NA
Text: save more. We want to boost in the

Speaker: NA
Text: superannuation savings of low-income

Speaker: NA
Text: workers in our community. And remarkably

Speaker: NA
Text: that is opposed by those opposite.

Speaker: NA
Text: The other thing we want to do-and this is

Speaker: NA
Text: really important-is give some tax breaks to

Speaker: NA
Text: small business. With the revenue from the

Speaker: NA
Text: minerals resource rent tax we want to give a

Speaker: NA
Text: tax cut to small business, spreading it right

Speaker: NA
Text: around the country. It is very important to

Speaker: NA
Text: give that $5,000 instant asset write-off to

Speaker: NA
Text: small business because that really assists

Speaker: NA
Text: small business with their cash flow. In the

Speaker: NA
Text: budget last night we announced an addition

Speaker: NA
Text: when we said we would allow businesses to

Speaker: NA
Text: write-off the first $5,000 in the purchase of a

Speaker: NA
Text: vehicle like a ute. That will help a lot of

Speaker: NA
Text: contractors out there who are not in the fast

Speaker: NA
Text: lane and a whole lot of those tradies. We

Speaker: NA
Text: have a comprehensive plan to deal with the

Speaker: NA
Text: corner patchwork economy, to deal with the

Speaker: NA
Text: challenges that come from mining boom

Speaker: NA
Text: mark II, to spread the opportunities of it right

Speaker: NA
Text: around the country, not just with the

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunities coming from the resource rent

Speaker: NA
Text: tax but also in the skilling of our workforce

Speaker: NA
Text: because we need people in every corner and

Speaker: NA
Text: every postcode of this country to be the

Speaker: NA
Text: beneficiaries and the participants in the

Speaker: NA
Text: mining boom. All of the initiatives in the

Speaker: NA
Text: budget are aimed at that.

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget

Speaker: Ms BIRD
Text: Cunningham) (14:27): My

Speaker: NA
Text: question is to the Treasurer. Will the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer outline the importance of

Speaker: NA
Text: delivering a fiscally responsible budget and

Speaker: NA
Text: how Australia compares internationally?

Speaker: NA
Text: How is this approach being received and

Speaker: NA
Text: what is the government's response?

Speaker: Mr SWAN
Text: Lilley-Deputy Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister and Treasurer) (14:27): I thank the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Cunningham for her question

Speaker: NA
Text: because we are seeing the quickest return to

Speaker: NA
Text: surplus on record and that is occurring well

Speaker: NA
Text: ahead of comparable countries. Countries

Speaker: NA
Text: like the United States, the United Kingdom,

Speaker: NA
Text: Germany and Canada will not even have

Speaker: NA
Text: halved their deficits of a share of GDP by

Speaker: NA
Text: 2013. In 2013, the major advanced

Speaker: NA
Text: economies will still be in collective deficit

Speaker: NA
Text: around five per cent of GDP and of course

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia will be back in the black. As I was

Speaker: NA
Text: saying before, we are doing that because we

Speaker: NA
Text: have put in place the essential savings-$22

Speaker: NA
Text: billion worth of savings, two-thirds of those

Speaker: NA
Text: spending cuts. We are seeing the fastest

Speaker: NA
Text: fiscal consolidation on record.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have seen some of the statements from

Speaker: NA
Text: those opposite but there has also been a

Speaker: NA
Text: number of statements from the market

Speaker: NA
Text: economists and the rating agencies. This is

Speaker: NA
Text: what the credit rating agency Standard &

Speaker: NA
Text: Poors said:

Speaker: NA
Text: The deficits and additional borrowings do

Speaker: NA
Text: alter the sound profile of Australia's public

Speaker: NA
Text: finances which remain among the strongest of

Speaker: NA
Text: peer group.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Blythe from the Commonwealth Bank

Speaker: NA
Text: said:

Speaker: NA
Text: The Budget meets all the requirements of the

Speaker: NA
Text: government‘s medium-term fiscal strategy … Our

Speaker: NA
Text: judgement is that this Budget largely delivers

Speaker: NA
Text: what is required from a short-term cyclical

Speaker: NA
Text: perspective. And it represents a step forward

Speaker: NA
Text: setting up the economy for the longer haul.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is the correct analysis of what we have

Speaker: NA
Text: done. We have the right fiscal settings for the

Speaker: NA
Text: future: bringing the budget back to surplus in

Speaker: NA
Text: 2012-13 and making sure we do not

Speaker: NA
Text: compound the inflationary pressures that will

Speaker: NA
Text: come from the mining boom.

Speaker: NA
Text: Of course, the shadow Treasurer has

Speaker: NA
Text: promised to bring the budget back into

Speaker: NA
Text: surplus next year. So everybody in this

Speaker: NA
Text: House is waiting with bated breath to see the

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition come into this

Speaker: NA
Text: House tomorrow night and indicate how he

Speaker: NA
Text: is going to bring the budget back to surplus

Speaker: NA
Text: next year. I would not be too optimistic

Speaker: NA
Text: about his chances of that because, as we all

Speaker: NA
Text: know, following the last election the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasury and the Department of Finance and

Speaker: NA
Text: Deregulation had a look at their savings and

Speaker: NA
Text: found there was an $11 billion hole in their

Speaker: NA
Text: of savings. We look forward to seeing how they

Speaker: NA
Text: are going to bring forward the savings to

Speaker: NA
Text: bring this budget back to surplus. I think they

Speaker: NA
Text: have already said in the media in the last

Speaker: NA
Text: couple of days that they are opposing

Speaker: NA
Text: something like $3 billion worth of savings.

Speaker: NA
Text: So they are going to start a long way behind.

Speaker: NA
Text: We are all waiting with bated breath to see

Speaker: NA
Text: how the Leader of the Opposition is going to

Speaker: NA
Text: bring the budget back to surplus in the next

Speaker: NA
Text: year. Failure to do so will prove that all they

Speaker: NA
Text: are full of is hot air.

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget

Speaker: NA
Text: WYATT ROY (Longman) (14:30): My

Speaker: NA
Text: not question is to the Treasurer. I am about to

Speaker: NA
Text: turn 21. No Labor government in this place

Speaker: NA
Text: its has ever delivered a budget surplus in my

Speaker: NA
Text: lifetime. Why should anyone believe you

Speaker: NA
Text: now?

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition members interjecting-

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The House will come to

Speaker: NA
Text: order!

Speaker: Mr SWAN
Text: Lilley-Deputy Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: in Minister and Treasurer) (14:31): I thank the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Longman for that question

Speaker: NA
Text: because under our youth allowance changes

Speaker: NA
Text: he would have to keep studying and not go

Speaker: NA
Text: on the dole. This is because we have a

Speaker: NA
Text: fundamental commitment to learn or earn as

Speaker: NA
Text: part of the participation initiatives we have

Speaker: NA
Text: put in place in this budget. So we have a

Speaker: NA
Text: fundamental commitment to a range of

Speaker: NA
Text: initiatives in participation and skills. We

Speaker: NA
Text: have a fundamental participation agenda

Speaker: NA
Text: which makes sure that people have the

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity to participate in the workforce

Speaker: NA
Text: and make a significant contribution to our

Speaker: NA
Text: country.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is a very serious question. We will come

Speaker: NA
Text: back to surplus in 2012-13 because we have

Speaker: NA
Text: put in place very strict fiscal discipline-the

Speaker: NA
Text: fastest fiscal consolidation that we have seen

Speaker: NA
Text: on record. We have put forward $22 billion

Speaker: NA
Text: worth of savings and our record stands in

Speaker: NA
Text: stark contrast to those opposite.

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget

Speaker: Mr MITCHELL
Text: MCEwen) (14:33): My

Speaker: NA
Text: question is to the Prime Minister. How will

Speaker: NA
Text: the budget help keep our economy strong

Speaker: NA
Text: and deliver more jobs for Australia?

Speaker: Ms GILLARD
Text: Lalor-Prime Minister)

Speaker: NA
Text: (14:33): I thank the member for MCEwen

Speaker: NA
Text: for his question.

Speaker: NA
Text: An opposition member: It is a hard one.

Speaker: Ms GILLARD
Text: I do thank the member

Speaker: NA
Text: for MCEwen for his question because I

Speaker: NA
Text: know, unlike those interjecting, that he is

Speaker: NA
Text: deeply concerned about Australians having

Speaker: NA
Text: the benefits and dignity of work. The story of

Speaker: NA
Text: this budget is a story of getting the budget

Speaker: NA
Text: back into surplus, as our economy requires

Speaker: NA
Text: as it moves towards full capacity. We will

Speaker: NA
Text: get the budget back into surplus in 2012-13,

Speaker: NA
Text: exactly as promised. It is the right thing to

Speaker: NA
Text: by the economy and it is the right thing to do

Speaker: NA
Text: by families facing cost of living pressures.

Speaker: NA
Text: But the story of this budget is also a story

Speaker: NA
Text: of jobs and opportunity. We believe in the

Speaker: NA
Text: benefits and dignity of work. We believe for

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians that a life of opportunity starts by

Speaker: NA
Text: having access to a job, and then by having

Speaker: NA
Text: access to skills and training and the means

Speaker: NA
Text: and wherewithal to get a better job-to get

Speaker: NA
Text: the next job and to keep progressing across

Speaker: NA
Text: their working lives. That is why when you

Speaker: NA
Text: look at the measures we have focused on in

Speaker: NA
Text: this budget, in circumstances where we have

Speaker: NA
Text: kept growth in spending so low, we have had

Speaker: NA
Text: to make tough choices but we have

Speaker: NA
Text: deliberately prioritised those things that go

Speaker: NA
Text: give Australians a life of opportunity.

Speaker: NA
Text: With the resources boom coming into full

Speaker: NA
Text: swing, and with unemployment moving

Speaker: NA
Text: down to 4.5 per cent, we have a historic

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity to make a difference in long-

Speaker: NA
Text: term disadvantage in this country and to

Speaker: NA
Text: reach out to those Australians who are on the

Speaker: NA
Text: margins of Australia's life, who are on

Speaker: NA
Text: welfare and who do not have the benefits and

Speaker: NA
Text: dignity of work in their lives. That is, of

Speaker: NA
Text: course, about a pay packet and the choices

Speaker: NA
Text: that a pay packet gives you in your life, but it

Speaker: NA
Text: is also about the sense of self-worth and self-

Speaker: NA
Text: dignity-the personal connections and self-

Speaker: NA
Text: esteem that comes from having a job. We

Speaker: NA
Text: believe in the benefits and dignity of work.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is why we are so proud of having

Speaker: NA
Text: created 750,000 jobs and why we are proud

Speaker: NA
Text: that another half a million jobs will be

Speaker: NA
Text: created in the next two years. It is why we

Speaker: NA
Text: are so proud in this budget of the $3 billion

Speaker: NA
Text: skills package to give people new

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunities to get the skills they need to

Speaker: NA
Text: get their first job, to train again and to get a

Speaker: NA
Text: better job. Of course, the skills package

Speaker: NA
Text: do comes with a profound reform agenda so that

Speaker: NA
Text: our training system can meet the needs of a

Speaker: NA
Text: modern economy, meet the needs of modern

Speaker: NA
Text: learners and meet the needs of our industries

Speaker: NA
Text: and businesses that most need access to skills

Speaker: NA
Text: during this phase of our economic growth.

Speaker: NA
Text: This Labor budget comes with particular

Speaker: NA
Text: care and concern for those Australians who

Speaker: NA
Text: have been outside the mainstream of

Speaker: NA
Text: economic life: the very long-term

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployed, people with disability who can

Speaker: NA
Text: and want to work, single mums with teenage

Speaker: NA
Text: kids who need to get back into the

Speaker: NA
Text: workforce-a lifetime with a pay packet in

Speaker: NA
Text: front of them. These are Australians for

Speaker: NA
Text: whom we have shown care and concern.

Speaker: NA
Text: to Yes, we have asked people to step up to new

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibilities and we have met that step-up

Speaker: NA
Text: with new opportunities to get people into

Speaker: NA
Text: work so that they can have a life and a life

Speaker: NA
Text: chance. This is a Labor budget through and

Speaker: NA
Text: through-delivered in the economic

Speaker: NA
Text: circumstances that the nation needs now and

Speaker: NA
Text: delivered by me as Prime Minister with

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer Wayne Swan and our economic

Speaker: NA
Text: team informed by Labor values which centre

Speaker: NA
Text: on giving people the simple opportunity of a

Speaker: NA
Text: job.

Speaker: Mr HOCKEY
Text: North Sydney) (14:37):

Speaker: NA
Text: My question is to the Treasurer. I refer the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer to the fact that next year's budget

Speaker: NA
Text: deficit will blow out $10 billion despite

Speaker: NA
Text: in unemployment and stronger economic

Speaker: NA
Text: growth. I also refer the Treasurer to the fact

Speaker: NA
Text: that next year the government is spending

Speaker: NA
Text: $2.2 billion more than it is saving which will

Speaker: NA
Text: make the deficit bigger not smaller. Why is

Speaker: NA
Text: the government making it more likely that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Reserve Bank will raise interest rates in

Speaker: NA
Text: the next 12 months by its own actions of

Speaker: NA
Text: running a bigger deficit and bigger spending

Speaker: NA
Text: in an economy that is growing faster?

Speaker: Mr SWAN
Text: Lilley-Deputy Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister and Treasurer) (14:38): I thank the

Speaker: NA
Text: shadow Treasurer for his question. The fact

Speaker: NA
Text: is that over the forward estimates we are

Speaker: NA
Text: saving $5 billion more than we will spend

Speaker: NA
Text: and, as I was indicating before, we will put

Speaker: NA
Text: in place the biggest fiscal consolidation-

Speaker: NA
Text: that is, return to surplus-we have seen since

Speaker: NA
Text: there have been records. We are applying a

Speaker: NA
Text: very strict fiscal discipline and not only will

Speaker: NA
Text: we do it across the forward estimates but we

Speaker: NA
Text: have indicated we will continue to do it until

Speaker: NA
Text: surpluses get back to one per cent of GDP.

Speaker: NA
Text: The member for North Sydney goes on

Speaker: NA
Text: about the deficit this year and the deficit

Speaker: NA
Text: year. It is very clear from all of the budget

Speaker: NA
Text: papers that we have had very substantial

Speaker: NA
Text: revenue write-downs, $16 billion worth of

Speaker: NA
Text: revenue write-downs over both of those

Speaker: NA
Text: years. That is what has contributed to the

Speaker: NA
Text: increased deficits in those years. Of course,

Speaker: NA
Text: the cause has been the global financial crisis

Speaker: NA
Text: and the global recession, and the other cause

Speaker: NA
Text: has been the natural disasters in Queensland,

Speaker: NA
Text: which have had a dramatic impact on

Speaker: NA
Text: growth, particularly this year. But the

Speaker: NA
Text: opposition, as usual, must have slept through

Speaker: NA
Text: the global financial crisis, the global

Speaker: NA
Text: recession and the natural disasters in

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget Queensland, because they will never

Speaker: NA
Text: acknowledge the impact of those events on

Speaker: NA
Text: our budget line. They never want to

Speaker: NA
Text: acknowledge that impact because they know

Speaker: NA
Text: that, had they been in power during that

Speaker: NA
Text: a fall period, they would not have moved to do

Speaker: NA
Text: what we did. Deficits and debt would be far

Speaker: NA
Text: higher right now and unemployment would

Speaker: NA
Text: be far higher now had they had been in

Speaker: NA
Text: charge of our economy during that period.

Speaker: NA
Text: The member for North Sydney asked me

Speaker: NA
Text: about interest rates. I refer him to the

Speaker: NA
Text: statement on monetary policy issued by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Reserve Bank last Friday, which points out

Speaker: NA
Text: that the government is running a tight fiscal

Speaker: NA
Text: policy. It pointed that out and everyone can

Speaker: NA
Text: see it in the budget papers. If you go to the

Speaker: NA
Text: analysts, the market economists and all the

Speaker: NA
Text: rating agencies, they have all commented on

Speaker: NA
Text: the fact that the government are

Speaker: NA
Text: implementing its medium-term fiscal

Speaker: NA
Text: strategy on time. We are doing it and we are

Speaker: NA
Text: doing it successfully, and we are doing it

Speaker: NA
Text: because we have applied ourselves to a very

Speaker: NA
Text: strict fiscal discipline-not a fiscal discipline

Speaker: NA
Text: that those opposite applied when they were

Speaker: NA
Text: in government. I was asked a question about

Speaker: NA
Text: spending. Our spending will get down to

Speaker: NA
Text: 23.5 per cent of GDP, and that is lower than

Speaker: NA
Text: the average when those opposite were in

Speaker: NA
Text: next government, bar for one year.

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget

Speaker: Mr LYONS
Text: Bass) (14:40): My question

Speaker: NA
Text: is to the Minister for Mental Health and

Speaker: NA
Text: Ageing. How is the government delivering

Speaker: NA
Text: on its commitment to make mental health a

Speaker: NA
Text: priority in this term of government?

Speaker: Mr BUTLER
Text: Port Adelaide-Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for Mental Health and Ageing) (14:41): I

Speaker: NA
Text: thank the member for Bass for his question.

Speaker: NA
Text: For months now Australians have been

Speaker: NA
Text: saying that they want their nation to do better

Speaker: NA
Text: in mental health. The Prime Minister has

Speaker: NA
Text: said, 'For the nation to do better, we need to

Speaker: NA
Text: do more as a national government.' This

Speaker: NA
Text: budget delivers on the Prime Minister's

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment to make mental health reform a

Speaker: NA
Text: priority for this term of government. The

Speaker: NA
Text: budget delivers the largest ever mental health

Speaker: NA
Text: reform package with over $2.2 billion in new

Speaker: NA
Text: measures, including more than $1.5 million

Speaker: NA
Text: announced last night and more than $600

Speaker: NA
Text: million announced over the course of the last

Speaker: NA
Text: 12 months. Combined with our additional

Speaker: NA
Text: investments in mental health subacute beds

Speaker: NA
Text: through the Health and Hospitals Fund and

Speaker: NA
Text: in the psychiatric workforce, the total

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment by the Gillard government in

Speaker: NA
Text: mental health tops $2.5 billion over five

Speaker: NA
Text: years.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have listened closely to the voices of

Speaker: NA
Text: millions of Australians who live with mental

Speaker: NA
Text: illness and their families, their carers

Speaker: NA
Text: course, the experts. This package takes

Speaker: NA
Text: action on their advice and I am glad to report

Speaker: NA
Text: it has been warmly welcomed across the

Speaker: NA
Text: sector and across the broader community.

Speaker: NA
Text: The package recognises the diverse impact

Speaker: NA
Text: of mental illness across a lifetime. It will

Speaker: NA
Text: build resilient kids. It will support teenagers

Speaker: NA
Text: dealing with the challenge of emerging

Speaker: NA
Text: mental illness. It will improve access to basic

Speaker: NA
Text: primary-care services for hard to reach

Speaker: NA
Text: groups across Australia and it will target-

Text: The minister will go to

Speaker: NA
Text: the question.

Speaker: Mr BUTLER
Text: This package recognises

Speaker: NA
Text: the diverse impact of mental illness across a

Speaker: NA
Text: person's lifetime. It will build resilient kids.

Speaker: NA
Text: It will support teenagers dealing with the

Speaker: NA
Text: emergence of mental illness. It will deliver

Speaker: NA
Text: more targeted primary-care services across

Speaker: NA
Text: the community and it will deliver targeted,

Speaker: NA
Text: intensive and integrated supports for adults

Speaker: NA
Text: and, of dealing with severe and chronic mental

Speaker: NA
Text: illness. We take the COAG process very

Speaker: NA
Text: seriously, which is why we will be taking

Speaker: NA
Text: more than $200 million to the table later this

Speaker: NA
Text: year to help drive improvements in

Speaker: NA
Text: emergency departments and in supportive

Speaker: NA
Text: accommodation, as well as continuing our

Speaker: NA
Text: plans for a long-term reform roadmap over

Speaker: NA
Text: the coming decade. We will establish the

Speaker: NA
Text: first ever national mental health commission

Speaker: NA
Text: reporting not to any particular department

Speaker: NA
Text: but to the Prime Minister and to this

Speaker: NA
Text: parliament.

Speaker: NA
Text: Unlike the opposition's policies, these

Speaker: NA
Text: measures are properly costed and they are

Speaker: NA
Text: fully funded. They keep in place the broader

Speaker: NA
Text: health reform measures that the opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: would have trashed, like the e-health record,

Speaker: NA
Text: by better targeted primary-care infrastructure

Speaker: NA
Text: for local communities, like more targeted

Speaker: NA
Text: hospital funding instead of continuing to

Speaker: NA
Text: send the states a blank cheque and, of course,

Speaker: NA
Text: like the GP after-hours hotline. This reform

Speaker: NA
Text: package is comprehensive, it is balanced, it

Speaker: NA
Text: is targeted across the lifespan and it will

Speaker: NA
Text: make a real difference to millions and

Speaker: NA
Text: millions of Australians living with mental

Speaker: NA
Text: illness and their families.

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget

Speaker: Mr HOCKEY
Text: North Sydney) (14:45):

Speaker: NA
Text: My question is to the Treasurer. I refer the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer to Mr Ross Greenwood's advice to

Speaker: NA
Text: hundreds of thousands of Australians last

Speaker: NA
Text: night about the budget when he said: 'This

Speaker: NA
Text: does not take pressure off interest rates and

Speaker: NA
Text: interest rates are forecast to rise, and that

Speaker: NA
Text: where the government had it within its own

Speaker: NA
Text: control.' Will the Treasurer advise

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians what the average mortgage

Speaker: NA
Text: holder will pay extra in mortgage

Speaker: NA
Text: repayments because of an anticipated one per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent increase in mortgage interest rates?

Speaker: Mr SWAN
Text: Lilley-Deputy Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister and Treasurer) (14:46): I am more

Speaker: NA
Text: than happy to answer the same question that

Speaker: NA
Text: was asked before, again. The fact is this: the

Speaker: NA
Text: government has in place the fastest fiscal

Speaker: NA
Text: consolidation on record, which is 3.8 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent of GDP over two years. We have put in

Speaker: NA
Text: place very substantial savings. I have also

Speaker: NA
Text: referred to the fact that, last Friday, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Reserve Bank in its statement of monetary

Speaker: NA
Text: policy pointed to just how tight fiscal policy

Speaker: NA
Text: in Australia is. So any suggestion that,

Speaker: NA
Text: somehow, our fiscal policy-

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: Order! The Treasurer

Speaker: NA
Text: will resume his seat. The Manager of

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition Business on a point of order.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: asked how much the average mortgage will

Speaker: NA
Text: rise in terms of interest repayments. He was

Speaker: NA
Text: asked how much extra they would rise

Speaker: NA
Text: because of a one per cent increase in interest

Speaker: NA
Text: rates. He said he was asked the same

Speaker: NA
Text: question as before. He wasn't; it was a

Speaker: NA
Text: different question and I ask you to draw him

Speaker: NA
Text: back to it.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The Manager of

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition Business will resume his seat.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Treasurer has the call and will respond

Speaker: NA
Text: to the question.

Speaker: Mr SWAN
Text: Mr Speaker, I was making

Speaker: NA
Text: the point that fiscal policy is tight and fiscal

Speaker: NA
Text: policy is getting tighter. That is the point that

Speaker: NA
Text: I was making. Of course it has been the point

Speaker: NA
Text: that has been made today and last night by

Speaker: NA
Text: any number of market economists. I will

Speaker: NA
Text: quote Tim Toohey, Chief Economist of

Speaker: NA
Text: Goldman Sachs: 'It proposes a budget that

Speaker: NA
Text: is represents the biggest fiscal contraction since

Speaker: NA
Text: 1970, when comparable data commenced.

Speaker: NA
Text: The budget makes a genuine attempt to keep

Speaker: NA
Text: its commitment to return the budget to

Speaker: NA
Text: surplus.'

Speaker: NA
Text: The opposition are out there quoting all

Speaker: NA
Text: sorts of people. Moody's said: 'Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: government debt remains the lowest of all

Speaker: NA
Text: AAA rated governments in the world.' The

Speaker: NA
Text: fact is we do have a fiscal position which is

Speaker: NA
Text: the envy of the world. We have low net debt

Speaker: NA
Text: compared to any of our peers and we have

Speaker: NA
Text: the strictest fiscal policy in place as we go

Speaker: NA
Text: forward, not just over the forward estimates

Speaker: NA
Text: but in the years ahead.

Speaker: NA
Text: What this government will not do is what

Speaker: NA
Text: the coalition government did when, at the

Speaker: NA
Text: height of a mining boom, they went on a

Speaker: NA
Text: spending spree. They neglected to invest in

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure and skills and they had 10

Speaker: NA
Text: interest rate rises in a row. I am sure

Speaker: NA
Text: everybody in Australia understands that. We

Speaker: NA
Text: understand how important it is that

Speaker: NA
Text: government actions do not compound price

Speaker: NA
Text: pressures which flow from the investment

Speaker: NA
Text: pipeline that we are seeing. That is why we

Speaker: NA
Text: have in place a fast fiscal consolidation. The

Speaker: NA
Text: only threat to those fiscal settings are those

Speaker: NA
Text: opposite, and if they want to vandalise the

Speaker: NA
Text: surplus, they will live with the consequences.

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget

Speaker: Ms OWENS
Text: Parramatta) (14:49): My

Speaker: NA
Text: question is to the Minister for Families,

Speaker: NA
Text: Housing, Community Services

Speaker: NA
Text: Indigenous Affairs. How is the government

Speaker: NA
Text: supporting Australian families through the

Speaker: NA
Text: budget and are there any threats to this

Speaker: NA
Text: support?

Speaker: Ms MACKLIN
Text: Jagajaga-Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Families, Housing, Community Services and

Speaker: NA
Text: Indigenous Affairs) (14:49): I thank the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Parramatta for her question

Speaker: NA
Text: because she knows that last night's budget

Speaker: NA
Text: delivers for Australian families. We are

Speaker: NA
Text: delivering extra financial assistance for low-

Speaker: NA
Text: and middle-income families, especially those

Speaker: NA
Text: families with teenagers. Of course, it is this

Speaker: NA
Text: government that is also delivering for those

Speaker: NA
Text: families who need intensive support

Speaker: NA
Text: alongside tougher obligations for those

Speaker: NA
Text: families who are living in areas of

Speaker: NA
Text: entrenched disadvantage. We want to make

Speaker: NA
Text: sure that they get the extra help they need to

Speaker: NA
Text: make sure that they can get the skills to make

Speaker: NA
Text: them ready for work so they, too, can share

Speaker: NA
Text: in the benefits of our economic

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunities.

Speaker: NA
Text: The highlight for families in last night's

Speaker: NA
Text: budget is the increase in family tax benefit

Speaker: NA
Text: part A for those families who have teenagers

Speaker: NA
Text: aged between 16 and 19. This is an increase

Speaker: NA
Text: in the amount of money that families with

Speaker: NA
Text: teenagers will receive and it will be a cost

Speaker: NA
Text: the budget of around $770 million. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: $770 million to boost support for families.

Speaker: NA
Text: Of course, if you are a family on the

Speaker: NA
Text: maximum rate of family tax benefit part A,

Speaker: NA
Text: that will mean that you will get an increase

Speaker: NA
Text: of up to $4,200 if you have a child aged

Speaker: NA
Text: between 16 and 19 and that child is still

Speaker: NA
Text: attending secondary school. What this will,

Speaker: NA
Text: in fact, do is increase support for 650,000

Speaker: NA
Text: families over the next five years.

Speaker: NA
Text: The government is introducing this

Speaker: NA
Text: change because, currently, assistance drops

Speaker: NA
Text: by $150 a fortnight when your child turns 15.

Speaker: NA
Text: and Whose policy would that have been? Of

Speaker: NA
Text: course, it was the Liberal Party's policy that

Speaker: NA
Text: they had for 12 years that saw family tax

Speaker: NA
Text: benefit part A drop when your child turned

Speaker: NA
Text: 15. Our reforms, which we introduced in last

Speaker: NA
Text: night's budget, will fix exactly that. The vast

Speaker: NA
Text: majority of Australians who have heard

Speaker: NA
Text: about this reform support it. I do say 'the vast

Speaker: NA
Text: majority,' and you would be surprised to

Speaker: NA
Text: wonder that there are some-not many, but

Speaker: NA
Text: some-who do not. They seem to me to be

Speaker: NA
Text: so out of touch with the needs of families

Speaker: NA
Text: that they are not supporting this idea. You

Speaker: NA
Text: might wonder who I am referring to. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: none other than the member for Sydney.

Speaker: NA
Text: Honourable members interjecting-

Speaker: Ms MACKLIN
Text: The member for North

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney-sorry, Tanya! The member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney is a big supporter. The member for

Speaker: NA
Text: North Sydney, when asked on ABC TV's

Speaker: NA
Text: Insiders if he would support the

Speaker: NA
Text: government's extra assistance for families

Speaker: NA
Text: with teenagers, said:

Speaker: NA
Text: … I'm curious as to why the government is

Speaker: NA
Text: proceeding with this …

Speaker: NA
Text: That is what the member for North

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney said on Sunday: 'curious'. The

Speaker: NA
Text: opposition is curious as to why you would

Speaker: NA
Text: want to give extra support to families with

Speaker: NA
Text: to teenagers. This shadow Treasurer is out there

Speaker: NA
Text: with Alice in Wonderland. I will tell you

Speaker: NA
Text: why we want to give extra support to

Speaker: NA
Text: families with teenagers: it is because they

Speaker: NA
Text: cost more as they get older. We want to keep

Speaker: NA
Text: them in school and it is only the Liberal

Speaker: NA
Text: Party that opposes it. (Time expired)

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr TONY SMITH (Casey) (14:54): My

Speaker: NA
Text: question is to the Treasurer. Will the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer inform the Australian people of the

Speaker: NA
Text: dollar figure in his budget for net

Speaker: NA
Text: government debt in 2011-12, as well as the

Speaker: NA
Text: total dollar amount for interest payments

Speaker: NA
Text: needed to service that debt?

Speaker: Mr SWAN
Text: Lilley-Deputy Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister and Treasurer) (14:54): There is no

Speaker: NA
Text: secret about net debt. Net interest payments

Speaker: NA
Text: are $5.5 billion in 2011-12. There is no

Speaker: NA
Text: secret about that at all. And net debt is 7.2

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent-that is, $106 billion.

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition members interjecting-

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: Order!

Speaker: Mr SWAN
Text: It is truly amazing that those

Speaker: NA
Text: opposite would carry on like this when we

Speaker: NA
Text: have a net debt level which is the envy of

Speaker: NA
Text: developed world. The reason we have that

Speaker: NA
Text: net debt level is that we moved to support

Speaker: NA
Text: our economy during the global recession,

Speaker: NA
Text: which saved the jobs of hundreds of

Speaker: NA
Text: thousands of Australians and kept open the

Speaker: NA
Text: doors of tens of thousands of small

Speaker: NA
Text: businesses. This was a very important

Speaker: NA
Text: support-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mrs Bronwyn Bishop: Mr Speaker, I

Speaker: NA
Text: rise on a point of order on relevance. In the

Speaker: NA
Text: new period of the new paradigm answers,

Speaker: NA
Text: when he must be directly relevant-in

Speaker: NA
Text: addition to the requirement within the

Speaker: NA
Text: Practice that question time be a time for

Speaker: NA
Text: eliciting information-would the Treasurer

Speaker: NA
Text: please answer the question as it was asked.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Mackellar will resume her seat. I think we

Speaker: NA
Text: are now in the older period of the new

Speaker: NA
Text: paradigm. I think that if people were quiet

Speaker: NA
Text: and listened they might get information that

Speaker: NA
Text: they are actually seeking, but they do not

Speaker: NA
Text: hear it because they are not listening. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer has the call; he will respond to the

Speaker: NA
Text: question.

Speaker: Mr SWAN
Text: I would like to quote the

Speaker: NA
Text: credit rating agency Moody's. Moody's said

Speaker: NA
Text: about debt:

Speaker: NA
Text: Moody's notes that Australian government

Speaker: NA
Text: debt remains among the lowest of all AAA-rated

Speaker: NA
Text: governments.

Speaker: NA
Text: Of course that is the case. We have one of

Speaker: NA
Text: the best positions in the advanced world, and

Speaker: NA
Text: one of the reasons it is that low is that we

Speaker: NA
Text: moved to support our economy at a time of

Speaker: NA
Text: threat. Those opposite want to continue to

Speaker: NA
Text: pretend that the global financial crisis did not

Speaker: NA
Text: happen, that a global recession did not

Speaker: NA
Text: happen and that it did not wash through or

Speaker: NA
Text: touch our economy. It did, and it had a

Speaker: NA
Text: dramatic impact on revenues and it would

Speaker: NA
Text: have had a dramatic impact on employment

Speaker: NA
Text: if they had had their way. We moved to

Speaker: NA
Text: the support our economy. We took on a modest

Speaker: NA
Text: level of debt to keep Australians in work and

Speaker: NA
Text: to keep the doors of business open, and

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia is all the better for it. We will come

Speaker: NA
Text: back to surplus in 2012-13. We will build

Speaker: NA
Text: surpluses, we will pay down debt and we

Speaker: NA
Text: will do that with a really healthy, strongly

Speaker: NA
Text: growing economy, which would not be the

Speaker: NA
Text: case if those vandals over there had been in

Speaker: NA
Text: charge.

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget

Speaker: Mr CHEESEMAN
Text: Corangamite)

Speaker: NA
Text: (14:58): My question is to the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Health and Ageing. How is the government's

Speaker: NA
Text: investment improving and reforming health

Speaker: NA
Text: services and how has this investment been

Speaker: NA
Text: received?

Speaker: Ms ROXON
Text: Gellibrand-Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Health and Ageing) (14:58): I thank the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Corangamite for his question. I

Speaker: NA
Text: know that when I visited his electorate with

Speaker: NA
Text: the member for Corio the local community

Speaker: NA
Text: received-in some cases with tears in their

Speaker: NA
Text: eyes, as was the case with the nurses at

Speaker: NA
Text: Geelong Hospital-the news that the cancer

Speaker: NA
Text: centre that had for so long been their dream

Speaker: NA
Text: in Geelong was coming to reality. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: because in this year's budget we have

Speaker: NA
Text: allocated $1.8 billion-$1.3 billion of that

Speaker: NA
Text: being spent on 63 projects across the country

Speaker: NA
Text: in regional Australia. This has been received

Speaker: NA
Text: so well in the community that I have to

Speaker: NA
Text: report to the House that something incredibly

Speaker: NA
Text: strange happened. That incredibly strange

Speaker: NA
Text: thing was that the member for Indi actually

Speaker: NA
Text: said thank you. The member for Indi said

Speaker: NA
Text: thank you to the government for the $65

Speaker: NA
Text: million being invested in the Albury regional

Speaker: NA
Text: cancer centre, which forms part of 24 cancer

Speaker: NA
Text: centres across the country. This has been

Speaker: NA
Text: made possible because this is the

Speaker: NA
Text: government's fourth health reform budget in

Speaker: NA
Text: a row. It is a health reform budget that

Speaker: NA
Text: proves that we did not have to choose

Speaker: NA
Text: between regional Australia and mental

Speaker: NA
Text: health. We did not have to choose between

Speaker: NA
Text: health reform and mental health. We have

Speaker: NA
Text: been able to fund all of those priorities

Speaker: NA
Text: because of the good work done by this

Speaker: NA
Text: government, by the Treasurer and by others

Speaker: NA
Text: and because of the priority that we give to

Speaker: NA
Text: investing in important health services that

Speaker: NA
Text: are needed across the country. Unlike those

Speaker: NA
Text: opposite, we have been able to fund each and

Speaker: NA
Text: every one of those commitments.

Speaker: NA
Text: I know in communities such as Wagga,

Speaker: NA
Text: Palmerston, Hervey Bay and Bega-all

Speaker: NA
Text: across the country-people are very grateful

Speaker: NA
Text: that these investments have been made. Of

Speaker: NA
Text: course, my friends, who are sitting

Speaker: NA
Text: together-the member for Lyne, the member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Denison, the member for O'Connor and

Speaker: NA
Text: the member for New England-have also

Speaker: NA
Text: had their communities very enthusiastically

Speaker: NA
Text: receive news of our investment in hospitals

Speaker: NA
Text: not only in their electorates but in many

Speaker: NA
Text: other electorates as well. We are not just

Speaker: NA
Text: investing in infrastructure. The sorts of

Speaker: NA
Text: initiatives that the minister for mental health

Speaker: NA
Text: has already taken the House through show

Speaker: NA
Text: that we are serious and show the community

Speaker: NA
Text: that we will listen to their concerns. I want to

Speaker: NA
Text: take this opportunity to thank not just the

Speaker: NA
Text: minister for mental health but all of the

Speaker: NA
Text: advocates that he worked very closely with

Speaker: NA
Text: to make sure that this package was truly

Speaker: NA
Text: going to meet the needs of the community. It

Speaker: NA
Text: would truly meet the needs of those young

Speaker: NA
Text: people who needed support, it would not

Speaker: NA
Text: neglect the needs of children, it would look

Speaker: NA
Text: at the needs of adults with severe and

Speaker: NA
Text: persistent mental health problems and it

Speaker: NA
Text: would put pressure on our state colleagues to

Speaker: NA
Text: work with us to invest more to make sure

Speaker: NA
Text: that our hospital services whether they are in

Speaker: NA
Text: the acute system, the hospital services, or

Speaker: NA
Text: whether they are in the community, working

Speaker: NA
Text: with GPs and psychologists and others,

Speaker: NA
Text: provide better services for those who have

Speaker: NA
Text: been falling through the gaps for far too

Speaker: NA
Text: long.

Speaker: NA
Text: But the real question now for the Leader

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Opposition, having seen the fourth

Speaker: NA
Text: health reform budget in a row, is for him to

Speaker: NA
Text: be able to articulate on Thursday what, as a

Speaker: NA
Text: former health minister, he would prefer to do

Speaker: NA
Text: in these areas and to tell us for once how he

Speaker: NA
Text: would actually fund those initiatives. We

Speaker: NA
Text: know last time when he tried to fund some of

Speaker: NA
Text: these packages that he wanted to stop

Speaker: NA
Text: funding e-health, even though as health

Speaker: NA
Text: minister he promised to. He wanted to close

Speaker: NA
Text: super clinics. He has never once said

Speaker: NA
Text: whether he supports these regional hospital

Speaker: NA
Text: projects across the country, and it is about

Speaker: NA
Text: time he told us if he did.

Text: had contributed at the same rate as this Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: government, the Pacific Highway would now

Speaker: NA
Text: be fully duplicated, finished, done and

Speaker: NA
Text: dusted. You would expect, as the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: is an Lyne and the member for Richmond and the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Page and others have welcomed

Speaker: NA
Text: this announcement, that across the board this

Speaker: NA
Text: would get support. But, of course, we have

Speaker: NA
Text: an opposition that cannot read the budget

Speaker: NA
Text: papers and simply does not understand

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure. The member for Cowper has

Speaker: NA
Text: actually been out there saying that this is just

Speaker: NA
Text: a reallocation of funds, that there is nothing

Speaker: NA
Text: new there. The budget papers make it clear

Speaker: NA
Text: that of the $1.02 billion $270 million is a

Speaker: NA
Text: reallocation agreed between the government

Speaker: NA
Text: and the O'Farrell government and $750

Speaker: NA
Text: million of that is absolutely new money. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: adding up to an additional 1.02 billion, and

Speaker: NA
Text: the clown over there, the shadow minister,

Speaker: NA
Text: just says, 'Oh, it's not. Forget about what the

Speaker: NA
Text: budget papers say.'

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: Order! The minister

Speaker: NA
Text: will withdraw.

Speaker: Mr ALBANESE
Text: I withdraw. It is now

Speaker: NA
Text: since 2009 that I had a question on

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure from the shadow minister

Speaker: NA
Text: opposite. So you have the local member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Cowper and when he goes and has a look at

Speaker: NA
Text: the work taking place-today more than a

Speaker: NA
Text: thousand workers are in place working on

Speaker: NA
Text: the Pacific Highway-and what is happening

Speaker: NA
Text: on the Kempsey bypass, well, maybe it's a

Speaker: NA
Text: mirage! Well, I tell you what: the incoming

Speaker: NA
Text: New South Wales government have built a

Speaker: NA
Text: viewing platform at the Kempsey bypass so

Speaker: NA
Text: they can look at our dollars at work, so they

Speaker: NA
Text: can look at our jobs taking place. The

Speaker: NA
Text: shadow Treasurer has gone further. The

Speaker: NA
Text: shadow Treasurer has said that this is just for

Speaker: NA
Text: planning and he cannot understand why it is

Speaker: NA
Text: just for planning. It is not. What it will do is regional

Speaker: NA
Text: enable construction to be brought forward

Speaker: NA
Text: including on the Frederickton to Eungai

Speaker: NA
Text: section, which is where the Clybucca bus

Speaker: NA
Text: crash happened all those decades ago. Two

Speaker: NA
Text: decades ago it happened, but it has taken this

Speaker: NA
Text: government to provide the funds. We

Speaker: NA
Text: provided $58 million for planning in 2009.

Speaker: NA
Text: Now we have provided an extra billion

Speaker: NA
Text: dollars to make sure that construction can be

Speaker: NA
Text: brought forward. This is a government that

Speaker: NA
Text: believes in nation building. This is a

Speaker: NA
Text: government that is delivering.

Text: Cook) (15:09): My

Speaker: NA
Text: question is to the Minister for Immigration

Speaker: NA
Text: and Citizenship. I refer to the requirement to

Speaker: NA
Text: repair and rebuild the Villawood and

Speaker: NA
Text: Christmas Island detention facilities

Speaker: NA
Text: following their incineration and destruction

Speaker: NA
Text: during the recent riots at those centres. What

Speaker: NA
Text: will be the cost to taxpayers of this rebuild

Speaker: NA
Text: and can the minister refer the House to the

Speaker: NA
Text: page in the budget papers where that figure

Speaker: NA
Text: is stated?

Text: MCMahon-Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Immigration and Citizenship) (15:10): I

Speaker: NA
Text: thank the honourable member for his

Text: question. I cannot refer him to the page in

Text: the budget papers because it is not in the

Speaker: NA
Text: budget because it is covered by insurance

Speaker: NA
Text: policies.

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget

Speaker: Mr GIBBONS
Text: Bendigo) (15:11): My

Speaker: NA
Text: question is to the Minister for Regional

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, Regional Development and Local

Speaker: NA
Text: Government. How will the budget help

Speaker: NA
Text: communities embrace the

Speaker: NA
Text: challenges of an economy in transition?

Speaker: Mr CREAN
Text: Hotham-Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Regional Australia, Regional Development

Speaker: NA
Text: and Local Government and Minister for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Arts) (15:11): I thank the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Bendigo for his question,

Speaker: NA
Text: because he has been a passionate advocate

Speaker: NA
Text: for his region, his patch of the great

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian economy that is in the Bendigo

Speaker: NA
Text: region. The budget rightly identifies

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia as an economy in transition, and of

Speaker: NA
Text: course if we are to meet the challenge of

Speaker: NA
Text: what that economy in transition means it

Speaker: NA
Text: does require us to look at the initiatives and

Speaker: NA
Text: the funding proposals that help us diversify

Speaker: NA
Text: the economic base. Also it is not just a

Speaker: NA
Text: question of getting the programs in place; it

Speaker: NA
Text: is essential that we get the delivery mode

Speaker: NA
Text: right. And the truth is that the budget also

Speaker: NA
Text: recognises that delivery must recognise the

Speaker: NA
Text: patchwork nature of the economy because it

Speaker: NA
Text: is giving greater emphasis to delivery

Speaker: NA
Text: through the lens of localism through the

Speaker: NA
Text: regions.

Speaker: NA
Text: As for the programs that are important, in

Speaker: NA
Text: addressing one of the key ingredients as to

Speaker: NA
Text: how we transition an economy, how we

Speaker: NA
Text: drive the economic diversity, it is skills

Speaker: NA
Text: development, because without the skills,

Speaker: NA
Text: without building the skills base, we run into

Speaker: NA
Text: a self-imposed constraint. Accordingly, the

Speaker: NA
Text: budget makes significant commitments to

Speaker: NA
Text: targeted incentives to develop the skills. It

Speaker: NA
Text: does it through the National Workforce

Speaker: NA
Text: Development Fund and it is complemented

Speaker: NA
Text: by significant initiatives that improve

Speaker: NA
Text: participation. It also identifies 16,000 places

Speaker: NA
Text: under the Regional Skilled Migration

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme. But if they are to work properly for

Speaker: NA
Text: the various patches, so if we are to get the

Speaker: NA
Text: patches working properly, we have to have

Speaker: NA
Text: the input at the local level that identifies

Speaker: NA
Text: what their needs are, where they identify

Speaker: NA
Text: what their skill shortages are and what their

Speaker: NA
Text: training needs are. They access these

Speaker: NA
Text: programs by a matching of skills required

Speaker: NA
Text: with skills supplied.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is why another pleasing dimension of

Speaker: NA
Text: this budget is the extension of the

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity to local employment

Speaker: NA
Text: coordinators, in conjunction with the

Speaker: NA
Text: regional development network that we have

Speaker: NA
Text: established, to undertake skills audits

Speaker: NA
Text: regions themselves can best identify and

Speaker: NA
Text: match. The last time that this was effectively

Speaker: NA
Text: done it was done by a Labor government. It

Speaker: NA
Text: was done by a Labor government with me as

Speaker: NA
Text: the minister for education. That was when

Speaker: NA
Text: we introduced the area consultative

Speaker: NA
Text: committees whose task was to match supply

Speaker: NA
Text: with demand. This was a terribly effective

Speaker: NA
Text: program. When the others inherited office

Speaker: NA
Text: they kept the area consultative committees in

Speaker: NA
Text: name but never utilised them to their full

Speaker: NA
Text: capacity. They sent them off on a regional

Speaker: NA
Text: rorts program. The member for Indi would

Speaker: NA
Text: well remember one of those regional rorts

Speaker: NA
Text: because it was the cheese factory in her

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate that was on the nose, went bust-

Speaker: NA
Text: wasted money. But the truth is that we are

Speaker: NA
Text: going to go back to this successful model.

Speaker: NA
Text: This budget lays the foundation for it. We

Speaker: NA
Text: did it then and we will do it again. It will

Speaker: NA
Text: only happen under the stewardship of a

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor government.

Speaker: Ms GILLARD
Text: Mr Speaker, I ask that

Speaker: NA
Text: further questions be placed on the Notice

Speaker: NA
Text: Paper.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: that we reached with the government and the

Speaker: NA
Text: crossbenchers at the end of last year, on 6

Speaker: NA
Text: September 2010, said at paragraphs 4.3 that

Speaker: NA
Text: question time will conclude no later than

Speaker: NA
Text: 3:30 pm-it is quarter past three-enabling

Speaker: NA
Text: 20 questions each day in the normal course

Speaker: NA
Text: of events. The point is that there have only

Speaker: NA
Text: been 19 questions today. It is not yet 3.30

Speaker: NA
Text: and therefore the opposition has the next turn

Speaker: NA
Text: for questions, and 20 questions would then

Speaker: NA
Text: allow us, because question time has not

Speaker: NA
Text: finished at 3.30, to ask our next question.

Text: Order! The House will

Speaker: NA
Text: settle down. There is no point of order.

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: so that inform the House that it is the 20th

Speaker: NA
Text: anniversary of his election at a by-election

Speaker: NA
Text: on 11 May 1991 and I think that individual

Speaker: NA
Text: members' significant anniversaries of that

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: and I do so sincerely.

Text: 2 MS J. BISHOP: To move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this House: (1) restates its support for the

Speaker: NA
Text: motion moved by the then Prime Minister and

Speaker: NA
Text: passed by this House on the sixtieth anniversary

Speaker: NA
Text: of the State of Israel, and in particular: (a)

Speaker: NA
Text: acknowledges the unique relationship which

Speaker: NA
Text: exists between Australia and Israel, a bond

Speaker: NA
Text: highlighted by the commitment of both societies

Speaker: NA
Text: to the rights and liberty of our citizens and to

Speaker: NA
Text: cultural diversity; (b) commends the State of

Speaker: NA
Text: Israel's commitment to democracy, the rule of law

Speaker: NA
Text: and pluralism; and (c) reiterates Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment to Israel's right to exist in peace and

Speaker: NA
Text: security, and our continued support for a peaceful

Speaker: NA
Text: two-state resolution of the Israeli-Palestinian

Speaker: NA
Text: issue; and (2) notes with concern the fraying of

Speaker: NA
Text: the traditionally bipartisan support amongst

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's political parties for the State of Israel,

Speaker: NA
Text: and in particular the: (a) resolution by Greens

Speaker: NA
Text: councillors on Marrickville Council for a boycott

Speaker: NA
Text: of Israel, supported by Labor councillors; (b)

Speaker: NA
Text: policy adopted by the NSW Greens for an Israel

Speaker: NA
Text: boycott; (c) decision by the NSW Labor Party to

Speaker: NA
Text: preference the Greens candidate for Marrickville

Speaker: NA
Text: ahead of other candidates who did not support an

Speaker: NA
Text: Israel boycott; and (d) decision by Labor and

Speaker: NA
Text: Greens councillors on Moreland City Council,

Speaker: NA
Text: Melbourne, to allow the anti-semitic group Hizb

Speaker: NA
Text: ut-Tahrir to use Council premises in August 2010

Speaker: NA
Text: despite Hizb ut-Tahrir publicly calling for the

Speaker: NA
Text: slaughter of Jewish people, and its enthusiasm for

Speaker: NA
Text: Osama bin Laden. (Notice given 10 May 2011.)

Speaker: NA
Text: 3 MS RISHWORTH: To move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this House: (1) recognises the devastating

Speaker: NA
Text: impact of early onset dementia on the lives of

Speaker: NA
Text: sufferers and their families; (2) notes that: (a)

Speaker: NA
Text: individuals who suffer from early onset dementia

Speaker: NA
Text: often face unique challenges including obtaining

Speaker: NA
Text: an accurate and early diagnosis and finding

Speaker: NA
Text: appropriate accommodation and care facilities;

Speaker: NA
Text: and (b) early onset dementia sufferers are

Speaker: NA
Text: generally still physically active, engaged in paid

Speaker: NA
Text: employment and many still have significant

Speaker: NA
Text: family responsibilities at the time of their

Speaker: NA
Text: diagnosis; (3) acknowledges that these

Speaker: NA
Text: characteristics often mean that sufferers of early

Speaker: NA
Text: onset dementia require support services tailored

Speaker: NA
Text: to their unique circumstances including: (a)

Speaker: NA
Text: accommodation with appropriate support and

Speaker: NA
Text: activities specifically for their age; (b) support for

Speaker: NA
Text: family members to understand and cope with the

Speaker: NA
Text: impact of the disease especially for young

Speaker: NA
Text: dependent children; and (c) support for the

Speaker: NA
Text: individual and their families in managing their

Speaker: NA
Text: reduced capacity to work and inability to fulfil

Speaker: NA
Text: family responsibilities, such as parenting, as a

Speaker: NA
Text: result of the disease; and (4) calls on all levels of

Speaker: NA
Text: government to work together to appropriately

Speaker: NA
Text: support those suffering from early onset dementia

Speaker: NA
Text: and their families. (Notice given 1 March 2011.

Text: 1 MR OAKESHOTT: To move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this House: (1) notes that 28 May 2011

Speaker: NA
Text: marks the fiftieth anniversary of Amnesty

Speaker: NA
Text: International, a global movement of over three

Speaker: NA
Text: million supporters dedicated to defending and

Speaker: NA
Text: protecting human rights; (2) recognises the

Speaker: NA
Text: important role Amnesty International continues to

Speaker: NA
Text: play in promoting and protecting human rights

Speaker: NA
Text: and shining a light on human rights abuses around

Speaker: NA
Text: the world; (3) acknowledges the many

Speaker: NA
Text: achievements of Amnesty International, including

Speaker: NA
Text: its: (a) integral role in the development,

Speaker: NA
Text: promotion and ultimate adoption of the United

Speaker: NA
Text: Nations Convention Against Torture in 1975, it

Speaker: NA
Text: being awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 1977 and

Speaker: NA
Text: the Sydney Peace Prize in 2006; and (b)

Speaker: NA
Text: successful campaigning for the release of

Speaker: NA
Text: thousands of political prisoners around the world;

Speaker: NA
Text: and (4) notes that from 1961 till the end of 2010

Speaker: NA
Text: the organisation: (a) conducted at least 3341

Speaker: NA
Text: missions to research human rights abuses around

Speaker: NA
Text: the world; and (b) produced and published an

Speaker: NA
Text: estimated 17 093 reports and public documents

Speaker: NA
Text: including the annual human rights report which is

Speaker: NA
Text: now produced in 25 languages; and (c) issued

Speaker: NA
Text: over 31 000 urgent actions for individuals

Speaker: NA
Text: (Notice given 10 May 2011.)

Text: 4 MS HALL: To move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this House: (1) notes that cardiovascular

Speaker: NA
Text: disease: (a) is a heart, stroke and blood vessel

Speaker: NA
Text: disease; (b) kills one Australian nearly every 11

Speaker: NA
Text: minutes; (c) affects more that 3.4 million

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians; (d) prevents 1.4 million people from

Speaker: NA
Text: living a full life because of disability caused by

Speaker: NA
Text: the disease; (e) affects one in five Australians,

Speaker: NA
Text: and two out of three families; and (f) claimed the

Speaker: NA
Text: lives of almost 48 000 Australians (34 per cent of

Speaker: NA
Text: all deaths) in 2008-deaths that are largely

Speaker: NA
Text: preventable; (2) notes that cardiovascular risk

Speaker: NA
Text: factors include: (a) tobacco smoking; (b)

Speaker: NA
Text: insufficient physical activity; (c) poor nutrition;

Speaker: NA
Text: (d) alcohol consumption; (e) high blood pressure;

Speaker: NA
Text: (f) high blood cholesterol; (g) being overweight;

Speaker: NA
Text: (h) having diabetes; and (i) kidney (renal)

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) notes the importance of knowing the warning

Speaker: NA
Text: signs of heart attack: (a) discomfort

Speaker: NA
Text: centre of the chest; (b) discomfort in the arms,

Speaker: NA
Text: neck, shoulders, jaw and back; and (c) shortness

Speaker: NA
Text: of breath, nausea, cold sweat, dizziness or light

Speaker: NA
Text: headedness; (4) notes that recognition of heart

Speaker: NA
Text: attack and early response increases cardiovascular

Speaker: NA
Text: awareness, saving lives and preventing related

Speaker: NA
Text: disability; and (5) acknowledges that promotion

Speaker: NA
Text: of healthy eating and increased exercise will lead

Speaker: NA
Text: to healthier lifestyles and a reduction in

Speaker: NA
Text: cardiovascular disease. (Notice given 18 October

Text: 7 MS PARKE: To move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this House: (1) notes that: (a) by resolution

Speaker: NA
Text: 57/129 of 11 December 2002, the General

Speaker: NA
Text: Assembly designated 29 May as the International

Speaker: NA
Text: Day of United Nations Peacekeepers to: (i) pay

Speaker: NA
Text: tribute to all the men and women who have

Speaker: NA
Text: served and continue to serve in United Nations

Speaker: NA
Text: peacekeeping operations; (ii) recognise their high

Speaker: NA
Text: level of professionalism, dedication and courage;

Speaker: NA
Text: and (iii) honour the memory of those who have

Speaker: NA
Text: lost their lives in the cause of peace; (b) on 29

Speaker: NA
Text: May 2011 Australia joins with other nations to

Speaker: NA
Text: commemorate United Nations workers who

Speaker: NA
Text: provide life-saving assistance to millions of

Speaker: NA
Text: people around the world; who work in conflict

Speaker: NA
Text: zones and areas of natural hazards; and who place

Speaker: NA
Text: their own lives at risk in the line of duty; (c)

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia has been a strong supporter of United

Speaker: NA
Text: Nations peacekeeping operations since the first

Speaker: NA
Text: mission in 1947, and is one of the top 20

Speaker: NA
Text: contributors to the United Nations peacekeeping

Speaker: NA
Text: budget; (d) the United Nations' total peacekeeping

Speaker: NA
Text: budget is US$7.8 billion, or half of one per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: of global military spending, indicating that

Speaker: NA
Text: building and keeping the

Speaker: NA
Text: overwhelmingly cheaper than the pursuit of war;

Speaker: NA
Text: (e) there are over 122 000 military and civilian

Speaker: NA
Text: men and women working in 15 different United

Speaker: NA
Text: Nations missions around the world, who are not

Speaker: NA
Text: there for personal gain, rather, they are engaged

Speaker: NA
Text: in maintaining peace and security and in building

Speaker: NA
Text: the political, social and economic infrastructure

Speaker: NA
Text: required to ensure conflict zones can make the

Speaker: NA
Text: transition to peace on a sustainable and lasting

Speaker: NA
Text: basis; (f) in the last decade, more than 1100

Speaker: NA
Text: United Nations peacekeepers have died while

Speaker: NA
Text: striving to help those most in need in some of the

Speaker: NA
Text: world's most hostile environments, with recent

Speaker: NA
Text: examples being in April 2011, when: (i) 28

Speaker: NA
Text: United Nations staff and 5 non-government

Speaker: NA
Text: organisations workers were killed in a plane crash

Speaker: NA
Text: in Kinshasa in the Democratic Republic of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Congo; and (ii) 7 international United Nations

Speaker: NA
Text: staff were killed in an attack on a United Nations

Speaker: NA
Text: compound in Mazar-e-Sharif in northern

Speaker: NA
Text: Afghanistan, which was the third direct attack

Speaker: NA
Text: against United Nations personnel in Afghanistan

Speaker: NA
Text: in the past 18 months; and (g) United Nations and

Speaker: NA
Text: other humanitarian workers are increasingly

Speaker: NA
Text: being targeted for political and ideological

Speaker: NA
Text: reasons; and (2) commends the vital work carried

Speaker: NA
Text: out by United Nations peacekeepers and other

Speaker: NA
Text: humanitarian workers and calls upon all United

Speaker: NA
Text: Nations member states to ensure the safety and

Speaker: NA
Text: security of United Nations peacekeepers and

Speaker: NA
Text: other humanitarian workers, and to appropriately

Speaker: NA
Text: punish perpetrators of violence against such

Speaker: NA
Text: workers. (Notice given 10 May 2011.)

Speaker: NA
Text: MATTERS OF PUBLIC

Speaker: NA
Text: IMPORTANCE

Speaker: NA
Text: The SPEAKER (15:19): I have received

Speaker: NA
Text: a letter from the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: North Sydney proposing that a definite

Speaker: NA
Text: matter of public importance be submitted to

Speaker: NA
Text: the House for discussion, namely:

Speaker: NA
Text: The government's failure to deal with cost of

Speaker: NA
Text: living pressures on Australia's families in the

Speaker: NA
Text: budget.

Speaker: NA
Text: I call upon those members who approve of

Speaker: NA
Text: the proposed discussion to rise in their

Speaker: NA
Text: places.

Speaker: NA
Text: More than the number of members

Speaker: NA
Text: required by the standing orders having risen

Speaker: NA
Text: in their places-

Speaker: Mr HOCKEY
Text: North Sydney) (15:22):

Speaker: NA
Text: At 7.30 last night the Treasurer rose to his

Speaker: NA
Text: feet to deliver his budget speech. His

Speaker: NA
Text: opening words were, 'This is a Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: budget.' Well, most Australians turned off at

Speaker: NA
Text: 7.31, as soon as he said that. Why? Because

Speaker: NA
Text: being a true Labor budget it delivered bigger

Speaker: NA
Text: debt, bigger deficits and bigger spin. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Orders deficits in this budget, the stuff that really

Speaker: NA
Text: matters to Australians today, are growing.

Speaker: NA
Text: The budget deficit this year has grown in the

Speaker: NA
Text: last six months from $42 billion to nearly

Speaker: NA
Text: $50 billion. That means the government is

Speaker: NA
Text: borrowing $135 million every day just to

Speaker: NA
Text: fund the deficit. The budget deficit for next

Speaker: NA
Text: year, which is the appropriation bill that this

Speaker: NA
Text: House is going to vote on, is actually

Speaker: NA
Text: growing from $12 billion to $22.6 billion.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Treasurer expects us to believe the

Speaker: NA
Text: fairytale story and for the Australian people

Speaker: NA
Text: to accept-with this year's budget deficit

Speaker: NA
Text: situation deteriorating because of external

Speaker: NA
Text: circumstances and the government's increase

Speaker: NA
Text: in its own expenditure, and next year's

Speaker: NA
Text: budget deficit increasing, including increased

Speaker: NA
Text: government expenditure-the only budget

Speaker: NA
Text: narrative the government had today, and that

Speaker: NA
Text: is that in two years time they will bring the

Speaker: NA
Text: budget back into surplus. That is the only

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget narrative they had in this place today-to

Speaker: NA
