Text: promise something that they promised last

Speaker: NA
Text: year, to promise something that they

Speaker: NA
Text: promised the year before. But the difference

Speaker: NA
Text: is that with the Labor Party it is 50 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: promise, 50 per cent excuse. The debt of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, the net debt of the government, is

Speaker: NA
Text: now $106.6 billion-in dollar terms, the

Speaker: NA
Text: highest of all time. It is a deterioration in the

Speaker: NA
Text: net debt figure from $94 billion. Buried deep

Speaker: NA
Text: in the budget papers we have now discovered

Speaker: NA
Text: that the government is going to ask the

Speaker: NA
Text: parliament to increase the amount of debt

Speaker: NA
Text: issuance to $250 billion in gross terms. Of

Speaker: NA
Text: course, they are going to use the excuse of

Speaker: NA
Text: Basel III to maintain what will be since

Speaker: NA
Text: World War II the largest debt issuance in our

Speaker: NA
Text: modern history.

Speaker: NA
Text: What does this all mean? For everyday

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians it means that the interest on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor Party debt will increase to $18 million

Speaker: NA
Text: a day every day for the next four years. It

Speaker: NA
Text: means that by the fourth year of this budget,

Speaker: NA
Text: interest will rise to $7½ billion. And the

Speaker: NA
Text: government expect us to believe the fairytale

Speaker: NA
Text: story that somehow they are going to bring

Speaker: NA
Text: the budget back to surplus with fiscal

Speaker: NA
Text: discipline. They sold and spun in the budget

Speaker: NA
Text: speech last night $22 billion of so-called

Speaker: NA
Text: savings. Ignore the fact that a third of that

Speaker: NA
Text: was tax increases. Even so, $22 billion, and

Speaker: NA
Text: now people are becoming more aware that

Speaker: NA
Text: the government is spending $19 billion of

Speaker: NA
Text: that $22 billion. But most intriguingly, and

Speaker: NA
Text: this is where the rubber hits the road, next

Speaker: NA
Text: year-in the year when we have stronger

Speaker: NA
Text: economic growth, where we have

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployment dropping to 4.5 per cent,

Speaker: NA
Text: where the government is running a bigger

Speaker: NA
Text: budget deficit-in that year the government

Speaker: NA
Text: is going to spend $2.2 billion more than it is

Speaker: NA
Text: saving. These much lauded savings that are

Speaker: NA
Text: going to bring the budget whirring back to

Speaker: NA
Text: surplus, in the budget where the rubber hits

Speaker: NA
Text: the road they are spending $2.2 billion more,

Speaker: NA
Text: and it is not even an election year. Growth is

Speaker: NA
Text: going up to four per cent but employment

Speaker: NA
Text: growth is actually slowing.

Speaker: NA
Text: If we cut through the spin of this

Speaker: NA
Text: incompetent Treasurer, what we can

Speaker: NA
Text: recognise is that he is desperate to get

Speaker: NA
Text: adulation. He talks about the emotion of

Speaker: NA
Text: putting together a budget, how he is sleepless

Speaker: NA
Text: at night about the difficulty and challenges

Speaker: NA
Text: associated with the Australian economy, an

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian economy that he lauds as the best

Speaker: NA
Text: in the world. Yet he is so sleepless, he is so

Speaker: NA
Text: lost, he is suffering such insomnia.

Speaker: NA
Text: Employment growth is slowing even

Speaker: NA
Text: though this government is desperate to spin

Speaker: NA
Text: half a million jobs being created over the

Speaker: NA
Text: next two years. That is an employment

Speaker: NA
Text: growth rate of just 2.2 per cent. It is less

Speaker: NA
Text: the last three years of the Howard

Speaker: NA
Text: government at three per cent and, what is

Speaker: NA
Text: more, it is less than the last 12 months of this

Speaker: NA
Text: government itself, which had employment

Speaker: NA
Text: growth of three per cent, with 320,000 jobs

Speaker: NA
Text: created in the last calendar year. And

Speaker: NA
Text: somehow they think that it is a momentous

Speaker: NA
Text: achievement for them to be in the business of

Speaker: NA
Text: overseeing an economy creating half a

Speaker: NA
Text: million jobs in two years when the same

Speaker: NA
Text: economy created 320,000 jobs in the last 12

Speaker: NA
Text: months.

Speaker: NA
Text: On inflation, what I think was quite

Speaker: NA
Text: alarming was that last night, when you dig

Speaker: NA
Text: deep into the budget, the core inflation

Speaker: NA
Text: figures indicate that inflation is going up to

Speaker: NA
Text: three per cent, the top of the Reserve Bank

Speaker: NA
Text: band, by June 2013. Currently it is 2.25 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent. We are in an environment where the

Speaker: NA
Text: Reserve Bank has clearly indicated it is

Speaker: NA
Text: going to take action. I want to make it

Speaker: NA
Text: perfectly clear to the Australian people and

Speaker: NA
Text: this parliament that Wayne Swan and Julia

Speaker: NA
Text: Gillard are going to own every interest rate

Speaker: NA
Text: increase from here on. They are going to be

Speaker: NA
Text: responsible for making life harder for

Speaker: NA
Text: everyday Australians and not easier. They

Speaker: NA
Text: had the chance in this budget. They had the

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity to make the hard yards, and they

Speaker: NA
Text: failed that test because they lack courage.

Speaker: NA
Text: They talk courage but they display no

Speaker: NA
Text: courage. They talk surplus but they deliver

Speaker: NA
Text: deficit. They talk net debt as a negative and

Speaker: NA
Text: now they are going to deliver a significant

Speaker: NA
Text: increase in net debt.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is a government that has never met

Speaker: NA
Text: its budget targets. I say to you why, Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Deputy Speaker. It is because this

Speaker: NA
Text: government does not have internal

Speaker: NA
Text: discipline. They lack the processes for

Speaker: NA
Text: actually making hard decisions, as illustrated

Speaker: NA
Text: by the fact that they leaked $400 million in

Speaker: NA
Text: than cuts in medical research and did not proceed

Speaker: NA
Text: with it. They leaked that they were going to

Speaker: NA
Text: cut childcare benefits and then did not

Speaker: NA
Text: proceed with it. What did they do? They cut

Speaker: NA
Text: families by $2 billion. It is something I said

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Leader of the Opposition in the lock-

Speaker: NA
Text: up: I cannot believe this government is

Speaker: NA
Text: reducing the real increases in the family tax

Speaker: NA
Text: benefit for families on $45,000 a year. Why

Speaker: NA
Text: would they do it?

Speaker: Mr Bradbury
Text: It is a supplement.

Speaker: Mr HOCKEY
Text: He says it is a

Speaker: NA
Text: supplement. It is not real money: is that it,

Speaker: NA
Text: sunshine? It is not real money. Two billion

Speaker: NA
Text: dollars is not real money. Somehow it is in

Speaker: NA
Text: your budget, so either it is real money and it

Speaker: NA
Text: is really going to affect Australians or, as the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Lindsay would say, it is not real

Speaker: NA
Text: money. I say to you, sir, that Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: families are struggling, and particularly in

Speaker: NA
Text: your electorate of Lindsay. Your budget is

Speaker: NA
Text: indifferent to the plight of your people. Your

Speaker: NA
Text: budget is ignorant of the fact that everyday

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians are struggling: they are finding it

Speaker: NA
Text: harder to pay for higher electricity bills, for

Speaker: NA
Text: higher mortgage repayments, for higher fruit

Speaker: NA
Text: and vegetable prices, for higher petrol prices.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is a government that is overseeing a

Speaker: NA
Text: deterioration in the living standards of

Speaker: NA
Text: middle Australia. And why? Because of their

Speaker: NA
Text: own fiscal recklessness.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is one figure set that illustrates this

Speaker: NA
Text: more graphically than any other. It is the fact

Speaker: NA
Text: that since Labor was elected the Public

Speaker: NA
Text: Service in Canberra has increased by 20,000

Speaker: NA
Text: employees. Last night in the so-called tough

Speaker: NA
Text: budget the government increased the size of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Public Service by a further 1,100

Speaker: NA
Text: employees, including 200 in the Department

Speaker: NA
Text: of Prime Minister and Cabinet alone and 55

Speaker: NA
Text: in the Department of the Treasury. So at that

Speaker: NA
Text: time, when they are talking tough and

Speaker: NA
Text: expecting Australians to cut their cloth, this

Speaker: NA
Text: is a government that is going on a binge, a

Speaker: NA
Text: binge that is based on politics and not policy.

Speaker: NA
Text: Of course, in the budget there are reflections

Speaker: NA
Text: of their policy failures, which Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: families are now paying for. The $1.2 billion

Speaker: NA
Text: blow-out in the computers in schools

Speaker: NA
Text: program grew a further $200 million in last

Speaker: NA
Text: night's budget to $1.4 billion. The

Speaker: NA
Text: government's failed border protection policy

Speaker: NA
Text: has grown out by an additional $1.75 billion,

Speaker: NA
Text: and I suspect we will hear more about the

Speaker: NA
Text: growing bill for their failed border protection

Speaker: NA
Text: policies. What about the $111 million that is

Speaker: NA
Text: going to have to be spent mopping up the

Speaker: NA
Text: failed pink batts policy? How about that one,

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Deputy Speaker? Of course this all

Speaker: NA
Text: reflects the fact that the Labor Party cannot

Speaker: NA
Text: rein in its spending. The Treasurer keeps

Speaker: NA
Text: talking about spending growth. He is

Speaker: NA
Text: working off a very high base because of

Speaker: NA
Text: course the government went for the credit

Speaker: NA
Text: card during the financial crisis, handing out

Speaker: NA
Text: $900 cheques, building school halls,

Speaker: NA
Text: installing pink batts, putting solar panels on

Speaker: NA
Text: roofs-they did it all. They smoked the

Speaker: NA
Text: credit card at the moment when Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: could not afford to have an excessive fiscal

Speaker: NA
Text: stimulus. It turns out that Australia gets a

Speaker: NA
Text: silver medal, or maybe even a bronze medal,

Speaker: NA
Text: for the biggest fiscal stimulus in the world as

Speaker: NA
Text: a percentage of GDP, and now we are paying

Speaker: NA
Text: a heavy price for it.

Speaker: NA
Text: At no time in the forward estimates-and

Speaker: NA
Text: wasn't the Treasurer caught out by this

Speaker: NA
Text: today!-or at any time has the government's

Speaker: NA
Text: expenditure as a percentage of GDP been as

Speaker: NA
Text: low as it was in the last year of the Howard

Speaker: NA
Text: government. The Treasurer says that we

Speaker: NA
Text: were a profligate government-

Speaker: Mr Shorten
Text: You were.

Speaker: Mr HOCKEY
Text: yet nowhere in all of the

Speaker: NA
Text: budget figures at any time does the Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: Party ever get to the 22.9 per cent of GDP of

Speaker: NA
Text: the coalition in its last year. Then, belatedly,

Speaker: NA
Text: in a defensive mood, the Treasurer comes

Speaker: NA
Text: into this place and says, 'Oh, well, look at the

Speaker: NA
Text: average of the coalition. We are less than

Speaker: NA
Text: that.' So I looked at the average of the Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: Party so that we can compare apples with

Speaker: NA
Text: apples. Under the coalition on average over

Speaker: NA
Text: all of that period, including the very difficult

Speaker: NA
Text: period when we had negative growth during

Speaker: NA
Text: the Asian financial crisis, the coalition's

Speaker: NA
Text: percentage increased significantly, as it does

Speaker: NA
Text: when the economy comes down-the

Speaker: NA
Text: percentage of government expenditure rises

Speaker: NA
Text: as a percentage of GDP-but on average the

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor Party has been spending 24.6 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: of GDP and the coalition just 24.03 per cent.

Speaker: NA
Text: When you add in the revenue and

Speaker: NA
Text: expenditure associated with the carbon tax at

Speaker: NA
Text: $26 a tonne-boom, boom! It all goes.

Speaker: NA
Text: Do you know what, Mr Deputy Speaker?

Speaker: NA
Text: This is the challenge for the government:

Speaker: NA
Text: assuming there are no major new policy

Speaker: NA
Text: initiatives over the next two years, assuming

Speaker: NA
Text: the carbon tax is not going to have any

Speaker: NA
Text: impact on the budget, assuming there are no

Speaker: NA
Text: other challenges ahead, assuming that the

Speaker: NA
Text: terms of trade will remain at the highest level

Speaker: NA
Text: in 150 years, assuming that old Penny Wong

Speaker: NA
Text: can control the Prime Minister as she

Speaker: NA
Text: claimed to do. My goodness, what a mud

Speaker: NA
Text: wrestle! Senator Penny Wong claimed that

Speaker: NA
Text: she was going to control the Prime Minister's

Speaker: NA
Text: excessive demands for spending. I say to

Speaker: NA
Text: you: this mob will never deliver a budget

Speaker: NA
Text: surplus. This mob will never have the

Speaker: NA
Text: courage to deliver a budget surplus and, as

Speaker: NA
Text: the member for Longman said so vividly

Speaker: NA
Text: earlier, in question time, in his entire lifetime

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor have never delivered a budget surplus.

Speaker: NA
Text: Even though he was conceived in a surplus

Speaker: NA
Text: he was delivered in a deficit. It just goes to

Speaker: NA
Text: show what a celebration it was when Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: last delivered a budget surplus, and when

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor delivers a surplus again we will all

Speaker: NA
Text: give a good cheer and have a great party.

Speaker: Mr SHORTEN
Text: Maribyrnong-Assistant

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer and Minister for Financial Services

Speaker: NA
Text: and Superannuation) (15:34): I listened

Speaker: NA
Text: carefully to the shadow Treasurer's speech. I

Speaker: NA
Text: think he has missed a lot of what happened

Speaker: NA
Text: in the budget last night, so I am pleased to

Speaker: NA
Text: assist and to be a torchlight of clarity in this

Speaker: NA
Text: matter of public importance debate. I am

Speaker: NA
Text: pleased to switch on the lights.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia is experiencing an economy in

Speaker: NA
Text: transition. We need to get our policy settings

Speaker: NA
Text: right. We on this side of the House

Speaker: NA
Text: understand that our economy is changing,

Speaker: NA
Text: and we need to make sure that government

Speaker: NA
Text: policies change to assist Australians to

Speaker: NA
Text: prosper from the transition of our economy.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are transformative forces at work in

Speaker: NA
Text: our world. On this side we understand the

Speaker: NA
Text: growth in the emergence of Asia. We

Speaker: NA
Text: understand that our population is growing

Speaker: NA
Text: older. We understand that information is

Speaker: NA
Text: king in the modern era and that the

Speaker: NA
Text: information pipeline is going to be a

Speaker: NA
Text: fundamental driver of economic

Speaker: NA
Text: organisation. We understand that, along with

Speaker: NA
Text: the high commodities prices in the mineral

Speaker: NA
Text: boom, we are also expanding as a services

Speaker: NA
Text: economy. We also understand that we need

Speaker: NA
Text: to change to a low-pollution economy.

Speaker: NA
Text: This budget is an attempt to get away

Speaker: NA
Text: from sound bite style policy, which is,

Speaker: NA
Text: tragically, so beloved of the opposition. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: a search for systemic ways to make our

Speaker: NA
Text: nation more sustainable, more innovative

Speaker: NA
Text: and indeed more competitive. It is to help us

Speaker: NA
Text: make the transition into a digital economy, a

Speaker: NA
Text: low-pollution economy and an economy

Speaker: NA
Text: which can spread the benefits of the mining

Speaker: NA
Text: boom throughout all parts of this nation.

Speaker: NA
Text: After all, if the global phenomena of climate

Speaker: NA
Text: change and the global financial crisis have

Speaker: NA
Text: taught us anything at all it is this: everything

Speaker: NA
Text: and everyone is connected and change is not

Speaker: NA
Text: optional; it is inevitable. That is why this

Speaker: NA
Text: budget is so important. That is why

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer Swan's fourth budget is such a

Speaker: NA
Text: very good one. It is a statement of purpose,

Speaker: NA
Text: and the purpose is to secure our future his

Speaker: NA
Text: budget endeavours to tackle the cost of living

Speaker: NA
Text: issues and it builds upon Treasurer Swan's

Speaker: NA
Text: previous three budgets. Let us go through

Speaker: NA
Text: some of the contributions of the government

Speaker: NA
Text: to tackling the cost of living. People are

Speaker: NA
Text: paying lower taxes. Someone on $50,000 a

Speaker: NA
Text: year is paying $1,750, or 18 per cent, less

Speaker: NA
Text: than in 2007-08. The tax to GDP ratio-a

Speaker: NA
Text: statistic which was cleverly, selectively and

Speaker: NA
Text: disingenuously ignored by the opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: spokesperson who just gave us his

Speaker: NA
Text: contribution-has dropped from 23½ per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent in the last year of the Howard-Costello

Speaker: NA
Text: regime, when we came to office, to 20.3 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent in 2009-10.

Speaker: NA
Text: Since September 2009 we have tackled

Speaker: NA
Text: the cost of living pressure on pensioners by

Speaker: NA
Text: increasing the age pension. It is up $128 a

Speaker: NA
Text: fortnight for single pensioners and around

Speaker: NA
Text: $116 for pensioner couples. We have

Speaker: NA
Text: developed the education tax refund. This is

Speaker: NA
Text: where families can claim up to 50 per cent of

Speaker: NA
Text: their education costs, up to $397 per year, for

Speaker: NA
Text: every child in primary school and up to $794

Speaker: NA
Text: for each child in secondary school. There are

Speaker: NA
Text: over one million families and 1.7 million

Speaker: NA
Text: children who have already benefited from

Speaker: NA
Text: this education tax refund. We have also

Speaker: NA
Text: extended the education tax refund to school

Speaker: NA
Text: uniforms. Parents now will be able to claim

Speaker: NA
Text: up to 50 per cent of the cost of uniforms

Speaker: NA
Text: incurred from 1 July 2011-yet again

Speaker: NA
Text: helping with the cost of living pressures.

Speaker: NA
Text: In this budget we were pleased to

Speaker: NA
Text: announce the increase of $4,200 to families

Speaker: NA
Text: who are receiving family tax benefit A. We

Speaker: NA
Text: have committed to increasing it up to $4,200

Speaker: NA
Text: a year per teenager to help families meet the

Speaker: NA
Text: costs of older children still at school and to

Speaker: NA
Text: encourage more teenagers to stay at school.

Speaker: NA
Text: From 1 January 2012 we will increase the

Speaker: NA
Text: maximum payment rate of family tax benefit

Speaker: NA
Text: A by around $160 per fortnight for teenagers

Speaker: NA
Text: who are aged between 16 and 19 years who

Speaker: NA
Text: are in school or studying for an equivalent

Speaker: NA
Text: vocational qualification. This is going to

Speaker: NA
Text: benefit 650,000 teenagers turning 16 over the

Speaker: NA
Text: next five years.

Speaker: NA
Text: But of course the best way to deal with the

Speaker: NA
Text: cost of living is to ensure that people have a

Speaker: NA
Text: job. Having a decent job is the best way to

Speaker: NA
Text: tax deal with cost of living pressures. Since

Speaker: NA
Text: 2007, under the stewardship of our

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer, we have overseen the creation of

Speaker: NA
Text: 700,000 new jobs, in mining, retail, health

Speaker: NA
Text: and the skilled trades. That is 550 jobs a day,

Speaker: NA
Text: every day, since Labor took office. And now

Speaker: NA
Text: there are over 440,000 Australians in training

Speaker: NA
Text: or apprenticeships. They are getting real

Speaker: NA
Text: training for careers in construction,

Speaker: NA
Text: automotive, furnishing, tourism, plumbing

Speaker: NA
Text: and hairdressing. We will increase the

Speaker: NA
Text: number of apprenticeships over the next

Speaker: NA
Text: three years by another 50,000. Liberal

Speaker: NA
Text: policy, I am afraid to report to the House, is

Speaker: NA
Text: to cut $2 billion from training and to sack

Speaker: NA
Text: 80,000 trainees.

Speaker: NA
Text: When we look at this cost of living debate

Speaker: NA
Text: and what this budget contributes, we need to

Speaker: NA
Text: further put the facts in black and white. If

Speaker: NA
Text: you have got children in child care, you will

Speaker: NA
Text: get the choice of claiming childcare

Speaker: NA
Text: payments more regularly-getting the

Speaker: NA
Text: money in your pocket and off the bill you

Speaker: NA
Text: have. As I said, if you have children at

Speaker: NA
Text: school, you will be able to claim for their

Speaker: NA
Text: school uniforms. If your children are

Speaker: NA
Text: teenagers, we are increasing the family tax

Speaker: NA
Text: benefit payment by about $160 per fortnight.

Speaker: NA
Text: Also, importantly, if you are one of 50,000

Speaker: NA
Text: single parents, tax rates will be cut by up to

Speaker: NA
Text: 20c in the dollar. If you want some training,

Speaker: NA
Text: to obtain a higher wage, as I have said, we

Speaker: NA
Text: are creating 130,000 training spots. If you

Speaker: NA
Text: want to be an apprentice, or if you have a

Speaker: NA
Text: teenage son or daughter who wants to be

Speaker: NA
Text: one, we will give more support for people to

Speaker: NA
Text: complete their training, through mentoring

Speaker: NA
Text: guidance and allowing good apprentices to

Speaker: NA
Text: get their qualifications quickly. If you are a

Speaker: NA
Text: tradesperson or a small business, if you are

Speaker: NA
Text: buying a new ute or car which is necessary

Speaker: NA
Text: for the business, you will be able to claim

Speaker: NA
Text: $5,000 back in tax. That is real help in terms

Speaker: NA
Text: of the cost of living.

Speaker: NA
Text: If you are a low-income earner, you will

Speaker: NA
Text: get more in your pay packet each week

Speaker: NA
Text: through the advance payment of the low-

Speaker: NA
Text: income tax offset. If you are finding it tough

Speaker: NA
Text: to get a job, there will be 35,000 wage

Speaker: NA
Text: subsidies for the very long-term unemployed

Speaker: NA
Text: job seekers, to help them get a job, and

Speaker: NA
Text: 30,000 training places for single and teenage

Speaker: NA
Text: parents, to help them get the skills they need.

Speaker: NA
Text: Importantly-and dear to my heart-if you

Speaker: NA
Text: have the challenges and the financial costs

Speaker: NA
Text: which arise from having a disabled child in

Speaker: NA
Text: the school system, we will be contributing

Speaker: NA
Text: $200 million to the special schools and the

Speaker: NA
Text: school systems of various states in order to

Speaker: NA
Text: better support disabled children getting an

Speaker: NA
Text: education. If you are worried about your

Speaker: NA
Text: local hospital, there is $3.4 billion for

Speaker: NA
Text: emergency departments and elective surgery.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is $613 million for new medicines and

Speaker: NA
Text: making immunisation more affordable. If

Speaker: NA
Text: there is a teacher in your family, or you are a

Speaker: NA
Text: family that places a lot of value on the

Speaker: NA
Text: quality of your child's teacher, there is $425

Speaker: NA
Text: million to reward our top performing

Speaker: NA
Text: teachers across the country.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is a real list of things which go to the

Speaker: NA
Text: day-to-day lives, the lived experience, of

Speaker: NA
Text: people in the suburbs and regions of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. But I would not want the House

Speaker: NA
Text: just to take my word for the benefits of this

Speaker: NA
Text: budget. I will quote David Koch, who is a

Speaker: NA
Text: very well-known commentator. He said in

Speaker: NA
Text: today's paper-and it is a fair assessment:

Speaker: NA
Text: The overriding theme is that if you don‘t

Speaker: NA
Text: a job, or if you earn a comfortable income, there

Speaker: NA
Text: are no more easy Government handouts.

Speaker: NA
Text: Perhaps that is what is worrying the

Speaker: NA
Text: opposition. Kochie also said:

Speaker: NA
Text: Compared with the rest of the world we are an

Speaker: NA
Text: economic miracle. Economic growth will be

Speaker: NA
Text: reasonable (after the hiccup of the natural

Speaker: NA
Text: disasters), inflation on target, unemployment

Speaker: NA
Text: falling and-

Speaker: NA
Text: despite the Chicken Little prognostications

Speaker: NA
Text: of those opposite-

Speaker: NA
Text: Government debt tiny compared with the rest

Speaker: NA
Text: of the world.

Speaker: NA
Text: Kochie could be viewed to be a commentator

Speaker: NA
Text: for the government, but he is not. He is

Speaker: NA
Text: independent, as I know the shadow Treasurer

Speaker: NA
Text: thinks. If Kochie were not sufficiently

Speaker: NA
Text: convincing and compelling, CommSec Chief

Speaker: NA
Text: Economist Craig James, who is hardly a

Speaker: NA
Text: member of the Marxist international, said:

Speaker: NA
Text: Overall, it is a smart Budget, right for the

Speaker: NA
Text: times and challenges ahead.

Speaker: NA
Text: Meanwhile, the ratings agency Moody's, who

Speaker: NA
Text: are hardly Green Left Weekly, have

Speaker: NA
Text: reconfirmed our AAA rating and said:

Speaker: NA
Text: … Moody's notes that Australia's government

Speaker: NA
Text: debt remains amongst the lowest of all AAA-

Speaker: NA
Text: rated governments.

Speaker: NA
Text: The chief economist of UBS, Scott Haslem

Speaker: NA
Text: said:

Speaker: NA
Text: The bias towards reduced spending over new

Speaker: NA
Text: taxes to offset revenue shortfalls is commendable.

Speaker: NA
Text: UBS says that what the government has done

Speaker: NA
Text: is commendable. Heather Ridout of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Industry Group has said:

Speaker: NA
Text: We believe this budget is very solid on the

Speaker: NA
Text: fundamentals. It makes a solid investment in

Speaker: NA
Text: skills … I think it will take pressure off interest

Speaker: NA
Text: rates in the longer term.

Speaker: NA
Text: But again it does not stop there with the

Speaker: NA
Text: commentary. On Bloomberg, it says:

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's government will end 23 years of

Speaker: NA
Text: have spending growth to ease inflation from the

Speaker: NA
Text: biggest mining investment boom in the nation's

Speaker: NA
Text: history.

Speaker: NA
Text: But of course the opposition would not rate

Speaker: NA
Text: CommSec, they would not rate UBS, they

Speaker: NA
Text: would not rate Kochie, they would not rate

Speaker: NA
Text: Bloomberg, because they do not agree with

Speaker: NA
Text: their view of the world.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think it is important, when we are having

Speaker: NA
Text: a debate about who is doing the best in terms

Speaker: NA
Text: of the budget, that we understand that this

Speaker: NA
Text: budget is not formed in isolation. Politics is

Speaker: NA
Text: not a one-horse race; it is a two-horse race.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have to see what the opposition would

Speaker: NA
Text: do. We all remember last year when the

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition got up and gave a

Speaker: NA
Text: speech and made some political points and,

Speaker: NA
Text: at the end, said, 'By the way, the shadow

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer will deal with the costings in our

Speaker: NA
Text: propositions at the Press Club next

Speaker: NA
Text: Wednesday.' So we all waited with bated

Speaker: NA
Text: breath-what would the shadow Treasurer

Speaker: NA
Text: say the following Wednesday at the National

Speaker: NA
Text: Press Club? Unfortunately, he got up and

Speaker: NA
Text: said nothing. He said, 'Actually, that is the

Speaker: NA
Text: shadow finance minister's job.' So what we

Speaker: NA
Text: have is sort of the opposition equivalent of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Three Stooges: 'It was not me; it is him.'

Speaker: NA
Text: 'No, it is not me; it is the other person.'

Speaker: NA
Text: The more important point is not even the

Speaker: NA
Text: gaffe of last year. The issue is this: good

Speaker: NA
Text: budgets are not centrally just about politics

Speaker: NA
Text: and parties. They have to be about good

Speaker: NA
Text: policy; they have to be about the future. So

Speaker: NA
Text: we need to have a good-faith debate here.

Speaker: NA
Text: This budget week is not just a test of the

Speaker: NA
Text: government; it is a test of the opposition. If

Speaker: NA
Text: the Liberal-National Party coalition have real

Speaker: NA
Text: alternatives that they truly believe in, they

Speaker: NA
Text: should set them out. They should set out

Speaker: NA
Text: their alternatives-anything less than that is

Speaker: NA
Text: absolutely wasting the opportunity.

Speaker: NA
Text: On the issue of getting the budget back

Speaker: NA
Text: into the black, the shadow Treasurer made

Speaker: NA
Text: some rather garrulous comments on 4 May

Speaker: NA
Text: and again on 6 May-indeed on any day that

Speaker: NA
Text: you talk to him. But on 4 May and 6 May he

Speaker: NA
Text: made it clear that he could get the budget

Speaker: NA
Text: back into the black by next year. When in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian politics will there be any

Speaker: NA
Text: accountability for the comments of the

Speaker: NA
Text: shadow Treasurer? We all know that it took

Speaker: NA
Text: the Leader of the National Party to slap him

Speaker: NA
Text: down over his motormouth comments on

Speaker: NA
Text: trusts, when the shadow Treasurer said that

Speaker: NA
Text: trusts should be taxed in the same way as

Speaker: NA
Text: companies. It did not take long for the red

Speaker: NA
Text: warning light in the National Party bunker to

Speaker: NA
Text: go beep, beep, beep. And I have no doubt

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Trussinator was on the phone saying,

Speaker: NA
Text: 'This is not coalition policy.' I could just hear

Speaker: NA
Text: the Nationals going: 'Oh my god! The moose

Speaker: NA
Text: is loose; he is out again and he is making

Speaker: NA
Text: policy on the run'.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think that what we need to do here is to

Speaker: NA
Text: make sure. Perhaps we need a little bit of

Speaker: NA
Text: National Party iron rigour- the wheaty hand

Speaker: NA
Text: in the glove-saying to Joe Hockey, 'Mate,

Speaker: NA
Text: what is our policy? What is our plan? What

Speaker: NA
Text: are we going to do? It is all right for us to

Speaker: NA
Text: bag the government-okay, that is one thing.

Speaker: NA
Text: What are we going to do?' All we have is

Speaker: NA
Text: their costings from the election and we all

Speaker: NA
Text: remember the $11 billion black hole. Tony

Speaker: NA
Text: Abbott fronted up, ran around the 36-hour-

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Hon. Peter

Speaker: NA
Text: Slipper): Order! The Assistant Treasurer

Speaker: NA
Text: ought to refer to other honourable members

Speaker: NA
Text: by their titles.

Speaker: Mr SHORTEN
Text: Indeed. The Leader of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition, which he was then and

Speaker: NA
Text: thankfully still is now, was running around

Speaker: NA
Text: on a 36-hour New South Wales law and

Speaker: NA
Text: order binge, where he was clearly submitting

Speaker: NA
Text: himself as the candidate for premier in the

Speaker: NA
Text: state election. But he did say, 'We have $50

Speaker: NA
Text: billion in savings up our sleeves, in our gear.'

Speaker: NA
Text: But after the election, when they were forced

Speaker: NA
Text: to demonstrate at least some degree of

Speaker: NA
Text: financial rigour, there was an $11 billion

Speaker: NA
Text: costings black hole. Indeed when we were

Speaker: NA
Text: dealing with the floods package-very

Speaker: NA
Text: necessary to help with the reconstruction of

Speaker: NA
Text: terribly flood affected areas-they said, 'We

Speaker: NA
Text: can find cuts,' and we all know how that

Speaker: NA
Text: descended into farce. The shadow foreign

Speaker: NA
Text: minister told the shadow leader, 'You are not

Speaker: NA
Text: cutting foreign aid,' when in fact the

Speaker: NA
Text: opposition leader was trying to use One

Speaker: NA
Text: Nation's policy on cutting foreign aid. Of

Speaker: NA
Text: course we do not talk about the war now, do

Speaker: NA
Text: we?

Speaker: NA
Text: Returning to what is most important: I

Speaker: NA
Text: have submitted to this House today what we

Speaker: NA
Text: are doing to tackle cost of living pressures.

Speaker: NA
Text: have submitted that this is a budget about

Speaker: NA
Text: getting us back into black by 2012-13. This

Speaker: NA
Text: is a budget which is about creating more jobs

Speaker: NA
Text: and spreading the benefits of the mining

Speaker: NA
Text: boom across all of the economy. We are an

Speaker: NA
Text: economy in transition; we need good policies

Speaker: NA
Text: in this country. But the challenge tomorrow

Speaker: NA
Text: night for the opposition is saying, 'If we do

Speaker: NA
Text: not like what you are doing, what is our

Speaker: NA
Text: plan?' The challenge for them is to

Speaker: NA
Text: demonstrate that they will not just keep this

Speaker: NA
Text: economy in deficit, unlike yesterday's

Speaker: NA
Text: capable Swan budget.

Speaker: Mr TRUSS
Text: Wide Bay-Leader of The

Speaker: NA
Text: Nationals) (15:50): The government's 2011

Speaker: NA
Text: federal budget is an absolute shambles.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is no plan; there is no vision; there are

Speaker: NA
Text: no solutions. The Treasurer told us at the

Speaker: NA
Text: beginning of his budget speech that it was a

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor budget with Labor values. Budgets

Speaker: NA
Text: that are a shambles, without a plan and

Speaker: NA
Text: without a vision are Labor values. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: what Labor budgets are all about. If,

Speaker: NA
Text: perchance, the economic circumstances

Speaker: NA
Text: improve, Labor have no idea how to deal

Speaker: NA
Text: with it. When tough decisions need to be

Speaker: NA
Text: made to reduce government expenditure,

Speaker: NA
Text: they disguise the expenditure with the

Speaker: NA
Text: traditional Labor value, the traditional Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: way of fixing problems: new taxes.

Speaker: NA
Text: We hear a lot about $22 billion worth of

Speaker: NA
Text: so-called savings in this budget, but a third

Speaker: NA
Text: of that amount is actually new taxes. And the

Speaker: NA
Text: great big new carbon tax is not to be seen or

Speaker: NA
Text: heard of in this budget. It is the tax we dare

Speaker: NA
Text: not speak of, except of course when it comes

Speaker: NA
Text: to funding the promotion campaign-the

Speaker: NA
Text: campaign for the tax that is not even

Speaker: NA
Text: mentioned in the budget.

Speaker: NA
Text: We all know that this budget will do

Speaker: NA
Text: nothing to deal with the problems of

Speaker: NA
Text: I struggling families. Labor's extra spending

Speaker: NA
Text: means greater pressure on interest rates and

Speaker: NA
Text: the near certainty of extra interest rate rises

Speaker: NA
Text: this year. Inflation is on the march, but the

Speaker: NA
Text: budget does nothing to halt that advance.

Speaker: NA
Text: And over everything is the threat of the

Speaker: NA
Text: carbon tax, which hangs like a sword over

Speaker: NA
Text: the heads of every family, every small

Speaker: NA
Text: business and every community across the

Speaker: NA
Text: nation. This Labor budget is all about a

Speaker: NA
Text: return to Labor's core values, with attacks on

Speaker: NA
Text: the people Labor always hate. Bring out the

Speaker: NA
Text: old class prejudices again-an assault on

Speaker: NA
Text: people who care for their own welfare by

Speaker: NA
Text: taking out private health insurance, one of

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor's pet hates, and on families who save

Speaker: NA
Text: up so that they can fund in advance their

Speaker: NA
Text: children's university fees, also on Labor's hit

Speaker: NA
Text: list. And what about single-income families,

Speaker: NA
Text: how they have been assaulted in this budget

Speaker: NA
Text: with removal of the dependent spouse rebate

Speaker: NA
Text: and the changes to the family tax benefits?

Speaker: NA
Text: All of this makes it more and more difficult

Speaker: NA
Text: for a family to decide that one of the parents

Speaker: NA
Text: will stay home to raise the children. Indeed,

Speaker: NA
Text: in future, under Labor's plan, the single-

Speaker: NA
Text: income family will become a thing of the

Speaker: NA
Text: past. It seems that is also one of Labor's core

Speaker: NA
Text: values.

Speaker: NA
Text: The other thing about Labor budgets is all

Speaker: NA
Text: the overgrown rhetoric-grand statements,

Speaker: NA
Text: commitments about the biggest this, the

Speaker: NA
Text: biggest that, the largest programs of all

Speaker: NA
Text: kinds-but when you search through it all

Speaker: NA
Text: you find the numbers are not real. There is a

Speaker: NA
Text: $2.2 billion mental health strategy but they

Speaker: NA
Text: do not bother to mention the mental health

Speaker: NA
Text: programs they have axed to help fund it.

Speaker: NA
Text: They do not bother to mention that some of

Speaker: NA
Text: this is just restoring money they have taken

Speaker: NA
Text: away from programs like headspace. It is a

Speaker: NA
Text: big headline. That is what they are interested

Speaker: NA
Text: in. The absolute classic at this has always

Speaker: NA
Text: been the minister for infrastructure. When

Speaker: NA
Text: you read his press statements they always

Speaker: NA
Text: say 'the biggest road project of all times'. He

Speaker: NA
Text: has been well and truly caught out with his

Speaker: NA
Text: statements in relation to the Pacific

Speaker: NA
Text: Highway-a big banner headline 'More

Speaker: NA
Text: funding for the Pacific Highway':

Speaker: NA
Text: The Gillard government is prepared to increase

Speaker: NA
Text: investment in this road by $1 billion as a part

Speaker: NA
Text: the 2011-12 budget.

Speaker: NA
Text: Then he goes on to talk about what this extra

Speaker: NA
Text: funding will achieve. He makes it clear that

Speaker: NA
Text: there is an extra $1 billion in the budget for

Speaker: NA
Text: the Pacific Highway. He tried to defend

Speaker: NA
Text: himself in question time today when the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Cowper quite rightly pointed out

Speaker: NA
Text: that this is not $1 billion extra for the Pacific

Speaker: NA
Text: Highway. This is not $1 billion worth of new

Speaker: NA
Text: money. He said the member for Cowper

Speaker: NA
Text: should go back and read budget paper No. 2,

Speaker: NA
Text: which has all the details about this item. Let

Speaker: NA
Text: us go to page 267 of budget paper No. 2 and

Speaker: NA
Text: remember that Minister Albanese is claiming

Speaker: NA
Text: he is providing $1 billion of extra money for

Speaker: NA
Text: the Pacific Highway. Page 267 says of this

Speaker: NA
Text: $1.02 billion:

Speaker: NA
Text: Of the contribution, $700 million has been

Speaker: NA
Text: previously provisioned for in the budget.

Speaker: NA
Text: So of the $1.02 billion, $700 million has

Speaker: NA
Text: been previously provisioned. It is not new

Speaker: NA
Text: money at all. It is re-announcing the same

Speaker: NA
Text: money which was announced previously. He

Speaker: NA
Text: did acknowledge that of the rest, $270

Speaker: NA
Text: million was in fact money which has been

Speaker: NA
Text: taken off other projects in New South Wales.

Speaker: NA
Text: So $970 million at least of this money is not

Speaker: NA
Text: new money at all. The next thing he went on

Speaker: NA
Text: to say was that this money was going to

Speaker: NA
Text: deliver us a better Pacific Highway but if

Speaker: NA
Text: you read his press statement, he says:

Speaker: NA
Text: This extra funding will complete necessary

Speaker: NA
Text: detailed planning for the remaining sections of

Speaker: NA
Text: the highway.

Speaker: NA
Text: Detailed planning! It is not as though the

Speaker: NA
Text: minister went off on his own path on this

Speaker: NA
Text: one. That is also repeated in the budget

Speaker: NA
Text: document-a whole billion dollars spent on

Speaker: NA
Text: planning. Planning! They go even further by

Speaker: NA
Text: saying that if this money is matched by the

Speaker: NA
Text: New South Wales government further

Speaker: NA
Text: construction might be able to begin. They are

Speaker: NA
Text: waiting for the New South Wales

Speaker: NA
Text: its government to put up the money to actually

Speaker: NA
Text: of build the road. Yet the minister is trying to

Speaker: NA
Text: take credit for it all. However, he has caught

Speaker: NA
Text: himself out again because in 2009, when

Speaker: NA
Text: announcing the new N1 road network in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, he said that the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: would pick up 100 per cent of the cost of

Speaker: NA
Text: building the Pacific Highway. He was letting

Speaker: NA
Text: the New South Wales government off their

Speaker: NA
Text: traditional fifty-fifty share. It seems that the

Speaker: NA
Text: old destitute, hopeless Labor government in

Speaker: NA
Text: New South Wales was to be let off making

Speaker: NA
Text: any contributions, but the moment they have

Speaker: NA
Text: been relieved of office he expects the new

Speaker: NA
Text: incoming coalition government to pick up 50

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent of the funding. So if there is going

Speaker: NA
Text: to be one centimetre of bitumen provided to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Pacific Highway in addition to what is

Speaker: NA
Text: planned as a result of this budget the minister

Speaker: NA
Text: says it has to be provided by New South

Speaker: NA
Text: Wales. This is the brave new investment.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is the new regional policy the

Speaker: NA
Text: Independents have been so willing to

Speaker: NA
Text: embrace. They are so quick to mouth the

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor rhetoric about new increased

Speaker: NA
Text: expenditure in the region.

Speaker: NA
Text: The regions are going to get another 100

Speaker: NA
Text: bureaucrats in the regional development

Speaker: NA
Text: department but they are not going to get any

Speaker: NA
Text: significant new expenditure. There is another

Speaker: NA
Text: announcement about $4.4 billion over 10

Speaker: NA
Text: years but nearly all of that money is

Speaker: NA
Text: dependent upon there being a mining tax,

Speaker: NA
Text: and what a lose-lose situation this is for

Speaker: NA
Text: regional Australia. If you do not have a

Speaker: NA
Text: mining tax, you do not get any of the money

Speaker: NA
Text: that has been promised to the Independents

Speaker: NA
Text: and others for regional projects, but if you

Speaker: NA
Text: do get the mining tax, you lose the jobs, the

Speaker: NA
Text: investment and the initiative that is necessary

Speaker: NA
Text: in regional communities to make them grow.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is Labor's lose-lose regional

Speaker: NA
Text: development policy. What they offered to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Independents and what is in this budget is

Speaker: NA
Text: less than what would have been delivered by

Speaker: NA
Text: a coalition government had we been elected.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is less, but for the Independents Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: to bulk it up by bringing in the traditional

Speaker: NA
Text: funding out of other portfolios, concentrating

Speaker: NA
Text: it all in a regional bucket and making it into

Speaker: NA
Text: a large number. Is anyone suggesting that

Speaker: NA
Text: there would not have been hospital

Speaker: NA
Text: funding-extensions, construction-if this

Speaker: NA
Text: new bucket had not been created? Of course,

Speaker: NA
Text: regional areas would have got something of a

Speaker: NA
Text: share. Are you suggesting there would not

Speaker: NA
Text: have been money for regional roads if it

Speaker: NA
Text: were not for this new bucket? All that has

Speaker: NA
Text: happened is that the titles on projects have

Speaker: NA
Text: been changed but there is no serious new

Speaker: NA
Text: money available for regional communities.

Speaker: NA
Text: What regional communities will have to

Speaker: NA
Text: pay is a heavier share of the burden, the

Speaker: NA
Text: changes to the fringe benefits tax, because

Speaker: NA
Text: country people have to travel further than

Speaker: NA
Text: people in the city. The tradies and the others

Speaker: NA
Text: who need their vehicles to travel around are

Speaker: NA
Text: now going to have the fringe benefits tax

Speaker: NA
Text: concessions cut. Those sorts of things will

Speaker: NA
Text: adversely affect regional areas.

Speaker: NA
Text: Look at the agriculture budget. What a sad

Speaker: NA
Text: and sorry sight that is. While Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: Albanese has scores of pages of press

Speaker: NA
Text: releases, there are only two pages for the

Speaker: NA
Text: whole of the department of agriculture

Speaker: NA
Text: because there is nothing there. Another $32

Speaker: NA
Text: billion has been taken away from it and there

Speaker: NA
Text: is no new expenditure on quarantine. This

Speaker: NA
Text: budget strategy has utterly failed. It has

Speaker: NA
Text: utterly failed regional Australians. It will

Speaker: NA
Text: deliver nothing for our communities. A

Speaker: NA
Text: government who can think nothing more

Speaker: NA
Text: than to introduce these costs is truly

Speaker: NA
Text: delivering on Labor values. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr BRADBURY
Text: Lindsay-

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

Speaker: NA
Text: (16:00): I rise with great interest in being

Speaker: NA
Text: able to contribute to this matter of public

Speaker: NA
Text: importance debate, although I find it

Speaker: NA
Text: tries somewhat hypocritical that the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: North Sydney would come forward and draw

Speaker: NA
Text: attention to one of the biggest contradictions

Speaker: NA
Text: in the budget response he has led for the

Speaker: NA
Text: opposition. As anyone who has followed any

Speaker: NA
Text: of the interviews that the member for North

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney has given over the last 24 hours

Speaker: NA
Text: would know, the contradiction is that, on the

Speaker: NA
Text: one hand, he wants to tell everybody that the

Speaker: NA
Text: budget handed down last night was too

Speaker: NA
Text: savage and ripped away at the heart of so-

Speaker: NA
Text: called middle-class welfare, as people out

Speaker: NA
Text: there say, but, on the other hand, he wants to

Speaker: NA
Text: tell us that it was not nearly savage enough.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is somewhat confusing and somewhat

Speaker: NA
Text: hypocritical but the member for North

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney will get his opportunity, through his

Speaker: NA
Text: leader, tomorrow night to spell out in clear

Speaker: NA
Text: detail exactly what this confused position

Speaker: NA
Text: will ultimately mean for the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: people.

Speaker: NA
Text: I saw that the member for North Sydney

Speaker: NA
Text: raised the issue of cost-of-living pressures. I

Speaker: NA
Text: note that the issue of cost of living pressures

Speaker: NA
Text: has been raised with him on numerous

Speaker: NA
Text: occasions over the last couple of weeks in

Speaker: NA
Text: relation to specific measures that the

Speaker: NA
Text: government has indicated will provide relief

Speaker: NA
Text: to families from those cost of living

Speaker: NA
Text: pressures. On each occasion that any of these

Speaker: NA
Text: initiatives have been put to the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: North Sydney, he has failed to commit

Speaker: NA
Text: himself and his party to supporting these

Speaker: NA
Text: measures to provide relief to those families

Speaker: NA
Text: facing these pressures. On each occasion

Speaker: NA
Text: when he has been asked whether or not he

Speaker: NA
Text: supports the government's initiatives the best

Speaker: NA
Text: he could do was to fail to agree to support

Speaker: NA
Text: the government's initiatives and respond by

Speaker: NA
Text: saying the following, which I quote from

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Agenda on 4 May:

Speaker: NA
Text: At this stage the best support

Speaker: NA
Text: give is to get the budget back to surplus as soon

Speaker: NA
Text: as possible and take some of the upward pressure

Speaker: NA
Text: off interest rates.

Speaker: NA
Text: Then on 8 May on the Insiders program he

Speaker: NA
Text: was asked the question again. I think it was

Speaker: NA
Text: Barrie Cassidy who tried to pin him down on

Speaker: NA
Text: whether or not he would support these

Speaker: NA
Text: measures which would provide relief to

Speaker: NA
Text: families. Once again, he refused to confirm

Speaker: NA
Text: that he would support those measures and the

Speaker: NA
Text: best he could come up with was to say:

Speaker: NA
Text: If you want to take pressure off families, if you

Speaker: NA
Text: want to take upward pressure off interest rates,

Speaker: NA
Text: you have to get back to surplus as quickly as

Speaker: NA
Text: possible.

Speaker: NA
Text: We agree that you have to get back to

Speaker: NA
Text: surplus as quickly as possible. That is why

Speaker: NA
Text: the budget that the Treasurer handed down

Speaker: NA
Text: last night charted out a pathway for a return

Speaker: NA
Text: to surplus in 2012-13. I know we have heard

Speaker: NA
Text: from the member for North Sydney that he

Speaker: NA
Text: thinks that somehow he is going to deliver a

Speaker: NA
Text: surplus sooner and I guess we will all see

Speaker: NA
Text: whether or not that is possible when his

Speaker: NA
Text: leader comes forward and sets out his party's

Speaker: NA
Text: plans tomorrow night. I think we all wait

Speaker: NA
Text: with bated breath to see that fiscal

Speaker: NA
Text: consolidation. That clearly would be the

Speaker: NA
Text: fastest fiscal consolidation known to man if

Speaker: NA
Text: that were to be achieved, but we will wait

Speaker: NA
Text: and see exactly how he intends to achieve

Speaker: NA
Text: that.

Speaker: NA
Text: So we have the member for North Sydney

Speaker: NA
Text: out there raising issues of concern about the

Speaker: NA
Text: cost of living pressures. I note that he has

Speaker: NA
Text: failed to acknowledge any of the measures

Speaker: NA
Text: and we will see tomorrow night whether he

Speaker: NA
Text: supports the measures that this government

Speaker: NA
Text: is proposing to ease those cost-of-living

Speaker: NA
Text: pressures. There are many. If you have

Speaker: NA
Text: children in child care, for example, apart

Speaker: NA
Text: from having benefitted from the increase in

Speaker: NA
Text: the childcare tax rebate from 30 per cent to

Speaker: NA
Text: 50 per cent that this government

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government can introduced-

Speaker: Mr Haase
Text: You want to freeze it.

Speaker: Mr BRADBURY
Text: The member opposite

Speaker: NA
Text: is so confused about these matters that he

Speaker: NA
Text: somehow thinks that this has something to

Speaker: NA
Text: do with family payments. I will come to the

Speaker: NA
Text: family payments in a minute, but I am

Speaker: NA
Text: talking about the childcare tax rebate. We

Speaker: NA
Text: increased the rebate from 30 per cent to 50

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent for out-of-pocket expenses. In

Speaker: NA
Text: addition to that, in this budget we are now

Speaker: NA
Text: providing families with a greater capacity to

Speaker: NA
Text: access those benefits sooner and in a more

Speaker: NA
Text: timely fashion. Those are the sorts of things

Speaker: NA
Text: you do if you want to relieve some of these

Speaker: NA
Text: cost of living pressures on families.

Speaker: NA
Text: The member opposite wanted to buy into

Speaker: NA
Text: the debate over family payments and the

Speaker: NA
Text: family tax benefit. I am sure that the member

Speaker: NA
Text: would be much more supportive of our

Speaker: NA
Text: proposition than the member for North

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney has been. It is a proposition that

Speaker: NA
Text: seeks to provide parents with family tax

Speaker: NA
Text: benefit relief if they have teenage children

Speaker: NA
Text: who are continuing high school. This is one

Speaker: NA
Text: of the anachronisms of the system. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: antiquated, it is old fashioned and it reflects

Speaker: NA
Text: time when not as many children went on to

Speaker: NA
Text: study in years 11 and 12. As we know, more

Speaker: NA
Text: and more young people are doing that and

Speaker: NA
Text: we encourage that because ultimately it will

Speaker: NA
Text: increase workforce participation, it will give

Speaker: NA
Text: those kids a better chance of getting a job

Speaker: NA
Text: and in the end they will end up with better

Speaker: NA
Text: income. We encourage this, but the pressure

Speaker: NA
Text: that families have been feeling has been

Speaker: NA
Text: acute. That is why we have been committed

Speaker: NA
Text: to delivering an increase in the funding that

Speaker: NA
Text: is available through the family tax benefit for

Speaker: NA
Text: parents with teenage kids. For some families

Speaker: NA
Text: that will mean an improvement of up to

Speaker: NA
Text: $4,000 a year. It is a significant improvement

Speaker: NA
Text: that will relieve those cost of living

Speaker: NA
Text: pressures.

Speaker: NA
Text: You do not hear anything on that today

Speaker: NA
Text: from the opposition, but we did hear

Speaker: NA
Text: something on this point from the shadow

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer the other day when he came out

Speaker: NA
Text: and said it was 'curious.' As the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Families, Housing, Community Services and

Speaker: NA
Text: Indigenous Affairs indicated today, his

Speaker: NA
Text: position has become curiouser, curiouser and

Speaker: NA
Text: curiouser. Unfortunately, he is so confused

Speaker: NA
Text: about it that none of us know where he

Speaker: NA
Text: stands on this issue. I tell you what, this

Speaker: NA
Text: government will be proceeding with this

Speaker: NA
Text: reform. It will put more money in the

Speaker: NA
Text: pockets of families as they try to help their

Speaker: NA
Text: kids go on to higher studies. n addition to

Speaker: NA
Text: that, we have expanded the availability of the

Speaker: NA
Text: education tax refund and one of the eligible

Speaker: NA
Text: items will now be school uniforms. This will

Speaker: NA
Text: provide relief to families who are facing cost

Speaker: NA
Text: of living pressures. In addition to that, if you

Speaker: NA
Text: are an apprentice, you will have the benefit

Speaker: NA
Text: of obtaining higher bonuses and more access

Speaker: NA
Text: to mentoring. If you are a tradie or a small

Speaker: NA
Text: business, you will have access to the new

Speaker: NA
Text: instant write-off up to $5,000, and we have

Speaker: NA
Text: expanded that to include utes and other

Speaker: NA
Text: a motor vehicles used by tradies and other

Speaker: NA
Text: small businesses. In addition to that, we have

Speaker: NA
Text: invested a considerable amount of money in

Speaker: NA
Text: schools for children with disabilities which

Speaker: NA
Text: will help families already stressed and under

Speaker: NA
Text: financial pressure because of all the

Speaker: NA
Text: pressures they face raising children with

Speaker: NA
Text: disabilities. They will now have access to

Speaker: NA
Text: more assistance in their schools as a result of

Speaker: NA
Text: these measures.

Speaker: NA
Text: These are the very real and tangible things

Speaker: NA
Text: that were outlined in last night's budget by

Speaker: NA
Text: the government that will relieve some of

Speaker: NA
Text: those cost of living pressures. They build

Speaker: NA
Text: upon a record of a government that have

Speaker: NA
Text: delivered many improvements that have

Speaker: NA
Text: assisted with the cost of living pressures. We

Speaker: NA
Text: could mention the $46.7 million worth of tax

Speaker: NA
Text: cuts between 2008-09 and 2011-12, the $3

Speaker: NA
Text: billion to establish the education tax refund,

Speaker: NA
Text: the $1.6 million that was the enhancement in

Speaker: NA
Text: the childcare tax rebate, not to mention our

Speaker: NA
Text: historic reforms to the pension-increasing

Speaker: NA
Text: the rate of the pension by $128 per fortnight

Speaker: NA
Text: for singles and $116 per fortnight for

Speaker: NA
Text: couples.

Speaker: NA
Text: During this debate, we have had some

Speaker: NA
Text: discussion about interest rates and the

Speaker: NA
Text: opposition say that they believe the best

Speaker: NA
Text: thing you can do for families is to take

Speaker: NA
Text: pressure off interest rates. The best thing you

Speaker: NA
Text: can do to take pressure off interest rates is to

Speaker: NA
Text: not oppose the savings measures in this

Speaker: NA
Text: budget. The Leader of the Opposition has

Speaker: NA
Text: already indicated they will block the $3

Speaker: NA
Text: billion. Every savings measure those

Speaker: NA
Text: opposite block will put more pressure on

Speaker: NA
Text: interest rates. They will put more cost-of-

Speaker: NA
Text: living pressures on the very people whom

Speaker: NA
Text: this government are determined to help. We

Speaker: NA
Text: will secure the passage of this budget

Speaker: NA
Text: through the parliament because it is

Speaker: NA
Text: important that we do that to deliver relief

Speaker: NA
Text: from cost-of-living pressures. Every time the

Speaker: NA
Text: opposition want to block the $3 billion worth

Speaker: NA
Text: of measures, they will be hurting the people

Speaker: NA
Text: who need relief.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr TONY SMITH (Casey) (16:10): The

Speaker: NA
Text: saddest thing about that 10-minute self-

Speaker: NA
Text: congratulation from the Parliamentary

Speaker: NA
Text: Secretary to the Treasurer is that he truly

Speaker: NA
Text: believes what he was given to say. This

Speaker: NA
Text: budget delivered last night fails on almost

Speaker: NA
Text: every ground, and that is rare. It is a budget

Speaker: NA
Text: that fails in substance. It is a budget that

Speaker: NA
Text: betrays the Australian people. It is a budget

Speaker: NA
Text: that knowingly increases the cost-of-living

Speaker: NA
Text: pressures that Australian families and small

Speaker: NA
Text: businesses face. Before last night's budget,

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian families and small businesses

Speaker: NA
Text: knew for sure that cost-of-living pressures,

Speaker: NA
Text: which have increased in recent months and

Speaker: NA
Text: years, would increase again thanks to the

Speaker: NA
Text: carbon tax. They did not know that before

Speaker: NA
Text: the election, but they knew it for sure last

Speaker: NA
Text: night thanks to the Prime Minister's backflip.

Speaker: NA
Text: They now know for sure, following last

Speaker: NA
Text: night's budget and the failure of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer, that that will be matched with

Speaker: NA
Text: increases in interest rates which will increase

Speaker: NA
Text: even further cost-of-living pressures.

Speaker: NA
Text: The government's failure on the budget

Speaker: NA
Text: has been identified by commentators here in

Speaker: NA
Text: Canberra and right across Australia. Alan

Speaker: NA
Text: Kohler described it as a budget on a 'wing

Speaker: NA
Text: and a prayer'. You do not need to take our

Speaker: NA
Text: word for it. For those backbenchers opposite,

Speaker: NA
Text: that respected economic commentator also

Speaker: NA
Text: said:

Speaker: NA
Text: Any decent CFO would be embarrassed by this

Speaker: NA
Text: budget. There has been an $8 billion blow-out

Speaker: NA
Text: this year's deficit since the Mid-Year Economic

Speaker: NA
Text: and Fiscal Review last November, a $10 billion

Speaker: NA
Text: blow-out in next year's deficit. The return to

Speaker: NA
Text: surplus the year after, requiring a $26 billion

Speaker: NA
Text: turnaround in the bottom line in 12 months,

Speaker: NA
Text: simply ignores what is happening and plugging in

Speaker: NA
Text: the same economic parameters for 2012-13 as

Speaker: NA
Text: before.

Speaker: NA
Text: Robert Gottliebson, whom colleagues quoted

Speaker: NA
Text: in question time, made similar points.

Speaker: NA
Text: A lot has been said quite rightly about

Speaker: NA
Text: debt. With this government, we know that

Speaker: NA
Text: the level of net government debt in dollar

Speaker: NA
Text: terms is going to be incredibly high, north of

Speaker: NA
Text: $100 billion. In 1996 when we won

Speaker: NA
Text: government from those opposite, we

Speaker: NA
Text: inherited a $96 billion debt. The Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: public are acutely aware of the cost of debt.

Speaker: NA
Text: They are acutely aware that the interest

Speaker: NA
Text: payments needed to service that debt is

Speaker: NA
Text: money that cannot be spent on day-to-day

Speaker: NA
Text: programs. They are acutely aware that the

Speaker: NA
Text: higher the level of net government debt the

Speaker: NA
Text: more pressure on interest rates. They are

Speaker: NA
Text: absolutely aware of that which is why it is

Speaker: NA
Text: like extracting teeth to get this Treasurer to

Speaker: NA
Text: name the figure for which he is responsible.

Speaker: NA
Text: Today he stated that figure. He mumbled it

Speaker: NA
Text: out. Do not take my word for the fact that

Speaker: NA
Text: this is a deceitful Treasurer; take the word of

Speaker: NA
Text: the former finance minister, who has written

Speaker: NA
Text: in his book and has belled the cat on the fact

Speaker: NA
Text: that this tactic, first in 2009, of not

Speaker: NA
Text: mentioning the budget deficit figure in the

Speaker: NA
Text: budget speech and trying to conceal the

Speaker: NA
Text: dollar figure of net government debt by

Speaker: NA
Text: referring only to the percentage of GDP was,

Speaker: NA
Text: in fact, a deliberate tactic. He has written

Speaker: NA
Text: about it in his book. What he said-and I

Speaker: NA
Text: would like those opposite to do what they

Speaker: NA
Text: normally do and howl interjections, because

Speaker: NA
Text: you will be interjecting against your own

Speaker: NA
Text: former colleague-was:

Speaker: NA
Text: Their-

Speaker: NA
Text: in former Prime Minister, Kevin Rudd, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer, Wayne Swan-

Speaker: NA
Text: understandable concern about handing a

Speaker: NA
Text: political weapon to their opponents-

Speaker: NA
Text: in naming this figure-

Speaker: NA
Text: was more than offset by the ridicule that

Speaker: NA
Text: apparent attempt to deny reality invited.

Speaker: NA
Text: It was an attempt to deny reality. That tells

Speaker: NA
Text: us a couple of things about this dishonest

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer. The public have had many

Speaker: NA
Text: examples over the last three or four years of

Speaker: NA
Text: where this government cannot be trusted.

Speaker: NA
Text: When we see the Treasurer refuse to name

Speaker: NA
Text: that figure, he is doing so to deliberately

Speaker: NA
Text: conceal it from the Australian people. He

Speaker: NA
Text: mumbled it out in question time today, but

Speaker: NA
Text: last night when interviewed on Sky Agenda

Speaker: NA
Text: we had the incredible spectacle where he was

Speaker: NA
Text: asked by David Speers about the level of net

Speaker: NA
Text: government debt. David Speers said: 'What

Speaker: NA
Text: sort of peak debt are we now looking at?'

Speaker: NA
Text: The Treasurer responded: 'The peak of net

Speaker: NA
Text: debt will be 7.2 per cent in 2011-12.' David

Speaker: NA
Text: Speers asked: 'But how many in dollar

Speaker: NA
Text: terms? How much in dollar terms?' Wayne

Speaker: NA
Text: Swan replied: 'Well it's relatively modest,'

Speaker: NA
Text: and listen to this, 'I haven't got the figure on

Speaker: NA
Text: me at the moment.'

Speaker: NA
Text: This Treasurer would have you believe

Speaker: NA
Text: that he is so incompetent that he does not

Speaker: NA
Text: know the dollar figure of the net debt for

Speaker: NA
Text: which he is responsible in the budget he has

Speaker: NA
Text: just delivered to parliament. In the contest

Speaker: NA
Text: between telling the truth and concealing the

Speaker: NA
Text: level of that debt from the public he would

Speaker: NA
Text: have you believe that he has no idea-and

Speaker: NA
Text: my friend and colleague with me at the table

Speaker: NA
Text: would agree, we think he has mostly no idea.

Speaker: NA
Text: But even we cannot accept that he would not

Speaker: NA
Text: know that figure, if only for the reason that

Speaker: NA
Text: we know from the exhibit released last week,

Speaker: NA
Text: the book of the former finance minister, that

Speaker: NA
Text: this was a deliberate tactic to conceal the

Speaker: NA
Text: level of the debt. The Treasurer even

Speaker: NA
Text: knowing that still ploughs on, like some sort

Speaker: NA
Text: of out-of-control lawn mower over wet grass,

Speaker: NA
Text: with the same inane, ridiculous strategy

Speaker: NA
Text: thinking that the Australian people will

Speaker: NA
Text: somehow be prevented from knowing that

Speaker: NA
Text: this net government debt will peak at $107

Speaker: NA
Text: billion. We even had the finance minister

Speaker: NA
Text: today, again, on Adelaide radio try and

Speaker: NA
Text: refuse to reveal the figure. She could only do

Speaker: NA
Text: it for a couple of answers and we had to ask

Speaker: NA
Text: the Treasurer today to state the figure.

Speaker: NA
Text: The $107 billion-the $106 billion and

Speaker: NA
Text: some change in the Treasurer's view-is the

Speaker: NA
Text: most generous construction that can be put

Speaker: NA
Text: on it. That is, of course-as my friend the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Groom knows, having been a

Speaker: NA
Text: minister in the previous government-the

Speaker: NA
Text: level of debt, but is not the level of fiscal

Speaker: NA
Text: deterioration. This government did not start

Speaker: NA
Text: with a debt position; it started with savings.

Speaker: NA
Text: In fact, it started in 2007-08 with $44 billion

Speaker: NA
Text: in the bank. This is like having a credit card

Speaker: NA
Text: with $44 billion in it and ready to go before

Speaker: NA
Text: you rack-up a dollar of debt. It is a $150

Speaker: NA
Text: billion deterioration.

Speaker: NA
Text: I was looking through the Treasurer's first

Speaker: NA
Text: budget. Every budget speech from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer has had some element of

Speaker: NA
Text: deception. We had temporary deficits one

Speaker: NA
Text: year; remember? In his first budget, when

Speaker: NA
Text: you look down at the same table that lists the

Speaker: NA
Text: level of net government debt-on page 10.8

Speaker: NA
Text: in this year's budget for those opposite-you

Speaker: NA
Text: would not have guessed that what was

Speaker: NA
Text: projected for this time, 2011-12, was $106

Speaker: NA
Text: billion, but in savings, not debt. He has

Speaker: NA
Text: managed to transpose the whole show.

Speaker: Ms SMYTH
Text: La Trobe) (16:20): I am

Speaker: NA
Text: very pleased to speak this afternoon in this

Speaker: NA
Text: matter of public importance debate about the

Speaker: NA
Text: cost of living, and it is very good to see that

Speaker: NA
Text: the opposition has decided to play catch-up

Speaker: NA
Text: in today's MPI because yesterday they

Speaker: NA
Text: certainly had no interest in the economy or

Speaker: NA
Text: budget settings and the way that it impacts

Speaker: NA
Text: on ordinary Australians. They had no interest

Speaker: NA
Text: in the way that this government is

Speaker: NA
Text: responding to the cost-of-living pressures

Speaker: NA
Text: that face Australians. They had no questions

Speaker: NA
Text: to ask and, frankly, today's efforts by the

Speaker: NA
Text: opposition in question time were not terribly

Speaker: NA
Text: much better.

Speaker: NA
Text: This afternoon there is apparently a

Speaker: NA
Text: newfound interest in these issues from the

Speaker: NA
Text: other side of the chamber. Those of us on

Speaker: NA
Text: this side are extremely happy to talk about

Speaker: NA
Text: the way that this government is responding

Speaker: NA
Text: to the real needs of Australians through this

Speaker: NA
Text: budget and how we have responded to it

Speaker: NA
Text: since coming to office. Let us have a look at

Speaker: NA
Text: some of the practical measures that this

Speaker: NA
Text: government has been responsible for. In

Speaker: NA
Text: skills and training we have been ensuring

Speaker: NA
Text: that skills and training opportunities for

Speaker: NA
Text: young people in electorates such as mine are

Speaker: NA
Text: available to ensure that they have productive

Speaker: NA
Text: working lives and to enable them to meet

Speaker: NA
Text: living expenses. In my electorate of La

Speaker: NA
Text: Trobe the most recent commitments made in

Speaker: NA
Text: last night's budget mean that around 2,500

Speaker: NA
Text: apprentices in my electorate alone will be

Speaker: NA
Text: able to benefit from Labor's investment in

Speaker: NA
Text: apprenticeships, which will enable more

Speaker: NA
Text: people in my electorate to ultimately get

Speaker: NA
Text: skilled jobs. Our commitments in relation to

Speaker: NA
Text: families with children have been fairly

Speaker: NA
Text: significant since coming to office and were

Speaker: NA
Text: expanded upon in yesterday's budget. We are

Speaker: NA
Text: providing families with children with the

Speaker: NA
Text: support that they need through increases to

Speaker: NA
Text: family tax benefit part A. Around 5,000

Speaker: NA
Text: families in my electorate are affected by this

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment. They will receive an extra

Speaker: NA
Text: $4,200 per child aged between 16 and 19

Speaker: NA
Text: years old. I am sure that those 5,000 local

Speaker: NA
Text: families will appreciate the meaningful and

Speaker: NA
Text: practical effects of our commitment to

Speaker: NA
Text: responding to their cost-of-living pressures.

Speaker: NA
Text: During its term of office the Howard

Speaker: NA
Text: government certainly talked the talk of

Speaker: NA
Text: supporting pensioners and older Australians,

Speaker: NA
Text: but it took this government, in its first

Speaker: NA
Text: and against the backdrop of a global

Speaker: NA
Text: financial crisis, to make a meaningful

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment to pensioners in real and

Speaker: NA
Text: financial terms. We have supported

Speaker: NA
Text: pensioners with a historic increase in the

Speaker: NA
Text: pension. Since September 2009 we have

Speaker: NA
Text: increased the age pension by $128 per

Speaker: NA
Text: fortnight for singles and $116 per fortnight

Speaker: NA
Text: for couples. We have also delivered an

Speaker: NA
Text: improved pension work bonus so that age

Speaker: NA
Text: pensioners can hold onto an extra $125 per

Speaker: NA
Text: week of their income from work. These are

Speaker: NA
Text: practical measures, real measures, things that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Howard government refused to do during

Speaker: NA
Text: more than a decade in office.

Speaker: NA
Text: Meaningfully, since coming to office we

Speaker: NA
Text: have provided tax cuts three years in a row-

Speaker: NA
Text: $46.7 billion in cuts. We have also

Speaker: NA
Text: committed $1.25 billion in this budget to

Speaker: NA
Text: delivering up to $300 more in the low

Speaker: NA
Text: income tax offset during the year. We

Speaker: NA
Text: established a $300 billion education tax

Speaker: NA
Text: rebate and in this year's budget we have

Speaker: NA
Text: extended that rebate by $460 million to cover

Speaker: NA
Text: school uniforms. Again, this is something the

Speaker: NA
Text: Howard government, during a decade in

Speaker: NA
Text: office, had absolutely no interest in pursuing.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have increased the childcare rebate,

Speaker: NA
Text: by $1.6 billion, from 30 per cent to 50 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent of out-of-pocket expenses. We have

Speaker: NA
Text: made the childcare rebate more flexible to

Speaker: NA
Text: allow families to access those benefits

Speaker: NA
Text: sooner and we have implemented a historic

Speaker: NA
Text: Paid Parental Leave scheme so that parents

Speaker: NA
Text: can be supported after the birth of a child.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have also committed nearly half a billion

Speaker: NA
Text: dollars under the Teen Dental Plan. These

Speaker: NA
Text: policies and reforms run right across areas

Speaker: NA
Text: from childcare to education, taxation,

Speaker: NA
Text: pensions, superannuation and skills

Speaker: NA
Text: development. They are meaningful measures

Speaker: NA
Text: that are tangible to ordinary Australians, and

Speaker: NA
Text: certainly to members of my electorate.

Speaker: NA
Text: With the announcements made in

Speaker: NA
Text: term yesterday's budget, Australians will know

Speaker: NA
Text: that we have increased our already

Speaker: NA
Text: significant commitments to boosting

Speaker: NA
Text: employment and making sure that all

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians are given an opportunity to

Speaker: NA
Text: participate in work and take home an

Speaker: NA
Text: income. We on this side of the chamber

Speaker: NA
Text: know that these are things that respond to

Speaker: NA
Text: cost-of-living pressures. They are things

Speaker: NA
Text: which give options to working people,

Speaker: NA
Text: pensioners, families with children and to

Speaker: NA
Text: young people looking to develop skills and

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure they have a meaningful job and

Speaker: NA
Text: career. They are things which give them the

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity to meet cost-of-living pressures.

Speaker: NA
Text: In addition to doing all of these things in

Speaker: NA
Text: context of the financial crisis and the natural

Speaker: NA
Text: disasters around the country, which have had

Speaker: NA
Text: a significant impact on our budget measures,

Speaker: NA
Text: we understand the need to make significant

Speaker: NA
Text: and transformative economic changes. That

Speaker: NA
Text: is why our budget will ensure that there are

Speaker: NA
Text: settings in place to put downward pressure

Speaker: NA
Text: on inflation. We are investing in our

Speaker: NA
Text: workforce. We are investing in

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure. I notice that in this matter of

Speaker: NA
Text: public importance discussion the Leader of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Nationals declined to mention any

Speaker: NA
Text: significant means by which those on the

Speaker: NA
Text: other side of the House would contribute to

Speaker: NA
Text: our national infrastructure development and

Speaker: NA
Text: the jobs associated with any such

Speaker: NA
Text: development.

Speaker: NA
Text: We know that the most important thing

Speaker: NA
Text: for Australian families, for all Australians

Speaker: NA
Text: and for the future of our country is ensuring

Speaker: NA
Text: that more Australians than ever have the

Speaker: NA
Text: security and dignity of work. That is why we

Speaker: NA
Text: acted swiftly to protect 200,000 jobs in the

Speaker: NA
Text: face of the global financial crisis, an event

Speaker: NA
Text: which seems to have escaped the

Speaker: NA
Text: opposition's interest and has been excised

Speaker: NA
Text: from their collective memory. Our

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment to ensuring the security and

Speaker: NA
Text: dignity of work for working Australians is

Speaker: NA
Text: reflected in our proudest achievement in

Speaker: NA
Text: government: the creation of over 750,000

Speaker: NA
Text: jobs since coming to office. It is also why we

Speaker: NA
Text: have the settings in place for the economy to

Speaker: NA
Text: generate around 500,000 new jobs within the

Speaker: NA
Text: next couple of years. This sets the opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: in stark contrast to us. They made no effort

Speaker: NA
Text: to support our efforts to stimulate the

Speaker: NA
Text: economy in the face of the global financial

Speaker: NA
Text: crisis. Jobs were at the bottom of their list of

Speaker: NA
Text: priorities.

Speaker: NA
Text: The opposition was asleep at the wheel

Speaker: NA
Text: during the last resources boom. We are not

Speaker: NA
Text: and we will not be. We are determined to

Speaker: NA
Text: the ensure that the minerals resource rental tax

Speaker: NA
Text: will give all Australians a better share in the

Speaker: NA
Text: proceeds that come from our mineral wealth.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is something which will ensure that all

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians can profit from those mineral

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth gains, that there is a level of equity

Speaker: NA
Text: for Australians and that we can support

Speaker: NA
Text: significant programs into the future.

Speaker: NA
Text: Despite all these things, the opposition are

Speaker: NA
Text: yet to present anything constructive or

Speaker: NA
Text: positive which would indicate how they

Speaker: NA
Text: would respond to the cost-of-living pressures

Speaker: NA
Text: which they are seemingly concerned about

Speaker: NA
Text: today-though perhaps not tomorrow,

Speaker: NA
Text: because they were certainly not interested in

Speaker: NA
Text: them yesterday during question time. On the

Speaker: NA
Text: one hand, the opposition assert that they will

Speaker: NA
