Text: restore the budget to surplus by next year; on

Speaker: NA
Text: the other hand, they continue with their

Speaker: NA
Text: boundless spending commitments. I know

Speaker: NA
Text: that those spending commitments were made

Speaker: NA
Text: with gay abandon in my electorate during the

Speaker: NA
Text: last federal election campaign. There were a

Speaker: NA
Text: variety of election 'commitments' made by

Speaker: NA
Text: the former Liberal member for La Trobe

Speaker: NA
Text: which were not included in the costings of

Speaker: NA
Text: the coalition prior to the election. There were

Speaker: NA
Text: more than $80 million worth of election

Speaker: NA
Text: commitments in my electorate alone. This

Speaker: NA
Text: indicates the level of fiscal responsibility

Speaker: NA
Text: runs right the way down from the leaders of

Speaker: NA
Text: the coalition to their individual members and

Speaker: NA
Text: candidates in local elections. Given that the

Speaker: NA
Text: opposition will make a swifter return to

Speaker: NA
Text: surplus while making these spending

Speaker: NA
Text: commitments, and not saying what their

Speaker: NA
Text: spending cuts are likely to be, presumably

Speaker: NA
Text: someone on the other side has the colour

Speaker: NA
Text: copier out, because the only way they can

Speaker: NA
Text: achieve those two ends is to start printing

Speaker: NA
Text: money. e know what happened the last time

Speaker: NA
Text: they tried to achieve spending cuts at the

Speaker: NA
Text: same time as making their election

Speaker: NA
Text: commitments. We know that there was an

Speaker: NA
Text: $11 billion black hole that was

Speaker: NA
Text: independently verified and tested. We know

Speaker: NA
Text: that the opposition has form when it comes

Speaker: NA
Text: to inaccurate representations of their

Speaker: NA
Text: economic commitments, and I certainly

Speaker: NA
Text: expect that to be the case tomorrow night.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Order! The

Speaker: NA
Text: discussion is now concluded.

Text: BILLS

Text: Electoral and Referendum

Speaker: NA
Text: COMMITTEES

Speaker: NA
Text: Electoral Matters Committee

Speaker: NA
Text: Reference

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Hon. BC

Speaker: NA
Text: Scott): I have received a message from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Senate transmitting a resolution agreed to by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Senate on 11 May 2011 relating to the

Speaker: NA
Text: referral of an inquiry to the Joint Standing

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee on Electoral Matters and an

Speaker: NA
Text: amendment to the resolution of appointment

Speaker: NA
Text: for the purposes of this inquiry. Copies of the

Speaker: NA
Text: that message have been placed on the table for

Speaker: NA
Text: the information of honourable members. I do

Speaker: NA
Text: not propose to read its terms, which will be

Speaker: NA
Text: recorded in the Votes and Proceedings and

Speaker: NA
Text: Hansard. The Senate requests the

Speaker: NA
Text: concurrence of the House.

Speaker: NA
Text: The message read as follows-

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) That the following matter be referred to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters

Speaker: NA
Text: for inquiry and report by 30 September 2011:

Speaker: NA
Text: Options to improve the system for the funding of

Speaker: NA
Text: political parties and election campaigns, with

Speaker: NA
Text: particular reference to:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) issues raised in the Government's Electoral

Speaker: NA
Text: Reform Green Paper - Donations, Funding and

Speaker: NA
Text: Expenditure, released in December 2008;

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) the role of third parties in the electoral

Speaker: NA
Text: process;

Speaker: NA
Text: (c) the transparency and accountability of the

Speaker: NA
Text: funding regime;

Speaker: NA
Text: (d) limiting the escalating cost of elections;

Speaker: NA
Text: (e) any relevant measures at the state and

Speaker: NA
Text: territory level and implications for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (f) the international practices for the funding of

Speaker: NA
Text: political parties and election campaigns, including

Speaker: NA
Text: in Canada, the United Kingdom, New Zealand

Speaker: NA
Text: and the United States of America.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) That, for the purposes of this inquiry only,

Speaker: NA
Text: paragraph (3) of the resolution of appointment be

Speaker: NA
Text: amended to read:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the committee consist of 12 members, 3

Speaker: NA
Text: Members of the House of Representatives to be

Speaker: NA
Text: nominated by the Government Whip or Whips, 4

Speaker: NA
Text: Members of the House of Representatives to be

Speaker: NA
Text: nominated by the Opposition Whip or Whips and

Speaker: NA
Text: 1 non-aligned Member, 2 Senators to be

Speaker: NA
Text: nominated by the Leader of the Government in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Senate, 1 Senator to be nominated by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate and 1

Speaker: NA
Text: Senator to be nominated by any minority group or

Speaker: NA
Text: groups or independent Senator or independent

Speaker: NA
Text: Senators

Speaker: Mr GRAY
Text: Brand-Special Minister of

Speaker: NA
Text: State for the Public Service and Integrity and

Speaker: NA
Text: Special Minister of State) (16:31): I move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the message be considered immediately.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question agreed to.

Speaker: Mr GRAY
Text: I move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this House concurs with the resolution

Speaker: NA
Text: transmitted from the Senate with the following

Speaker: NA
Text: amendment:

Speaker: NA
Text: After Paragraph (2), insert:

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) For the purposes of this inquiry only, the

Speaker: NA
Text: resolution of appointment be amended by

Speaker: NA
Text: inserting the following paragraph:

Speaker: NA
Text: (3A) That participating members may be

Speaker: NA
Text: appointed to the committee. Participating

Speaker: NA
Text: members may participate in hearings of evidence

Speaker: NA
Text: and deliberations of the committee, and have all

Speaker: NA
Text: the rights of a member of the committee, but may

Speaker: NA
Text: not vote on any questions before the committee.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: Electoral and Referendum

Speaker: NA
Text: Amendment (Provisional Voting) Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: Consideration of Senate Message

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill returned from the Senate with

Speaker: NA
Text: amendments.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ordered that the amendments be

Speaker: NA
Text: considered immediately.

Speaker: NA
Text: Senate's amendments-

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) That the following matter be referred to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters

Speaker: NA
Text: for inquiry and report by 30 September 2011:

Speaker: NA
Text: Options to improve the system for the funding of

Speaker: NA
Text: political parties and election campaigns, with

Speaker: NA
Text: particular reference to:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) issues raised in the Government's Electoral

Speaker: NA
Text: Reform Green Paper - Donations, Funding and

Speaker: NA
Text: Expenditure, released in December 2008;

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) the role of third parties in the electoral

Speaker: NA
Text: process;

Speaker: NA
Text: (c) the transparency and accountability of the

Speaker: NA
Text: funding regime;

Speaker: NA
Text: (d) limiting the escalating cost of elections;

Speaker: NA
Text: (e) any relevant measures at the state and

Speaker: NA
Text: territory level and implications for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (f) the international practices for the funding of

Speaker: NA
Text: political parties and election campaigns, including

Speaker: NA
Text: in Canada, the United Kingdom, New Zealand

Speaker: NA
Text: and the United States of America.

Speaker: Mr GRAY
Text: Brand-Special Minister of

Speaker: NA
Text: State for the Public Service and Integrity and

Speaker: NA
Text: Special Minister of State) (16:33): I move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the amendments be agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: As members would recall the Electoral and

Speaker: NA
Text: Referendum Amendment (Provisional

Speaker: NA
Text: Voting) Bill 2011 will repeal the

Speaker: NA
Text: requirements for provisional voters to

Speaker: NA
Text: provide evidence of identity as a

Speaker: NA
Text: precondition of their votes being included in

Speaker: NA
Text: the count for an election. This requirement

Speaker: NA
Text: BILLS was put in place by the previous government

Speaker: NA
Text: in 2006. It resulted in a situation where

Speaker: NA
Text: provisional votes were dealt with in a way

Speaker: NA
Text: 2011 that was inconsistent with the treatment of

Speaker: NA
Text: other types of declaration votes-namely,

Speaker: NA
Text: absent, postal and pre-poll votes. By

Speaker: NA
Text: repealing the requirement for provisional

Speaker: NA
Text: voters to provide evidence of identity, all

Speaker: NA
Text: declaration votes will be treated equally.

Speaker: NA
Text: The bill replaces the requirement to

Speaker: NA
Text: provide evidence of identity with a test

Speaker: NA
Text: similar to that used in previous elections.

Speaker: NA
Text: The test provides for the divisional returning

Speaker: NA
Text: officer to compare the signature on the

Speaker: NA
Text: provisional vote envelope with the signature

Speaker: NA
Text: of the elector on previously lodged

Speaker: NA
Text: enrolment records if there is any doubt as to

Speaker: NA
Text: the bona fides of the elector.

Speaker: NA
Text: This bill is supported by the Electoral

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission, which in its submissions to the

Speaker: NA
Text: inquiry by the Joint Standing Committee on

Speaker: NA
Text: Electoral Matters into the 2010 federal

Speaker: NA
Text: election and matters related thereto

Speaker: NA
Text: recommended that the requirement for the

Speaker: NA
Text: production of evidence of identity by

Speaker: NA
Text: provisional voters should be repealed. The

Speaker: NA
Text: government will be supporting the

Speaker: NA
Text: amendments to the bill moved by Senator

Speaker: NA
Text: Xenophon and agreed to by the Senate.

Speaker: NA
Text: These amendments provide for the divisional

Speaker: NA
Text: returning officer if not satisfied that a

Speaker: NA
Text: signature on an envelope is that of the elector

Speaker: NA
Text: must make all reasonable attempts to contact

Speaker: NA
Text: the elector to require them to provide

Speaker: NA
Text: evidence of identity.

Speaker: NA
Text: We see these amendments as providing a

Speaker: NA
Text: desirable safety net to prevent what would be

Speaker: NA
Text: otherwise valid additional votes from being

Speaker: NA
Text: discarded. They are a substantive

Speaker: NA
Text: improvement to the bill, and we will support

Speaker: NA
Text: them. I commend the bill to the House.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mrs BRONWYN BISHOP (Mackellar)

Speaker: NA
Text: (16:35): The opposition is supporting this

Speaker: NA
Text: amendment, as we did in the Senate, for the

Speaker: NA
Text: following reason. When we amended the

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation and put in place that those people

Speaker: NA
Text: wishing to cast a provisional vote should

Speaker: NA
Text: provide proof of identity we did so to protect

Speaker: NA
Text: the integrity of the roll. The minister makes

Speaker: NA
Text: the case that that meant we treated

Speaker: NA
Text: provisional votes as declaration votes

Speaker: NA
Text: different from other declaration votes, but of

Speaker: NA
Text: course the government by its own hand, by

Speaker: NA
Text: allowing pre-poll votes to be dealt with on

Speaker: NA
Text: the evening of the count, instead of being

Speaker: NA
Text: dealt with as they previously were, means

Speaker: NA
Text: that those declaration votes are already dealt

Speaker: NA
Text: with differently.

Speaker: NA
Text: We were concerned, and so opposed the

Speaker: NA
Text: change to the legislation that would do away

Speaker: NA
Text: with proof of identity. Senator Xenophon's

Speaker: NA
Text: amendment will make more work for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Electoral Commission and I would have

Speaker: NA
Text: preferred it, and the opposition would have

Speaker: NA
Text: preferred it, if the responsibility had

Speaker: NA
Text: remained with the individual to ensure that

Speaker: NA
Text: they brought their proof of identity. I would

Speaker: NA
Text: point out that in the 2010 election

Speaker: NA
Text: somewhere between 75 and 80 per cent of

Speaker: NA
Text: people who wished to cast a provisional vote

Speaker: NA
Text: did so by providing that proof of identity. So

Speaker: NA
Text: that was an improvement over the 2007

Speaker: NA
Text: position. Clearly, it was becoming accepted

Speaker: NA
Text: by those who wished to cast that sort of vote.

Speaker: NA
Text: By supporting the amendment as moved by

Speaker: NA
Text: Senator Xenophon it does mean that the

Speaker: NA
Text: concept of the need for a provisional voter to

Speaker: NA
Text: provide a proof of identity is an important

Speaker: NA
Text: one. Also I think it is important to recap as to

Speaker: NA
Text: why a person cast a provisional vote. The

Speaker: NA
Text: first point is that you were not found to be on

Speaker: NA
Text: the roll when you presented yourself. The

Speaker: NA
Text: second is that somebody had already voted in

Speaker: NA
Text: your name. The third is that the DRO simply

Speaker: NA
Text: did not like the look of you. The fourth is

Speaker: NA
Text: that you are on the confidential, secret roll

Speaker: NA
Text: because of security or other reasons that are

Speaker: NA
Text: acceptable. The way the government had

Speaker: NA
Text: drafted its amending bill meant that it was

Speaker: NA
Text: simply saying that the DRO had to compare

Speaker: NA
Text: the signature on the envelope with the

Speaker: NA
Text: existing signature. It is quite possible and

Speaker: NA
Text: indeed probable that in many instances there

Speaker: NA
Text: was no signature to compare it too. In the

Speaker: NA
Text: state election in New South Wales they had a

Speaker: NA
Text: similar provision where they had begun the

Speaker: NA
Text: process of automatic enrolment so there

Speaker: NA
Text: would be no signature because people were

Speaker: NA
Text: automatically put on the roll. So we believe

Speaker: NA
Text: that the concept of returning to the

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation the requirement for proof of

Speaker: NA
Text: identity is a step in the right direction. We

Speaker: NA
Text: would still at a future time in government

Speaker: NA
Text: revisit this because we believe it is the only

Speaker: NA
Text: way that you can adequately protect the

Speaker: NA
Text: integrity of the roll. The Electoral

Speaker: NA
Text: Commissioner, when he put in his

Speaker: NA
Text: submission to the Joint Standing Committee

Speaker: NA
Text: on Electoral Matters, or JSCEM, made it

Speaker: NA
Text: quite clear that one of the key parts, if not the

Speaker: NA
Text: key part, of his task was to protect the

Speaker: NA
Text: integrity of the roll. We do see cases of

Speaker: NA
Text: multiple voting and we see that they are not

Speaker: NA
Text: followed up, and those are issues that we will

Speaker: NA
Text: be addressing in that committee. But for the

Speaker: NA
Text: purposes of this bill and this amendment, I

Speaker: NA
Text: say very firmly that returning to the

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation the concept that a provisional

Speaker: NA
Text: voter can be required to produce proof of

Speaker: NA
Text: identity is a step in the right direction.

Speaker: NA
Text: Therefore we support the amendment.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: Social Security Legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: Amendment (Job Seeker Compliance)

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill 2011

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate resumed on the motion:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mrs GRIGGS (Solomon) (16:44): As I

Speaker: NA
Text: was saying earlier today, the coalition

Speaker: NA
Text: requires a firm but fair system to ensure that

Speaker: NA
Text: those in receipt of income support who can

Speaker: NA
Text: work have a responsibility to look for work

Speaker: NA
Text: and contribute back to the society that

Speaker: NA
Text: supports them. In addition to this they need

Speaker: NA
Text: to recognise that welfare is a temporary

Speaker: NA
Text: safety net and not a lifestyle choice-a hand

Speaker: NA
Text: up, not a handout.

Speaker: NA
Text: On the other hand, in 2008 the Rudd

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor government watered down mutual

Speaker: NA
Text: obligation, introducing their no show, no pay

Speaker: NA
Text: compliance model, which saw job seekers

Speaker: NA
Text: docked a day's welfare payment for failing to

Speaker: NA
Text: attend interviews. The department and the

Speaker: NA
Text: minister were writing to providers asking

Speaker: NA
Text: them to be more lenient on those who

Speaker: NA
Text: breached the rules. Since then, the coalition

Speaker: NA
Text: has advocated for more stringent and

Speaker: NA
Text: appropriate compliance mechanisms as

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor's no show, no pay compliance model

Speaker: NA
Text: has been a failure. It is clear that there

Speaker: NA
Text: neither a real financial disincentive for job

Speaker: NA
Text: seekers to comply with their activity test

Speaker: NA
Text: requirements, nor an enforced administration

Speaker: NA
Text: of this scheme.

Speaker: NA
Text: This current Labor government has also

Speaker: NA
Text: failed job seekers by increasing the amount

Speaker: NA
Text: of time a job seeker spends out of work and

Speaker: NA
Text: unengaged in activities like Work for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Dole. This further increases their separation

Speaker: NA
Text: from the workforce as they are not engaging

Speaker: NA
Text: in job-like activities and are unable to get

Speaker: NA
Text: into a routine. Let me remind members of

Speaker: NA
Text: this House that, as was the case with border

Speaker: NA
Text: protection, the Howard government had a

Speaker: NA
Text: proven formula for Work for the Dole. New

Speaker: NA
Text: figures reveal the coalition's Work for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Dole program is being killed off under this

Speaker: NA
Text: federal Labor government, with 3,000

Speaker: NA
Text: participants slashed from the scheme in the

Speaker: NA
Text: last eight months of 2010. Since 2007, when

Speaker: NA
Text: the Labor government started withering

Speaker: NA
Text: away Work for the Dole, they have increased

Speaker: NA
Text: long-term unemployment under their passive

Speaker: NA
Text: welfare model, where people are required to

Speaker: NA
Text: be unemployed for 12 months or more before

Speaker: NA
Text: this Labor government will fund a work

Speaker: NA
Text: experience activity. Evidence also suggests

Speaker: NA
Text: that the longer someone is out of the

Speaker: NA
Text: workforce it becomes less likely that they

Speaker: NA
Text: will work again. Now the Gillard Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: government are looking at slowly bringing

Speaker: NA
Text: back past Liberal government policies. The

Speaker: NA
Text: coalition has strongly advocated that Work

Speaker: NA
Text: for the Dole should become mandatory for

Speaker: NA
Text: people under 50 who have been receiving

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployment benefits for more than six

Speaker: NA
Text: months.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Social Security Legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: Amendment (Job Seeker Compliance) Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: has a number of key points which should be

Speaker: NA
Text: noted. Firstly, it seeks to introduce tougher

Speaker: NA
Text: compliance measures for job seekers who

Speaker: NA
Text: have activity test requirements. Secondly, it

Speaker: NA
Text: was will suspend income support payments for

Speaker: NA
Text: job seekers who fail to attend an appointment

Speaker: NA
Text: or activity like Work for the Dole without a

Speaker: NA
Text: reasonable excuse given in advance. When

Speaker: NA
Text: the job seeker does attend a rescheduled

Speaker: NA
Text: appointment their payment will be reinstated

Speaker: NA
Text: with back pay. Where the job seeker fails to

Speaker: NA
Text: attend the rescheduled meeting and fails to

Speaker: NA
Text: provide an adequate excuse then payment

Speaker: NA
Text: will be suspended until they do attend an

Speaker: NA
Text: appointment. No back pay will be payable

Speaker: NA
Text: for this period. Thirdly, reasonable excuse

Speaker: NA
Text: provisions will also be tightened, so that

Speaker: NA
Text: even if a job seeker has a reasonable excuse

Speaker: NA
Text: for not attending an appointment or activity

Speaker: NA
Text: on the day it will not be accepted if they

Speaker: NA
Text: could have given advance notice that they

Speaker: NA
Text: could not attend and failed to do so.

Speaker: NA
Text: I note that there have been some concerns

Speaker: NA
Text: received on this bill from various community

Speaker: NA
Text: groups outside my electorate. These include

Speaker: NA
Text: that this legislation is too punitive and that it

Speaker: NA
Text: fails to clarify the circumstances in which

Speaker: NA
Text: job seekers will not be required to give prior

Speaker: NA
Text: notice of their absence. The coalition is

Speaker: NA
Text: satisfied that the wording of the legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: such that if a job seeker does have a valid

Speaker: NA
Text: reason for missing an appointment and was

Speaker: NA
Text: not in a position to advise the provider

Speaker: NA
Text: beforehand then their payment will be

Speaker: NA
Text: immediately reinstated. Like the coalition,

Speaker: NA
Text: the people of my electorate are supportive of

Speaker: NA
Text: Work for the Dole and mutual obligation. In

Speaker: NA
Text: Solomon, as in many other electorates

Speaker: NA
Text: around the nation, there are a range of

Speaker: NA
Text: community projects where unemployed

Speaker: NA
Text: people can contribute back to the society that

Speaker: NA
Text: supports them.

Speaker: NA
Text: In conclusion, I would like to reiterate the

Speaker: NA
Text: support of the coalition for this bill. I hope

Speaker: NA
Text: that these reforms will do as intended and

Speaker: NA
Text: that all job seekers will benefit from moving

Speaker: NA
Text: from welfare to work. My only concern is to

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure that the administration of these

Speaker: NA
Text: reforms is carefully implemented so as to not

Speaker: NA
Text: to bring an additional burden to the already

Speaker: NA
Text: stretched Centrelink staff.

Speaker: Mr HAYES
Text: Fowler-Government

Speaker: NA
Text: Whip) (16:49): I join with others in rising to

Speaker: NA
Text: support the Social Security Legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: Amendment (Job Seeker Compliance) Bill,

Speaker: NA
Text: because it is quite frankly what it takes to do

Speaker: NA
Text: something positive in affecting people

Speaker: NA
Text: peoples lives through employment. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Gillard government certainly

Speaker: NA
Text: employment participation seriously, because

Speaker: NA
Text: we know the positive impact that having a

Speaker: NA
Text: job has on somebody's life. We know also

Speaker: NA
Text: that there are deleterious effects on the lives

Speaker: NA
Text: of people who do not have the opportunity to

Speaker: NA
Text: work. Whilst we wish to do everything we

Speaker: NA
Text: can to encourage people to take up the

Speaker: NA
Text: challenge of getting a job, at the same time

Speaker: NA
Text: we are a government of compassion and I

Speaker: NA
Text: think we do reflect that long-held Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: principle of lending a helping hand to people

Speaker: NA
Text: in need, particularly when people in various

Speaker: NA
Text: circumstances are doing it tough. Getting

Speaker: NA
Text: is that balance right-I suppose therein is the

Speaker: NA
Text: conundrum. What we have before us in this

Speaker: NA
Text: bill is an honest attempt to ensure that that

Speaker: NA
Text: balance is right. Through the amendments in

Speaker: NA
Text: the legislation, it has achieved the right

Speaker: NA
Text: balance in supporting those who are doing it

Speaker: NA
Text: tough in our community and in encouraging

Speaker: NA
Text: workforce participation by providing an

Speaker: NA
Text: incentive for those people to go the extra

Speaker: NA
Text: mile in gaining a job.

Speaker: NA
Text: Over the past few days we have heard a

Speaker: NA
Text: lot from the Prime Minister and Treasurer

Speaker: NA
Text: about the importance of jobs. The issue of

Speaker: NA
Text: jobs was front and centre of the budget that

Speaker: NA
Text: was introduced yesterday Nevertheless, our

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployment rate is the envy of the world

Speaker: NA
Text: and is something Australians should be

Speaker: NA
Text: proud of, something I think we have all

Speaker: NA
Text: collectively worked very hard to achieve and

Speaker: NA
Text: something that we should continue to

Speaker: NA
Text: improve to ensure that we continue to enjoy

Speaker: NA
Text: the fruits of our economic prosperity.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think Wayne Swan got it right when he

Speaker: NA
Text: said there is not an Australian to waste. We

Speaker: NA
Text: have all got a role to play in this, and one of

Speaker: NA
Text: the things we can try to do is ensure that we

Speaker: NA
Text: have full workplace participation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Yesterday's budget was all about maximising

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's employment potential to continue

Speaker: NA
Text: takes our growth. It included essential training

Speaker: NA
Text: programs and incentives for a wide sector of

Speaker: NA
Text: the community, from young apprentices to

Speaker: NA
Text: people on disability support. In my electorate

Speaker: NA
Text: alone, these programs will have an enormous

Speaker: NA
Text: impact. I do know that, for instance, Hoxton

Speaker: NA
Text: Industries provides employment

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunities for over 100 people with

Speaker: NA
Text: disabilities. It has been operating in my

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate since 1969 and is doing a fantastic

Speaker: NA
Text: job. I try to visit them on a reasonably

Speaker: NA
Text: regular basis and Nicole Bruce, the general

Speaker: NA
Text: manager, and all those involved in the

Speaker: NA
Text: supervisory team of Hoxton Industries do a

Speaker: NA
Text: great job in providing opportunity for people

Speaker: NA
Text: with disabilities. It is good to say that last

Speaker: NA
Text: night they were recognised by being awarded

Speaker: NA
Text: $1.1 million to continue their great work in

Speaker: NA
Text: south-west Sydney.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have often said in this place that people

Speaker: NA
Text: are not necessarily having the best of days,

Speaker: NA
Text: and I admit I have one or two of those. But

Speaker: NA
Text: go and visit this place and here are people

Speaker: NA
Text: who have been dealt a pretty hard hand in

Speaker: NA
Text: life. It always impresses me that what they

Speaker: NA
Text: want to do is to turn up for work. They want

Speaker: NA
Text: to feel that they are wanted. They want to

Speaker: NA
Text: feel that their services are appreciated. They

Speaker: NA
Text: want to feel that they have a sense of worth.

Speaker: NA
Text: do not mind admitting that when you are

Speaker: NA
Text: feeling a bit down you go there and, I tell

Speaker: NA
Text: you what, Mr Deputy Speaker, it does lift

Speaker: NA
Text: your spirits to see these people who really

Speaker: NA
Text: want to come to work and want to engage in

Speaker: NA
Text: talking to you about everything else,

Speaker: NA
Text: including the football. But they genuinely

Speaker: NA
Text: enjoy the opportunity of going to work

Speaker: NA
Text: because it actually fulfils something in their

Speaker: NA
Text: lives. I am very proud to be part of a

Speaker: NA
Text: government that can recognise that and

Speaker: NA
Text: proud of the $1.1 million that has just been

Speaker: NA
Text: delivered to Hoxton Industries, amongst

Speaker: NA
Text: many others. I have got to say that when I go

Speaker: NA
Text: to various functions with the local Chamber

Speaker: NA
Text: of Commerce, whether it be in Liverpool or

Speaker: NA
Text: Cabramatta or elsewhere, as I have indicated

Speaker: NA
Text: to many employers, if you are not going to

Speaker: NA
Text: jeopardise your bottom line, if you are not

Speaker: NA
Text: going to cut short your return to your

Speaker: NA
Text: shareholders, if you can actually direct work

Speaker: NA
Text: to places such as Hoxton Industries that

Speaker: NA
Text: provide opportunities for people with

Speaker: NA
Text: disabilities, that is a very good thing to do

Speaker: NA
Text: for your community. As I say, I am very

Speaker: NA
Text: proud of what they achieve and I will

Speaker: NA
Text: continue to work as closely as I can to

Speaker: NA
Text: support their interests because I know that

Speaker: NA
Text: they do a fantastic job for all of us.

Speaker: NA
Text: But on the other side of the coin we need

Speaker: NA
Text: to ensure that our welfare system is also

Speaker: NA
Text: encouraging those that can work to do so.

Speaker: NA
Text: We need to provide, I suppose it is fair to

Speaker: NA
Text: say, a carrot and stick approach which

Speaker: NA
Text: reflects how seriously this government takes

Speaker: NA
Text: the issue of workforce participation. Clearly

Speaker: NA
Text: on any reading of this amendment it does

Speaker: NA
Text: just that. As part of the Modernising

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's Welfare System policy,

Speaker: NA
Text: announced in August 2010, the government

Speaker: NA
Text: gave a commitment to introduce tougher

Speaker: NA
Text: rules for job seekers from July 2011. These

Speaker: NA
Text: measures will apply to all job seekers on

Speaker: NA
Text: I participation benefits, including parents,

Speaker: NA
Text: though it will not impact on family

Speaker: NA
Text: payments, which is an important element of

Speaker: NA
Text: the amendment.

Speaker: NA
Text: The crux of this amendment is that it

Speaker: NA
Text: imposes financial penalties on job seekers

Speaker: NA
Text: who fail to comply with appointments, or

Speaker: NA
Text: mandated activities such as training, without

Speaker: NA
Text: a reasonable excuse. Once the job seeker re-

Speaker: NA
Text: engages, payments will be restored. I think

Speaker: NA
Text: that is probably a fair balance. If a job seeker

Speaker: NA
Text: is successful in obtaining a job and does not

Speaker: NA
Text: report to work, we know what happens then.

Speaker: NA
Text: They do not get paid and more than likely

Speaker: NA
Text: they get sacked. There is an aspect to this of

Speaker: NA
Text: making sure that this also builds upon the co-

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibilities that apply in respect of

Speaker: NA
Text: welfare payments. In our society we do look

Speaker: NA
Text: after people who find themselves in hard

Speaker: NA
Text: times, we do look after people who fall

Speaker: NA
Text: through the cracks, and we help them

Speaker: NA
Text: remediate their position, help them to get

Speaker: NA
Text: back. But it does require a measure of self-

Speaker: NA
Text: help in all that as well. So if somebody does

Speaker: NA
Text: not turn up for their appointments, does not

Speaker: NA
Text: undertake training they have been required to

Speaker: NA
Text: do, the Commonwealth will not continue

Speaker: NA
Text: with their payments until such time as they

Speaker: NA
Text: re-engage. On behalf of those we represent,

Speaker: NA
Text: we are responsible for administering the

Speaker: NA
Text: public purse, so that is a fair thing. It

Speaker: NA
Text: on the government's election commitment to

Speaker: NA
Text: introduce tougher rules for job seekers.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is a need for a tightening of the

Speaker: NA
Text: system, and this government has shown that

Speaker: NA
Text: it is up to the task. The Disney report

Speaker: NA
Text: released in September 2010 says just that. It

Speaker: NA
Text: sought the tightening up of the regime

Speaker: NA
Text: around participation payments to encourage

Speaker: NA
Text: people to engage in a level of self-help with

Speaker: NA
Text: a view to obtaining a job.

Speaker: NA
Text: This amendment will also simplify the

Speaker: NA
Text: system for job seekers so that they can focus

Speaker: NA
Text: on their most important task, and that has got

Speaker: NA
Text: to be finding a job. It is going to be a

Speaker: NA
Text: situation where people will want to

Speaker: NA
Text: participate. They will need to attend the

Speaker: NA
Text: interviews which have been arranged for

Speaker: NA
Text: them by their job search agency and they

Speaker: NA
Text: will need to undertake the training that has

Speaker: NA
Text: been mandated to help them become

Speaker: NA
Text: employable. I know this is stating the

Speaker: NA
Text: obvious, but this is trying to help people help

Speaker: NA
Text: themselves.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am proud to represent the electorate of

Speaker: NA
Text: Fowler in the south-west of Sydney and I

Speaker: NA
Text: know this will be of benefit to people in my

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate. I am not terribly proud of the fact

Speaker: NA
Text: that we have one of the highest youth

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployment rates in the country. We need

Speaker: NA
Text: to ensure that young people between the ages

Speaker: NA
Text: of 15 and 24 are engaged in either education

Speaker: NA
Text: or employment, because we all know what

Speaker: NA
Text: the answer is if they are left on long-term

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployment; the answer is that they stay

Speaker: NA
Text: on it. This is trying to provide the incentive

Speaker: NA
Text: not to fall into that trap, because of what it

Speaker: NA
Text: means for them and for our communities in

Speaker: NA
Text: this country.

Speaker: NA
Text: We know that, by and large, people are

Speaker: NA
Text: keen to work. They are keen to work hard.

Speaker: NA
Text: They are keen to have their labours

Speaker: NA
Text: appreciated. They want to participate in the

Speaker: NA
Text: delivers workforce and they are keen for the

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunities that are being provided for

Speaker: NA
Text: them under these programs. We have just got

Speaker: NA
Text: to make sure that there is a certain amount of

Speaker: NA
Text: disciplined balance that goes into achieving

Speaker: NA
Text: that. Unfortunately, there are also some

Speaker: NA
Text: people who have been left behind. Clearly,

Speaker: NA
Text: they were left behind under the

Speaker: NA
Text: administration of the Howard government,

Speaker: NA
Text: who failed to invest in skills and

Speaker: NA
Text: apprenticeship training when they had the

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity to do so. The Howard

Speaker: NA
Text: government were very good at using the

Speaker: NA
Text: stick, there is no question about that, and

Speaker: NA
Text: taking payments away from people who did

Speaker: NA
Text: not comply. They did it. But what they failed

Speaker: NA
Text: to do was invest in skills development and

Speaker: NA
Text: training support needs for the unemployed.

Speaker: NA
Text: They failed to invest in having people job

Speaker: NA
Text: ready. They failed to do all that before we

Speaker: NA
Text: got hit with a mining boom. Most of our

Speaker: NA
Text: tradesmen, including my sons, went to make

Speaker: NA
Text: significant dollars working up in your neck

Speaker: NA
Text: of the woods, Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER -at

Speaker: NA
Text: Emerald and other places up there.

Speaker: Mr Chester
Text: So Howard caused the

Speaker: NA
Text: mining boom now!

Speaker: Mr HAYES
Text: I am sure the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Gippsland had a very similar experience,

Speaker: NA
Text: actually. What the Howard government

Speaker: NA
Text: failed to do was invest in the training of

Speaker: NA
Text: young people to participate in that growth in

Speaker: NA
Text: jobs. Filling those vacancies that occurred in

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney, Melbourne and everywhere else was

Speaker: NA
Text: very much the responsibility of a

Speaker: NA
Text: government that sat back, sat on its hands

Speaker: NA
Text: and failed to invest in training and skills

Speaker: NA
Text: development over the period when it had the

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity to do so.

Speaker: NA
Text: We know that the issue of employment

Speaker: NA
Text: participation is more complex than just

Speaker: NA
Text: punishing the long-term unemployed. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: about skilling and reskilling people and

Speaker: NA
Text: providing them with a suitable incentive, as

Speaker: NA
Text: said from the start, so that they can

Speaker: NA
Text: go the extra mile and get the job. There is a

Speaker: NA
Text: certain amount of hunger associated with

Speaker: NA
Text: that and, to some extent, we need to

Speaker: NA
Text: encourage people to have the drive to

Speaker: NA
Text: actually go and do that. We need to break

Speaker: NA
Text: that chain, particularly in long-term

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployment. We cannot be a modern

Speaker: NA
Text: society, a compassionate society, and tolerate

Speaker: NA
Text: long-term generational unemployment. That

Speaker: NA
Text: is not compassion; that is not something that

Speaker: NA
Text: you would expect from a modern society that

Speaker: NA
Text: cares about people and the future of the

Speaker: NA
Text: country.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is particularly the case as we address another day.

Speaker: NA
Text: the issue of long-term unemployment. This is

Speaker: NA
Text: an important amendment. It is an amendment

Speaker: NA
Text: that will send a message to all those seeking

Speaker: NA
Text: work that we as a government take their

Speaker: NA
Text: search for work very seriously. This

Speaker: NA
Text: amendment will demonstrate that the Gillard

Speaker: NA
Text: government's commitment to workforce

Speaker: NA
Text: participation to ensure the continued growth

Speaker: NA
Text: of the country is certainly addressed. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: certainly an amendment that deserves the

Speaker: NA
Text: support of both sides of this chamber

Speaker: NA
Text: because it goes not only to looking after the

Speaker: NA
Text: interest of individuals, not only to looking

Speaker: NA
Text: after generational aspects of having a job

Speaker: NA
Text: what that means to your children into the

Speaker: NA
Text: future; it sets the example that shows you

Speaker: NA
Text: can achieve in this country through

Speaker: NA
Text: education and participation in the workforce.

Speaker: NA
Text: I commend this amendment bill to the

Speaker: NA
Text: House and I, for one, am very keen to

Speaker: NA
Text: advocate in support of the amendments

Speaker: NA
Text: throughout my electorate because I know

Speaker: NA
Text: this is where we will see considerable

Speaker: NA
Text: benefits over the years to come as there is

Speaker: NA
Text: greater participation in the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: workforce and the breaking of the scourge of

Speaker: NA
Text: long-term unemployment.

Speaker: Mr CHESTER
Text: Gippsland) (17:04): I

Speaker: NA
Text: I rise to speak in relation to the Social Security

Speaker: NA
Text: actually Legislation Amendment (Job Seeker

Speaker: NA
Text: Compliance) Bill 2011. In doing so I will

Speaker: NA
Text: raise several issues of concern to my

Speaker: NA
Text: community, some of which I believe have

Speaker: NA
Text: broader national implications. But I cannot

Speaker: NA
Text: resist commenting at least a little on the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Fowler's contribution. He is a

Speaker: NA
Text: member who I find to be very thoughtful in

Speaker: NA
Text: his comments, as a general rule, and I agree

Speaker: NA
Text: with a lot of what he said, particularly about

Speaker: NA
Text: the need to keep young people engaged. I

Speaker: NA
Text: take great exception to his assertions that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Howard government did nothing in relation

Speaker: NA
Text: to skills and training, but that is a debate for

Speaker: NA
Text: It is worth noting that the Rudd

Speaker: NA
Text: government actually watered down the

Speaker: NA
Text: mutual obligation in 2008, introducing their

Speaker: NA
Text: 'no show no pay' compliance model, which

Speaker: NA
Text: saw job seekers docked a day's welfare for

Speaker: NA
Text: failing to attend interviews. It is all very well

Speaker: NA
Text: to have a soft heart in this place, but there is

Speaker: NA
Text: no excuse for a government having a soft

Speaker: NA
Text: head. I am afraid it was a soft-headed

Speaker: NA
Text: response by the Rudd government. The high

Speaker: NA
Text: rate of missed appointments is a clear

Speaker: NA
Text: indication of the failure of Labor's

Speaker: NA
Text: compliance regime, which I do not believe

Speaker: NA
Text: and provided sufficient disincentive for many

Speaker: NA
Text: people. In March 2011 there were 179,000

Speaker: NA
Text: people classed as long-term unemployed in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, and in the past 12 months leading

Speaker: NA
Text: up to that period approximately two million

Speaker: NA
Text: people missed job interviews. I think that is a

Speaker: NA
Text: fair reflection that there was nothing to

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure the compliance of those people who

Speaker: NA
Text: were meant to attend activities with the

Speaker: NA
Text: providers.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have spoken in the past about the need to

Speaker: NA
Text: reform our welfare system, particularly as it

Speaker: NA
Text: relates to young people in receipt of

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployment benefits. I do get the chance

Speaker: NA
Text: to speak to many young people in my

Speaker: NA
Text: community, as I am sure many other

Speaker: NA
Text: members do, particularly in our secondary

Speaker: NA
Text: schools, and I always encourage them to aim

Speaker: NA
Text: high to achieve their full potential and to

Speaker: NA
Text: never sell themselves short. Just because

Speaker: NA
Text: they come from a regional community, there

Speaker: NA
Text: is no reason to sell themselves short and

Speaker: NA
Text: think that some things are beyond them in

Speaker: NA
Text: their future career prospects. I also tell them

Speaker: NA
Text: that they really should treat unemployment

Speaker: NA
Text: as being a situation of last resort for them, in

Speaker: NA
Text: terms of receiving unemployment benefits.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is no-one that I ever speak to in

Speaker: NA
Text: secondary school that regards being long-

Speaker: NA
Text: term unemployed as a career goal, so I think

Speaker: NA
Text: there is something that goes wrong from

Speaker: NA
Text: those mid-secondary school years to when

Speaker: NA
Text: the young people are actually seeking work.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is where we need to make sure that, as a

Speaker: NA
Text: government, we have a firm hand but a

Speaker: NA
Text: supporting system. That is a critical issue for

Speaker: NA
Text: us: to help young people in those very

Speaker: NA
Text: difficult transitional years as they move out

Speaker: NA
Text: of secondary school and into the workforce.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am concerned that for some young

Speaker: NA
Text: people who may go off the rails, for

Speaker: NA
Text: whatever reasons, the option of receiving

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployment benefits has become too easy.

Speaker: NA
Text: I support an overhaul of the unemployment

Speaker: NA
Text: benefits system, with a view to making sure

Speaker: NA
Text: that people who can work are actually

Speaker: NA
Text: working. That is not intended as some sort of

Speaker: NA
Text: punishment to these people in any way

Speaker: NA
Text: whatsoever. I believe we do these young

Speaker: NA
Text: people a huge disservice if we allow them to

Speaker: NA
Text: remain on unemployment benefits without

Speaker: NA
Text: ensuring that there are some very stringent

Speaker: NA
Text: obligations on them to make a contribution

Speaker: NA
Text: to our community.

Speaker: NA
Text: Programs like Work for the Dole and

Speaker: NA
Text: Green Corps have been successful in many

Speaker: NA
Text: parts of Gippsland in providing opportunities

Speaker: NA
Text: for young unemployed people to develop a

Speaker: NA
Text: work ethic, to develop new skills and to

Speaker: NA
Text: make a meaningful contribution to our

Speaker: NA
Text: community. They should not be seen as any

Speaker: NA
Text: form of punishment. I would advocate that

Speaker: NA
Text: we find a new name for the Work for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Dole program, something that is far more

Speaker: NA
Text: positive and encourages people to feel that

Speaker: NA
Text: they are actually making a contribution to the

Speaker: NA
Text: community rather than it being some sort of

Speaker: NA
Text: punitive measure.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are, however, concerns with the

Speaker: NA
Text: program and concerns with the compliance

Speaker: NA
Text: regime. I have had the opportunity to speak

Speaker: NA
Text: to coordinators from different agencies who

Speaker: NA
Text: are involved in these types of work activity

Speaker: NA
Text: programs and work based training programs.

Speaker: NA
Text: They have met with me and described the

Speaker: NA
Text: problems that they are having in making sure

Speaker: NA
Text: that long-term unemployed people are

Speaker: NA
Text: meeting their obligations. In a typical case, a

Speaker: NA
Text: training allowance may be provided for

Speaker: NA
Text: someone to work in some sort of Green

Speaker: NA
Text: Corps type program, and they will be given

Speaker: NA
Text: clothes and suitable equipment to participate

Speaker: NA
Text: in that program. Sometimes there is some

Speaker: NA
Text: financial incentive involved. The problem

Speaker: NA
Text: starts if they turn up on the first day but on

Speaker: NA
Text: subsequent days they simply do not turn up

Speaker: NA
Text: and participate at all in the activity they are

Speaker: NA
Text: meant to be participating in. The problem

Speaker: NA
Text: continues when the agencies submit to

Speaker: NA
Text: Centrelink a participation report and

Speaker: NA
Text: Centrelink does not actually breach the

Speaker: NA
Text: people involved; there are no sanctions

Speaker: NA
Text: applied to them.

Speaker: NA
Text: I can understand the situation from the

Speaker: NA
Text: side of the Centrelink staff faced with a

Speaker: NA
Text: disgruntled client, someone who is making

Speaker: NA
Text: all sorts of claims as to why they could not

Speaker: NA
Text: reasonably attend that activity or work

Speaker: NA
Text: training program. It is probably easier in

Speaker: NA
Text: many cases for the Centrelink staff to simply

Speaker: NA
Text: wave it through and allow the person to not

Speaker: NA
Text: be breached. But it goes to the core of what

Speaker: NA
Text: we are talking about here today in terms of

Speaker: NA
Text: the compliance measures.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are people out there right now who

Speaker: NA
Text: are taking the Australian taxpayers for a ride.

Speaker: NA
Text: This type of rorting of the system has to stop.

Speaker: NA
Text: We need to set higher standards of workforce

Speaker: NA
Text: participation. In that sense, I do support the

Speaker: NA
Text: new compliance legislation before the House

Speaker: NA
Text: this evening. In her second reading speech,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister for Employment Participation

Speaker: NA
Text: said:

Speaker: NA
Text: As soon as Centrelink is advised that a job

Speaker: NA
Text: seeker has missed an appointment with their

Speaker: NA
Text: employment services provider, or if the

Speaker: NA
Text: believes that the job seeker has become

Speaker: NA
Text: disengaged from an activity they are supposed

Speaker: NA
Text: be participating in, Centrelink will suspend

Speaker: NA
Text: job seeker‘s payment.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is a positive step. I know there are a

Speaker: NA
Text: range of issues to do with what are

Speaker: NA
Text: reasonable excuses and ensuring that the

Speaker: NA
Text: most vulnerable people are not adversely

Speaker: NA
Text: impacted unnecessarily by this new approach

Speaker: NA
Text: from the government, but I certainly support

Speaker: NA
Text: the general thrust of the new compliance

Speaker: NA
Text: regime.

Speaker: NA
Text: I would like to note a submission from

Speaker: NA
Text: Mission Australia to the inquiry into this

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation. Mission Australia supported the

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed amendments, saying that they 'are

Speaker: NA
Text: critical to ensure the compliance regime is

Speaker: NA
Text: not too lenient and has a more immediate

Speaker: NA
Text: effect,' the point being that, unless there is a

Speaker: NA
Text: direct and obvious effect on the job seeker at

Speaker: NA
Text: the time of the actual breach, the impact of

Speaker: NA
Text: such sanctions is likely to be diminished.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Mission Australia submission also

Speaker: NA
Text: highlights the high number of participation

Speaker: NA
Text: reports that are being overturned by

Speaker: NA
Text: Centrelink. That is something I referred to

Speaker: NA
Text: earlier. The majority of participation reports

Speaker: NA
Text: are overturned on 'reasonable excuse'

Speaker: NA
Text: grounds. Around 20 per cent of the

Speaker: NA
Text: reasonable excuses upheld by Centrelink

Speaker: NA
Text: were on the grounds of a medical reason

Speaker: NA
Text: where specific evidence was not provided.

Speaker: NA
Text: That goes again to the core of the issue: we

Speaker: NA
Text: really must be expecting some level of

Speaker: NA
Text: credibility to the excuses being put forward,

Speaker: NA
Text: and these reasonable excuses must be

Speaker: NA
Text: legitimate if we are to ensure that people are

Speaker: NA
Text: meeting their obligations.

Speaker: NA
Text: I would like to stress that, in the

Speaker: NA
Text: comments I am making tonight, I am not

Speaker: NA
Text: seeking to typecast people on unemployment

Speaker: NA
Text: benefits simply as dole bludgers just because

Speaker: NA
Text: they are not in full-time employment or

Speaker: NA
Text: gainfully employed in the community. For

Speaker: NA
Text: provider many people, it is a source of great

Speaker: NA
Text: embarrassment. There is financial, social and

Speaker: NA
Text: to emotional difficulty associated for those who

Speaker: NA
Text: the are genuinely unemployed. But we do have

Speaker: NA
Text: to provide additional motivation for those

Speaker: NA
Text: people in our community who simply refuse

Speaker: NA
Text: to comply with their obligations. I believe

Speaker: NA
Text: that a new form of mutual obligation is

Speaker: NA
Text: necessary. I understand the government has

Speaker: NA
Text: made some announcements in the budget.

Speaker: NA
Text: For my liking, they simply do not go far

Speaker: NA
Text: enough. I believe that, if you are fit and able

Speaker: NA
Text: to work, then after a period of between three

Speaker: NA
Text: and six months of being unemployed we

Speaker: NA
Text: really need to make sure that you are actually

Speaker: NA
Text: doing some sort of community based project

Speaker: NA
Text: where you will have the opportunity to make

Speaker: NA
Text: a meaningful contribution to the community

Speaker: NA
Text: in which you live.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is an unlimited amount of work that

Speaker: NA
Text: could be done in our community through a

Speaker: NA
Text: range of community projects like Work for

Speaker: NA
Text: the Dole or Green Corps. Look at any coastal

Speaker: NA
Text: community. There are a number of things

Speaker: NA
Text: that you could be doing, such as foreshore

Speaker: NA
Text: reparation works, rubbish removal,

Speaker: NA
Text: improving community halls and sporting

Speaker: NA
Text: facilities and even helping older people to

Speaker: NA
Text: remain in their homes longer. There are a

Speaker: NA
Text: whole range of tasks that are available and

Speaker: NA
Text: out there in the community. People could

Speaker: NA
Text: learn new skills and participate in these

Speaker: NA
Text: tasks, even after they have only been in

Speaker: NA
Text: receipt of unemployment benefits for a

Speaker: NA
Text: comparatively short time.

Speaker: NA
Text: I believe that even in that short period

Speaker: NA
Text: time, three to six months, there is a real

Speaker: NA
Text: impact on the morale of the person involved.

Speaker: NA
Text: They can get into poor habits in terms of

Speaker: NA
Text: their work ethic and end up being

Speaker: NA
Text: disconnected from the community in which

Speaker: NA
Text: they live. So I do not think we are doing

Speaker: NA
Text: anyone any favours by just handing out

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployment benefits without some

Speaker: NA
Text: reasonable expectation that the recipients

Speaker: NA
Text: will then make a contribution to the society

Speaker: NA
Text: that has provided them.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are also sections of my community

Speaker: NA
Text: where we are now faced with the entrenched

Speaker: NA
Text: welfare dependency problem of second and

Speaker: NA
Text: third generation welfare recipients. If you

Speaker: NA
Text: have never seen someone get out of bed and

Speaker: NA
Text: go to work, if you have never experienced

Speaker: NA
Text: the discipline of providing for your own

Speaker: NA
Text: family, if you have never felt the pride and

Speaker: NA
Text: growth in self-esteem which comes from

Speaker: NA
Text: making a contribution to the community and

Speaker: NA
Text: if you have never seen anyone in your

Speaker: NA
Text: immediate family doing that either, it is very

Speaker: NA
Text: difficult for you to break out of the welfare

Speaker: NA
Text: cycle. I believe that we need to do more in

Speaker: NA
Text: this place-and in that regard I welcome this

Speaker: NA
Text: new compliance regime-to encourage that

Speaker: NA
Text: work ethic, particularly amongst the families

Speaker: NA
Text: in my community which have had such a

Speaker: NA
Text: reliance on welfare over a long period of

Speaker: NA
Text: time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Passive welfare really does destroy lives

Speaker: NA
Text: and I do not think we need to look any

Speaker: NA
Text: further than the Indigenous community in

Speaker: NA
Text: Gippsland. Too many people in that

Speaker: NA
Text: community have been receiving benefits for

Speaker: NA
Text: many years without any expectation

Speaker: NA
Text: whatsoever of doing some work in return. I

Speaker: NA
Text: think we really need to understand that the

Speaker: NA
Text: issues facing Aboriginal families in Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: do not reside purely in the Northern Territory

Speaker: NA
Text: or other remote areas. The passive welfare

Speaker: NA
Text: of system that has developed over many

Speaker: NA
Text: years-most of it well-intentioned, but

Speaker: NA
Text: unfortunately poorly directed-has destroyed

Speaker: NA
Text: families in my community. Gippsland right

Speaker: NA
Text: now has many young people growing up in

Speaker: NA
Text: quite hopeless environments. I believe that

Speaker: NA
Text: paid employment is the way out of poverty

Speaker: NA
Text: for these people and that the decency of a job

Speaker: NA
Text: leads to a wide range of very positive

Speaker: NA
Text: outcomes.

Speaker: NA
Text: The issues I am talking about that are

Speaker: NA
Text: facing the Indigenous people in my

Speaker: NA
Text: community are centred around health,

Speaker: NA
Text: education and jobs. It is a vicious circle if

Speaker: NA
Text: any one of these boxes is not ticked. We

Speaker: NA
Text: need to ensure that, at a very early age, our

Speaker: NA
Text: Aboriginal children are being well looked

Speaker: NA
Text: after. Healthy kids who are well looked after

Speaker: NA
Text: at home go on to do well at school, they go

Speaker: NA
Text: on to enjoy their education and they go on to

Speaker: NA
Text: lead successful lives. It is easy to say that; it

Speaker: NA
Text: is very hard to provide that in every local

Speaker: NA
Text: community.

Speaker: NA
Text: On the flip side, there are children who

Speaker: NA
Text: witness violence or abuse, who are neglected

Speaker: NA
Text: in some way or who are not properly

Speaker: NA
Text: checked by doctors or nurses at an early age

Speaker: NA
Text: and develop health problems. These children

Speaker: NA
Text: are starting behind the eight ball when it

Speaker: NA
Text: comes to the education sector, so naturally

Speaker: NA
Text: they do not get the opportunity to develop

Speaker: NA
Text: the skills required for them to go on into the

Speaker: NA
Text: workforce.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is an enormous challenge for us to break

Speaker: NA
Text: that cycle of welfare dependency in our

Speaker: NA
Text: Aboriginal community and we need to keep

Speaker: NA
Text: working very hard with the service providers

Speaker: NA
Text: to make sure that we have individual families

Speaker: NA
Text: taking responsibility and helping these

Speaker: NA
Text: children achieve their full potential. We can

Speaker: NA
Text: run all the programs we want-and

Speaker: NA
Text: governments from both sides of politics have

Speaker: NA
Text: tried many programs-but, at the grassroots

Speaker: NA
Text: level, the people themselves have to want to

Speaker: NA
Text: make some changes.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is some terrific work being done in

Speaker: NA
Text: my community, particularly in Morwell,

Speaker: NA
Text: Sale, Bairnsdale, Lake Tyers and Lakes

Speaker: NA
Text: Entrance, where there are elders in the

Speaker: NA
Text: community who are doing a power of work.

Speaker: NA
Text: But in many cases I fear they are swimming

Speaker: NA
Text: against the tide. I have had the opportunity

Speaker: NA
Text: recent times to participate in an activity at

Speaker: NA
Text: Lake Tyers Mission, where there has been a

Speaker: NA
Text: fishing competition. It was designed to get

Speaker: NA
Text: young kids together with their families to

Speaker: NA
Text: participate in a good, friendly, healthy

Speaker: NA
Text: outdoor activity without any alcohol and

Speaker: NA
Text: without any pressure whatsoever being

Speaker: NA
Text: placed on the community. It was a great

Speaker: NA
Text: event and it helped to bring everyone

Speaker: NA
Text: together to start thinking about what we can

Speaker: NA
Text: do to provide a more functional community

Speaker: NA
Text: throughout Gippsland. Many of the primary

Speaker: NA
Text: schools and sporting clubs in my electorate

Speaker: NA
Text: are working overtime to engage with the

Speaker: NA
Text: local Aboriginal community as much as

Speaker: NA
Text: possible. We need to break down those

Speaker: NA
Text: barriers, to provide opportunities and to

Speaker: NA
Text: make sure the Aboriginal community is

Speaker: NA
Text: involved in everything that we do in

Speaker: NA
Text: Gippsland.

Speaker: NA
Text: The government, to its credit, has funded

Speaker: NA
Text: a major new childcare and kindergarten

Speaker: NA
Text: facility in Bairnsdale which should assist, I

Speaker: NA
Text: believe, in getting young children ready for

Speaker: NA
Text: school-to help send them on their way and

Speaker: NA
Text: make the most positive step possible. At the

Speaker: NA
Text: moment we have too many young Aboriginal

Speaker: NA
Text: kids who are starting their prep school

Speaker: NA
Text: already behind. They are already a year or

Speaker: NA
Text: two behind their counterparts in the

Speaker: NA
Text: classroom. Unfortunately they

Speaker: NA
Text: disenchanted and too many of them drop out

Speaker: NA
Text: of the school system as young as 10 or 12

Speaker: NA
Text: years old. As I said, we are making some

Speaker: NA
Text: improvements and many people are

Speaker: NA
Text: committed to the cause.

Speaker: NA
Text: I accept that there are no easy answers. If

Speaker: NA
Text: there were easy answers, these situations

Speaker: NA
Text: would have been fixed many years ago. But I

Speaker: NA
Text: want to bring these issues to the attention of

Speaker: NA
Text: the House and to make the point that the

Speaker: NA
Text: urban or regional Indigenous experience in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia is, in many ways, as perilous as

Speaker: NA
Text: that of the more remote communities that we

Speaker: NA
Text: in hear so much about and which attract a lot of

Speaker: NA
Text: the media attention. I think we need to do a

Speaker: NA
Text: lot better to make sure that our Aboriginal

Speaker: NA
Text: communities are engaged in community life.

Speaker: NA
Text: In particular, I believe there is an opportunity

Speaker: NA
Text: for us to work much more closely with our

Speaker: NA
Text: sporting clubs. People from those

Speaker: NA
Text: communities often excel at sporting activities

Speaker: NA
Text: and that provides a bridge for them to get

Speaker: NA
Text: more involved in mainstream activities. I

Speaker: NA
Text: believe very strongly in local solutions to

Speaker: NA
Text: local problems. I think the opportunities are

Speaker: NA
Text: there for us to work in this place for the

Speaker: NA
Text: betterment of all people in our community,

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly those Aboriginal members of our

Speaker: NA
Text: community who are falling so far behind in

Speaker: NA
Text: Gippsland at the moment.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr CRAIG THOMSON (Dobell)

Speaker: NA
Text: (17:20): It is a pleasure to follow the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Gippsland, who has made a very

Speaker: NA
Text: thoughtful contribution today. He has

Speaker: NA
Text: obviously thought long and hard about the

Speaker: NA
Text: effects of unemployment in his community.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is not often that I get up following the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Gippsland and say that I agree

Speaker: NA
Text: with most of the sentiments he has

Speaker: NA
Text: expressed, but I do today. He has outlined

Speaker: NA
Text: well the issues about the importance of

Speaker: NA
Text: personal responsibility in looking for jobs,

Speaker: NA
Text: but he has also emphasised the need for

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunities for people to get the proper

Speaker: NA
Text: get education and have access to jobs-

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly in relation to Indigenous

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians. The important issues of

Speaker: NA
Text: Aboriginal health and life expectancy need

Speaker: NA
Text: to be looked after.

Speaker: NA
Text: The approach on employment that the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Gippsland has outlined is the

Speaker: NA
Text: approach the Australian Labor Party has

Speaker: NA
Text: adopted. I look forward to the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Gippsland actually supporting the budget

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Treasurer brought down last night,

Speaker: NA
Text: because if ever there were a budget focused

Speaker: NA
Text: on jobs, health and education, it was the one

Speaker: NA
Text: last night. That is clearly the flip side to

Speaker: NA
Text: implementing welfare system measures

Speaker: NA
Text: relating to obligations and personal

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility, which this bill is about. So I

Speaker: NA
Text: am looking forward to seeing the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Gippsland coming across to this side and

Speaker: NA
Text: supporting the budget in a wholehearted

Speaker: NA
Text: way, because I know he is very genuine

Speaker: NA
Text: person who expresses his views in this place

Speaker: NA
Text: in a very forthright manner, as he has today.

Speaker: NA
Text: Clearly he is supporting the Swan budget of

Speaker: NA
Text: last night.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Social Security Legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: Amendment (Job Seeker Compliance) Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: 2011, which I am speaking in support of

Speaker: NA
Text: today, will allow for immediate suspension

Speaker: NA
Text: of a job seeker's income support payment if

Speaker: NA
Text: the job seeker fails to attend an appointment

Speaker: NA
Text: with their employment service provider or

Speaker: NA
Text: attend an activity under

Speaker: NA
Text: circumstances and allows the penalty amount

Speaker: NA
Text: for a reconnection failure-applied when a

Speaker: NA
Text: job seeker fails to attend are a scheduled

Speaker: NA
Text: appointment-to be deducted from the job

Speaker: NA
Text: seeker's next payment. It tightens the

Speaker: NA
Text: reasonable excuse provisions to require job

Speaker: NA
Text: seekers to give prior notice if they are unable

Speaker: NA
Text: to attend an appointment or activity on a

Speaker: NA
Text: particular day. Both the current compliance

Speaker: NA
Text: framework and the new arrangements take

Speaker: NA
Text: into account the individual circumstances of

Speaker: NA
Text: job seekers in rural and regional areas-

Speaker: NA
Text: which both the member for Gippsland and I

Speaker: NA
Text: are-and of course this is very important.

Speaker: NA
Text: Allowances are made for transport or

Speaker: NA
Text: communication difficulties which may

Speaker: NA
Text: impact on job seeker's ability to meet their

Speaker: NA
Text: participation requirements or where it may

Speaker: NA
Text: not be possible to arrange a new appointment

Speaker: NA
Text: with an employment service provider in the

Speaker: NA
Text: next two business days.

Speaker: NA
Text: The bill will introduce suspension of

Speaker: NA
Text: payment for job seekers following an initial

Speaker: NA
Text: failure to attend an appointment or, in some

Speaker: NA
Text: circumstances, an activity such as training. If

Speaker: NA
Text: the job seeker then agrees to re-engage as

Speaker: NA
Text: required, payment will be restored with full

Speaker: NA
Text: back-payment. It is a measure which has the

Speaker: NA
Text: stick there but does not have the punitive

Speaker: NA
Text: nature of penalising the job seeker in the

Speaker: NA
Text: long term. Its aim is to have them

Speaker: NA
Text: reconnected with the system so that they can

Speaker: NA
Text: get the assistance they need. If the job seeker

Speaker: NA
Text: then fails to re-engage, payment will again

Speaker: NA
Text: be suspended pending agreement to re-

Speaker: NA
Text: engage, but if they do not have a reasonable

Speaker: NA
Text: excuse they will lose payment for each day

Speaker: NA
Text: from their second missed appointment until

Speaker: NA
Text: they do attend a rescheduled appointment.

Speaker: NA
Text: This penalty will be deducted from their very

Speaker: NA
Text: next payment, rather than from their second

Speaker: NA
Text: next payment as is required under the current

Speaker: NA
Text: certain legislation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Reasonable excuse provisions will also be

Speaker: NA
Text: tightened so that, even if a job seeker has a

Speaker: NA
Text: reasonable excuse for not attending an

Speaker: NA
Text: appointment or activity on the day, it will not

Speaker: NA
Text: be accepted if they could have given advance

Speaker: NA
Text: notice of their inability to attend but failed to

Speaker: NA
Text: do so. This is important in relation to the

Speaker: NA
Text: type of behaviour one would expect if a job

Speaker: NA
Text: seeker were in employment. We should not

Speaker: NA
Text: be setting lower standards for a job seeker

Speaker: NA
Text: than we would expect from an employee.

Speaker: NA
Text: This starts to match up those obligations.

Speaker: NA
Text: Job seekers with vulnerability indicators

Speaker: NA
Text: on their Centrelink record-such as those

Speaker: NA
Text: who are homeless or who have a mental

Speaker: NA
Text: illness-will not have their payment

Speaker: NA
Text: immediately suspended following the first

Speaker: NA
Text: non-attendance, although they will continue

Speaker: NA
Text: to be subject to the other arrangements I

Speaker: NA
Text: have already outlined.

Speaker: NA
Text: This bill delivers on the government's

Speaker: NA
Text: election commitment to introduce tighter

Speaker: NA
Text: rules for job seekers. Available data supports

Speaker: NA
Text: the need for some tightening of the system.

Speaker: NA
Text: After some improvement immediately

Speaker: NA
Text: following the introduction of the current

Speaker: NA
Text: compliance framework in July 2009,

Speaker: NA
Text: attendance rates at provider appointments

Speaker: NA
Text: fell during 2009-10.

Speaker: NA
Text: Suspension of payment provides a strong

Speaker: NA
Text: immediate incentive for job seekers who

Speaker: NA
Text: miss appointments to re-engage quickly.

Speaker: NA
Text: When a job seeker's payment is suspended

Speaker: NA
Text: following a missed appointment, they get all

Speaker: NA
Text: their money back once they do what is

Speaker: NA
Text: required of them. This is an effective way of

Speaker: NA
Text: encouraging compliance without taking the

Speaker: NA
Text: punitive approach of immediately applying a

Speaker: NA
Text: penalty that the job seeker cannot get back.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Disney report into job seeker

Speaker: NA
Text: compliance, released in September 2010,

Speaker: NA
Text: recommended that the government consider

Speaker: NA
Text: introducing payment suspensions if the

Speaker: NA
Text: attendance rate at provider appointments did

Speaker: NA
Text: not significantly improve within 12 months

Speaker: NA
Text: or so. Although the tougher rules measure

Speaker: NA
Text: was announced before the report was

Speaker: NA
Text: released, recent appointment attendance data

Speaker: NA
Text: suggests that this pre-emptive approach is

Speaker: NA
Text: justified.

Speaker: NA
Text: Just today the House Standing Committee

Speaker: NA
Text: on Education and Employment tabled its

Speaker: NA
Text: advisory report on this bill. The committee's

Speaker: NA
Text: chair, the member for Kingston, has said in

Speaker: NA
Text: the report that the importance of fostering

Speaker: NA
Text: and enhancing employment participation

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot be overstated. The member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Kingston also said:

Speaker: NA
Text: The benefits of employment stretch far beyond

Speaker: NA
Text: the receipt of a pay packet. Employment

Speaker: NA
Text: participation brings not only economic security,

Speaker: NA
Text: but also dignity, purpose, and direction. A central

Speaker: NA
Text: element of fostering employment participation is

Speaker: NA
Text: encouraging job seekers to communicate and

Speaker: NA
Text: interact with employment service providers

Speaker: NA
Text: through attendance at appointments. The bill

Speaker: NA
Text: seeks to encourage job seekers to do this.

Speaker: NA
Text: Specifically, the committee recommended

Speaker: NA
Text: that a plain English redrafting of the changes

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed by the bill be produced to combat

Speaker: NA
Text: the existing complexity of the social security

Speaker: NA
Text: system and ensure that job seekers fully

Speaker: NA
Text: understand their obligations under the

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed changes.

Speaker: NA
Text: The committee also recommended that the

Speaker: NA
Text: word 'special' be removed from the proposed

Speaker: NA
Text: reasonable excuse provision in the bill in

Speaker: NA
Text: order to eliminate an unnecessary layer of

Speaker: NA
Text: complexity and ensure equitable and clear

Speaker: NA
Text: implementation of the measures proposed by

Speaker: NA
Text: the bill. Other areas of interest highlighted

Speaker: NA
Text: by the committee include the development of

Speaker: NA
Text: consistent guidance and training material for

Speaker: NA
Text: front-line staff; the provision of

Speaker: NA
Text: comprehensive training to front-line staff;

Speaker: NA
Text: the collection of data on why job seekers

Speaker: NA
Text: miss appointments without a reasonable

Speaker: NA
Text: excuse and the undertaking of a review of

Speaker: NA
Text: the impact of the measures proposed by the

Speaker: NA
Text: bill; the provision of additional training and

Speaker: NA
Text: guidance to front-line staff in relation to

Speaker: NA
Text: vulnerable job seekers; and, the monitoring

Speaker: NA
Text: of possible increased workloads for front-

Speaker: NA
Text: line staff.

Speaker: NA
Text: The amendments in this bill will enhance

Speaker: NA
Text: the current job seeker compliance framework

Speaker: NA
Text: by providing additional incentives for job

Speaker: NA
Text: seekers to engage with their employment

Speaker: NA
Text: services providers and to participate fully in

Speaker: NA
Text: activities designed to improve their

Speaker: NA
Text: employment prospects. Immediate

Speaker: NA
Text: suspension of payment, either with full back

Speaker: NA
Text: payment on compliance or with resumption

Speaker: NA
Text: of payment upon compliance, is consistent

Speaker: NA
Text: with the government's broad approach to job

Speaker: NA
Text: seeker compliance, which focuses on early

Speaker: NA
Text: intervention and the use of immediate

Speaker: NA
Text: corrective action to keep job seekers on the

Speaker: NA
Text: right path. The amendments should simplify

Speaker: NA
Text: the system for job seekers in that the

Speaker: NA
Text: consequences of not attending appointments

Speaker: NA
Text: and activities will be clearer and more

Speaker: NA
Text: immediate. These amendments are not

Speaker: NA
Text: intended to increase penalty numbers per se.

Speaker: NA
Text: The principle that no job seeker should

Speaker: NA
Text: actually lose payment without warning or a

Speaker: NA
Text: second chance to comply will remain in

Speaker: NA
Text: place.

Speaker: NA
Text: Employment services providers will still

Speaker: NA
Text: have the discretion not to initiate compliance

Speaker: NA
Text: action in most circumstances and will still

Speaker: NA
Text: able to use the contact request arrangements

Speaker: NA
Text: when they want Centrelink to contact a job

Speaker: NA
Text: seeker for them without taking compliance

Speaker: NA
Text: action.

Speaker: NA
Text: I was very pleased to hear in last night's

Speaker: NA
Text: budget that the Wyong local government

Speaker: NA
Text: area which takes up most of my electorate on

Speaker: NA
Text: the New South Wales Central Coast has been

Speaker: NA
Text: chosen for extra help in getting young

Speaker: NA
Text: parents and families skilled up and educated

Speaker: NA
Text: so they can enter the workforce. This is the

Speaker: NA
Text: other side of getting people into jobs which

Speaker: NA
Text: the member for Gippsland highlighted in

Speaker: NA
Text: relation to saying that there needs to be

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunities for jobs and there needs to be

Speaker: NA
Text: education. The Wyong local government

Speaker: NA
Text: area has been chosen from just 10 areas

Speaker: NA
Text: around Australia to receive a $304 million

Speaker: NA
Text: boost in the budget for this help. The

Speaker: NA
Text: comprehensive package recognises the skills

Speaker: NA
Text: and employment disadvantages of the area

Speaker: NA
Text: and has been specifically designed to help

Speaker: NA
Text: boost job rate numbers in Wyong shire.

Speaker: NA
Text: Again, I go back to the contribution of the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Gippsland when he said that the

Speaker: NA
Text: best solutions in relation to jobs are local.

Speaker: NA
Text: The announcement last night in the budget in

Speaker: NA
Text: relation to these 10 areas-the 10 worst-hit

Speaker: NA
Text: areas in relation to employment-was that

Speaker: NA
Text: local solutions were going to be developed

Speaker: NA
Text: with this money. We are looking forward to

Speaker: NA
Text: these local solutions in the Wyong shire. I

Speaker: NA
Text: am sure, as I mentioned earlier, that when

Speaker: NA
Text: the appropriation documents and all the

Speaker: NA
Text: measures of the budget come into this House

Speaker: NA
Text: we will welcome the member for Gippsland

Speaker: NA
Text: over to this side to vote in support of those

Speaker: NA
Text: documents, given the statements that he

Speaker: NA
Text: made in his contribution to this debate.

Speaker: NA
Text: The comprehensive package that was

Speaker: NA
Text: announced last night recognises the skills

Speaker: NA
Text: and employment disadvantage of the area

Speaker: NA
Text: be that I represent and it is designed to boost

Speaker: NA
Text: jobs in that area. This is great news for my

Speaker: NA
Text: area, which has long been disadvantaged

Speaker: NA
Text: with low education and skill levels and has

Speaker: NA
Text: previously missed out on the sort of help

Speaker: NA
Text: needed to get us on par with many other

Speaker: NA
Text: regions in Australia in relation to

Speaker: NA
Text: employment.

Speaker: NA
Text: We know that many teenage parents leave

Speaker: NA
Text: school early without year 12 qualifications

Speaker: NA
Text: and end up as long-term welfare recipients,

Speaker: NA
Text: with negative consequences for them, their

Speaker: NA
Text: children and their families. The new package

Speaker: NA
Text: announced in the budget will help teenage

Speaker: NA
Text: parents in Wyong get a better job so that they

Speaker: NA
Text: can provide for their children as they grow

Speaker: NA
Text: older. From 1 January 2012, teenage parents

Speaker: NA
Text: in the Wyong LGA who have not finished

Speaker: NA
Text: year 12 or equivalent and are receiving the

Speaker: NA
Text: government's parenting payment will need to

Speaker: NA
Text: meet an individually crafted participation

Speaker: NA
Text: plan.

Speaker: NA
Text: But this is not just about toughening up

Speaker: NA
Text: the rules for job seekers; they will also be

Speaker: NA
Text: given support to help them meet their extra

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibilities and milestones. In Wyong,

Speaker: NA
Text: support for teenage parents will include

Speaker: NA
Text: access to quality child care while they are

Speaker: NA
Text: studying or training, with close to 100 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent of their childcare costs covered. They

Speaker: NA
Text: will also receive support from Youth

Speaker: NA
Text: Connections services to help them enrol in

Speaker: NA
Text: and attend school, TAFE or other training.

Speaker: NA
