Text: And teens will also be supported with their

Speaker: NA
Text: parenting responsibilities through play

Speaker: NA
Text: groups, parenting education classes, early

Speaker: NA
Text: learning programs and mentoring.

Speaker: NA
Text: This package supports young parents to

Speaker: NA
Text: engage their children in early education, and

Speaker: NA
Text: development opportunities to gain skills and

Speaker: NA
Text: education for themselves. It enables teenage

Speaker: NA
Text: parents to position themselves to enter the

Speaker: NA
Text: labour market once their youngest child is

Speaker: NA
Text: aged six, when participation requirements

Speaker: NA
Text: mean they need to commence at least part-

Speaker: NA
Text: time work. The measures support families

Speaker: NA
Text: who are at risk of disadvantage by ensuring

Speaker: NA
Text: they will have access to the services they

Speaker: NA
Text: need to fulfil their goals. The measures

Speaker: NA
Text: achieve this in a way that recognises the

Speaker: NA
Text: autonomy of parents and their responsibility

Speaker: NA
Text: to provide for their children. The $304

Speaker: NA
Text: million package provides for several

Speaker: NA
Text: initiatives across the 10 places and of

Speaker: NA
Text: includes the Wyong LGA.

Speaker: NA
Text: The budget last night and this legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: here today are both part of a government

Speaker: NA
Text: strategy that looks at making sure that

Speaker: NA
Text: individuals take responsibility for their own

Speaker: NA
Text: actions in terms of participating. The

Speaker: NA
Text: changes to this bill that we are talking

Speaker: NA
Text: today but also the measures that were

Speaker: NA
Text: announced in the budget last night look at

Speaker: NA
Text: making sure they have the absolutely

Speaker: NA
Text: essential opportunities, support, mentoring

Speaker: NA
Text: and ability to gain skills that mean they will

Speaker: NA
Text: be able to go into gainful employment. This

Speaker: NA
Text: bill also places an emphasis on responsibility

Speaker: NA
Text: for attendance.

Speaker: NA
Text: Getting Australians into the workforce is a

Speaker: NA
Text: matter of personal dignity for those who are

Speaker: NA
Text: out of work at the moment. It is an

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity for them and their families to be

Speaker: NA
Text: provided for and an opportunity for this

Speaker: NA
Text: country. With 4.9 per cent unemployment at

Speaker: NA
Text: the moment and a tightening labour market,

Speaker: NA
Text: we need increased participation rates. So

Speaker: NA
Text: everyone wins in making sure we get people

Speaker: NA
Text: out of the dole queues and into employment.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is why the measures that this

Speaker: NA
Text: government has introduced both in this bill

Speaker: NA
Text: and also, most importantly, through the

Speaker: NA
Text: budget last night are ones that anyone in this

Speaker: NA
Text: place who is interested in getting people

Speaker: NA
Text: back into employment should be supporting.

Speaker: NA
Text: So I look forward to the support of both sides

Speaker: NA
Text: for this bill but, as importantly, I look

Speaker: NA
Text: forward to the support of everyone in this

Speaker: NA
Text: parliament for the measures announced last

Speaker: NA
Text: night by the Treasurer to make sure that we

Speaker: NA
Text: help Australians get back into the workforce

Speaker: NA
Text: and get jobs in which they can truly

Speaker: NA
Text: participate in this economy. I commend this

Speaker: NA
Text: bill to the House.

Speaker: Mr RAMSEY
Text: Grey) (17:35): I rise in

Speaker: NA
Text: support of the Social Security Legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: Amendment (Job Seeker Compliance) Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: 2011. The greatest piece of welfare any

Speaker: NA
Text: course government or any person can give to

Speaker: NA
Text: another is in fact a job. It is a plain truth,

Speaker: NA
Text: because we know that with a job comes a

Speaker: NA
Text: whole raft of other things like self-respect,

Speaker: NA
Text: better education for your children and more

Speaker: NA
Text: likely better health outcomes. A job is the

Speaker: NA
Text: most important thing to improve the standard

Speaker: NA
Text: about of living of any Australian or, indeed,

Speaker: NA
Text: anyone in the world.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am privileged to be the Deputy Chair of

Speaker: NA
Text: the House Standing Committee on Education

Speaker: NA
Text: and Employment. We were responsible for

Speaker: NA
Text: the review that was done on this legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: and the recommendations that came back to

Speaker: NA
Text: the House. We thought it was reasonably cut

Speaker: NA
Text: and dried in that we had flagged on this side

Speaker: NA
Text: of the House that we were in general in

Speaker: NA
Text: support of the government's legislation. But

Speaker: NA
Text: in the end the review process was quite

Speaker: NA
Text: beneficial to the legislation in general and

Speaker: NA
Text: certainly in drawing up the guidelines of the

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation. I believe there may even be a

Speaker: NA
Text: small amendment moved at the completion

Speaker: NA
Text: of this debate to one of the terms. But in

Speaker: NA
Text: particular it gave an opportunity for the

Speaker: NA
Text: industry to air some of their concerns and

Speaker: NA
Text: ongoing issues with the way the job seeker

Speaker: NA
Text: arrangements are dealt with, and it gave us

Speaker: NA
Text: an opportunity to express the view that the

Speaker: NA
Text: language should be very clear and that

Speaker: NA
Text: people should understand what is going on

Speaker: NA
Text: here. One of the recommendations was that

Speaker: NA
Text: things should be in plain English because

Speaker: NA
Text: often the people dealing with it at this end of

Speaker: NA
Text: the field are not well educated and they need

Speaker: NA
Text: to easily understand what is going on.

Speaker: NA
Text: Another interesting thing for the

Speaker: NA
Text: committee was the quite wide support

Speaker: NA
Text: through the industry, if not the welfare lobby

Speaker: NA
Text: organisations, for this move to tighten up

Speaker: NA
Text: these obligations. We recommended there be

Speaker: NA
Text: a comprehensive training package and the

Speaker: NA
Text: department be required to collect data on the

Speaker: NA
Text: reasons why people are no-shows for

Speaker: NA
Text: interviews and appointments so that we can

Speaker: NA
Text: better understand what it is that drives them

Speaker: NA
Text: and perhaps find better ways to get them to

Speaker: NA
Text: participate. In the end, you cannot give

Speaker: NA
Text: people a job if they are not prepared to

Speaker: NA
Text: participate or are not interested in

Speaker: NA
Text: participating in the process.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of the other recommendations was

Speaker: NA
Text: after a full year of operation, the data be

Speaker: NA
Text: analysed and the department have another

Speaker: NA
Text: look at how the regime is operating. There

Speaker: NA
Text: was also a recommendation concerning

Speaker: NA
Text: vulnerable job seekers. Initially I was a

Speaker: NA
Text: concerned about this insofar as it sounded

Speaker: NA
Text: like a watering down of the process, but

Speaker: NA
Text: when we consider what a vulnerable job

Speaker: NA
Text: seeker is this recommendation has merit.

Speaker: NA
Text: They may not have a home or may have a

Speaker: NA
Text: mental disability, so I think the

Speaker: NA
Text: recommendation is well founded. We must

Speaker: NA
Text: be very careful not to alienate those who are

Speaker: NA
Text: unable to help themselves in this process. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is very much pointed at getting those who

Speaker: NA
Text: are able to help themselves and better

Speaker: NA
Text: themselves involved in the process and

Speaker: NA
Text: making sure they make the most of their

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunities.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are some confusing messages here.

Speaker: NA
Text: While we support the government's

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation, there have been quite a few times

Speaker: NA
Text: when this government has sent mixed

Speaker: NA
Text: messages to the electorate and to the people

Speaker: NA
Text: at large. I remind the House that the Rudd

Speaker: NA
Text: government watered down the terms of

Speaker: NA
Text: mutual obligation in 2008, and how the

Speaker: NA
Text: government must sometimes wish that they

Speaker: NA
Text: had left well enough alone with some

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation. If we turn our minds to the

Speaker: NA
Text: current interceptions of people trying to

Speaker: NA
Text: come to Australia in boats, perhaps the

Speaker: NA
Text: government may reflect that some of the

Speaker: NA
Text: settings that were on the clock when they

Speaker: NA
Text: took over the job 3½ years ago were in fact

Speaker: NA
Text: good models. They may well look back on

Speaker: NA
Text: mutual obligation in the same way.

Speaker: NA
Text: In a very closely related field, I am

Speaker: NA
Text: reminded that the government also relaxed

Speaker: NA
Text: the regime surrounding the Work for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Dole program at about the same time, in

Speaker: NA
Text: 2008. Previously, if someone had been on

Speaker: NA
Text: the dole for six months they may have been

Speaker: NA
Text: required to attend a Work for the Dole

Speaker: NA
Text: program. That was changed to 12 months.

Speaker: NA
Text: That may not seem all that much of a

Speaker: NA
Text: change, on the face of it, but I have talked to

Speaker: NA
Text: little a number of people who have coordinated

Speaker: NA
Text: Work for the Dole groups, and the program

Speaker: NA
Text: has been gutted as a result of that change.

Speaker: NA
Text: Because there was that six-month break, they

Speaker: NA
Text: ran out of customers. The work crews were

Speaker: NA
Text: abandoned and those who were running the

Speaker: NA
Text: work crews moved off to find new

Speaker: NA
Text: employment. It is just not that easy to line

Speaker: NA
Text: some of these things up again in a hurry. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor Party has long been uncomfortable

Speaker: NA
Text: with Work for the Dole provisions, but it has

Speaker: NA
Text: been a very popular program-and not only

Speaker: NA
Text: popular; it has been instrumental in engaging

Speaker: NA
Text: those people who were choosing to be

Speaker: NA
Text: unengaged in the process. While that does

Speaker: NA
Text: not strictly relate to this part of the

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation, it is certainly a related issue

Speaker: NA
Text: because we are talking once again about

Speaker: NA
Text: trying to get people engaged in a process.

Speaker: NA
Text: We can put this in the context of a bucket

Speaker: NA
Text: of measures where the government have

Speaker: NA
Text: shown inconsistency. I will not go into any

Speaker: NA
Text: detail on any of them, but I simply list

Speaker: NA
Text: I mentioned the asylum seekers. The

Speaker: NA
Text: government were going to adopt the save the

Speaker: NA
Text: Murray report, but of course then they did

Speaker: NA
Text: not adopt it. They were to have a CPRS, but

Speaker: NA
Text: then they were not to have a CPRS. They

Speaker: NA
Text: were never to have a carbon tax, and now

Speaker: NA
Text: they are to have a carbon tax. They were

Speaker: NA
Text: going to have a green car, but of course now

Speaker: NA
Text: we are not going to have a green car. We

Speaker: NA
Text: were going to have cash for clunkers and

Speaker: NA
Text: now we are not. In my electorate we were to

Speaker: NA
Text: have an MRI machine and now we are not.

Speaker: NA
Text: The government were going to introduce a

Speaker: NA
Text: dental scheme, and now we find in

Speaker: NA
Text: yesterday's budget that it has been deferred.

Speaker: NA
Text: We were definitely going to have a mining

Speaker: NA
Text: tax and now we definitely may be going to

Speaker: NA
Text: have a mining tax, if the government can

Speaker: NA
Text: ever work out the detail. And we were

Speaker: NA
Text: always to have surplus budgets, but of course

Speaker: NA
Text: we have not seen one of those yet, either.

Speaker: NA
Text: I just bring these inconsistencies to this

Speaker: NA
Text: part of the debate. This is why people in the

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate, the Australian public, are

Speaker: NA
Text: becoming confused with the message. I am

Speaker: NA
Text: very happy that the government has seen the

Speaker: NA
Text: light on the issue of re-engaging those who

Speaker: NA
Text: may not wish in the first instance to seek a

Speaker: NA
Text: job, to get them back on board. That is why I

Speaker: NA
Text: am happy to support the legislation, but the

Speaker: NA
Text: government should take great care before it

Speaker: NA
Text: mucks around with things that are working

Speaker: NA
Text: okay.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mrs D'ATH (Petrie) (17:43): It is my

Speaker: NA
Text: pleasure to speak in support of the Social

Speaker: NA
Text: Security Legislation Amendment (Job

Speaker: NA
Text: Seeker Compliance) Bill 2011. This is

Speaker: NA
Text: certainly an important bill and it fits in very

Speaker: NA
Text: well with the budget announcements made

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Treasurer last night. It is important

Speaker: NA
Text: because it seeks to enhance the current job

Speaker: NA
Text: seeker compliance framework. The bill has

Speaker: NA
Text: come about as part of the Modernising

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's Welfare System program that the

Speaker: NA
Text: them. government announced on 11 August 2010.

Speaker: NA
Text: The government made a commitment at that

Speaker: NA
Text: time to introduce tougher rules for job

Speaker: NA
Text: seekers from 1 July 2011. Well, here we are,

Speaker: NA
Text: once again fulfilling a commitment that we

Speaker: NA
Text: have made to ensure that we do introduce

Speaker: NA
Text: tougher rules for job seekers and to deliver

Speaker: NA
Text: those rules from the 1 July 2011

Speaker: NA
Text: commencement date.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have heard a fair bit from those on the

Speaker: NA
Text: other side, including the member for Grey,

Speaker: NA
Text: about changes that the government made

Speaker: NA
Text: back in 2008 in relation to re-engaging

Speaker: NA
Text: workers. That those on the other side have

Speaker: NA
Text: failed to mention on each and every occasion

Speaker: NA
Text: that they have spoken on this bill and on the

Speaker: NA
Text: changes made in 2008-and we know they

Speaker: NA
Text: do not like to talk about this issue-is the

Speaker: NA
Text: fact that there was a global financial crisis

Speaker: NA
Text: occurring at that time. Consequently,

Speaker: NA
Text: because of the risks of job losses occurring at

Speaker: NA
Text: that time, there were changes made in

Speaker: NA
Text: relation to programs dealing with the

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployed to provide greater flexibility

Speaker: NA
Text: during those very difficult times for our

Speaker: NA
Text: economy. We are fortunate now, in 2011, to

Speaker: NA
Text: be in a position where unemployment is

Speaker: NA
Text: down to 4.9 per cent. We have a skills

Speaker: NA
Text: shortage and we have people in our society

Speaker: NA
Text: right now, in our local communities, who can

Speaker: NA
Text: re-engage with the workforce. Our job now

Speaker: NA
Text: as a government is to look at how we can set

Speaker: NA
Text: in place a framework that provides

Speaker: NA
Text: incentives to get those people to re-engage.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is what this bill seeks to do.

Speaker: NA
Text: Yes, it does put in place punitive measures

Speaker: NA
Text: if people seek to ignore their responsibilities

Speaker: NA
Text: in relation to trying to re-engage where they

Speaker: NA
Text: are capable of doing so. This bill aims to get

Speaker: NA
Text: job seekers to participate fully in activities

Speaker: NA
Text: designed to improve employment prospects.

Speaker: NA
Text: The mechanism that it seeks to use is to say

Speaker: NA
Text: that when a person does not attend an

Speaker: NA
Text: interview or an appointment then they will

Speaker: NA
Text: have their entitlements suspended. That only

Speaker: NA
Text: occurs if the individual does not notify that

Speaker: NA
Text: they cannot make the appointment. So it is

Speaker: NA
Text: not a case of simply being unavailable to

Speaker: NA
Text: attend an appointment; it is only in

Speaker: NA
Text: circumstances where they fail to give any

Speaker: NA
Text: reasonable excuse for not attending or fail to

Speaker: NA
Text: make any contact. There is a safety

Speaker: NA
Text: mechanism there that, if they reschedule and

Speaker: NA
Text: they attend that next appointment, they will

Speaker: NA
Text: get the money reimbursed. However, if they

Speaker: NA
Text: reschedule and once again fail to attend,

Speaker: NA
Text: there can be a suspension of their payments

Speaker: NA
Text: and a reconnection failure.

Speaker: NA
Text: So there is a punitive mechanism to say

Speaker: NA
Text: that you will have to sacrifice some of your

Speaker: NA
Text: entitlements if you do not seek to re-engage

Speaker: NA
Text: and you are capable of re-engaging. The

Speaker: NA
Text: government have said that we recognise the

Speaker: NA
Text: benefits and the dignity that come with work.

Speaker: NA
Text: We want to ensure that those who are

Speaker: NA
Text: currently not engaged in the workforce make

Speaker: NA
Text: all reasonable efforts to re-engage and that

Speaker: NA
Text: they understand the responsibility that comes

Speaker: NA
Text: with making appointments and attending

Speaker: NA
Text: those appointments whenever possible. Like

Speaker: NA
Text: any worker with a job, if you are unable to

Speaker: NA
Text: attend then you must make contact. If you

Speaker: NA
Text: have a job and you cannot go to work that

Speaker: NA
Text: day, it is unacceptable to just not turn up.

Speaker: NA
Text: You must make contact. Those who are not

Speaker: NA
Text: in the workforce must recognise that they

Speaker: NA
Text: have an equal responsibility if they cannot

Speaker: NA
Text: make an appointment. It is important,

Speaker: NA
Text: however, that we point out that there is still

Speaker: NA
Text: discretion with the employment service

Speaker: NA
Text: providers in relation to whether they issue a

Speaker: NA
Text: participation report. It is important that they

Speaker: NA
Text: use their discretion in relation to vulnerable

Speaker: NA
Text: job seekers and that they use every

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity and mechanism to help re-

Speaker: NA
Text: engage those workers in the workforce. We

Speaker: NA
Text: must ensure that those vulnerable job seekers

Speaker: NA
Text: are considered in relation to this bill.

Speaker: NA
Text: I will also make mention of the House of

Speaker: NA
Text: Representatives Standing Committee on

Speaker: NA
Text: Education and Employment, of which the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Grey is the deputy chair and the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Kingston is the chair. I am also a

Speaker: NA
Text: member of that House standing committee.

Speaker: NA
Text: Some very important evidence came from

Speaker: NA
Text: the inquiry into this bill. The evidence that

Speaker: NA
Text: was gathered and the comments of the

Speaker: NA
Text: committee have been detailed in our report,

Speaker: NA
Text: which was tabled this morning in this House.

Speaker: NA
Text: But what is important to note in the report of

Speaker: NA
Text: the committee are some of the mechanisms

Speaker: NA
Text: that the committee has recommended

Speaker: NA
Text: underpin this bill. They relate to ensuring

Speaker: NA
Text: consistency in guidelines across Centrelink

Speaker: NA
Text: and the employment service providers, and

Speaker: NA
Text: training on the system to ensure that it is

Speaker: NA
Text: implemented correctly and fairly.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is important that we make sure that

Speaker: NA
Text: there is support for Centrelink staff in

Speaker: NA
Text: relation to workloads arising from this

Speaker: NA
Text: mechanism. We should also make sure that

Speaker: NA
Text: there is proper guidance for the Centrelink

Speaker: NA
Text: staff on how to implement this legislation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Those comments, of course, should apply in

Speaker: NA
Text: regard to all programs that employment

Speaker: NA
Text: service providers and Centrelink implement.

Speaker: NA
Text: We should ensure there is consistent

Speaker: NA
Text: guidance. We should ensure that there is

Speaker: NA
Text: comprehensive training provided so that the

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation is implemented in the way it was

Speaker: NA
Text: intended, that it is being implemented fairly

Speaker: NA
Text: and that discretion is being used in an

Speaker: NA
Text: appropriate way.

Speaker: NA
Text: We note in relation to that discretion that

Speaker: NA
Text: we should be making sure that Centrelink

Speaker: NA
Text: staff and employment service providers are

Speaker: NA
Text: adequately trained and aware of the

Speaker: NA
Text: possibility that job seekers have undisclosed

Speaker: NA
Text: vulnerabilities. This is a very difficult area.

Speaker: NA
Text: A job seeker may not necessarily identify

Speaker: NA
Text: that they are vulnerable, whether because of

Speaker: NA
Text: a health condition, family circumstances or

Speaker: NA
Text: other circumstances. We need to better train

Speaker: NA
Text: our Centrelink staff to raise their awareness

Speaker: NA
Text: of those undisclosed vulnerabilities, to train

Speaker: NA
Text: them to assist those people and to manage

Speaker: NA
Text: the situation and those people's needs

Speaker: NA
Text: appropriately.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are two other recommendations I

Speaker: NA
Text: want to make mention of. Firstly, the

Speaker: NA
Text: committee recommended that

Speaker: NA
Text: Department of Education, Employment and

Speaker: NA
Text: Workplace Relations and the Department of

Speaker: NA
Text: Human Services collect and publish data in

Speaker: NA
Text: relation to why job seekers without

Speaker: NA
Text: reasonable excuses miss appointments. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: accurate-and those members who have

Speaker: NA
Text: spoken who have read this report or who are

Speaker: NA
Text: committee members have already drawn this

Speaker: NA
Text: House's attention to the fact-that there is

Speaker: NA
Text: very little data that is collected and published

Speaker: NA
Text: and in some areas there is basically no data

Speaker: NA
Text: on reasons for missed appointments. This

Speaker: NA
Text: data is important for us to ensure that the

Speaker: NA
Text: programs we put in place are adequate. To

Speaker: NA
Text: get the outcomes that we seek we need to be

Speaker: NA
Text: able to collect and publish that data and be

Speaker: NA
Text: tracking that data and looking at the

Speaker: NA
Text: outcomes.

Speaker: NA
Text: The other recommendation, which is

Speaker: NA
Text: recommendation 1 in the report, is that a

Speaker: NA
Text: brief, plain English explanation of the

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed changes and the obligations that

Speaker: NA
Text: will stem from them be produced and made

Speaker: NA
Text: available to all job seekers as soon as

Speaker: NA
Text: practicable. You might say, 'Well, it's just

Speaker: NA
Text: obvious that we would do that.' But the

Speaker: NA
Text: reality is that we need to make sure, if we are

Speaker: NA
Text: going to have these changes come about

Speaker: NA
Text: from 1 July this year, that job seekers who

Speaker: NA
Text: are going to be bound by these new job

Speaker: NA
Text: seeker compliance laws are very clear as to

Speaker: NA
Text: what they mean and what the obligations are

Speaker: NA
Text: on the individual job seeker so that they can

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure that they are complying with these

Speaker: NA
Text: requirements.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have talked generally about the bill, what

Speaker: NA
Text: it seeks to achieve and the recommendations

Speaker: NA
Text: of the committee. Before I finish may I say,

Speaker: NA
Text: and I have mentioned briefly already, that I

Speaker: NA
Text: believe this amendment to the social security

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation dealing with job seeker

Speaker: NA
Text: compliance goes hand in hand with the

Speaker: NA
Text: commitments that the Labor federal

Speaker: NA
Text: government made in the budget last night in

Speaker: NA
Text: the relation to jobs, employment, re-engaging

Speaker: NA
Text: workers, skills and incentives to

Speaker: NA
Text: employment. Looking at the incentives to

Speaker: NA
Text: employment that were announced in the

Speaker: NA
Text: budget, we are providing incentives to

Speaker: NA
Text: provide training and work experience for

Speaker: NA
Text: those very long term unemployed. I know

Speaker: NA
Text: that there are over 1,300 long-term

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployed people in the electorate of

Speaker: NA
Text: Petrie-people who have been without work

Speaker: NA
Text: for two years or more. The funding that was

Speaker: NA
Text: announced in the budget by the federal

Speaker: NA
Text: government last night will assist those

Speaker: NA
Text: people to get local employment services

Speaker: NA
Text: support through training and work

Speaker: NA
Text: experience and by providing a wage subsidy

Speaker: NA
Text: to encourage employers to engage those

Speaker: NA
Text: long-term unemployed people. That works

Speaker: NA
Text: hand in hand with the job seeker compliance

Speaker: NA
Text: and trying to get the unemployed re-

Speaker: NA
Text: engaging with the workforce.

Speaker: NA
Text: Of course, that was not the only

Speaker: NA
Text: announcement in relation to supporting jobs

Speaker: NA
Text: and trying to increase skills in our

Speaker: NA
Text: workforce. We announced improved

Speaker: NA
Text: incentives in the tax system and we

Speaker: NA
Text: announced restructuring of income support

Speaker: NA
Text: for single parents to promote and support

Speaker: NA
Text: participation by providing, from 1 January

Speaker: NA
Text: 2013, single parents on Newstart allowance

Speaker: NA
Text: with up to an extra $3,900 per year through a

Speaker: NA
Text: more generous income test, at the same time

Speaker: NA
Text: that grandfathering will be phased out for

Speaker: NA
Text: parenting payment recipients when their

Speaker: NA
Text: child turns 12 to more closely align

Speaker: NA
Text: eligibility with other recipients. Importantly,

Speaker: NA
Text: the government will also provide up to $103

Speaker: NA
Text: million to support single parents through

Speaker: NA
Text: training, career advice and other services.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is another way of re-engaging people

Speaker: NA
Text: with the workforce.

Speaker: NA
Text: We are implementing new initiatives to

Speaker: NA
Text: introduce participation requirements for

Speaker: NA
Text: people with disabilities. I know there are

Speaker: NA
Text: people with disabilities in my electorate who

Speaker: NA
Text: want to re-engage in the workforce. We need

Speaker: NA
Text: to provide them with the assistance to do so.

Speaker: NA
Text: We need to provide support and

Speaker: NA
Text: encouragement to employers to hire those

Speaker: NA
Text: people. We have new programs. We are

Speaker: NA
Text: extending the government's 'earn or learn'

Speaker: NA
Text: requirements to those aged 21. This is part of

Speaker: NA
Text: the broader changes to the youth allowance

Speaker: NA
Text: which will delay eligibility for Newstart

Speaker: NA
Text: allowance by one year and reward young

Speaker: NA
Text: workers with a more generous income test.

Speaker: NA
Text: Again ,we are trying to encourage those

Speaker: NA
Text: young people who have left school to get

Speaker: NA
Text: into the workforce or to take on further

Speaker: NA
Text: education.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have already announced the initiatives in

Speaker: NA
Text: relation to the very long term unemployed,

Speaker: NA
Text: and we will have a new approach to

Speaker: NA
Text: disadvantaged locations. I think that these

Speaker: NA
Text: initiatives announced in the budget by a

Speaker: NA
Text: federal Labor government-and it would

Speaker: NA
Text: only be a federal Labor government that

Speaker: NA
Text: would implement such initiatives to ensure

Speaker: NA
Text: that workers re-engage-complement what

Speaker: NA
Text: we are now debating in this House in relation

Speaker: NA
Text: to job seeker compliance and will help

Speaker: NA
Text: people in our communities to ensure that

Speaker: NA
Text: they can have the dignity of work.

Speaker: Ms HALL
Text: Shortland-Government

Speaker: NA
Text: Whip) (17:58): I rise to support the Social

Speaker: NA
Text: Security Legislation Amendment (Job

Speaker: NA
Text: Seeker Compliance) Bill 2011. In doing so, I

Speaker: NA
Text: would like to put on record my strong

Speaker: NA
Text: support for all initiatives that help people

Speaker: NA
Text: move from welfare to work. In my previous

Speaker: NA
Text: life before entering parliament, I worked

Speaker: NA
Text: with job seekers, both those that were in

Speaker: NA
Text: receipt of disability support pension and

Speaker: NA
Text: those that were disadvantaged and long-term

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployed, so I know that there are a

Speaker: NA
Text: number of issues that impact on their ability

Speaker: NA
Text: to move from welfare to work. I am pleased

Speaker: NA
Text: that this legislation was referred to the House

Speaker: NA
Text: of Representatives Standing Committee on

Speaker: NA
Text: Education and Employment and I support the

Speaker: NA
Text: recommendations of the committee.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is imperative that legislation and

Speaker: NA
Text: information that is given to job seekers be in

Speaker: NA
Text: plain English. It is important that the people

Speaker: NA
Text: who are involved in implementing this

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation develop and follow consistent

Speaker: NA
Text: guidelines and that there is training material

Speaker: NA
Text: that accompanies the bill. It is also important

Speaker: NA
Text: that Centrelink and employment services

Speaker: NA
Text: staff are provided with comprehensive

Speaker: NA
Text: training, as is the committee's

Speaker: NA
Text: recommendation. It is also important that

Speaker: NA
Text: employment providers be given clear and

Speaker: NA
Text: comprehensive guidelines in relation to this

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation. It is interesting that the

Speaker: NA
Text: committee recommends that the Department

Speaker: NA
Text: of Education, Employment and Workplace

Speaker: NA
Text: Relations and the Department of Human

Speaker: NA
Text: Services collect and publish data on the

Speaker: NA
Text: reasons why job seekers miss appointments

Speaker: NA
Text: without reasonable excuses. The committee

Speaker: NA
Text: also recommends that the department

Speaker: NA
Text: undertake a review of the impact of these

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed changes and that employment

Speaker: NA
Text: service providers be advised to utilise all

Speaker: NA
Text: engagement mechanisms available to them in

Speaker: NA
Text: relation to vulnerable job seekers.

Speaker: NA
Text: The committee recommends

Speaker: NA
Text: additional training and resources be provided

Speaker: NA
Text: to Centrelink staff. That is probably a very

Speaker: NA
Text: good point for me to come in on. Since this

Speaker: NA
Text: bill was introduced into the parliament I have

Speaker: NA
Text: spent quite a bit of time liaising with officers

Speaker: NA
Text: who work in the Centrelink offices in my

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate. They have expressed some

Speaker: NA
Text: concern to me about this legislation and the

Speaker: NA
Text: impact it will have on their workload and on

Speaker: NA
Text: a certain subset of job seekers. I am sure that

Speaker: NA
Text: those issues that have been raised by

Speaker: NA
Text: Centrelink staff, people who work each and

Speaker: NA
Text: every day with the long-term unemployed

Speaker: NA
Text: and people who are failing to attend

Speaker: NA
Text: appointments, will be looked at during the

Speaker: NA
Text: review.

Speaker: NA
Text: I should also put on the record that I have

Speaker: NA
Text: been speaking with a number of job service

Speaker: NA
Text: providers within my electorate. We are

Speaker: NA
Text: working on a very innovative program in a

Speaker: NA
Text: very disadvantaged area of my electorate,

Speaker: NA
Text: probably the most disadvantaged area in the

Speaker: NA
Text: whole of Australia, on a number of issues

Speaker: NA
Text: that are preventing people from returning to

Speaker: NA
Text: work. The majority of the population in that

Speaker: NA
Text: area are on some sort of Centrelink payment.

Speaker: NA
Text: We are working together to try to develop an

Speaker: NA
Text: innovative approach with job seeker

Speaker: NA
Text: providers across state and federal and even

Speaker: NA
Text: local government lines to see whether we can

Speaker: NA
Text: come up with an approach that will help

Speaker: NA
Text: people.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do have a little concern that perhaps

Speaker: NA
Text: some people will have their payments

Speaker: NA
Text: suspended for a variety of reasons. People

Speaker: NA
Text: can have their payments cancelled because

Speaker: NA
Text: of circumstances beyond their control. We

Speaker: NA
Text: all know that getting payments reinstated can

Speaker: NA
Text: be a rather cumbersome process. I am sure

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Minister for Employment

Speaker: NA
Text: Participation and Childcare will be looking

Speaker: NA
Text: re- at this issue very carefully in the review. I

Speaker: NA
Text: think changes such as this that are designed

Speaker: NA
Text: to increase people's participation in work are

Speaker: NA
Text: that vitally important because if people do not go

Speaker: NA
Text: along to their appointments with Job

Speaker: NA
Text: Network providers then they will find it very

Speaker: NA
Text: difficult to move from welfare to work. We

Speaker: NA
Text: just have to be very mindful that, with

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation such as this, we are not actually

Speaker: NA
Text: going to put in place barriers that will

Speaker: NA
Text: achieve a perverse outcome, the opposite

Speaker: NA
Text: outcome to the one we are seeking to

Speaker: NA
Text: achieve. For some people it will facilitate

Speaker: NA
Text: their meeting those appointments, but others

Speaker: NA
Text: may be faced with the situation where they

Speaker: NA
Text: get a call to go to work late in the day and

Speaker: NA
Text: they have to decide, 'Do I turn down paid

Speaker: NA
Text: work because I can't contact the Centrelink

Speaker: NA
Text: office before I go to work or during that

Speaker: NA
Text: time, or do I go to work and then miss the

Speaker: NA
Text: appointment and have to go through the

Speaker: NA
Text: process of having Centrelink payments

Speaker: NA
Text: reinstated?' which they would have to go

Speaker: NA
Text: through because it is a valid excuse.

Speaker: NA
Text: Maybe there will need to be some

Speaker: NA
Text: finetuning of this legislation further down

Speaker: NA
Text: the track. I support initiatives that will assist

Speaker: NA
Text: people to move from welfare to work. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: vitally important. We have a skills shortage.

Speaker: NA
Text: I welcome a number of the initiatives in the

Speaker: NA
Text: budget that are designed to assist the long-

Speaker: NA
Text: term unemployed to move from welfare to

Speaker: NA
Text: work. I think the wage subsidy schemes that

Speaker: NA
Text: are included in the budget will assist the

Speaker: NA
Text: long-term unemployed and will redress some

Speaker: NA
Text: of the disadvantage they have when they are

Speaker: NA
Text: competing for jobs within the workforce. I

Speaker: NA
Text: have worked with job subsidy schemes in the

Speaker: NA
Text: past and I know they work. I know that

Speaker: NA
Text: people can be employed under a job subsidy

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme and then end up in a long-term job.

Speaker: NA
Text: Nothing gives a person more dignity than

Speaker: NA
Text: being able to work. But I do think that we

Speaker: NA
Text: have to monitor this legislation very closely

Speaker: NA
Text: to ensure that the people whom we are

Speaker: NA
Text: seeking to assist by encouraging them to

Speaker: NA
Text: attend appointments are not disadvantaged. I

Speaker: NA
Text: have every confidence that the minister will

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure that the department does this and that

Speaker: NA
Text: the legislation will work to benefit those

Speaker: NA
Text: people who are unemployed rather than

Speaker: NA
Text: disadvantage them.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms KATE ELLIS (Adelaide-Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for Employment Participation and Childcare

Speaker: NA
Text: and Minister for the Status of Women)

Speaker: NA
Text: (18:05): I thank all members who have

Speaker: NA
Text: contributed to this debate. Our government

Speaker: NA
Text: has both reformed employment services and

Speaker: NA
Text: invested to improve their effectiveness. In

Speaker: NA
Text: reinforcing those improvements, we

Speaker: NA
Text: introduced a new compliance system from 1

Speaker: NA
Text: July 2009. Last night, in the 2011 budget, we

Speaker: NA
Text: provided for spending over the forward

Speaker: NA
Text: estimates towards employment services of

Speaker: NA
Text: some $8.5 billion. This includes a range of

Speaker: NA
Text: new initiatives to provide greater support for

Speaker: NA
Text: the very long term unemployed, for job

Speaker: NA
Text: seekers with a disability and for those who

Speaker: NA
Text: have become disengaged. We know that with

Speaker: NA
Text: this increased support, with the opportunities

Speaker: NA
Text: that this support provides, so too comes

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility. This bill delivers on the

Speaker: NA
Text: government's election commitment to

Speaker: NA
Text: modernising Australia's welfare system and

Speaker: NA
Text: introducing tougher measures to ensure that

Speaker: NA
Text: more unemployed people are getting back

Speaker: NA
Text: into work. We have a growing economy and

Speaker: NA
Text: a strong labour market. While millions of

Speaker: NA
Text: jobs have been lost in other advanced

Speaker: NA
Text: economies, employment in Australia has

Speaker: NA
Text: increased by around 750,000 jobs since

Speaker: NA
Text: 2007, driving unemployment below five per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent. At just 4.9 per cent, Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployment rate is lower than that of

Speaker: NA
Text: almost any of the other major advanced

Speaker: NA
Text: economies. It is at this time, with lower

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployment and employers searching for

Speaker: NA
Text: new workers to come on board, that we must

Speaker: NA
Text: embrace the greater opportunities to connect

Speaker: NA
Text: job seekers with this employment market. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is crucial that we do all that we can to ensure

Speaker: NA
Text: that unemployment payment recipients are

Speaker: NA
Text: participating to the full extent of their

Speaker: NA
Text: abilities. In order to do that, we need them to

Speaker: NA
Text: be actively engaged with the employment

Speaker: NA
Text: services and support that our government

Speaker: NA
Text: provides.

Speaker: NA
Text: This bill is not about punishing job

Speaker: NA
Text: seekers who have a valid reason for missing

Speaker: NA
Text: appointments or participation in activities.

Speaker: NA
Text: The government are aware of the challenges

Speaker: NA
Text: that job seekers face and we are aware that

Speaker: NA
Text: most job seekers are genuine in their

Speaker: NA
Text: attempts to find work. However, income

Speaker: NA
Text: support does come with responsibility. A

Speaker: NA
Text: strengthening of the compliance system is

Speaker: NA
Text: warranted so that more job seekers are

Speaker: NA
Text: actively engaged in work experience

Speaker: NA
Text: activities, such as training and work for the

Speaker: NA
Text: dole, so that they are getting the skills and

Speaker: NA
Text: experience they need to find a sustainable

Speaker: NA
Text: job into the future.

Speaker: NA
Text: Throughout this debate, whilst many

Speaker: NA
Text: opposition members have repeated their

Speaker: NA
Text: party-line talking points about nonattendance

Speaker: NA
Text: being a symptom of a broken system under

Speaker: NA
Text: this government, the reality that everybody

Speaker: NA
Text: should take note of is that under the Howard

Speaker: NA
Text: government the appointment attendance rate

Speaker: NA
Text: in 2006-07 was 54 per cent. In 2009-10,

Speaker: NA
Text: under this government's compliance system,

Speaker: NA
Text: it was 58 per cent. I say this so that we have

Speaker: NA
Text: the full facts on the table, but we know that

Speaker: NA
Text: neither of these figures is good enough. We

Speaker: NA
Text: need to work to make sure that everybody is

Speaker: NA
Text: engaging in the supports that are available to

Speaker: NA
Text: them.

Speaker: NA
Text: The new arrangements seek to improve

Speaker: NA
Text: job seekers' attendance at employment

Speaker: NA
Text: services provider and related appointments.

Speaker: NA
Text: Suspension of payment provides a strong and

Speaker: NA
Text: immediate incentive for job seekers who

Speaker: NA
Text: miss appointments to re-engage quickly.

Speaker: NA
Text: When a job seeker's payment is suspended

Speaker: NA
Text: following a missed appointment, they get all

Speaker: NA
Text: of their money back once they do what is

Speaker: NA
Text: required of them: attend their appointment.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is an effective way of encouraging

Speaker: NA
Text: compliance without taking the punitive

Speaker: NA
Text: approach of immediately applying a penalty

Speaker: NA
Text: that the job seeker cannot get back. The

Speaker: NA
Text: principle that no job seeker should actually

Speaker: NA
Text: lose payment without a warning or a second

Speaker: NA
Text: chance to comply will remain in place. The

Speaker: NA
Text: current range of legislative

Speaker: NA
Text: administrative protections for vulnerable job

Speaker: NA
Text: seekers will remain in place, with the

Speaker: NA
Text: additional provision that they will not be

Speaker: NA
Text: subject to suspension of payment in the first

Speaker: NA
Text: instance.

Speaker: NA
Text: The House of Representatives Standing

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee on Education and Employment

Speaker: NA
Text: has scrutinised this bill, as recommended by

Speaker: NA
Text: this parliament, and only this morning tabled

Speaker: NA
Text: its report. I thank the members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: committee for their work and assure them

Speaker: NA
Text: that the government will give serious

Speaker: NA
Text: consideration to all of

Speaker: NA
Text: recommendations. Indeed, at first reading, I

Speaker: NA
Text: can give in-principle support to all the

Speaker: NA
Text: recommendations.

Speaker: NA
Text: On the specifics of this bill, the committee

Speaker: NA
Text: makes one specific recommendation

Speaker: NA
Text: regarding this legislation-that is, that we

Speaker: NA
Text: remove the word 'special' from the proposed

Speaker: NA
Text: subsection 42UA, where it is used to

Speaker: NA
Text: describe a situation in which a job seeker

Speaker: NA
Text: would not be expected to give prior notice of

Speaker: NA
Text: their inability to attend an appointment.

Speaker: NA
Text: Following discussions with the opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: and given that the details of circumstances

Speaker: NA
Text: that will be excepted will in fact be

Speaker: NA
Text: explained in guidelines to Centrelink, the

Speaker: NA
Text: government has no objection to this

Speaker: NA
Text: recommendation.

Speaker: NA
Text: The government has noted a number of

Speaker: NA
Text: committee recommendations around

Speaker: NA
Text: additional measures in relation to this matter.

Speaker: NA
Text: In fact, participation and compliance

Speaker: NA
Text: arrangements are important to ensuring that

Speaker: NA
Text: job seekers engage with education, training

Speaker: NA
Text: and work experience opportunities and, by

Speaker: NA
Text: working with their providers, move off

Speaker: NA
Text: income support and into paid employment.

Speaker: NA
Text: We know that the current framework is

Speaker: NA
Text: working. In 2010, 82 per cent of job seekers

Speaker: NA
Text: satisfied their requirements, with no

Speaker: NA
Text: participation reports submitted. A further

Speaker: NA
Text: and nine per cent received only one participation

Speaker: NA
Text: report. However, a small number of job

Speaker: NA
Text: seekers-in fact, just two per cent-were the

Speaker: NA
Text: subject of over one-third of participation

Speaker: NA
Text: reports for failing to meet their obligations.

Speaker: NA
Text: As I mentioned earlier, the budget

Speaker: NA
Text: introduced by the Treasurer last night

Speaker: NA
Text: included funding for a range of new

Speaker: NA
Text: employment initiatives, including some

Speaker: NA
Text: $49.8 million for job seeker compliance and

Speaker: NA
Text: participation related measures to improve

Speaker: NA
Text: and streamline the system, to provide

Speaker: NA
Text: targeted assistance to those job seekers who

Speaker: NA
Text: their are most at risk of noncompliance and

Speaker: NA
Text: disengagement and to improve our

Speaker: NA
Text: communication of these measures. The

Speaker: NA
Text: measures announced in the budget follow

Speaker: NA
Text: consideration of the recommendations of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Independent Review of the Job Seeker

Speaker: NA
Text: Compliance Framework-the Disney

Speaker: NA
Text: review. They build on the job seeker

Speaker: NA
Text: compliance bill currently before the

Speaker: NA
Text: parliament, which provides for immediate

Speaker: NA
Text: suspension of payment for nonattendance at

Speaker: NA
Text: provider appointments or activities. These

Speaker: NA
Text: budget measures and this bill are consistent

Speaker: NA
Text: with the government's approach to job seeker

Speaker: NA
Text: compliance, which focuses on early

Speaker: NA
Text: intervention and the use of immediate

Speaker: NA
Text: corrective action to keep job seekers on the

Speaker: NA
Text: right path. They will benefit job seekers,

Speaker: NA
Text: especially those who are vulnerable or

Speaker: NA
Text: disengaged. The measures will also help

Speaker: NA
Text: providers by reducing complexity and

Speaker: NA
Text: increasing transparency.

Speaker: NA
Text: All Australians on income support should

Speaker: NA
Text: have the opportunity of work, but with this

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity, of course,

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibilities. With this bill we are going

Speaker: NA
Text: to firmly expect that people meet those

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibilities. I commend the bill to the

Speaker: NA
Text: House.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Consideration in Detail

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill-by leave-taken as a whole.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms KATE ELLIS (Adelaide-Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for Employment Participation and Childcare

Speaker: NA
Text: and Minister for the Status of Women)

Speaker: NA
Text: (18:13): I present a supplementary

Speaker: NA
Text: explanatory memorandum to the bill and ask

Speaker: NA
Text: leave of the House to move government

Speaker: NA
Text: amendments (1) to (3), as circulated,

Speaker: NA
Text: together.

Speaker: NA
Text: Leave granted.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms KATE ELLIS: I move government

Speaker: NA
Text: amendments (1) to (3), as circulated,

Speaker: NA
Text: together:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) Schedule 1, item 15, page 7 (table item 1),

Speaker: NA
Text: omit "special".

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) Schedule 1, item 15, page 7 (table item

Speaker: NA
Text: omit "special".

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) Schedule 1, item 15, page 8 (table item 3),

Speaker: NA
Text: omit "special".

Speaker: Mr BANDT
Text: Melbourne) (18:14): These

Speaker: NA
Text: amendments are supported for the reasons

Speaker: NA
Text: that have been outlined by the minister. Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Deputy Speaker, with your and the House's

Speaker: NA
Text: indulgence, I seek to make a few general

Speaker: NA
Text: comments about the remaining provisions of

Speaker: NA
Text: the bill. I ought to have made them earlier

Speaker: NA
Text: but, perhaps somewhat ironically, I was late

Speaker: NA
Text: and I hope that I will not be punished on this

Speaker: NA
Text: occasion for missing that appointment.

Speaker: NA
Text: If there was ever any proof needed that

Speaker: NA
Text: evidence based policy will give way to

Speaker: NA
Text: perceived political imperative every time it is

Speaker: NA
Text: the Social Security Legislation Amendment

Speaker: NA
Text: comes (Job Seeker Compliance) Bill 2011 and the

Speaker: NA
Text: committee inquiry process that led to it,

Speaker: NA
Text: which I participated in. The aim of this bill,

Speaker: NA
Text: as has been set out by the minister, is to

Speaker: NA
Text: impose financial sanctions on people who

Speaker: NA
Text: miss appointments. One might expect, then,

Speaker: NA
Text: that there would be a significant amount of

Speaker: NA
Text: data or research done by either the

Speaker: NA
Text: government, the department or independent

Speaker: NA
Text: experts about why it is that people miss

Speaker: NA
Text: appointments. What we found, though,

Speaker: NA
Text: during the committee inquiry process is that

Speaker: NA
Text: although we knew that 20 per cent of people

Speaker: NA
Text: who miss appointments are Indigenous

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians, and although 47 per cent of

Speaker: NA
Text: them are young, we do not know why it is

Speaker: NA
Text: that they are missing appointments-no-one

Speaker: NA
Text: could tell us. Witness after witness agreed

Speaker: NA
Text: with the proposition that it would be sensible

Speaker: NA
Text: to find out why it is that people are missing

Speaker: NA
Text: appointments and then to put in place the

Speaker: NA
Text: appropriate processes to ensure that they

Speaker: NA
Text: attended those appointments.

Speaker: NA
Text: Also, almost everyone who was involved

Speaker: NA
Text: in the provision of job services appeared

Speaker: NA
Text: 2), before the inquiry-with some exceptions-

Speaker: NA
Text: to say that this would destroy the relationship

Speaker: NA
Text: of trust that job service providers had with

Speaker: NA
Text: people who were seeking employment and

Speaker: NA
Text: would make them less likely to engage, and

Speaker: NA
Text: that it might lead to instances where people

Speaker: NA
Text: decide that the whole thing is too hard and

Speaker: NA
Text: they do not want to participate in the system

Speaker: NA
Text: at all.

Speaker: NA
Text: The government based much of its

Speaker: NA
Text: justification for this bill on the independent

Speaker: NA
Text: review into the bill that it commissioned last

Speaker: NA
Text: year, which was chaired by Professor Julian

Speaker: NA
Text: Disney. Professor Disney appeared before

Speaker: NA
Text: the committee inquiry into this bill to say

Speaker: NA
Text: that he did not support it, that it was

Speaker: NA
Text: premature, that it was not consistent with the

Speaker: NA
Text: report and that the only reason he even

Speaker: NA
Text: mentioned it in his original report was that it

Speaker: NA
Text: came up in the context of an election

Speaker: NA
Text: campaign. He, along with many others,

Speaker: NA
Text: agreed that there is an implicit assumption in

Speaker: NA
Text: this bill that people simply do not want to

Speaker: NA
Text: comply with the system and therefore do not

Speaker: NA
Text: turn up. But others before the committee

Speaker: NA
Text: made the very simple point that the people

Speaker: NA
Text: who want to rort the system are the ones who

Speaker: NA
Text: are going to turn up to every appointment

Speaker: NA
Text: because they will want to make sure that

Speaker: NA
Text: under no circumstances will they be kicked

Speaker: NA
Text: off. We know from the statistics that the ones

Speaker: NA
Text: who are most likely to suffer as a result of

Speaker: NA
Text: this bill are Indigenous Australians and

Speaker: NA
Text: young people, and according to the evidence

Speaker: NA
Text: presented to the committee inquiry they are

Speaker: NA
Text: more than likely to be those suffering from

Speaker: NA
Text: some kind of mental illness, those who find

Speaker: NA
Text: the whole system confusing, and those who

Speaker: NA
Text: are most at the fringes of society and most at

Speaker: NA
Text: risk of exclusion.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do support the amendment that has been

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed because it will go some way in

Speaker: NA
Text: reducing some of the confusion in the bill,

Speaker: NA
Text: but I will not be supporting the bill.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill, as amended, agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: Third Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms KATE ELLIS: by leave-I move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this bill be now read a third time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill read a third time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Therapeutic Goods Amendment (2011

Speaker: NA
Text: Measures No. 1) Bill 2011

Speaker: NA
Text: Reference to Main Committee

Speaker: Mr BOWEN
Text: by leave-I move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the Therapeutic Goods Amendment

Speaker: NA
Text: (2011 Measures No. 1) Bill 2011 be referred to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Main Committee for further consideration.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: Migration Amendment

Speaker: NA
Text: (Complementary Protection) Bill 2011

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate resumed on the motion:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: Mr MORRISON
Text: Cook) (18:20): The

Speaker: NA
Text: stated aim of the Migration Amendment

Speaker: NA
Text: (Complementary Protection) Bill 2011,

Speaker: NA
Text: reintroduced in this session of parliament, is

Speaker: NA
Text: to allow onshore claims to be made and

Speaker: NA
Text: considered under a new statutory process for

Speaker: NA
Text: a single visa application against all our non-

Speaker: NA
Text: refoulement obligations contained in

Speaker: NA
Text: instruments to which Australia is a signatory,

Speaker: NA
Text: other than the Refugee Convention and

Speaker: NA
Text: protocol. These include the International

Speaker: NA
Text: Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Optional Protocol to the International

Speaker: NA
Text: Covenant on Civil and Political Rights on the

Speaker: NA
Text: abolition of the death penalty, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Convention on the Rights of the Child and

Speaker: NA
Text: the Convention against Torture and Other

Speaker: NA
Text: Cruel, Inhuman or Degrading Treatment or

Speaker: NA
Text: Punishment.

Speaker: NA
Text: Complementary protection is a term that

Speaker: NA
Text: describes a state's obligations to those people

Speaker: NA
Text: who whilst not meeting the 1951 Refugee

Speaker: NA
Text: Convention definition and associated

Speaker: NA
Text: protocols are nonetheless in need of

Speaker: NA
Text: protection on the basis that they face serious

Speaker: NA
Text: violations of their rights if sent back to

Speaker: NA
Text: country of origin. This principle of non-

Speaker: NA
Text: refoulement is one that not only exists in all

Speaker: NA
Text: of these conventions and other treaties but

Speaker: NA
Text: also has become an established principle of

Speaker: NA
Text: international law more broadly, and that is a

Speaker: NA
Text: good thing. These amendments create a new

Speaker: NA
Text: statutory process to deal with applications.

Speaker: NA
Text: They create a new pathway for people who

Speaker: NA
Text: otherwise do not qualify as refugees to come

Speaker: NA
Text: to Australia to make and engage an onshore

Speaker: NA
Text: claim under another process. Currently, the

Speaker: NA
Text: minister considers all genuine applications

Speaker: NA
Text: against our international non-refoulement

Speaker: NA
Text: obligations when asked to exercise his

Speaker: NA
Text: intervention powers under the act. These

Speaker: NA
Text: decisions are non-reviewable.

Speaker: NA
Text: ministerial intervention model has the

Speaker: NA
Text: advantage of allowing the minister to deal

Speaker: NA
Text: flexibly and constructively with specific

Speaker: NA
Text: cases of individuals and families whose

Speaker: NA
Text: circumstances are invariably one-off and

Speaker: NA
Text: complex, and who maybe disadvantaged by a

Speaker: NA
Text: rigidly codified criteria, administered by

Speaker: NA
Text: departmental officials and subject to other

Speaker: NA
Text: broader processes. These are complex

Speaker: NA
Text: situations, they are difficult situations and

Speaker: NA
Text: they are amongst the very few cases that are

Speaker: NA
Text: found to be valid and where visas are

Speaker: NA
Text: granted. They involve devastating situations

Speaker: NA
Text: and they are genuine cases.

Speaker: NA
Text: The minister's office has confirmed that

Speaker: NA
Text: no-one who would be considered under the

Speaker: NA
Text: new provisions provided for in this bill have

Speaker: NA
Text: previously failed to obtain a protection

Speaker: NA
Text: outcome under the current arrangements.

Speaker: NA
Text: The debate is not about whether genuine

Speaker: NA
Text: people with claims under these treaties

Speaker: NA
Text: should or should not receive protection. This

Speaker: NA
Text: House, I think, is at one in honouring those

Speaker: NA
Text: treaties. The issue is how we go about that

Speaker: NA
Text: process and what others issues that gives rise

Speaker: NA
Text: to.

Speaker: NA
Text: It has also been confirmed that the number

Speaker: NA
Text: their of genuine applicants in this category is

Speaker: NA
Text: actually very small. Between 1 January 2010

Speaker: NA
Text: and 22 October 2010, the minister finalised

Speaker: NA
Text: 1,690 requests for intervention. Of those, the

Speaker: NA
Text: minister granted visas to a total of 438

Speaker: NA
Text: people. According to the minister's office, of

Speaker: NA
Text: those 438 visas, only six satisfied the

Speaker: NA
Text: requirements of the proposed new

Speaker: NA
Text: complementary protection provisions. So, at

Speaker: NA
Text: the end of the day, we are dealing with six

Speaker: NA
Text: applications that were considered genuine at

Speaker: NA
Text: that time.

Speaker: NA
Text: In evidence to the Senate committee

Speaker: NA
Text: which previously considered the bill in the

Speaker: NA
Text: last parliament, DIAC advised that of the

Speaker: NA
Text: 606 visas granted by the minister using

Speaker: NA
Text: The section 417 powers in the 2008-09 program,

Speaker: NA
Text: only 55 were granted under the humanitarian

Speaker: NA
Text: program and less than half of these cases

Speaker: NA
Text: involved non-refoulement issues, the subject

Speaker: NA
Text: of this bill.

Speaker: NA
Text: Consistent with evidence previously

Speaker: NA
Text: provided to the Senate committee, DIAC and

Speaker: NA
Text: the minister's office have reconfirmed that

Speaker: NA
Text: they do not expect the numbers of applicants

Speaker: NA
Text: being granted protection visas under these

Speaker: NA
Text: provisions to increase at all. This begs the

Speaker: NA
Text: question as to why the government now

Speaker: NA
Text: believe it is necessary to introduce a

Speaker: NA
Text: statutory framework, a new process, to deal

Speaker: NA
Text: with such a small number of cases, having

Speaker: NA
Text: decided during the last parliament to allow

Speaker: NA
Text: the bill to lapse.

Speaker: NA
Text: The bill, in substance, is largely the same

Speaker: NA
Text: as the one abandoned by the government

Speaker: NA
Text: during the last term. The bill was first

Speaker: NA
Text: introduced into the House of Representatives

Speaker: NA
Text: on 9 September 2009 by the then

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliamentary Secretary for Multicultural

Speaker: NA
Text: Affairs and Settlement Services, who I have

Speaker: NA
Text: to say did a very good job in that role. It was

Speaker: NA
Text: not debated and it lapsed on 19 July 2010,

Speaker: NA
Text: when parliament was prorogued for the 2010

Speaker: NA
Text: election.

Speaker: NA
Text: This bill is different in that it has

Speaker: NA
Text: simplified some definitions, removed the

Speaker: NA
Text: need for a risk of irreparable harm, replaced

Speaker: NA
Text: references to complementary protection

Speaker: NA
Text: criteria as matters with a definition of

Speaker: NA
Text: 'significant harm' and amended the

Speaker: NA
Text: requirement that the non-citizen have the

Speaker: NA
Text: death penalty imposed and it will be carried

Speaker: NA
Text: out-'and' is the key word there. There are

Speaker: NA
Text: some minor amendments that pick up on

Speaker: NA
Text: some of the issues raised in the Senate

Speaker: NA
Text: committee. In substance, the bill is

Speaker: NA
Text: essentially that which was presented in the

Speaker: NA
Text: last parliamentary term and one that could

Speaker: NA
Text: have picked up these matters at that time, but

Speaker: NA
Text: the government chose not to do so. The bill

Speaker: NA
Text: also introduces these definitions in a range of

Speaker: NA
Text: areas, but I think it is fairly clear what they

Speaker: NA
Text: are for those who have had the opportunity

Speaker: NA
Text: to read the bill.

Speaker: NA
Text: A new subclause 36(2B) provides a

Speaker: NA
Text: number of exclusion clauses, including that a

Speaker: NA
Text: real risk does not exist if the risk is

Speaker: NA
Text: the population of the country generally and is

Speaker: NA
Text: not faced by the non-citizen personally.

Speaker: NA
Text: Other exclusions include those who have

Speaker: NA
Text: committed serious crimes. These are

Speaker: NA
Text: important exclusions.

Speaker: NA
Text: In deciding to reintroduce the bill, the

Speaker: NA
Text: government advised that the minister had

Speaker: NA
Text: strong representations from the refugee

Speaker: NA
Text: advocacy sector. We understand that they

Speaker: NA
Text: neither sought nor received advice from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Federal Police, the Customs and

Speaker: NA
Text: Border Protection Service, ASIO or any

Speaker: NA
Text: other relevant agency about the potential

Speaker: NA
Text: impact of this measure to act as an incentive

Speaker: NA
Text: for people smuggling. That concerns me.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is a matter that clearly could have

Speaker: NA
Text: implications in this area and the opinion and

Speaker: NA
Text: advice of those agencies is critical to a

Speaker: NA
Text: decision to reintroduce this measure at this

Speaker: NA
Text: time into this parliament. It is not even clear

Speaker: NA
Text: whether a request was made for their advice.

Speaker: NA
Text: I understand none was, but I would happily

Speaker: NA
Text: be corrected on that point.

Speaker: NA
Text: The government's revised proposal will

Speaker: NA
Text: only widen the grounds for asylum seekers to

Speaker: NA
Text: make an onshore protection claim and,

Speaker: NA
Text: frankly, will put another product on the

Speaker: NA
Text: people smugglers' shelf, at a time when we

Speaker: NA
Text: can least afford to do so, while failing to

Speaker: NA
Text: extend legitimate protection to one additional

Speaker: NA
Text: person who genuinely needs it.

Speaker: NA
Text: The department and the minister's

Speaker: NA
Text: predictions about the small number of cases

Speaker: NA
Text: that would be approved under this new

Speaker: NA
Text: regime have an ominous echo of previous

Speaker: NA
Text: assurances given when a similar regime was

Speaker: NA
Text: introduced in the early 1980s and abandoned

Speaker: NA
Text: in 1989. In 1981, the Fraser government

Speaker: NA
Text: introduced the infamous section 6A(1)(e).

Speaker: NA
Text: This provision allowed an entry permit to be

Speaker: NA
Text: granted where there were 'strong,

Speaker: NA
Text: compassionate and humanitarian grounds'.

Speaker: NA
Text: These permits were to be provided to those

Speaker: NA
Text: faced by who did not meet other more specific

Speaker: NA
Text: migrant entry criteria. The decisions on these

Speaker: NA
Text: permits were judicially reviewable.

Speaker: NA
Text: It was claimed at the time these measures

Speaker: NA
Text: were introduced that they would deal with

Speaker: NA
Text: around 100 successful applicants per year. In

Speaker: NA
Text: 1981-82, 226 applications were approved.

Speaker: NA
Text: By 1987 this figure had risen to 3,260. In

Speaker: NA
Text: 1989, then Labor immigration minister,

Speaker: NA
Text: Senator Robert Ray, realised that the system

Speaker: NA
Text: had run off the rails and repealed the

Speaker: NA
Text: measure. At the time this measure was

Speaker: NA
Text: repealed-and remember, this was a measure

Speaker: NA
Text: that was going to produce around 100

Speaker: NA
Text: successful applicants per year-there were

Speaker: NA
Text: 8,000 outstanding applications covering

Speaker: NA
Text: some 10,000 persons. The Federal Court's

Speaker: NA
Text: interpretation of who should be provided

Speaker: NA
Text: protection under these measures transformed

Speaker: NA
Text: a provision intended to be exceptional, I am

Speaker: NA
Text: sure with all good intentions, into one that

Speaker: NA
Text: became routine. Where the department

Speaker: NA
Text: intended that strong, compassionate or

Speaker: NA
Text: humanitarian grounds applied only to

Speaker: NA
Text: applicants who had a fear of a 'substantial

Speaker: NA
Text: violation of human rights', a series of very

Speaker: NA
Text: creative court decisions led to a requirement

Speaker: NA
Text: that applicants only had to show that if they

Speaker: NA
Text: were forced to leave Australia, they would

Speaker: NA
Text: face a situation which would 'evoke strong

Speaker: NA
Text: feelings of pity or compassion in an ordinary

Speaker: NA
Text: member of the Australian public'. During

Speaker: NA
Text: Senate estimates questioning in 2009, shortly

Speaker: NA
Text: after the bill was introduced for the first

Speaker: NA
Text: time, Senator Fierravanti-Wells put the

Speaker: NA
Text: experience of section 6A(1)(e) to the

Speaker: NA
Text: department and the minister. The secretary of

Speaker: NA
Text: the department declared that 'this is

Speaker: NA
Text: completely different', because the criteria

Speaker: NA
Text: under the three conventions covered are

Speaker: NA
Text: quite clear in relation to non-refoulement

Speaker: NA
Text: obligations. The secretary said:

Speaker: NA
Text: We assess the potential for there to be a blow-

Speaker: NA
Text: out or even a statutory or judicial interpretation

Speaker: NA
Text: vastly widen the criteria as 'nil'.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is a fairly bold and dramatic claim.

Speaker: NA
Text: Frankly, I do not share that confidence.

Speaker: NA
Text: Indeed, the budget last night set out more

Speaker: NA
Text: than $100 million in new expenditure to deal

Speaker: NA
Text: with court appeals following the High

Speaker: NA
Text: Court's decision to strike down the

Speaker: NA
Text: government's former non-statutory process

Speaker: NA
Text: for considering refugee assessments,

Speaker: NA
Text: introduced by the government in July 2008,

Speaker: NA
Text: which was believed to be quarantined from

Speaker: NA
Text: judicial review. In February the department

Speaker: NA
Text: was asked in estimates how much extra they

Speaker: NA
Text: would have to pay as a result of that High

Speaker: NA
Text: Court decision, and they boldly stated in a

Speaker: NA
Text: written answer that it would be met from

Speaker: NA
Text: existing appropriations in terms of the cost of

Speaker: NA
Text: any further actions. Those appropriations last

Speaker: NA
Text: night had to be increased by more than $100

Speaker: NA
Text: million. We are already paying the price for

Speaker: NA
Text: misplaced confidence in the measures that

Speaker: NA
Text: have been introduced by the government in

Speaker: NA
Text: these areas. We have gone over those in

Speaker: NA
Text: some detail during the last 48 hours in this

Speaker: NA
Text: place as the government has sought to put

Speaker: NA
Text: forward new measures that are apparently

Speaker: NA
Text: the new great answer. But, sadly, we know

Speaker: NA
Text: how these measures often end with this

Speaker: NA
Text: government.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not share the confidence that what

Speaker: NA
Text: was intended to be a fairly small matter-

Speaker: NA
Text: enabling people with a genuine claim to be

Speaker: NA
Text: given genuine protection-could not follow

Speaker: NA
Text: suit of previous experience of our country in

Speaker: NA
Text: this area. We have system blow-outs being

Speaker: NA
Text: gained in the system and, frankly, we end up

Speaker: NA
Text: just putting another product on the people

Speaker: NA
Text: smugglers' shelf. For what purpose and at

Speaker: NA
Text: what gain? Our system, as the minister

Speaker: NA
Text: himself will acknowledge, is not denying a

Speaker: NA
Text: person who would be given protection under

Speaker: NA
Text: this measure protection that they are not

Speaker: NA
Text: already receiving. As I said, the Federal

Speaker: NA
Text: to Court's interpretation in this matter now

Speaker: NA
Text: provides the opportunity to get involved in

Speaker: NA
Text: reviewing these decisions and to go well

Speaker: NA
Text: beyond what may be considered by this

Speaker: NA
Text: parliament, and that could lead us down a

Speaker: NA
Text: very similar path to what we saw on the

Speaker: NA
Text: earlier occasion.

Speaker: NA
Text: It seems that eight days after having been

Speaker: NA
Text: sworn in as the new minister, the minister

Speaker: NA
Text: was reported in the Age as having said-and

Speaker: NA
Text: I make this comment in terms of reasserting

Speaker: NA
Text: his own commitment to this bill as

Speaker: NA
Text: something that he believes is important:

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor would seek to widen the criteria by

Speaker: NA
Text: which people can apply for protection before

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament breaks for summer.

Speaker: NA
Text: He did not quite make that goal but,

Speaker: NA
Text: nevertheless, it has been introduced. He

Speaker: NA
Text: further said:

Speaker: NA
Text: We'll be proceeding with that bill. ... I

Speaker: NA
Text: an important measure. Out of the immigration

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation that is outstanding, I see that as the

Speaker: NA
Text: most important.

Speaker: NA
Text: By contrast our current system enables

Speaker: NA
Text: legitimate claims to be identified and

Speaker: NA
Text: addressed while not opening up the system to

Speaker: NA
Text: the vexatious onshore claims to game the

Speaker: NA
Text: system in our courts, or allow a broader

Speaker: NA
Text: interpretation of the intended measures by

Speaker: NA
Text: the courts. The government are concerned

Speaker: NA
Text: that no-one who would be considered would

Speaker: NA
Text: be denied. They have also confirmed that the

Speaker: NA
Text: number of genuine applicants is very small.

Speaker: NA
Text: A senate inquiry into the proposal when it

Speaker: NA
Text: was floated by the government during the

Speaker: NA
Text: last parliamentary time focused almost

Speaker: NA
Text: entirely on the issue of variance in judicial

Speaker: NA
Text: and administrative interpretation of fixed

Speaker: NA
Text: criteria. There is a very strong argument that

Speaker: NA
Text: codification of this criteria may serve to both

Speaker: NA
Text: constrain our opportunity to provide

Speaker: NA
Text: protection as much as extend such protection

Speaker: NA
Text: beyond what was intended through these

Speaker: NA
Text: treaties and conventions.

Speaker: NA
Text: The inquiry also canvassed criticism of

Speaker: NA
Text: the current process as being 'administratively

Speaker: NA
Text: inefficient' on the basis that applicants 'must

Speaker: NA
Text: apply for a visa for which they are not

Speaker: NA
Text: eligible and exhaust merits review before

Speaker: NA
Text: their claim can be considered' by the

Speaker: NA
Text: minister. This criticism ignores the capacity

Speaker: NA
Text: of the minister to intervene under section

Speaker: NA
Text: 195A of the Migration Act to grant a visa to

Speaker: NA
Text: a person in detention whether or not they

Speaker: NA
Text: applied for one if he or she considers it is in

Speaker: NA
Text: the public interest to do so.

Speaker: NA
Text: A pre-removal clearance process is also

Speaker: NA
Text: undertaken by DIAC in which they assess

Speaker: NA
Text: whether the removal or deportation of an

Speaker: NA
Text: asylum seeker could otherwise engage

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's non-refoulement obligations

Speaker: NA
Text: under international human rights instruments

Speaker: NA
Text: to which Australia is a party. These measures

Speaker: NA
Text: see it as seem to be more than adequate additional

Speaker: NA
Text: safeguards.

Speaker: NA
Text: I appreciate there are some in the

Speaker: NA
Text: community who believe more is necessary.

Speaker: NA
Text: The great risk though is that by going down

Speaker: NA
Text: that path we open up the opportunity for

Speaker: NA
Text: vexatious claims and for systems to be

Speaker: NA
Text: abused. Particularly in the current

Speaker: NA
Text: environment the opportunity for that is at

Speaker: NA
Text: what I would call a 'high alert level'. In the

Speaker: NA
Text: process they undermine yet another avenue

Speaker: NA
Text: and opportunity for the government to move

Speaker: NA
Text: to provide protection to those who are in

Speaker: NA
Text: genuine need of it. The system currently is

Speaker: NA
Text: addressing those issues, maybe not to the

Speaker: NA
Text: satisfaction or the speed to which people

Speaker: NA
Text: would like or appreciate. But the way it

Speaker: NA
Text: works effectively provides a vetting system

Speaker: NA
Text: where the genuine applications rise to the

Speaker: NA
Text: top. When they do, this minister, the

Speaker: NA
Text: previous minister and the ministers that came

Speaker: NA
Text: from this side of the House have all acted to

Speaker: NA
Text: provide that protection when it has been

Speaker: NA
Text: deemed necessary.

Speaker: NA
Text: Liberal senators at the inquiry, when the

Speaker: NA
Text: bill was considered in the last parliament,

Speaker: NA
Text: submitted a dissenting report opposing the

Speaker: NA
Text: passage of the 2009 bill. The coalition will

Speaker: NA
Text: not be supporting this current bill. They said

Speaker: NA
Text: at that time that: the existing ministerial

Speaker: NA
Text: intervention process is a safeguard that has

Speaker: NA
Text: been in place for decades; it is a tried and

Speaker: NA
Text: proven system; there was no evidence that

Speaker: NA
Text: the ministerial intervention process has been

Speaker: NA
Text: anything other than effective; primary

Speaker: NA
Text: decisions would be appealable which, in

Speaker: NA
Text: turn, would lengthen the time in which cases

Speaker: NA
Text: remain unresolved and exacerbate an already

Speaker: NA
Text: fraught situation; codification risks curtailing

Speaker: NA
Text: discretion otherwise available to help

Speaker: NA
Text: genuine refugees languishing in camps

Speaker: NA
Text: around the world; and the bill would

Speaker: NA
Text: encourage the lodgement of non-refugee

Speaker: NA
Text: protection applications and the making of

Speaker: NA
Text: false asylum claims. They were the points

Speaker: NA
Text: made at the time and they are the same

Speaker: NA
Text: points the coalition makes today. They were

Speaker: NA
Text: the points made at the time and they are the

Speaker: NA
Text: same points the coalition makes today.

Speaker: NA
Text: Indeed, in a submission to the inquiry, Dr

Speaker: NA
Text: Ben Saul of the University of Sydney was of

Speaker: NA
Text: the view that the criteria contained in the

Speaker: NA
Text: 2009 bill were 'poorly drafted as a result of

Speaker: NA
Text: the inclusion of unnecessary qualifying

Speaker: NA
Text: phrases' and, far from creating certainty,

Speaker: NA
Text: would invite needless litigation. I believe

Speaker: NA
Text: those concerns remain valid. Vexatious

Speaker: NA
Text: claims, where every negative decision can be

Speaker: NA
Text: appealed, will also create further pressure on

Speaker: NA
Text: an already overstressed court system. It

Speaker: NA
Text: would also add further pressure to a

Speaker: NA
Text: detention network already in crisis and

Speaker: NA
Text: stretched beyond capacity.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the time between this bill's introduction stressed.

Speaker: NA
Text: into the House and today, these figures have

Speaker: NA
Text: become worse. At the time the bill was

Speaker: NA
Text: introduced around 53 per cent of the people

Speaker: NA
Text: who were in detention had been there for six

Speaker: NA
Text: months or more. That has now risen to 60

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent of the record 6,872 population of

Speaker: NA
Text: our detention network who have been held

Speaker: NA
Text: for more than six months. The costs in this

Speaker: NA
Text: area have also blown out by more than $1.75

Speaker: NA
Text: billion on one line item alone-output 4.3,

Speaker: NA
Text: offshore asylum seeker management-

Speaker: NA
Text: between the budget announcement last night

Speaker: NA
Text: and a year ago. That is a staggering figure.

Speaker: NA
Text: When you include the additional costs of

Speaker: NA
Text: capital that have been introduced over that

Speaker: NA
Text: 12-month period that figure rises to more

Speaker: NA
Text: than $2 billion in just one year.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is not a time for adding further stress

Speaker: NA
