Text: and strain to a system that has already

Speaker: NA
Text: collapsed under the pressures of his

Speaker: NA
Text: government's failures. This is not a time to

Speaker: NA
Text: be engaging in adding further opportunities

Speaker: NA
Text: and products for people smugglers to put on

Speaker: NA
Text: the table. It will allow and encourage people

Speaker: NA
Text: to try their chances-to game the system-

Speaker: NA
Text: for those we know will not meet the

Speaker: NA
Text: obligations of the refugee convention. We

Speaker: NA
Text: simply open up another pathway without one

Speaker: NA
Text: additional genuine applicant believed to be

Speaker: NA
Text: benefiting from these new processes. The

Speaker: NA
Text: outcome, based on the government's own

Speaker: NA
Text: representations, would be the same as that

Speaker: NA
Text: we have now. The process would be

Speaker: NA
Text: different but the outcome would be the same.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have had violent riots, destruction of

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth property and harm to

Speaker: NA
Text: persons, including self harm. This will all

Speaker: NA
Text: continue in the rolling crisis we have. In all

Speaker: NA
Text: likelihood this will increase not only in

Speaker: NA
Text: number, but in severity as the pressure

Speaker: NA
Text: continues to mount as more people arrive

Speaker: NA
Text: and our detention centres become even more

Speaker: NA
Text: There is a very great risk that the decision

Speaker: NA
Text: to provide a new channel for asylum claims

Speaker: NA
Text: for those who arrive illegally and are not

Speaker: NA
Text: refugees will just place another product on

Speaker: NA
Text: the shelf. The government's weakened border

Speaker: NA
Text: protection and immigration policies have

Speaker: NA
Text: already created a strong perception that those

Speaker: NA
Text: who seek to enter Australia illegally will

Speaker: NA
Text: advantage their opportunity to secure an

Speaker: NA
Text: immigration outcome by getting on a boat.

Speaker: NA
Text: Since the government weakened the regime,

Speaker: NA
Text: 224 boats have arrived carrying more than

Speaker: NA
Text: 11,000 people. That includes-and we

Speaker: NA
Text: should always remember this-the ill fated

Speaker: NA
Text: SIEV 36, that was set alight, the even more

Speaker: NA
Text: ill fated SIEV 221 that crashed against the

Speaker: NA
Text: rocks of Christmas Island, and, what would

Speaker: NA
Text: seem to be another tragedy, a vessel that is

Speaker: NA
Text: believed to have left Indonesia last

Speaker: NA
Text: November with 91 people on board who we

Speaker: NA
Text: have not heard from since. I know that

Speaker: NA
Text: matter has been raised with the government

Speaker: NA
Text: and I know we are not in a position to know

Speaker: NA
Text: what happened to that vessel. It is, as we

Speaker: NA
Text: understand, most likely outside our waters. I

Speaker: NA
Text: commend to the member for Gorton, the

Speaker: NA
Text: minister at the table, the opportunity to raise

Speaker: NA
Text: matters with the Indonesian government and

Speaker: NA
Text: others with whom we work closely, and I

Speaker: NA
Text: know with whom he works closely, to see if

Speaker: NA
Text: they can shed any light on this issue in order

Speaker: NA
Text: to bring some comfort to the families in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia who believe they had people on

Speaker: NA
Text: that vessel. It is no admission of

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility on the government's part, I

Speaker: NA
Text: believe, to have in some way intercepted that

Speaker: NA
Text: vessel outside Australian waters, or in any

Speaker: NA
Text: way had some obligation to go beyond our

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibilities to find it. When people get

Speaker: NA
Text: on these boats this is the risk they take, but

Speaker: NA
Text: is another terrible reminder-another 91

Speaker: NA
Text: souls who are likely to have perished at sea.

Speaker: NA
Text: The reason more people are coming to

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, the government has now I think

Speaker: NA
Text: accepted and agreed by their more recent

Speaker: NA
Text: decisions, is that the push factor argument

Speaker: NA
Text: that has been perpetrated for some years as

Speaker: NA
Text: the boats continued to arrive is exactly that: a

Speaker: NA
Text: political argument that has now fallen foul of

Speaker: NA
Text: the government's own actions and decisions,

Speaker: NA
Text: which have betrayed what has really been

Speaker: NA
Text: going on. You do not start to change your

Speaker: NA
Text: domestic policies if you do not think those

Speaker: NA
Text: domestic policies are providing a pull factor.

Speaker: NA
Text: Now we see the Prime Minister seeking to

Speaker: NA
Text: change some domestic policies, so clearly

Speaker: NA
Text: she believes that domestic policy has been a

Speaker: NA
Text: factor in attracting such a large number of

Speaker: NA
Text: vessels. It is not hard to work that out when

Speaker: NA
Text: the government's own figures show that if an

Speaker: NA
Text: Afghan applies offshore they have a one in

Speaker: NA
Text: 10 chance of being granted a visa, based on

Speaker: NA
Text: the figures for 2009-10, but if they got on a

Speaker: NA
Text: boat and sought to arrive in Australia nine

Speaker: NA
Text: out of 10, in the first nine months of 2010,

Speaker: NA
Text: got a positive refugee assessment. That is an

Speaker: NA
Text: incredibly strong incentive to get on a boat.

Speaker: NA
Text: The opening of another avenue for

Speaker: NA
Text: onshore applications that goes beyond the

Speaker: NA
Text: requirements of the Refugee Convention

Speaker: NA
Text: runs the risk of creating a further policy

Speaker: NA
Text: incentive for people smuggling, while, by

Speaker: NA
Text: their own admission, not assisting one extra

Speaker: NA
Text: genuine claimant. By contrast, the current

Speaker: NA
Text: process maintains a flexibility that avoids

Speaker: NA
Text: these outcomes, while affording protection to

Speaker: NA
Text: those who need it, consistent with our treaty

Speaker: NA
Text: and other obligations. I want to underscore

Speaker: NA
Text: that last point. I would hope there is no

Speaker: NA
Text: suggestion that anyone in this House or,

Speaker: NA
Text: indeed, the other chamber would have any

Speaker: NA
Text: sympathy with a view that would not have

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia meet its treaty obligations in these

Speaker: NA
Text: areas. We all share those commitments. Our

Speaker: NA
Text: it difference of view about this bill relates to

Speaker: NA
Text: process. We believe the same outcome can

Speaker: NA
Text: be achieved by maintaining the system that is

Speaker: NA
Text: currently in place, without exacerbating the

Speaker: NA
Text: clear catastrophe of problems we have on our

Speaker: NA
Text: borders, in our detention centres and in the

Speaker: NA
Text: budget of dealing with asylum seeker policy

Speaker: NA
Text: in this country.

Speaker: NA
Text: The coalition simply do not want to be in

Speaker: NA
Text: the position, yet again, of having to say that

Speaker: NA
Text: we warned the government of the risks of

Speaker: NA
Text: changing these systems. This is yet another

Speaker: NA
Text: change. This is yet another alteration to the

Speaker: NA
Text: set of arrangements that were put in place

Speaker: NA
Text: and followed by the coalition government in

Speaker: NA
Text: dealing with the matters of border protection

Speaker: NA
Text: and of ensuring that we did not provide

Speaker: NA
Text: incentives for people to come and chance

Speaker: NA
Text: their arm on claims when those claims were

Speaker: NA
Text: vexatious or, frankly, for people to seek to

Speaker: NA
Text: advance their claims by coming to Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: by boat in particular and illegally more

Speaker: NA
Text: broadly. We do not want to encourage that

Speaker: NA
Text: practice. We want to discourage that

Speaker: NA
Text: practice. By setting up other pathways, other

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunities for application, we think that is

Speaker: NA
Text: what this bill actually does with no ultimate

Speaker: NA
Text: greater gain in terms of those who are

Speaker: NA
Text: genuine claimants being given protection.

Speaker: NA
Text: We do not want to be in the position to

Speaker: NA
Text: say that we warned the government of the

Speaker: NA
Text: risk of changing these systems, and we

Speaker: NA
Text: provide that warning here again. Mr Deputy

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker, I would hope and you would hope

Speaker: NA
Text: that they would have learned from the scale

Speaker: NA
Text: of their failure to date in these areas

Speaker: NA
Text: take these risks. It would seem by the

Speaker: NA
Text: government's insistence on pushing this bill

Speaker: NA
Text: back into this House that they have not

Speaker: NA
Text: learned those lessons. The coalition will not

Speaker: NA
Text: be supporting this bill, and we encourage the

Speaker: NA
Text: government to reconsider bringing this bill

Speaker: NA
Text: the parliament at this time and urge them to

Speaker: NA
Text: maintain the system that has served

Speaker: NA
Text: governments well on both sides of this

Speaker: NA
Text: House for many years.

Speaker: Dr LEIGH
Text: Fraser) (18:47): As a child,

Speaker: NA
Text: four years of my childhood were spent in

Speaker: NA
Text: Malaysia and Indonesia, including attending

Speaker: NA
Text: primary school in Banda Aceh. I was there

Speaker: NA
Text: because my father was working on an

Speaker: NA
Text: AusAID project to improve education in

Speaker: NA
Text: Indonesia. As the only white child in my

Speaker: NA
Text: class, I came to appreciate perspectives and

Speaker: NA
Text: cultures quite different from my own. It also

Speaker: NA
Text: does not hurt to have the experience of being

Speaker: NA
Text: the outsider.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia is a modern nation. Our

Speaker: NA
Text: humanitarian ethos has advanced

Speaker: NA
Text: considerably since 1951, when the Refugee

Speaker: NA
Text: Convention was originally drafted. Our

Speaker: NA
Text: moral attitudes towards asylum applicants

Speaker: NA
Text: can no longer be bottlenecked by a

Speaker: NA
Text: convention written in the context of post-war

Speaker: NA
Text: Europe. Those who require humanitarian

Speaker: NA
Text: refuge but fall outside the 1951 convention

Speaker: NA
Text: include individuals who are at risk of being

Speaker: NA
Text: subjected to the death penalty, such as a

Speaker: NA
Text: woman at risk of an 'honour killing' or

Speaker: NA
Text: domestic abuse, or a person who would be

Speaker: NA
Text: prosecuted on the basis of their sexuality.

Speaker: NA
Text: These are all people of whom the vast

Speaker: NA
Text: majority of Australians would feel that the

Speaker: NA
Text: federal government has a duty to protect.

Speaker: NA
Text: Does the coalition really believe that

Speaker: NA
Text: someone who would be jailed for being gay

Speaker: NA
Text: in their home country does not deserve our

Speaker: NA
Text: protection? Is a woman who is at risk of an

Speaker: NA
Text: not to honour killing really a woman who is

Speaker: NA
Text: making a vexatious refugee claim?

Speaker: NA
Text: The Migration Amendment

Speaker: NA
Text: (Complementary Protection) Bill 2011 will

Speaker: NA
Text: provide an international standard

Speaker: NA
Text: complementary protection regime for those

Speaker: NA
Text: to individuals seeking protection visas under

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's non-refoulement (non-return)

Speaker: NA
Text: obligations. The bill will ensure that

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia continues to meet non-return

Speaker: NA
Text: obligations in a transparent and

Speaker: NA
Text: compassionate fashion, according with the

Speaker: NA
Text: International Covenant on Civil and Political

Speaker: NA
Text: Rights; the Convention Against Torture and

Speaker: NA
Text: Other Cruel, Inhuman or Degrading

Speaker: NA
Text: Treatment or Punishment; and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Convention on the Rights of the Child.

Speaker: NA
Text: The current bill reasserts the government's

Speaker: NA
Text: position to ensure that Australia meets its

Speaker: NA
Text: international legal and moral obligations.

Speaker: NA
Text: Rather than relying on an informal system

Speaker: NA
Text: employed at the discretion of the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Immigration and Citizenship, the new

Speaker: NA
Text: complementary protection legislation reflects

Speaker: NA
Text: the Gillard government's commitment to

Speaker: NA
Text: humane and just treatment of asylum

Speaker: NA
Text: seekers. This amendment will update an

Speaker: NA
Text: outdated law-a law that is now over two

Speaker: NA
Text: decades old. A number of legal academics,

Speaker: NA
Text: human rights lawyers and local and

Speaker: NA
Text: international humanitarian groups have noted

Speaker: NA
Text: that relying on a regime which is non-

Speaker: NA
Text: reviewable, non-compellable and wholly

Speaker: NA
Text: dependent on personal discretion is far from

Speaker: NA
Text: ideal. Under current arrangements, those

Speaker: NA
Text: seeking complementary protection are

Speaker: NA
Text: referred to the minister through section 417

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Migration Act. After review criteria

Speaker: NA
Text: are met, the minister may then exercise his or

Speaker: NA
Text: her discretion to intervene and grant the

Speaker: NA
Text: individual a protection visa.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is well-known that this process is

Speaker: NA
Text: inefficient and time-consuming. It adds

Speaker: NA
Text: stress to the applicants. The discretionary

Speaker: NA
Text: role of the minister in this process causes

Speaker: NA
Text: excessive uncertainty and delays for

Speaker: NA
Text: applicants seeking protection. Over the

Speaker: NA
Text: years, a broad consensus has formed over the

Speaker: NA
Text: need for complementary protection

Speaker: NA
Text: provisions to be explicitly incorporated into

Speaker: NA
Text: domestic legislation. Groups supportive of

Speaker: NA
Text: such a legal codification include: the United

Speaker: NA
Text: Nations; the Australian Human Rights

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission; Amnesty International; the

Speaker: NA
Text: Uniting Church; the Law Council of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia; and the Refugee Council of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: I would also note that the codification of

Speaker: NA
Text: complementary protection has

Speaker: NA
Text: recommended by several parliamentary

Speaker: NA
Text: committees, the most recent being the 2009

Speaker: NA
Text: Senate Legal and Constitutional Affairs

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee. The passage of this bill would

Speaker: NA
Text: place Australia along with nations such as

Speaker: NA
Text: Canada, the United States, New Zealand and

Speaker: NA
Text: 27 member states of the European Union. All

Speaker: NA
Text: of these nations have already moved to

Speaker: NA
Text: create harmonized, legal approaches to non-

Speaker: NA
Text: refoulement by codifying complementary

Speaker: NA
Text: protection within domestic laws. This is not

Speaker: NA
Text: a risky reform. This is not a radical reform.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is a common-sense reform. The bill

Speaker: NA
Text: ensures transparency, due process and

Speaker: NA
Text: consistent humanitarian outcomes and

Speaker: NA
Text: removes concern regarding the use of a non-

Speaker: NA
Text: codified system to address complementary

Speaker: NA
Text: protection obligations.

Speaker: NA
Text: This government does not believe that

Speaker: NA
Text: introducing a legislated complementary

Speaker: NA
Text: protection framework will increase people-

Speaker: NA
Text: smuggling. The single procedure process,

Speaker: NA
Text: already in place in the UK, the Netherlands,

Speaker: NA
Text: Canada and Ireland, will assess all claims for

Speaker: NA
Text: protective asylum, first against the refugees

Speaker: NA
Text: convention, and only then move to

Speaker: NA
Text: assessment under complementary protection

Speaker: NA
Text: criteria. Nor will this bill increase the

Speaker: NA
Text: number of protection places allocated to new

Speaker: NA
Text: arrivals. It should be remembered that those

Speaker: NA
Text: granted protection asylum, who are not

Speaker: NA
Text: recognised as refugees under the 1951

Speaker: NA
Text: convention but still owed complementary

Speaker: NA
Text: protection, are dealt with under the existing

Speaker: NA
Text: discretionary arrangement. This bill acts only

Speaker: NA
Text: to improve the system.

Speaker: NA
Text: The bill also saves administrative

Speaker: NA
Text: resources and relieves some of the pressure

Speaker: NA
Text: put on decision makers within the

Speaker: NA
Text: Department of Immigration and Citizenship

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Refugee Review Tribunal. In a

Speaker: NA
Text: recent editorial in the Australian, the member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Cook stated that the legislation runs the

Speaker: NA
Text: been risk of 'creating a further policy incentive for

Speaker: NA
Text: people-smuggling', while the current

Speaker: NA
Text: discretionary system should be retained

Speaker: NA
Text: because it promotes what he called

Speaker: NA
Text: 'flexibility'. This stands in stark contrast to

Speaker: NA
Text: his predecessor as the member for Cook, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Hon. Bruce Baird, who rightly said: 'This is

Speaker: NA
Text: not the way we should be treating the

Speaker: NA
Text: weakest and most vulnerable in our

Speaker: NA
Text: community.'

Speaker: NA
Text: The member for Cook, in his ongoing

Speaker: NA
Text: efforts to make political capital out of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's humanitarian and refugee

Speaker: NA
Text: programs, has in the past managed to

Speaker: NA
Text: confuse visa subclasses and erroneously

Speaker: NA
Text: introduced a private member's bill that

Speaker: NA
Text: accused the government, wrongly, of

Speaker: NA
Text: ignoring female applicants for the woman-at-

Speaker: NA
Text: risk visa. He argues that any amendment to

Speaker: NA
Text: our migration laws is a confession that 'push

Speaker: NA
Text: factors' do not matter. By this logic, Labor's

Speaker: NA
Text: fiscal stimulus in 2008-09 must have been an

Speaker: NA
Text: admission that Australia caused the global

Speaker: NA
Text: financial crisis. It is a strange view indeed.

Speaker: NA
Text: By blocking this bill, the opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: would be showing a callous attitude to

Speaker: NA
Text: women fleeing domestic violence, physical

Speaker: NA
Text: abuse and sexual assault who come to

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia to seek refuge. Too often we hear

Speaker: NA
Text: deliberate inflammatory language from our

Speaker: NA
Text: political opponents, rhetoric that is entirely

Speaker: NA
Text: divorced from reality. We must never forget

Speaker: NA
Text: that behind every statistic there is a human

Speaker: NA
Text: story. My grandparents lived in Victoria in

Speaker: NA
Text: Seaholme in a two-bedroom house with their

Speaker: NA
Text: four children. Their house was constructed

Speaker: NA
Text: by my grandfather, who was a boilermaker

Speaker: NA
Text: and not a carpenter, so there was always

Speaker: NA
Text: something that needed fixing around the

Speaker: NA
Text: home. Living by the seaside did not exactly

Speaker: NA
Text: help as the cold blustery winds were forever

Speaker: NA
Text: finding their way inside.

Speaker: NA
Text: My mother tells the story of her father, my

Speaker: NA
Text: grandfather, going down to the local tip to

Speaker: NA
Text: get some more building materials, where he

Speaker: NA
Text: met an Egyptian migrant woman who had

Speaker: NA
Text: three children with her; she was just there at

Speaker: NA
Text: the tip. The woman said they did not have a

Speaker: NA
Text: place to stay in, so my grandfather invited

Speaker: NA
Text: them back to his own home-a two-bedroom

Speaker: NA
Text: home that already housed six people. My

Speaker: NA
Text: mother said that as a little girl, when she

Speaker: NA
Text: this new family of four coming into her

Speaker: NA
Text: home, she wanted to cry as she was so angry

Speaker: NA
Text: with her father. But her father said, 'Well,

Speaker: NA
Text: they're not staying with us, they may not

Speaker: NA
Text: have a place to stay.' My mum told me how

Speaker: NA
Text: she was initially envious of the Egyptian

Speaker: NA
Text: refugees, people who had less than her but

Speaker: NA
Text: who, from her point of view, were 'taking

Speaker: NA
Text: things away' from her and the other kids in

Speaker: NA
Text: the family. All my mum could see was that

Speaker: NA
Text: she lived in a rickety, cramped, cold house

Speaker: NA
Text: with hardly any possessions and these people

Speaker: NA
Text: who were staying the night were taking

Speaker: NA
Text: something away from her. But later she went

Speaker: NA
Text: on to see the need that the immigrant family

Speaker: NA
Text: had.

Speaker: NA
Text: Being able to see the big picture-to see

Speaker: NA
Text: that refugees are not taking something but,

Speaker: NA
Text: rather, are giving back to our community-is

Speaker: NA
Text: fundamental to the success of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: multicultural story. The great success of

Speaker: NA
Text: multiculturalism in Australia has been the

Speaker: NA
Text: way that suburban Australians have, without

Speaker: NA
Text: fuss, accepted successive waves of new

Speaker: NA
Text: migrants into our neighbourhoods. As a local

Speaker: NA
Text: member of parliament, one of the things I

Speaker: NA
Text: most enjoy is to stand in a school

Speaker: NA
Text: assembly-amidst children from all

Speaker: NA
Text: ancestries in the world-and sing with them

Speaker: NA
Text: those terrific lines from the national anthem:

Speaker: NA
Text: 'For those who've come across the

Speaker: NA
Text: seas/We've boundless plains to share'.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia is a big country with a big heart.

Speaker: NA
Text: This bill reflects that fact. It harmonises our

Speaker: NA
Text: laws with our international responsibilities. It

Speaker: NA
Text: ensures we meet our moral obligations. It

Speaker: NA
Text: demonstrates that we in the Labor Party are

Speaker: NA
Text: committed to a humane and just approach to

Speaker: NA
Text: migration, and that we are not prepared to let

Speaker: NA
Text: the opposition's tub-thumping and incendiary

Speaker: NA
Text: rhetoric stand in the way of long-overdue

Speaker: NA
Text: reform.

Speaker: Mr ROBERT
Text: Fadden) (18:58):

Speaker: NA
Text: saw Cognisant of the time and cognisant of the

Speaker: NA
Text: day, we seek to stand here to discuss the

Speaker: NA
Text: Migration Amendment (Complementary

Speaker: NA
Text: if Protection) Bill 2011-another change and

Speaker: NA
Text: another piecemeal approach to what is now

Speaker: NA
Text: universally derided as a debacle in protecting

Speaker: NA
Text: our borders. When Labor came to power in

Speaker: NA
Text: November 2007, there was a handful of

Speaker: NA
Text: people in detention. It is, of course, a great

Speaker: NA
Text: euphemism meaning a small number of

Speaker: NA
Text: people but I mean literally a handful. In fact,

Speaker: NA
Text: there were four-just four-in detention. I

Speaker: NA
Text: am led to believe that at the time, given a bill

Speaker: NA
Text: of something like $100 million or less, the

Speaker: NA
Text: department-what is now DIAC-was

Speaker: NA
Text: saying that this was a large amount of money

Speaker: NA
Text: in expenditure. Well, we found yesterday in

Speaker: NA
Text: the budget that the expenditure that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor government is now facing is $1.7

Speaker: NA
Text: billion. It is an interesting aside that

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian families, some earning as little as

Speaker: NA
Text: $45,000 a year, will have the family tax

Speaker: NA
Text: benefit supplement frozen for two years with

Speaker: NA
Text: no indexation, therefore reducing it in real

Speaker: NA
Text: terms. Families will suffer to the tune of $2

Speaker: NA
Text: million in Australia whilst we spend $1.7

Speaker: NA
Text: billion in dealing with a boat person crisis

Speaker: NA
Text: caused by, started by, enacted by and

Speaker: NA
Text: maintained by an inept Labor government

Speaker: NA
Text: and the changes they made in August 2008.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is quite clear to the Australian people that

Speaker: NA
Text: the unwinding of the Howard government

Speaker: NA
Text: framework that commenced in 2008 has

Speaker: NA
Text: become a massive pull factor, a magnet that

Speaker: NA
Text: has drawn people smugglers to this country.

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate interrupted.

Speaker: NA
Text: ADJOURNMENT

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Hon. Peter

Speaker: NA
Text: Slipper): Order! I propose the question:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the House do now adjourn.

Speaker: NA
Text: Paterson Electorate: Building the

Speaker: NA
Text: Education Revolution Program

Speaker: Mr BALDWIN
Text: Paterson) (19:00): I rise

Speaker: NA
Text: today on behalf of small business tradesmen

Speaker: NA
Text: in my electorate of Paterson who have been

Speaker: NA
Text: failed by the Gillard Labor government.

Speaker: NA
Text: These workers are owed in excess of

Speaker: NA
Text: $600,000 for work they completed in good

Speaker: NA
Text: faith under Labor's Building the Education

Speaker: NA
Text: Revolution. Instead of helping them, Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: hung these businesses out to dry and then

Speaker: NA
Text: washed their hands of it. When Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister Rudd announced a $16.2 billion

Speaker: NA
Text: program to build infrastructure in our

Speaker: NA
Text: schools he said it was to boost the economy.

Speaker: NA
Text: The government's website says that the BER

Speaker: NA
Text: will 'support local jobs and stimulate

Speaker: NA
Text: investment'.

Speaker: NA
Text: In my electorate of Paterson a group of 56

Speaker: NA
Text: small businesses were subcontracted to build

Speaker: NA
Text: a school hall COLA facility at the Pacific

Speaker: NA
Text: Palms Public School. Unlike many others,

Speaker: NA
Text: these small businesses completed the job

Speaker: NA
Text: with distinction. They brought the supplies,

Speaker: NA
Text: they put in the hours and they finished the

Speaker: NA
Text: hall in August 2010. It is now six months

Speaker: NA
Text: later and they are still waiting for their

Speaker: NA
Text: payment. There are also subcontractors owed

Speaker: NA
Text: money for BER projects at Bungwahl Public

Speaker: NA
Text: School in my electorate and at Coopernook

Speaker: NA
Text: Public School in the member for Lyne's

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate. How on earth has this been

Speaker: NA
Text: allowed to happen?

Speaker: NA
Text: The company that subcontracted my

Speaker: NA
Text: constituents, Cape View Developments, has

Speaker: NA
Text: gone into liquidation. It failed to pay its

Speaker: NA
Text: subcontractors. The company that contracted

Speaker: NA
Text: Cape View Developments, Reed

Speaker: NA
Text: Constructions, failed to pay the

Speaker: NA
Text: subcontractors despite giving guarantees to

Speaker: NA
Text: the subcontractors they would once the work

Speaker: NA
Text: was completed. Neither the former state

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor Keneally government nor the current

Speaker: NA
Text: Gillard Labor government bothered to ensure

Speaker: NA
Text: the debt was settled.

Speaker: NA
Text: The buck must stop with the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister, who, as the former education

Speaker: NA
Text: minister, is responsible for the BER

Speaker: NA
Text: program. But our Prime Minister Gillard

Speaker: NA
Text: wants all of the gain and none of the pain.

Speaker: NA
Text: When it came to spruiking her program,

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister Gillard was happy to send

Speaker: NA
Text: Senator Forshaw to my electorate to open the

Speaker: NA
Text: building work at Pacific Palms Public School

Speaker: NA
Text: and to speak to the media, but when it comes

Speaker: NA
Text: to ensuring those who did the work in good

Speaker: NA
Text: faith get paid for it, neither she nor Senator

Speaker: NA
Text: Forshaw was anywhere to be seen. Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister Gillard has left those businesses and

Speaker: NA
Text: families under severe financial stress. She

Speaker: NA
Text: should be ashamed. For example, Carl Organ

Speaker: NA
Text: is a local plumber who signed a contract,

Speaker: NA
Text: bought supplies and completed the job. He is

Speaker: NA
Text: now owed more than $45,000. That is a

Speaker: NA
Text: massive amount of money for a small

Speaker: NA
Text: business and a family that is trying to make a

Speaker: NA
Text: living and put their kids through school.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are many other questions that are

Speaker: NA
Text: yet to be answered-questions such as: did

Speaker: NA
Text: Cape View sign a declaration of payment to

Speaker: NA
Text: a subcontractor under the Building and

Speaker: NA
Text: Construction Industry Security of Payment

Speaker: NA
Text: Act stating to Reed that it had paid its

Speaker: NA
Text: subbies in order to get paid itself? If so, it

Speaker: NA
Text: could be in breach of the law. I have put the

Speaker: NA
Text: question to Reed Constructions but they

Speaker: NA
Text: would not answer my questions. Even the

Speaker: NA
Text: subcontractors themselves have been largely

Speaker: NA
Text: shut out by Reed, which seems to have gone

Speaker: NA
Text: to ground on the issue. Put simply, no-one

Speaker: NA
Text: wants to take responsibility for the BER

Speaker: NA
Text: program when things go wrong. Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister Gillard has handed out billions of

Speaker: NA
Text: taxpayers' dollars but failed to put into place

Speaker: NA
Text: any mechanisms for accountability. So it is

Speaker: NA
Text: up to her to settle this matter.

Speaker: NA
Text: I wrote to the Minister for Tertiary

Speaker: NA
Text: Education, Skills, Jobs and Workplace

Speaker: NA
Text: Relations, Chris Evans, regarding this issue

Speaker: NA
Text: back on 3 March and he has not bothered to

Speaker: NA
Text: reply. Yet they continue to send Senator

Speaker: NA
Text: Forshaw to open school buildings in my

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate. Likewise the member for Lyne

Speaker: NA
Text: also had the chance to stand up for these

Speaker: NA
Text: workers, many of whom are his constituents,

Speaker: NA
Text: but he would not do anything for them.

Speaker: NA
Text: Sadly, I am not surprised, because he had a

Speaker: NA
Text: chance to vote with the coalition to approve

Speaker: NA
Text: an inquiry into the BER but he would not. I

Speaker: NA
Text: think he is more interested in his own job

Speaker: NA
Text: than he is interested in standing up for his

Speaker: NA
Text: own constituents. The small businesses who

Speaker: NA
Text: are already struggling because of these debts

Speaker: NA
Text: will now have to pay for lawyers to take this

Speaker: NA
Text: up in court on their behalf. It would be yet

Speaker: NA
Text: another burden.

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor must do something to fix this now

Speaker: NA
Text: and I will not rest until it does. I have written

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Prime Minister and the New South

Speaker: NA
Text: Wales Minister for Education, Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: Piccoli. Prime Minister, you are sending

Speaker: NA
Text: Senator Forshaw to open a building in

Speaker: NA
Text: Grahamstown on Monday and in another

Speaker: NA
Text: town on Tuesday. Will you instruct him to

Speaker: NA
Text: meet with the subbies who have not yet been

Speaker: NA
Text: paid? Prime Minister, I am demanding that

Speaker: NA
Text: you take an active role and end this debt

Speaker: NA
Text: problem for people who placed good faith in

Speaker: NA
Text: the BER program, built a great building but

Speaker: NA
Text: have not been paid and are wearing the

Speaker: NA
Text: burden of your policies.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Mammal Extinction

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr KELVIN THOMSON (Wills)

Speaker: NA
Text: (19:05): Over the past 200 years, more

Speaker: NA
Text: mammal species have become extinct in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia than anywhere on earth. Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: mammal extinctions account for about one-

Speaker: NA
Text: third of all mammals that have disappeared

Speaker: NA
Text: from the world over the past 500 years. Back

Speaker: NA
Text: just 50 years, we would still find quolls

Speaker: NA
Text: around Melbourne and pig-footed

Speaker: NA
Text: bandicoots, crescent nail-tail wallabies and

Speaker: NA
Text: desert rat-kangaroos in Central Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: Those animals have gone, in a time frame

Speaker: NA
Text: that in an evolutionary context is the blink of

Speaker: NA
Text: an eye.

Speaker: NA
Text: We assume that this is the fault of

Speaker: NA
Text: previous generations, who did not know any

Speaker: NA
Text: better, and that we now have a greater sense

Speaker: NA
Text: of environmental responsibility and that we

Speaker: NA
Text: now look after our unique animals. We have

Speaker: NA
Text: environment protection legislation, we have

Speaker: NA
Text: more national parks and we know a lot more

Speaker: NA
Text: about the Australian ecology. We assume

Speaker: NA
Text: that future generations will commend our

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility rather than condemn our

Speaker: NA
Text: neglect. We would be wrong. The decline

Speaker: NA
Text: goes on as fast as ever, and we face the real

Speaker: NA
Text: likelihood of a new wave of mammal

Speaker: NA
Text: extinctions on our watch.

Speaker: NA
Text: I commend the Australian Wildlife

Speaker: NA
Text: Conservancy, the Nature Conservancy, and

Speaker: NA
Text: the Pew Environment Group for drawing

Speaker: NA
Text: public attention to this ongoing crisis.

Speaker: NA
Text: drawn extensively on two of their reports-

Speaker: NA
Text: Into oblivion: the disappearing native

Speaker: NA
Text: mammals of northern Australia and The

Speaker: NA
Text: collapse of northern mammal populations-

Speaker: NA
Text: in preparing these remarks. Twenty years

Speaker: NA
Text: ago, people camping in northern Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: were likely to witness bandicoots and quolls

Speaker: NA
Text: scampering around their campsite during the

Speaker: NA
Text: night. For native mammals this was a land of

Speaker: NA
Text: plenty, one of the few remaining places with

Speaker: NA
Text: a fauna largely as it was at the time of

Speaker: NA
Text: European settlement. But three years ago a

Speaker: NA
Text: team of Australian Wildlife Conservancy

Speaker: NA
Text: ecologists was carrying out a fauna inventory

Speaker: NA
Text: survey of a property in the Northern

Speaker: NA
Text: Territory to assess its conservation value for

Speaker: NA
Text: possible acquisition. Over two weeks they

Speaker: NA
Text: set traps at a range of remote locations

Speaker: NA
Text: accessible only by helicopter. The survey

Speaker: NA
Text: sites were positioned in combinations of

Speaker: NA
Text: topography and vegetation that seemed

Speaker: NA
Text: guaranteed to deliver high diversities of

Speaker: NA
Text: various mammal species. But night after

Speaker: NA
Text: night the traps were empty. Amongst

Speaker: NA
Text: complex sandstone formations that should

Speaker: NA
Text: have been thick with rock rats, and northern

Speaker: NA
Text: quolls, the team found nothing, not even

Speaker: NA
Text: tracks. In lush paperbark forests, the rich

Speaker: NA
Text: loamy soil should have been dotted with the

Speaker: NA
Text: characteristic potholes of digging bandicoots.

Speaker: NA
Text: The survey team saw and caught nothing.

Speaker: NA
Text: Long-tailed planigales were absent from the

Speaker: NA
Text: black-soil plains. Native rodents were absent

Speaker: NA
Text: from the savanna woodlands and the creek

Speaker: NA
Text: banks. In over 1000 trap nights, the AWC

Speaker: NA
Text: caught only two species of small native

Speaker: NA
Text: mammal, which they described as a truly

Speaker: NA
Text: demoralising experience.

Speaker: NA
Text: AWC says this survey experience is not

Speaker: NA
Text: unique. In the past 20 years there has been a

Speaker: NA
Text: catastrophic decline in the diversity and

Speaker: NA
Text: abundance of small mammals across

Speaker: NA
Text: northern Australia. From Cape York to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Kimberley, small mammals are disappearing.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have A growing body of published and

Speaker: NA
Text: unpublished survey reports across the north

Speaker: NA
Text: provides compelling evidence of a dramatic

Speaker: NA
Text: collapse in mammal populations. What is

Speaker: NA
Text: causing this decline? The first culprit is fire.

Speaker: NA
Text: Prior to European settlement Aboriginal

Speaker: NA
Text: people generally lit fires with care and a

Speaker: NA
Text: close appreciation of environmental

Speaker: NA
Text: conditions. They were typically of low

Speaker: NA
Text: intensity and small in scale, producing an

Speaker: NA
Text: intricate landscape tapestry, a fine mosaic of

Speaker: NA
Text: burnt and unburnt areas. But the regime of

Speaker: NA
Text: fire is now very different. Across much of

Speaker: NA
Text: the land fires are now more extensive and

Speaker: NA
Text: burn with greater intensity and frequency.

Speaker: NA
Text: For example, many national parks and

Speaker: NA
Text: Aboriginal lands now are at least 50 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: burnt every year. The native mammals of

Speaker: NA
Text: northern Australia are highly susceptible to

Speaker: NA
Text: fire, and the frequent, intense and large-scale

Speaker: NA
Text: fires are driving declines. I urge northern

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian land managers to reduce the scale

Speaker: NA
Text: and intensity of fires so that burnt patches

Speaker: NA
Text: are on a scale of hectares rather than

Speaker: NA
Text: hundreds of square kilometres. The size and

Speaker: NA
Text: intensity of fire needs to be reduced so that

Speaker: NA
Text: fires occur in fine-scale mosaics.

Speaker: NA
Text: There also needs to be a big effort to

Speaker: NA
Text: effectively control introduced predators and

Speaker: NA
Text: pests such as cats and cane toads. Feral cats

Speaker: NA
Text: need to be effectively controlled through

Speaker: NA
Text: intensive management such as targeted

Speaker: NA
Text: baiting. Our native mammal species are part

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australia's rich heritage. They have an

Speaker: NA
Text: intrinsic value and the right to exist. It is a

Speaker: NA
Text: mark of our character as a nation, and we

Speaker: NA
Text: will be judged by future generations on the

Speaker: NA
Text: way we value and cherish this unique and

Speaker: NA
Text: irreplaceable heritage.

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget

Speaker: Mr BRIGGS
Text: Mayo) (19:10): It is a

Speaker: NA
Text: pleasure to rise tonight to talk in the

Speaker: NA
Text: adjournment debate about the topic of the

Speaker: NA
Text: day, and that is the big spending, high taxing

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor budget. Last night, the Treasurer said

Speaker: NA
Text: this was a Labor budget, and not a truer word

Speaker: NA
Text: has been said. He was right. This is a very

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor budget: a massive budget deficit,

Speaker: NA
Text: soaring to $50 billion this financial year,

Speaker: NA
Text: billion in the bill we will have to vote on in

Speaker: NA
Text: this House, and a blow-out from the

Speaker: NA
Text: projections in MYEFO of $9.6 billion. Net

Speaker: NA
Text: debt is peaking at over $100 billion, a

Speaker: NA
Text: shameful record for this Treasurer to have,

Speaker: NA
Text: and remaining above $100 billion in the

Speaker: NA
Text: forward estimates. This amounts to a bill for

Speaker: NA
Text: every single Australian of $4,700. Interest

Speaker: NA
Text: repayments are $5.5 billion in 2011-12 and

Speaker: NA
Text: climbing to $7.5 billion in 2014-15, or

Speaker: NA
Text: around $20 million a day. Labor is now

Speaker: NA
Text: borrowing $135 million a day to fund its

Speaker: NA
Text: reckless spending. As Alan Kohler said last

Speaker: NA
Text: night after the budget was handed down-an

Speaker: NA
Text: economist the Treasurer did not quote

Speaker: NA
Text: today-'Any decent CFO would be

Speaker: NA
Text: embarrassed by this budget.' Of course, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer takes the role of CFO in the

Speaker: NA
Text: government.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is definitely a Labor budget. How did

Speaker: NA
Text: we get here? The Labor Party will blame all

Speaker: NA
Text: sorts of other factors but they were handed a

Speaker: NA
Text: $20 billion surplus, no net debt and money in

Speaker: NA
Text: the bank when they came to government in

Speaker: NA
Text: 2007. The Treasurer uses every excuse to

Speaker: NA
Text: justify these horrendous figures, why he has

Speaker: NA
Text: taken the budget from a position of $20

Speaker: NA
Text: billion strength to a position of over $100

Speaker: NA
Text: billion net debt and deficit. The main reason

Speaker: NA
Text: why the federal budget is producing such

Speaker: NA
Text: ugly figures is the wasteful, reckless

Speaker: NA
Text: spending of this government. We heard from

Speaker: NA
Text: the member for Paterson earlier about one of

Speaker: NA
Text: those examples of the mismanagement of

Speaker: NA
Text: this government, the failed programs and the

Speaker: NA
Text: bad policy decisions. Building the Education

Speaker: NA
Text: Revolution, or the school halls debacle, was

Speaker: NA
Text: a $1.7 billion blow-out with up to $8 billion

Speaker: NA
Text: wasted. The home insulation disaster-$2.4

Speaker: NA
Text: billion wasted and mismanaged and homes

Speaker: NA
Text: being burnt down. The Solar Homes

Speaker: NA
Text: program-$850 million wasted. The Green

Speaker: NA
Text: $22 Loans program, which became Green Start

Speaker: NA
Text: before being dumped altogether-$300

Speaker: NA
Text: million wasted. Tax bonus payments-$46

Speaker: NA
Text: million wasted, with money being sent to

Speaker: NA
Text: people overseas, criminals and people who

Speaker: NA
Text: had passed away. Grocery Choice-$8

Speaker: NA
Text: million spent on a website that delivered

Speaker: NA
Text: nothing and was eventually shut down. The

Speaker: NA
Text: 2020 Summit-$2 million wasted on a great

Speaker: NA
Text: big talkfest. Labor has learnt nothing from its

Speaker: NA
Text: first term policy stuff-ups and budget blow-

Speaker: NA
Text: outs.

Speaker: NA
Text: Even in the Treasurer's fourth budget, he

Speaker: NA
Text: continues to waste money. Since coming to

Speaker: NA
Text: power, Labor has employed 24,000

Speaker: NA
Text: additional public servants. The government

Speaker: NA
Text: is asking the Australian people to tighten

Speaker: NA
Text: their belts, but it is refusing to do the same

Speaker: NA
Text: itself. They say they are cutting $2 billion

Speaker: NA
Text: from family payments to bring the budget

Speaker: NA
Text: back to surplus, but $1.75 billion of this

Speaker: NA
Text: money will disappear to pay for the boats

Speaker: NA
Text: failure thanks to Labor's failed border

Speaker: NA
Text: protection policies. We only need to look at

Speaker: NA
Text: these figures to see that Labor's failed border

Speaker: NA
Text: protection policies are now impacting on

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian family budgets. We see that in my

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate on a daily basis with the obscene

Speaker: NA
Text: waste associated with the Inverbrackie

Speaker: NA
Text: detention facility. The Treasurer is giving

Speaker: NA
Text: $10 million to the unions to build a new

Speaker: NA
Text: website. This is just more wasteful spending.

Speaker: NA
Text: While the government might claim that

Speaker: NA
Text: savings in this budget are $22 billion, they

Speaker: NA
Text: will actually spend $19 billion of it. Out of

Speaker: NA
Text: the $22 billion in savings, almost half is

Speaker: NA
Text: made up of levies imposed on ordinary

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians.

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor is addicted to spending. It lacks the

Speaker: NA
Text: courage to make the tough decisions, and

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian families are now paying the price

Speaker: NA
Text: of Labor's waste and mismanagement and its

Speaker: NA
Text: failed policies and policy implementation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Instead of cutting waste and making the hard

Speaker: NA
Text: decisions in this budget, Labor has stripped

Speaker: NA
Text: $2 billion from Australian families by

Speaker: NA
Text: freezing indexation of key family tax

Speaker: NA
Text: payments and income thresholds-as I

Speaker: NA
Text: remarked earlier, all to pay for the failed

Speaker: NA
Text: boats policy. The government is hitting

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian families and the economy with

Speaker: NA
Text: more than $6 billion in new taxes and higher

Speaker: NA
Text: charges. At the same time, electricity prices

Speaker: NA
Text: are up by 51 per cent, grocery prices are up

Speaker: NA
Text: by 14 per cent, education and health costs are

Speaker: NA
Text: up by 20 per cent and petrol prices are on

Speaker: NA
Text: their way up and up. Families are being hit,

Speaker: NA
Text: taxes are being raised and services are being

Speaker: NA
Text: cut. This is a very Labor budget.

Speaker: NA
Text: Victoria: Cattle Grazing and Duck

Speaker: NA
Text: Hunting

Speaker: Ms PARKE
Text: Fremantle) (19:15): In the

Speaker: NA
Text: relatively short time it has been in power,

Speaker: NA
Text: Victorian coalition government has lost no

Speaker: NA
Text: time in opening up the environment for

Speaker: NA
Text: exploitation. It reintroduced cattle grazing

Speaker: NA
Text: into Victoria's National Heritage listed

Speaker: NA
Text: Alpine National Park under the guise of

Speaker: NA
Text: 'scientific grazing' for the alleged purpose of

Speaker: NA
Text: seeing if cattle grazing could be a fire

Speaker: NA
Text: management tool. It also extended the season

Speaker: NA
Text: for recreational shooting of native waterbirds

Speaker: NA
Text: to a 12-week period, with bag limits of up to

Speaker: NA
Text: ten birds per day per person, meaning an

Speaker: NA
Text: individual could shoot up to 840 ducks per

Speaker: NA
Text: season. Both decisions were made in the face

Speaker: NA
Text: of overwhelming community opposition and

Speaker: NA
Text: contrary to the weight of scientific evidence.

Speaker: NA
Text: They also impact on areas of Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: jurisdiction.

Speaker: NA
Text: With regard to so-called scientific grazing,

Speaker: NA
Text: I note that the $50 million Victorian

Speaker: NA
Text: bushfires royal commission did not

Speaker: NA
Text: recommend it as a fuel reduction or fire

Speaker: NA
Text: management tool, or for further research.

Speaker: NA
Text: According to the Ecological Society of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, 'there is no scientific evidence to

Speaker: NA
Text: support the claim that grazing in alpine and

Speaker: NA
Text: subalpine zones plays any role in mitigating

Speaker: NA
Text: the effects of wildfire', while on the other

Speaker: NA
Text: hand, 'grazing by livestock in the subalpine

Speaker: NA
Text: and alpine zones represents a significant

Speaker: NA
Text: threat to water, soil, nature conservation and

Speaker: NA
Text: biodiversity values'. In March the federal

Speaker: NA
Text: minister for the environment ordered the

Speaker: NA
Text: removal of cattle from the national park, as

Speaker: NA
Text: the Victorian government had failed to seek

Speaker: NA
Text: the necessary federal approval. I understand

Speaker: NA
Text: that the cattle were, accordingly, removed by

Speaker: NA
Text: the 8 April deadline; however, the Victorian

Speaker: NA
Text: minister for the environment, Ryan Smith,

Speaker: NA
Text: has recently claimed that the trial will

Speaker: NA
Text: continue. The Victorian National Parks

Speaker: NA
Text: Association has likened the project to 'a

Speaker: NA
Text: domestic version of Japanese whaling, in that

Speaker: NA
Text: it uses the guise of science to justify what is

Speaker: NA
Text: the essentially a politically motivated decision

Speaker: NA
Text: that undermines the integrity of Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: world-class system of national parks'. As the

Speaker: NA
Text: VNPA has rightly said, 'It's a park not a

Speaker: NA
Text: paddock'.

Speaker: NA
Text: WA banned recreational duck hunting in

Speaker: NA
Text: 1990, New South Wales banned it in 1995

Speaker: NA
Text: and Queensland banned it in 2005. Surveys

Speaker: NA
Text: show that 87 per cent of Victorians support a

Speaker: NA
Text: ban on recreational duck shooting. Aerial

Speaker: NA
Text: surveys by respected scientist Professor

Speaker: NA
Text: Richard Kingsford have shown that

Speaker: NA
Text: waterbird numbers have fallen by 82 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: across eastern Australia in the past 25 years,

Speaker: NA
Text: yet the Baillieu government has seen fit to

Speaker: NA
Text: approve and expand this obscene activity this

Speaker: NA
Text: year. The Victorian Department of

Speaker: NA
Text: Sustainability and Environment's website

Speaker: NA
Text: even trumpeted the news with a headline that

Speaker: NA
Text: I am sure they imagined was funny: 'Duck!

Speaker: NA
Text: It's hunting season.' An editorial in the Age

Speaker: NA
Text: in January this year entitled 'State takes two

Speaker: NA
Text: steps back on conservation' comments:

Speaker: NA
Text: ... hunting flocks of wildfowl with a shotgun is

Speaker: NA
Text: unavoidably cruel and rare species are killed.

Speaker: NA
Text: Studies show that for every duck retrieved, a

Speaker: NA
Text: wounded bird flies off, often

Speaker: NA
Text: death.

Speaker: NA
Text: Dr Graeme Hamilton, CEO of Birds

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, has said:

Speaker: NA
Text: The level of mortality and wounding of these

Speaker: NA
Text: native birds for the amusement of a handful of

Speaker: NA
Text: shooters cannot be justified in a modern society.

Speaker: NA
Text: Young, inexperienced ducks will bear the brunt of

Speaker: NA
Text: the onslaught, which could be disastrous for the

Speaker: NA
Text: overall waterfowl population for years to come ...

Speaker: NA
Text: Our wildlife should not be sacrificed for political

Speaker: NA
Text: purposes. Victoria's Recreational Duck Shooting

Speaker: NA
Text: Season should be abandoned once and for all.

Speaker: NA
Text: The campaign director of the Coalition

Speaker: NA
Text: Against Duck Shooting, Laurie Levy, has

Speaker: NA
Text: noted:

Speaker: NA
Text: ... the Commonwealth is a signatory to the

Speaker: NA
Text: international RAMSAR Treaty giving it direct

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility for significant areas of Australia‘s

Speaker: NA
Text: wetlands known as RAMSAR Sites, being

Speaker: NA
Text: ‗Wetlands of International Importance, especially

Speaker: NA
Text: as Waterfowl Habitat‘.

Speaker: NA
Text: Given community concern over the ethics of duck

Speaker: NA
Text: shooting, combined with declining bird numbers,

Speaker: NA
Text: diminishing wetlands from drought and climate

Speaker: NA
Text: change, as well as inconsistent policies of the

Speaker: NA
Text: States/Territory governments on duck shooting,

Speaker: NA
Text: there is an urgent need for the Federal

Speaker: NA
Text: government to develop a national approach to the

Speaker: NA
Text: issue.

Speaker: NA
Text: In 2008 136 organisations, including the

Speaker: NA
Text: WWF, Birds Australia, Animals Australia,

Speaker: NA
Text: RSPCA Australia, Voiceless, the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Conservation Foundation, the Wilderness

Speaker: NA
Text: Society and Bird Observation and

Speaker: NA
Text: Conservation Australia, issued a joint

Speaker: NA
Text: common position statement highlighting the

Speaker: NA
Text: unsustainable and cruel nature of the

Speaker: NA
Text: recreational shooting of native waterbirds

Speaker: NA
Text: and calling for, inter alia, a permanent ban

Speaker: NA
Text: on recreational duck shooting on

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth controlled land and on all

Speaker: NA
Text: Ramsar sites throughout Australia. This is a

Speaker: NA
Text: matter firmly within federal jurisdiction, and

Speaker: NA
Text: I will certainly be advocating for it to be

Speaker: NA
Text: suffering a lingering implemented.

Speaker: NA
Text: Finally, I would like to quote from an

Speaker: NA
Text: email to Premier Baillieu from a concerned

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian, Nathan Cooper, who eloquently

Speaker: NA
Text: puts the case for an end to recreational duck

Speaker: NA
Text: hunting. He says:

Speaker: NA
Text: I believe society has transcended hunting as a

Speaker: NA
Text: sport and the great majority support measures of

Speaker: NA
Text: conservation and animal protection over cruel

Speaker: NA
Text: sport. While many rural Australians like myself

Speaker: NA
Text: allocate resources to improving biodiversity for

Speaker: NA
Text: wildlife on our properties, it is disappointing to

Speaker: NA
Text: see outdated political decisions working in

Speaker: NA
Text: antithesis to these efforts.

Speaker: NA
Text: Employment

Speaker: Mr CIOBO
Text: Moncrieff) (19:20): There

Speaker: NA
Text: is nothing more fundamental in terms of the

Speaker: NA
Text: core responsibilities of government than to

Speaker: NA
Text: provide an economic environment that

Speaker: NA
Text: fosters growth. There is nothing more

Speaker: NA
Text: fundamental that flows from an economic

Speaker: NA
Text: environment that fosters growth than the

Speaker: NA
Text: ability for someone to secure a job. In my

Speaker: NA
Text: city, the Gold Coast, Australia's sixth largest

Speaker: NA
Text: city, we have seen now the compounding

Speaker: NA
Text: consequences of Labor's stubborn refusal to

Speaker: NA
Text: adopt policy that is in Australia's economic

Speaker: NA
Text: interests and in the interests of my

Speaker: NA
Text: constituents on the Gold Coast, who are now

Speaker: NA
Text: facing the ravages of bad policy decisions,

Speaker: NA
Text: which are driving up unemployment. It has

Speaker: NA
Text: not always been this way on the Gold Coast.

Speaker: NA
Text: Traditionally this services based city has

Speaker: NA
Text: enjoyed levels of unemployment much lower

Speaker: NA
Text: than they are today. Historically the Gold

Speaker: NA
Text: Coast has had above national average levels

Speaker: NA
Text: of unemployment. But the previous coalition

Speaker: NA
Text: government recognised that there were

Speaker: NA
Text: policy decisions that could be taken, and,

Speaker: NA
Text: importantly, we took them, to empower

Speaker: NA
Text: small business owners, for example, to take

Speaker: NA
Text: the risk of putting on new staff, knowing full

Speaker: NA
Text: well that they would have the flexibility to

Speaker: NA
Text: make decisions about the consequences of

Speaker: NA
Text: that employment. These were the kinds of

Speaker: NA
Text: policies that drove unemployment down in a

Speaker: NA
Text: small business city like the Gold Coast.

Speaker: NA
Text: As a direct result of coalition policies,

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's sixth largest city

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployment rate went from historically

Speaker: NA
Text: sitting above the national average to reaching

Speaker: NA
Text: a low in January 2008 of 2.3 per cent. There

Speaker: NA
Text: can be no doubt that that was a direct

Speaker: NA
Text: consequence of a number of the coalition's

Speaker: NA
Text: policies and the management of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian economy that the coalition had

Speaker: NA
Text: fostered for the 13 or so years previously.

Speaker: NA
Text: In four short years, we have seen the

Speaker: NA
Text: consequences of Labor's economic

Speaker: NA
Text: recklessness with respect to the job prospects

Speaker: NA
Text: of so many of my constituents. We have seen

Speaker: NA
Text: the consequences of Labor's bungled bank

Speaker: NA
Text: guarantee. We have seen it drive away non-

Speaker: NA
Text: bank lenders and drive many of them to the

Speaker: NA
Text: wall, so that non-bank lenders, which

Speaker: NA
Text: historically accounted for over 10 per cent of

Speaker: NA
Text: the lending market, now account for

Speaker: NA
Text: something like two per cent of the lending

Speaker: NA
Text: market. This source of capital was crucial for

Speaker: NA
Text: the development industry in my city of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Gold Coast and provided a massive amount

Speaker: NA
Text: of employment for local Gold Coasters.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have seen, in addition to that, the

Speaker: NA
Text: consequences of Labor's debt and deficit.

Speaker: NA
Text: Incidentally, in the budget handed down just

Speaker: NA
Text: last night, net debt reached a record $106

Speaker: NA
Text: billion and we saw the budget deficit blow

Speaker: NA
Text: out to nearly $50 billion for this financial

Speaker: NA
Text: year, expected to be $22 billion in the

Speaker: NA
Text: subsequent financial year. These levels of

Speaker: NA
Text: debt and deficit are forcing up interest rates.

Speaker: NA
Text: So the bungled bank deposits guarantee,

Speaker: NA
Text: coupled with debt and deficit from the Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: Party forcing up interest rates, have killed off

Speaker: NA
Text: the construction industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: Another consequence has been the rapid

Speaker: NA
Text: appreciation of the Australian dollar. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian dollar is rapidly appreciating as a

Speaker: NA
Text: consequence of expectations about interest

Speaker: NA
Text: rates in this country. And interest rates are

Speaker: NA
Text: going up in this country because the

Speaker: NA
Text: in government is spending like a drunken

Speaker: NA
Text: the sailor. Because the Australian dollar is

Speaker: NA
Text: appreciating rapidly, we now have a situation

Speaker: NA
Text: where international tourists are finding

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia too expensive to visit, and

Speaker: NA
Text: domestic tourists are finding it advantageous

Speaker: NA
Text: to travel abroad.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Gold Coast is now seeing more

Speaker: NA
Text: tourists travelling overseas than there are

Speaker: NA
Text: international tourists coming to Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: And tourism is the single largest employer of

Speaker: NA
Text: local Gold Coasters. The simple reality is

Speaker: NA
Text: that now, when the Gold Coast has nearly

Speaker: NA
Text: double the national average of

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployment, at eight per cent, there are

Speaker: NA
Text: some important policy changes that need to

Speaker: NA
Text: happen for the Labor government to bring

Speaker: NA
Text: down the unemployment rate. There is

Speaker: NA
Text: assistance that should flow from Labor to

Speaker: NA
Text: help the Gold Coast in its hour of need.

Speaker: NA
Text: Instead of assisting, they have turned their

Speaker: NA
Text: back on the city.

Speaker: NA
Text: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome

Speaker: Mr LYONS
Text: Bass) (19:26): I rise to

Speaker: NA
Text: bring the House's attention to the seriousness

Speaker: NA
Text: of chronic fatigue syndrome, commonly

Speaker: NA
Text: known as CFS, in Australia. As many of you

Speaker: NA
Text: would be aware, this week is ME/CFS

Speaker: NA
Text: Awareness Week. It is estimated by ME/CFS

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia that approximately 180,000

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians suffer from this severe

Speaker: NA
Text: neurological disease, often referred to as the

Speaker: NA
Text: 'invisible disease' as so many people that are

Speaker: NA
Text: suffering go unnoticed.

Speaker: NA
Text: Many Australians are unaware of the

Speaker: NA
Text: suffering that those with CFS endure.

Speaker: NA
Text: Symptoms include fatigue; post-exertional

Speaker: NA
Text: malaise; pain; dysfunctional

Speaker: NA
Text: neurological and cognitive manifestations,

Speaker: NA
Text: including issues with short-term memory and

Speaker: NA
Text: concentration; autonomic manifestations;

Speaker: NA
Text: and immune system and neuroendocrine

Speaker: NA
Text: manifestations. And this suffering is not for

Speaker: NA
Text: short time. This is a serious illness-some

Speaker: NA
Text: people are housebound, some are bed bound

Speaker: NA
Text: and some, sadly, never recover. A study

Speaker: NA
Text: described CFS this way:

Speaker: NA
Text: … the patient's activity level is reduced by

Speaker: NA
Text: approximately 50% or more … ME/CFS is

Speaker: NA
Text: "actually more debilitating than most other

Speaker: NA
Text: medical problems in the world" …

Speaker: NA
Text: Yet there is very little support for those

Speaker: NA
Text: suffering.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is not just the physical symptoms that

Speaker: NA
Text: affect sufferers. Looking after someone who

Speaker: NA
Text: has fallen victim to this illness is a heart-

Speaker: NA
Text: wrenching job, and this can lead to family

Speaker: NA
Text: and social breakdown. There is also the cost

Speaker: NA
Text: of doctors appointments, ongoing tests and

Speaker: NA
Text: seeking a treatment that might help even a

Speaker: NA
Text: little to ease the pain and discomfort

Speaker: NA
Text: associated with the illness. A study by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australasian College of Physicians found

Speaker: NA
Text: that in 2000-01 the annual aggregate cost

Speaker: NA
Text: totalled $13,471 per patient. Although this

Speaker: NA
Text: figure is from some time ago, it demonstrates

Speaker: NA
Text: the high cost of this illness.

Speaker: NA
Text: Many younger people cannot complete

Speaker: NA
Text: their high school or college years or are too

Speaker: NA
Text: unwell to attend university, which has

Speaker: NA
Text: implications for their long-term employment

Speaker: NA
Text: prospects. Adult sufferers often miss large

Speaker: NA
Text: amounts of work or are unable to resume

Speaker: NA
Text: their careers at the level they were once at.

Speaker: NA
Text: This illness is so multifaceted and it affects

Speaker: NA
Text: not only the sufferer but also their carers,

Speaker: NA
Text: family and all of those close to them.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think that it is particularly difficult for

Speaker: NA
Text: younger sufferers. Often their peers do not

Speaker: NA
Text: realise the magnitude of the illness, and it is

Speaker: NA
Text: sleep; easy for them to say that the person is putting

Speaker: NA
Text: it on or seeking attention by saying they are

Speaker: NA
Text: sick. It is not like this at all. This is a time in

Speaker: NA
Text: the sufferer's life when they need all the

Speaker: NA
Text: support they can get, but so many

Speaker: NA
Text: a Australians just do not realise exactly what

Speaker: NA
Text: this illness means to someone who has it.

Speaker: NA
Text: The reason I am speaking about CFS tonight

Speaker: NA
Text: is that I want to raise awareness of what this

Speaker: NA
Text: illness is-the magnitude of the illness and

Speaker: NA
Text: what it is like to be a sufferer. Treatment for

Speaker: NA
Text: this illness is not simple-it is not simply

Speaker: NA
Text: taking medication to alleviate symptoms. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is a complex illness which affects sufferers

Speaker: NA
Text: differently, but all need treatment, support

Speaker: NA
Text: and recognition of what they are going

Speaker: NA
Text: through. I want to raise awareness of it so

Speaker: NA
Text: that we can work together to provide support

Speaker: NA
Text: for these sufferers. It is important that we

Speaker: NA
Text: provide support for the organisations that so

Speaker: NA
Text: need funding and the resources these people

Speaker: NA
Text: need to fight this debilitating illness.

Speaker: NA
Text: Finally and importantly I urge everyone in

Speaker: NA
Text: this place to be involved in ME/CFS

Speaker: NA
Text: Awareness Week and to wear a ribbon

Speaker: NA
Text: tomorrow. This is a way of showing our

Speaker: NA
Text: support and recognising the suffering that

Speaker: NA
Text: this terrible, debilitating illness inflicts.

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget

Speaker: Mr BILSON
Text: Dunkley) (19:30): This

Speaker: NA
Text: federal Labor budget is a disappointment for

Speaker: NA
Text: most and a disaster for many small

Speaker: NA
Text: businesses and family enterprises. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Gillard Labor government has short-changed

Speaker: NA
Text: small businesses and family enterprises by

Speaker: NA
Text: delivering a budget that fails to address any

Speaker: NA
Text: of the key concerns and challenges currently

Speaker: NA
Text: faced by this engine room of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: economy. Instead, the budget relies on tricks

Speaker: NA
Text: with smokes and mirrors to claim to be

Speaker: NA
Text: helpful to small businesses, but those tricks

Speaker: NA
Text: are funded by measures that are actually

Speaker: NA
Text: harmful to smaller enterprises.

Speaker: NA
Text: The claimed cash flow benefit resulting

Speaker: NA
Text: from the instant write-off of the first $5,000

Speaker: NA
Text: of a new work vehicle requires a small

Speaker: NA
Text: business to spend nearly $34,000 dollars in

Speaker: NA
Text: cash to receive an extra tax benefit worth

Speaker: NA
Text: around $1,275 in 2013, according to the

Speaker: NA
Text: example promoted by the Treasurer. This

Speaker: NA
Text: 'spend a lot to benefit a little' measure does

Speaker: NA
Text: not actually start in this financial year nor

Speaker: NA
Text: the next; it starts in 2012-13, with a payment

Speaker: NA
Text: possibly arriving in late 2013. It risks

Speaker: NA
Text: delaying vehicle sales and also comes at the

Speaker: NA
Text: expense of over 400,000 of Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: smallest businesses and self-employed

Speaker: NA
Text: enterprises which are set to lose up to $2,500

Speaker: NA
Text: by the scrapping of the entrepreneurs tax

Speaker: NA
Text: offset. Changes to vehicle fringe benefits tax,

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly punishing for rural and regional

Speaker: NA
Text: communities, will be leaving small

Speaker: NA
Text: businesses with an additional potential

Speaker: NA
Text: burden of up to $3,000 for providing

Speaker: NA
Text: employees with vehicles, vans or delivery

Speaker: NA
Text: cars of some description-the result of

Speaker: NA
Text: caving in to the Greens' demands to change

Speaker: NA
Text: FBT.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Gillard government has given with

Speaker: NA
Text: one hand and taken with the other while

Speaker: NA
Text: ignoring the big challenges the small

Speaker: NA
Text: business community was desperate for the

Speaker: NA
Text: government to address. In fact, those

Speaker: NA
Text: challenges have been made worse by this

Speaker: NA
Text: budget. The punishing impact on small

Speaker: NA
Text: business viability and its capacity to employ

Speaker: NA
Text: has been worsened by Labor's flawed carbon

Speaker: NA
Text: dioxide tax. The tax itself, and any detail

Speaker: NA
Text: about it, has been completely left out of the

Speaker: NA
Text: budget, yet this is a real and compelling issue

Speaker: NA
Text: for the small business community.

Speaker: NA
Text: Difficulties accessing affordable credit have

Speaker: NA
Text: also been made worse by a budget which

Speaker: NA
Text: puts upward pressure on interest rates and by

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth borrowings of $135 million

Speaker: NA
Text: a day crowding out small businesses seeking

Speaker: NA
Text: finance. Burgeoning red tape burdens are

Speaker: NA
Text: made worse with new disincentives and

Speaker: NA
Text: punishing reporting requirements for

Speaker: NA
Text: independent contracting and new compliance

Speaker: NA
Text: complexities for employer supplied

Speaker: NA
Text: vehicles-a couple of key areas.

Speaker: NA
Text: What is it about this government that so

Speaker: NA
Text: leads them to simply hate small business?

Speaker: NA
Text: The government will pocket $365 million

Speaker: NA
Text: from axing an important incentive for the

Speaker: NA
Text: in microbusiness community, a tax incentive I

Speaker: NA
Text: touched on earlier, which shows the disdain

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor has for those wishing to pursue their

Speaker: NA
Text: own employment trajectory and livelihoods

Speaker: NA
Text: without being in the traditional employer-

Speaker: NA
Text: employee relationship. The budget scraps the

Speaker: NA
Text: enterprise tax offset. Self-employed people,

Speaker: NA
Text: home based businesses, small retailers,

Speaker: NA
Text: service providers and people using their own

Speaker: NA
Text: wit and entrepreneurship to enter, re-enter,

Speaker: NA
Text: participate in or defer retiring from the

Speaker: NA
Text: workforce will be rewarded by a new tax hit

Speaker: NA
Text: through the scrapping of the ETO.

Speaker: NA
Text: You hear the Prime Minister talk about

Speaker: NA
Text: the dignity of work and the government's

Speaker: NA
Text: effort of 'insisting on participation of more

Speaker: NA
Text: workers', yet this government has that

Speaker: NA
Text: unionist view that only employees are

Speaker: NA
Text: workers, that if you happen to be self-

Speaker: NA
Text: employed, that if you are actually receiving

Speaker: NA
Text: payment for your services or your work or

Speaker: NA
Text: revenue in your business, that does not

Speaker: NA
Text: count. It is only if you are receiving a pay

Speaker: NA
Text: cheque as an employee that it counts.

Speaker: NA
Text: Through that attitude and the decisions in

Speaker: NA
Text: this budget, an avenue that sees millions of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians able to support themselves and

Speaker: NA
Text: pursue a livelihood is being made more

Speaker: NA
Text: difficult.

Speaker: NA
Text: In another area, the Assistant Treasurer

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill Shorten has broken an explicit promise

Speaker: NA
Text: not to make it more difficult for those

Speaker: NA
Text: involved in independent contracting and

Speaker: NA
Text: employment. He promised, in an article in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Financial Review on 13

Speaker: NA
Text: October, that he would 'not make life

Speaker: NA
Text: difficult for self-employed working people',

Speaker: NA
Text: yet what the budget announces is another

Speaker: NA
Text: instalment in this Gillard Labor government's

Speaker: NA
Text: concerted and coordinated campaign to

Speaker: NA
Text: hound and harass small-business people out

Speaker: NA
Text: of legitimate contracting arrangements and

Speaker: NA
Text: force them into employee-employer

Speaker: NA
Text: relationships that facilitate union

Speaker: NA
Text: intervention and control. There are two

Speaker: NA
Text: million Australians who derive their

Speaker: NA
Text: livelihood from self-employment and

Speaker: NA
Text: independent contracting. Bill Shorten

Speaker: NA
Text: assured them that he would not make their

Speaker: NA
Text: lives more difficult. He has. He stands

Speaker: NA
Text: condemned. This is yet another example of

Speaker: NA
Text: why only the coalition can support the small

Speaker: NA
Text: business community in Australia. (Time

Speaker: NA
Text: expired)

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Hon. Peter

Speaker: NA
Text: Slipper): I would remind the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member that he ought to refer to other

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable members by their title and not by

Speaker: NA
Text: their actual name.

Speaker: NA
Text: Braddon Electorate

Speaker: Mr SIDEBOTTOM
Text: Braddon) (19:36):

Speaker: NA
Text: Since 2007, the Labor government has been

Speaker: NA
Text: highly supportive of, and has invested

Speaker: NA
Text: heavily in, my region. The budget last night

Speaker: NA
Text: continued to support my region and I thank

Speaker: NA
Text: this government very much. I would like to

Speaker: NA
Text: mention at least five really good activities

Speaker: NA
Text: and programs that I have been able to share

Speaker: NA
Text: with my community recently. The first is the

Speaker: NA
Text: Mersey Bluff development-I

Speaker: NA
Text: representing Simon Crean, who was the

Speaker: NA
Text: architect of the Better Regions Program.

Speaker: NA
Text: That program provided $1 million in funding

Speaker: NA
Text: for the Devonport Surf Club, part of a $7

Speaker: NA
Text: million recreation and wellbeing precinct in

Speaker: NA
Text: selfDevonport. I want to congratulate the

Speaker: NA
Text: government and the Devonport council, in

Speaker: NA
Text: particular its mayor, for the tremendous

Speaker: NA
Text: investment in what is one of the most

Speaker: NA
Text: beautiful parts of not just the north-west

Speaker: NA
Text: coast but indeed Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: The second enterprise I would like to

Speaker: NA
Text: mention is what we call the Community

Speaker: NA
Text: Infrastructure Development Group in my

Speaker: NA
Text: region. Through the jobs fund and more

Speaker: NA
Text: specifically the Get Communities Working

Speaker: NA
Text: project, $900,000 or a little over was

Speaker: NA
Text: allocated to the O Group to create a program

Speaker: NA
Text: using construction supervisors and a number

Speaker: NA
Text: of apprentices and trade experienced and

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployed people who worked on a whole

Speaker: NA
Text: range of projects for the last 12 months, in

Speaker: NA
Text: particular the Picton Grange building at the

Speaker: NA
Text: Latrobe Sport and Recreation Centre.

Speaker: NA
Text: Representing Minister Ellis, the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Employment Participation and Childcare, I

Speaker: NA
Text: was able to congratulate the Latrobe City

Speaker: NA
Text: Council staff, members of the Latrobe Sport

Speaker: NA
Text: and Recreation Centre management

Speaker: NA
Text: committee and the O Group on what is a

Speaker: NA
Text: fantastic community facility, a gymnasium

Speaker: NA
Text: which will be available to that community.

Speaker: NA
Text: A third area of investment by this

Speaker: NA
Text: government-indeed, I was able to do this

Speaker: NA
Text: with the Minister for Home Affairs and

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Justice, Brendan O'Connor-

Speaker: NA
Text: was the allocation of $250,000 to, again, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Devonport City Council for the setting up of

Speaker: NA
Text: CCTV cameras as part of the community

Speaker: NA
Text: safety program. Again, I congratulate the

Speaker: NA
Text: council, the local community and the local

Speaker: NA
Text: police representatives on getting funding for

Speaker: NA
Text: was the CCTV cameras in order to enhance even

Speaker: NA
Text: further the liveability and amenity of the

Speaker: NA
Text: beautiful city of Devonport.

Speaker: NA
Text: A fourth area I was able to take part in,

Speaker: NA
Text: and very proudly so, is one of the few

Speaker: NA
Text: projects throughout Australia at the moment

Speaker: NA
Text: launching the local connections to work at

Speaker: NA
Text: Burnie, particularly the Centrelink area. This

Speaker: NA
Text: is a unique service bringing together all the

Speaker: NA
Text: services helping long-term unemployed and

Speaker: NA
Text: youth who are facing barriers to social

Speaker: NA
Text: inclusion and economic participation. So

Speaker: NA
Text: under the one roof, you have employment

Speaker: NA
Text: services through Job Services Australia and

Speaker: NA
Text: disability employment service providers and

Speaker: NA
Text: services to help people with carer needs,

Speaker: NA
Text: housing, advocacy, legal issues, mental

Speaker: NA
Text: health needs and youth services including

Speaker: NA
Text: educational services, as well as working with

Speaker: NA
Text: Medicare in order to allow for electronic

Speaker: NA
Text: funds transfers, trying to get people into a

Speaker: NA
Text: 'tell it once' wraparound service surrounding

Speaker: NA
Text: customers with assistance. I want to

Speaker: NA
Text: congratulate Centrelink at Burnie for the

Speaker: NA
Text: fantastic job they do.

Speaker: NA
Text: Finally, there are two fantastic social

Speaker: NA
Text: housing initiatives. On 28 April, I was in

Speaker: NA
Text: Ulverstone at Grove Street where we had

Speaker: NA
Text: supported accommodation of some 20-unit

Speaker: NA
Text: complexes put together by the Tasmanian

Speaker: NA
Text: government through their housing fund, an

Speaker: NA
Text: additional six units costing $1.65 million by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commonwealth and finally the Optia

Speaker: NA
Text: units in Mussen Court, Burnie, 20 one-

Speaker: NA
Text: bedroom units designed for persons living

Speaker: NA
Text: with a disability at a cost of $3.3 million

Speaker: NA
Text: with Optia providing $700,000 and the land

Speaker: NA
Text: provided by the Burnie City Council. (Time

Speaker: NA
Text: expired)

Speaker: NA
Text: Hinkler Electorate

Speaker: Mr NEVILLE
Text: Hinkler-The Nationals

Speaker: NA
Text: Deputy Whip) (19:41): In recent months the

Speaker: NA
Text: local economies of Hervey Bay and

Speaker: NA
Text: Bundaberg have taken sustained and

Speaker: NA
Text: consecutive blows with the closure of key

Speaker: NA
Text: businesses. Regional economies are doing it

Speaker: NA
Text: tougher than ever because when businesses

Speaker: NA
Text: and banks reduce their exposure and

Speaker: NA
Text: consolidate their operations, private

Speaker: NA
Text: investment dries up and local jobs disappear.

Speaker: NA
Text: In Bundaberg alone, hundreds of jobs

Speaker: NA
Text: have disappeared since the beginning of the

Speaker: NA
Text: year with the closure of a Salmat call centre

Speaker: NA
Text: which was subcontracted to Telstra, APN's

Speaker: NA
Text: decision to close its printing works in

Speaker: NA
Text: Bundaberg, the failure of two local builders

Speaker: NA
Text: and the collapse of Barbera Farms, one of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's biggest producers of tomatoes and

Speaker: NA
Text: zucchinis and certainly one of Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: biggest producers of capsicums. The APN

Speaker: NA
Text: and Barbera Farms situations have also

Speaker: NA
Text: impacted on the electorate of my colleague

Speaker: NA
Text: the member for Dawson in the Mackay-

Speaker: NA
Text: Bowen area. If these were not enough, the

Speaker: NA
Text: recent floods added yet another dimension of

Speaker: NA
Text: challenge to our community.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is time the government recognised that

Speaker: NA
