Text: regional areas are doing it really tough. They

Speaker: NA
Text: deserve their fair share of the economic cake

Speaker: NA
Text: as well. Typically, the government blew the

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity to give back to regional

Speaker: NA
Text: communities in this year's budget.

Speaker: NA
Text: 'Productivity' seems to be the government's

Speaker: NA
Text: catchcry-yet there has been no recognition

Speaker: NA
Text: that Queensland's productivity is driven by

Speaker: NA
Text: its rail and road systems.

Speaker: NA
Text: The systemic failure of transport was

Speaker: NA
Text: roundly sheeted home to the condition of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Bruce Highway during the recent flood.

Speaker: NA
Text: There were sections of the Bruce Highway

Speaker: NA
Text: closed all the way from the Sunshine Coast

Speaker: NA
Text: to Cairns and at times cities the size of

Speaker: NA
Text: Gympie and Maryborough were closed off.

Speaker: NA
Text: Not one new dollar has been invested in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Bruce Highway. The minister has announced

Speaker: NA
Text: old funding and reinstated funding that was

Speaker: NA
Text: deferred from earlier this year, but has failed

Speaker: NA
Text: to invest any new funding for Queensland's

Speaker: NA
Text: key highway network. For example, it

Speaker: NA
Text: reinstated what is known as the rollercoaster

Speaker: NA
Text: north of Gin Gin and it announced the Isis

Speaker: NA
Text: River bridge, which is under construction as

Speaker: NA
Text: we speak. In fact, the minister has removed

Speaker: NA
Text: funding from the notorious Cooroy to Curra

Speaker: NA
Text: section of the Bruce Highway, where

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable members would be surprised to

Speaker: NA
Text: know that traffic has to travel at 90

Speaker: NA
Text: kilometres per hour for nearly 38 kilometres.

Speaker: NA
Text: On page 270 of budget paper 2 there is a

Speaker: NA
Text: report that $325.4 million will be stripped

Speaker: NA
Text: from the Ipswich Motorway and the Cooroy

Speaker: NA
Text: to Curra section of the Bruce Highway,

Speaker: NA
Text: section B, because the 'the funding will not

Speaker: NA
Text: be required'-that is a joke. It is common

Speaker: NA
Text: knowledge that the section B project is

Speaker: NA
Text: running under budget, but if spare money is

Speaker: NA
Text: now available surely the minister should

Speaker: NA
Text: have directed those funds towards starting

Speaker: NA
Text: construction of section A of the upgrade. It

Speaker: NA
Text: emblematic of a budget which has

Speaker: NA
Text: consistently robbed Peter to pay Paul.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let me give you yet another example on a

Speaker: NA
Text: smaller scale, but a no less significant one

Speaker: NA
Text: my electorate. It is Labor's decision to pull

Speaker: NA
Text: $8 million of funding from the Veterans'

Speaker: NA
Text: Affairs portfolio, specifically the Veteran

Speaker: NA
Text: and Community grants program and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Building Excellence in Support and Training

Speaker: NA
Text: program, whilst outlaying $8.2 million to

Speaker: NA
Text: advertise its carbon tax. It is a slap in the

Speaker: NA
Text: face to our veterans to pull funding from

Speaker: NA
Text: vital support programs while shovelling the

Speaker: NA
Text: equivalent amount, if not more, into a self-

Speaker: NA
Text: promoting PR blitz for a tax that nobody

Speaker: NA
Text: wants and that this nation cannot afford.

Speaker: NA
Text: Of course, the budget contained absolutely

Speaker: NA
Text: no detail on the carbon tax, which leaves

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian families and businesses in the

Speaker: NA
Text: dark over just how much this tax will hurt

Speaker: NA
Text: them. What do we know about this tax other

Speaker: NA
Text: than it will be another crushing burden for

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians who are already struggling with

Speaker: NA
Text: a 51 per cent increase in the cost of

Speaker: NA
Text: electricity, a 14 per cent increase in the cost

Speaker: NA
Text: of groceries and a 20 per cent increase in the

Speaker: NA
Text: costs of health and education? This year's

Speaker: NA
Text: budget was an opportunity to help regional

Speaker: NA
Text: communities, to help families, and to help

Speaker: NA
Text: small and medium businesses. Labor has

Speaker: NA
Text: squandered that chance. It is a disgrace, as is

Speaker: NA
Text: its budget.

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland Floods

Speaker: NA
Text: Mrs PRENTICE (Ryan) (19:46): On 16

Speaker: NA
Text: January this year thousands of

Speaker: NA
Text: Queenslanders were returning to their homes

Speaker: NA
Text: and businesses after the recent floods, often

Speaker: NA
Text: to find them completely destroyed. Many

Speaker: NA
Text: tragically lost whatever hope they had held

Speaker: NA
Text: that maybe, just maybe, something had been

Speaker: NA
Text: saved. But whilst these people were grieving,

Speaker: NA
Text: whilst we were comforting our friends and

Speaker: NA
Text: is neighbours, and whilst local councils were

Speaker: NA
Text: kicking into gear and fronting up to the

Speaker: NA
Text: mammoth clean-up task ahead, Senator Bob

Speaker: NA
Text: Brown, a political leader in this country, was

Speaker: NA
Text: to in the media-safe in Tasmania and far away

Speaker: NA
Text: from the devastation-pushing his own

Speaker: NA
Text: political agenda. Whilst people were, and

Speaker: NA
Text: still are, left uncertain about what their lives

Speaker: NA
Text: now hold, Senator Brown could only concern

Speaker: NA
Text: himself with the political point scoring that

Speaker: NA
Text: the floods offered. That was a despicable

Speaker: NA
Text: action not worthy of him or the position he

Speaker: NA
Text: holds.

Speaker: NA
Text: I believe passionately in the importance of

Speaker: NA
Text: full and frank debate concerning the issues

Speaker: NA
Text: confronting our nation. I have a genuine

Speaker: NA
Text: interest and concern as to the ongoing debate

Speaker: NA
Text: regarding our environment. But as important

Speaker: NA
Text: as Senator Brown believes this debate to be,

Speaker: NA
Text: there is a time and a place for things to be

Speaker: NA
Text: said. There is a time and a place for things to

Speaker: NA
Text: be done. To seek to make political capital

Speaker: NA
Text: just as Queenslanders were confronting the

Speaker: NA
Text: devastating results of the floods was

Speaker: NA
Text: insensitive and uncaring because that was a

Speaker: NA
Text: time for things to be done-not for politics.

Speaker: NA
Text: That was a time for our leaders to lead and

Speaker: NA
Text: lend a hand-not for politics. That was a

Speaker: NA
Text: time when so many Australians dropped

Speaker: NA
Text: what they were doing and asked, 'How can I

Speaker: NA
Text: help?'

Speaker: NA
Text: If Senator Brown had joined that

Speaker: NA
Text: magnificent effort and had spoken to as

Speaker: NA
Text: many flood victims as I did, I am sure he

Speaker: NA
Text: would have understood that the people of

Speaker: NA
Text: Emerald, of Toowoomba, of the Lockyer, of

Speaker: NA
Text: Ipswich and of Brisbane needed support at

Speaker: NA
Text: that time and a generous hand of friendship.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is what we saw from so many others of

Speaker: NA
Text: different political persuasions. They did not

Speaker: NA
Text: shout their differences. They stood side by

Speaker: NA
Text: side, not to debate or score points but simply

Speaker: NA
Text: to help. So many of them did their bit-often

Speaker: NA
Text: for complete strangers-but Senator Brown

Speaker: NA
Text: appears only to have seen political

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am concerned about Senator Brown's

Speaker: NA
Text: contribution to this debate because he

Speaker: NA
Text: appears so driven by an absolute conviction

Speaker: NA
Text: of his own infallibility and by an almost

Speaker: NA
Text: manic determination to ride over any

Speaker: NA
Text: alternative view, no matter how reasonable it

Speaker: NA
Text: might be. This driven approach-that rules

Speaker: NA
Text: out debate and paints all those who dare

Speaker: NA
Text: question his extreme views as environmental

Speaker: NA
Text: vandals and deniers-no doubt led Senator

Speaker: NA
Text: Brown to play the politics of the disaster

Speaker: NA
Text: not deal with the tragic reality.

Speaker: NA
Text: Senator Brown knew that the parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: would meet within weeks but he could not

Speaker: NA
Text: wait. Before the leader of the Greens again

Speaker: NA
Text: uses others' adversity for political

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunism, I simply ask that he considers

Speaker: NA
Text: those who have suffered and that not all

Speaker: NA
Text: development is bad. Indeed, with careful

Speaker: NA
Text: consideration and proper environmental

Speaker: NA
Text: safeguards, even dams have their place.

Speaker: NA
Text: When looking at the Brisbane and Ipswich

Speaker: NA
Text: floods, Senator Brown should consider this:

Speaker: NA
Text: Wivenhoe Dam was built after the 1974

Speaker: NA
Text: Brisbane floods for flood mitigation and, as

Speaker: NA
Text: such, it was to be complemented by

Speaker: NA
Text: Wolffdene Dam, which was to provide a safe

Speaker: NA
Text: and viable water supply for Brisbane and the

Speaker: NA
Text: south-east corner of Queensland. Although

Speaker: NA
Text: building the Wolffdene Dam would not have

Speaker: NA
Text: changed rainfall patterns, it would have

Speaker: NA
Text: greatly decreased the pressure on Wivenhoe

Speaker: NA
Text: to provide water for a rapidly growing

Speaker: NA
Text: population and it would have planned for

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland's future. Without that pressure,

Speaker: NA
Text: Wivenhoe could have proved so much more

Speaker: NA
Text: effective in minimising the impact of the

Speaker: NA
Text: recent floods. The Wolffdene Dam was

Speaker: NA
Text: cancelled in 1989 by the Goss Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: administration. Interestingly, Premier Goss'

Speaker: NA
Text: chief of staff at the time was the now

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Griffith. This year we reaped the

Speaker: NA
Text: consequences of that decision.

Speaker: NA
Text: So as Senator Brown drives the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: government's implementation of his carbon

Speaker: NA
Text: tax, let me say this: Senator Brown's

Speaker: NA
Text: comments are a timely reminder to us all that

Speaker: NA
Text: it is easy to seek out the 10-second media

Speaker: NA
Text: grab, to make a speech and to fight the

Speaker: NA
Text: political fight, but in so doing we should

Speaker: NA
Text: always remember that there are some times

Speaker: NA
Text: that must be above politics. There are some

Speaker: NA
Text: times when we must put aside the bludgeon

Speaker: NA
Text: of politics and stand, even in this place,

Speaker: NA
Text: and shoulder to shoulder while doing what we

Speaker: NA
Text: can best do for our nation and for our people

Speaker: NA
Text: in their time of greatest need. The message

Speaker: NA
Text: for Senator Brown is that politics has its time

Speaker: NA
Text: and place, but so too does caring,

Speaker: NA
Text: compassion and plain common sense.

Speaker: NA
Text: D'Orazio, Mr John

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr STEPHEN SMITH (Perth-Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for Defence and Deputy Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House) (19:51): I rise this evening during

Speaker: NA
Text: the adjournment debate as the federal

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Perth to make some remarks

Speaker: NA
Text: about the late John D'Orazio, a former Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: member of the Western Australian state

Speaker: NA
Text: parliament. He died suddenly on Monday, 11

Speaker: NA
Text: April. John D'Orazio was a lifelong friend of

Speaker: NA
Text: mine and remained a friend until his death.

Speaker: NA
Text: Fortunately from a personal perspective, I

Speaker: NA
Text: had the opportunity to have a good

Speaker: NA
Text: conversation with him by phone on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Friday before his death. He told me that that

Speaker: NA
Text: day was a good day. He was suffering from

Speaker: NA
Text: amyloidosis and he had his ups and downs.

Speaker: NA
Text: As ever, when we spoke, we spoke about

Speaker: NA
Text: politics, we spoke about his pharmacy

Speaker: NA
Text: business and we spoke about family.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have known John since we were both in

Speaker: NA
Text: grade 7. He lived in his beloved Bayswater

Speaker: NA
Text: and attended Christian Brothers College

Speaker: NA
Text: Bedford. I lived in Mount Lawley and

Speaker: NA
Text: attended Christian Brothers High School

Speaker: NA
Text: Highgate. In those days, CBC Bedford only

Speaker: NA
Text: went to junior, so for subleaving and leaving

Speaker: NA
Text: the Bedford boys came to Highgate. When

Speaker: NA
Text: we finished school together, he went to what

Speaker: NA
Text: is now Curtin University and graduated as a

Speaker: NA
Text: pharmacist, and opened his pharmacy in

Speaker: NA
Text: Guildford Road, Bayswater. He subsequently

Speaker: NA
Text: became a councillor and mayor of the city of

Speaker: NA
Text: Bayswater, a mayor of long standing. It was

Speaker: NA
Text: here that he made his mark and left a

Speaker: NA
Text: longstanding and great impression on the

Speaker: NA
Text: local area and the broader city of Bayswater

Speaker: NA
Text: community.

Speaker: NA
Text: It was a great personal and professional

Speaker: NA
Text: privilege in my early years as the federal

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Perth from 1993 to 2000 to work

Speaker: NA
Text: closely with him when he was mayor of the

Speaker: NA
Text: city of Bayswater. He retired as mayor in

Speaker: NA
Text: 2000 and subsequently became a state

Speaker: NA
Text: member of parliament. His

Speaker: NA
Text: achievements as mayor included the

Speaker: NA
Text: development of the Galleria shopping centre

Speaker: NA
Text: in Morley and what is widely regarded as the

Speaker: NA
Text: best waste and recycle collection system for

Speaker: NA
Text: a local authority in Australia. He established

Speaker: NA
Text: the first citywide 24-hour security watch for

Speaker: NA
Text: a local authority in Australia. And he made

Speaker: NA
Text: sure his council became debt free. I was very

Speaker: NA
Text: pleased to be able to work closely with him

Speaker: NA
Text: to establish the first Bendigo Community

Speaker: NA
Text: Bank in Western Australia, in Bayswater

Speaker: NA
Text: itself. I also worked very closely with him to

Speaker: NA
Text: protect the residents of the city of Bayswater

Speaker: NA
Text: from aircraft noise from the Perth airport.

Speaker: NA
Text: When he entered the state parliament in

Speaker: NA
Text: 2001, he had my very strong support for

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor Party preselection and my very strong

Speaker: NA
Text: support for his election to parliament. His

Speaker: NA
Text: preselection and his subsequent election was

Speaker: NA
Text: widely welcomed and broadly acclaimed. He

Speaker: NA
Text: was a person regarded as a future minister,

Speaker: NA
Text: and he duly became a minister. Initially that

Speaker: NA
Text: was a happy experience, but it was not

Speaker: NA
Text: without its difficulties. The political

Speaker: NA
Text: difficulty never justified the treatment he

Speaker: NA
Text: received at the Western Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Corruption and Crime Commission in

Speaker: NA
Text: respect of which he was subsequently

Speaker: NA
Text: exonerated, nor did it justify his peremptory

Speaker: NA
Text: expulsion from the state parliamentary Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: Party at the hands of the then Western

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Premier, Alan Carpenter. This

Speaker: NA
Text: action was both unjustified and unjustifiable

Speaker: NA
Text: on the part of the Premier and it was a

Speaker: NA
Text: mistake for which he would pay dearly. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Premier, the Labor Party and the Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: government paid a heavy price for that

Speaker: NA
Text: mistake when Labor, at a subsequent

Speaker: NA
Text: election, lost the seat of Morley, thereby

Speaker: NA
Text: enabling a Barnett-led minority government

Speaker: NA
Text: to take the helm in Western Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: I was honoured to be able to attend John's

Speaker: NA
Text: great requiem mass at St Columbus in Bayswater

Speaker: NA
Text: and to attend his service at the Karrakatta

Speaker: NA
Text: mausoleum. I was pleased to be able to

Speaker: NA
Text: express my condolences to his son, Greg, his

Speaker: NA
Text: daughter, Jessica, his wife, Ailsa, and his

Speaker: NA
Text: first wife, Ros, whom I have known for

Speaker: NA
Text: many years. I again extend those

Speaker: NA
Text: condolences.

Speaker: NA
Text: His departure from public life was not a

Speaker: NA
Text: happy one. It was unfortunate. But he

Speaker: NA
Text: retained the respect of his community and

Speaker: NA
Text: friends, of which I was proud to say I was

Speaker: NA
Text: one. His untimely and early death was a

Speaker: NA
Text: tragedy for his family. I again express my

Speaker: NA
Text: regards to his family and his broader family

Speaker: NA
Text: and his brothers. As we ended many

Speaker: NA
Text: conversations since grade 7, I do so in the

Speaker: NA
Text: same way tonight: arrivederci, paisan.

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliamentary Friends of Surf Life

Speaker: NA
Text: Saving

Speaker: Mr CHESTER
Text: Gippsland) (19:56): I

Speaker: NA
Text: commend the minister for his tender farewell

Speaker: NA
Text: to a close colleague and friend. It is with

Speaker: NA
Text: great pleasure that I inform the House of the

Speaker: NA
Text: formation of the Parliamentary Friends of

Speaker: NA
Text: Surf Life Saving, an organisation which had

Speaker: NA
Text: its first meeting this week under the

Speaker: NA
Text: stewardship of our inaugural president, the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Bass. The member for Bass is a

Speaker: NA
Text: man who has a great reputation in the surf

Speaker: NA
Text: lifesaving movement in Australia and I

Speaker: NA
Text: understand he is a life member of Surf Life

Speaker: NA
Text: Saving Australia. As I have remarked once

Speaker: NA
Text: in the past, it is not something that you

Speaker: NA
Text: on the back of a cornflakes packet; you have

Speaker: NA
Text: to serve. I believe the member for Bass has

Speaker: NA
Text: served with great distinction in the surf

Speaker: NA
Text: lifesaving movement.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is a great occasion for the House to

Speaker: NA
Text: establish such a parliamentary friends

Speaker: NA
Text: organisation, when you understand that the

Speaker: NA
Text: surf lifesaving movement is such an integral

Speaker: NA
Text: part of the Australian community. There are

Speaker: NA
Text: more than 150,000 surf lifesaving volunteers

Speaker: NA
Text: across the nation and more than 300 clubs.

Speaker: NA
Text: When you talk about surf lifesaving

Speaker: NA
Text: members, it is not a male domain; it is very

Speaker: NA
Text: much a community organisation with strong

Speaker: NA
Text: representation from female athletes and

Speaker: NA
Text: female volunteers who serve on our beaches.

Speaker: NA
Text: It also has the great distinction of being a

Speaker: NA
Text: community and charitable organisation

Speaker: NA
Text: which develops young people from a very

Speaker: NA
Text: early age at, say, seven or eight years old as

Speaker: NA
Text: his nippers and they continue their involvement

Speaker: NA
Text: right through to masters carnivals. It is one

Speaker: NA
Text: of those few organisations in the community

Speaker: NA
Text: which is continuing to grow-as I

Speaker: NA
Text: understand, at about two per cent per annum.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is a fantastic achievement for the surf

Speaker: NA
Text: lifesaving movement.

Speaker: NA
Text: Surf lifesavers in Australia do a fantastic

Speaker: NA
Text: job. They keep our beaches safe and I think

Speaker: NA
Text: we sometimes forget how important that is

Speaker: NA
Text: from a tourism and economic development

Speaker: NA
Text: perspective. Can you imagine the Gold Coast

Speaker: NA
Text: without patrolled beaches? Can you imagine

Speaker: NA
Text: the beach in my own community, the 90-

Speaker: NA
Text: mile beach, without patrols? The tourist

Speaker: NA
Text: industry would suffer enormously. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: magnificent that we have these people

Speaker: NA
Text: prepared to patrol as volunteers on a daily

Speaker: NA
Text: basis throughout summer to help keep our

Speaker: NA
Text: beaches safe.

Speaker: NA
Text: The red and yellow image of the surf

Speaker: NA
Text: lifesaving movement is an iconic Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: image and it is something that we have been

Speaker: NA
Text: get able to export to other nations. Our surf

Speaker: NA
Text: lifesavers through Surf Life Saving Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: have been prepared to engage in an

Speaker: NA
Text: international program to spread the word and

Speaker: NA
Text: help educate other nations who perhaps have

Speaker: NA
Text: not had the same level of surf safety that we

Speaker: NA
Text: have been able to enjoy in Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: I congratulate those who have shown

Speaker: NA
Text: interest in the Parliamentary Friends of Surf

Speaker: NA
Text: Life Saving. I certainly congratulate Surf

Speaker: NA
Text: Life Saving Australia and all its state based

Speaker: NA
Text: organisations, but most of all I congratulate

Speaker: NA
Text: the men and women and the young people

Speaker: NA
Text: who contribute their time and make such an

Speaker: NA
Text: extraordinary commitment to serve our

Speaker: NA
Text: nation. I wish them well over the winter

Speaker: NA
Text: months as they prepare for another busy

Speaker: NA
Text: summer season ahead. Finally, I encourage

Speaker: NA
Text: other members to get involved in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliamentary Friends of Surf Life Saving

Speaker: NA
Text: under the guardianship of our president, the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Bass.
